fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
ACCOUNT NOTES - Chamber Partnership Strategy Meeting

Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

Meeting Type: Strategic Partnership Planning Session

Important Clarification: This was NOT a conversation with an employer prospect about ICHRA. This was an internal strategy meeting between Thatch and partners to develop a chamber of commerce distribution channel for ICHRA solutions.

1. KEY DISCUSSION POINTS

Business Context & Recent Success:
- Thatch completed a highly successful January 1, 2026 enrollment cycle with exceptional membership growth
- Direct-to-employer pilot program (August 2025 - present) achieved significant traction:
  - 340 employers connected bank accounts
  - 1,300+ quotes generated
  - 226 employers live (2-48 employees)
  - Tested in 5 states: California, Texas, Florida, Illinois, New York
  - Over 70% of enrolled groups previously had NO health insurance
- Major partnership announcement: Thatch integrated into ADP Run platform and mentioned on ADP earnings call

Chamber Distribution Strategy:
- Goal: Scale ICHRA sales through chamber of commerce partnerships
- Chambers provide co-branded microsites with self-service quoting tools
- 20% discount for chamber members vs. public pricing
- Compensation model: $5 per employee per month (PEPM), paid annually
- Technology platform proven through direct-to-employer success can be white-labeled for chambers

Current Chamber Relationships:
- Sarasota Chamber: Most aggressive partner, co-branded site built, meeting scheduled for 2025-12-17
- FACP (Florida Association of Chamber Professionals): Site built, relationship established
- Big Sky Montana: Discussions ongoing, concerns about conflict with existing United Healthcare level-funded product
- Additional discussions: Minnesota, Indiana, Illinois, Oregon, Washington state associations

Key Differentiators:
- Year-round enrollment (not limited to open enrollment periods)
- Self-service quoting platform with high conversion rates
- Serves 1-2 person businesses (traditionally underserved market)
- Employees maintain individual plan choice while employers control costs
- No minimum group size requirements

2. STAKEHOLDERS & RESPONSIBILITIES

Internal Team (Thatch):
- Gary Daniels - Leadership, strategic direction, partnership approvals, high-level chamber presentations
- Ty Phillippay - Business development execution, chamber relationship management, day-to-day operations
- Taryn - Attended FACP event, demonstrated strong chamber engagement capabilities
- Matthias - Technical lead for microsite development and implementation
- Sales Team - 20+ salespeople currently working 14-15 hour days on enrollment

External Partners:
- Kyle Sexton - Chamber consultant, will lead chamber outreach and education, marketing materials development, has existing chamber relationships and speaking engagements
- Ed Hill - Sarasota Chamber (VP level), wants in-person meetings and active ICHRA promotion
- Brad - Big Sky Montana Chamber CEO (formerly from Oregon, tour operator background)
- Tammy - FACP leadership, concerned about revenue conflicts with member chambers

Broker Considerations:
- Brokers can participate if involved from beginning of sales process
- 30-day window for legitimate late additions
- No retroactive broker attachments after 30 days
- No "broker of record" overrides for chamber plans

3. CRITICAL MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Completed Milestones:
- August 2025: Launched direct-to-employer pilot program
- 2021-2022: Early ICHRA awareness and product development
- Late 2024/Early 2025: FACP sponsorship and initial chamber outreach
- December 2025: ADP Run integration announced
- December 16, 2025: This strategic planning meeting

Current Status (as of 2025-12-16):
- Post-enrollment "cleanup" phase - following up with prospects in various stages of signup
- Technology platform validated and ready for chamber deployment
- Template microsite structure established and replicable
- Pricing and compensation models finalized

Upcoming Milestones:
- 2025-12-17: Meeting with Ed Hill (Sarasota Chamber) to walk through process
- January 2026: Gary releasing white paper on direct-to-employer learnings with state-by-state data
- Mid-January 2026: Kyle's first chamber speaking engagements begin
- February 2026 (Week 1-2): WACE Conference (California/Vegas/Oregon/Washington)
- May 2026 (Week 1): MACE Conference (Mid-America Chamber Executives)
- May 2026 (Week 1): MAKO Conference (Missouri, Arkansas, Kansas, Oklahoma)
- July 2026: ACC Conference in New Orleans (Association of Chamber of Commerce Executives)

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES & OWNERS

Immediate Actions (Pre-Holiday 2025):

1. Partnership Agreement Finalization
   - Owner: Gary Daniels
   - Deadline: ASAP (before Kyle's January speaking engagements)
   - Action: Finalize and send referral agreement (1.5 page document) to Kyle

2. Marketing Materials Audit
   - Owner: Ty Phillippay
   - Deadline: During holiday period
   - Action: Share all existing chamber marketing materials with Kyle (despite being "homespun")

3. Technical Architecture Meeting
   - Owners: Kyle Sexton + Matthias (Thatch technical lead)
   - Deadline: Before end of December 2025
   - Action: Discuss microsite automation, embedding capabilities, and scalable deployment strategy
   - Note: Gary does not need to attend

4. Sarasota Chamber Follow-up
   - Owner: Gary Daniels/Thatch team
   - Deadline: 2025-12-17
   - Action: Walk Ed Hill through co-branded site and process

Short-term Actions (January 2026):

5. Content Development & Messaging Framework
   - Owners: Kyle Sexton (lead) + Ty Phillippay
   - Deadline: January 2026 (before mid-month speaking engagements)
   - Actions:
     - Develop problem-aware → solution-aware → brand-aware content flow
     - Create "plain English" vs. "insurance speak" messaging
     - Build chamber-specific collateral addressing: problem awareness, ICHRA education, Thatch benefits, member distribution, broker integration, employer FAQs
     - Establish shared workspace for collaborative editing
     - Define Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) for target employers (average 3-4 employees, focus on 1-2 employee businesses initially)

6. White Paper Release
   - Owner: Gary Daniels
   - Deadline: January 2026
   - Content: Direct-to-employer pilot results, state-by-state data, uninsured employer statistics

7. Regular Coordination Cadence
   - Owners: Ty Phillippay + Kyle Sexton
   - Start Date: Right after holidays (early January 2026)
   - Frequency: Twice weekly standing meetings

Medium-term Actions (Q1-Q2 2026):

8. Conference Sponsorship Planning
   - Owner: Kyle Sexton
   - Deadline: January 2026
   - Action: Compile sponsorship opportunities for WACE, MACE, MAKO, ACC with budget estimates for Gary's approval

9. Microsite Automation & Scaling
   - Owner: Kyle Sexton (with Matthias support)
   - Timeline: Q1 2026
   - Goal: Build automated microsite generation (form submission → logo upload → live site)
   - Benefit: Remove bottleneck from Thatch technical team

10. State Association Strategy
    - Owners: Ty Phillippay + Kyle Sexton
    - Timeline: Ongoing through 2026
    - Decision: Pursue individual chamber relationships vs. state association umbrella approach
    - Current direction: Individual chamber microsites (not state-level consolidation)

Ongoing Operational Items:

11. Broker Policy Enforcement
    - Owner: Gary Daniels/Thatch operations
    - Policy: 30-day window for broker attachment, no retroactive additions, annual renewal for late requests

12. Chamber Support & Metrics
    - Owner: Thatch team
    - Deliverable: Monthly reporting dashboard showing employer enrollments, employee counts, revenue attribution by chamber
    - Already built and operational

13. Educational Resources
    - Owners: Thatch marketing team + Kyle Sexton
    - Assets available: 60-second explainer videos (YouTube), broker portal content, co-branded materials
    - Need: Unlocked/editable versions for Kyle's customization

Strategic Considerations:

- Positioning: Emphasize "new model" for benefits vs. traditional insurance, focus on Main Street/plain English communication
- Target Market: Small businesses (1-4 employees initially), 70%+ previously uninsured
- Competitive Advantage: Year-round enrollment, self-service capability, no minimum group size
- Quality Control: Prioritize getting "first wins" for chambers with ideal employer profiles (right states, appropriate average age)
- Scalability: Balance aggressive growth with maintaining service quality and chamber satisfaction

Meeting Outcome: Clear alignment on partnership structure, roles, and go-to-market approach for scaling ICHRA through chamber distribution channel in 2026.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect/Client Profile: Chambers of Commerce (multiple prospects including Sarasota Chamber, FACP, Big Sky Montana, Minnesota, Indiana, Illinois, Oregon, Washington)

What They Have in Place:
- Existing membership bases with small business members
- Some chambers have traditional health insurance partnerships (e.g., United Healthcare, level-funded products)
- Limited or no ICHRA offerings currently

Priorities:
- Generate new revenue streams for the chamber
- Provide differentiated value to members, especially small businesses
- Maintain brand reputation through reliable partner relationships
- Support local businesses with affordable health insurance access
- Avoid conflicts with existing broker relationships on their boards

Pain Points & Challenges:
- 70%+ of target small businesses (1-2 employees) lack health insurance entirely
- Traditional group insurance has minimum size requirements that exclude smallest businesses
- High annual renewal costs for businesses with existing coverage
- Lack of ICHRA awareness among members (solution awareness gap)
- Need for education and marketing materials in plain English vs. "insurance speak"
- Concerns about broker commission stacking (can reach 30% of total plan costs)
- Resource constraints for manual outreach and education
- Fear of technology/billing failures damaging chamber brand

Optimization Goals:
- Scale chamber partnerships efficiently with standardized processes
- Provide intuitive self-service quoting tools (proven with 340 employers, 1,300+ quotes since August 2025)
- Offer 20% member discount vs. public pricing
- Create co-branded microsites quickly and systematically
- Develop formulaic marketing materials and communication workflows
- Position as "new model" rather than "insurance light"
- Target ideal customer profile (ICP) - focus on best 50 opportunities first, then scale to 500
- Provide monthly metrics/reporting to chambers showing enrollment progress

Stated Timelines:
- Sarasota Chamber presentation: 2025-12-17
- Partnership paperwork: Expedited, before holidays
- Kyle's speaking engagements: Mid-January 2026 (Wisconsin/Michigan)
- Standing bi-weekly meetings (Ty/Kyle): Starting after holidays
- White paper release on direct-to-employer strategy: January 2026
- WACE Conference: February 2026 (first or second week)
- MACE & MACO Conferences: First week of May 2026
- ACC Conference: July 2026 (New Orleans)
- Compensation structure: $5 per employee per month, paid annually after enrollment

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Immediate Next Steps:

1. Gary (Thatch) - 12/17/2025: Meet with Ed Hill at Sarasota Chamber to walk through the co-branded site process

2. Gary (Thatch) - By end of December 2025: Finalize and send partnership/referral agreement to Kyle for chamber relationships

3. Ty (Thatch) - By end of December 2025: Share all existing chamber marketing materials with Kyle for review and optimization

4. Kyle & Matthias (Thatch) - Before mid-January 2026: Schedule technical call to discuss microsite building strategy, automation capabilities, and scaling approach (Ty and Gary do not need to attend)

5. Kyle - By early January 2026: Compile sponsorship opportunities for key 2026 chamber conferences (WACE, MACE, MAKO, ACC) and send to Gary for budgeting

6. Ty & Kyle - After holidays/mid-January 2026: Establish twice-weekly standing meetings to collaborate on chamber content, messaging, and materials

7. Kyle - Mid-January 2026: Begin chamber outreach at speaking engagements in Wisconsin and Michigan to capture chamber partnerships for Thatch

Key Conferences to Attend (Gary/Ty):
- WACE: February 2026 (first or second week)
- MACE: First week of May 2026
- MAKO: First week of May 2026
- ACC: July 2026 in New Orleans

Overall Deal Progress: The partnership is moving from planning to execution phase. Once the referral agreement is finalized and marketing materials are refined over the holidays, Kyle will begin active chamber recruitment in mid-January 2026 with full support infrastructure in place.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Thatch and Sanchez, Mitchell, Eastmant & Cure (Composition Wealth)

Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

ICHRA Solution Overview
- First-time introduction to Thatch's ICHRA platform for the brokerage firm
- Thatch offers pre-tax benefit solution allowing employees to choose from ~40+ health plans per ZIP code (some areas have 100+ options)
- Key differentiators vs. Government Exchange:
  - Pre-tax payroll deductions for cost-sharing scenarios (not available on government exchanges)
  - Robust tech platform with compliance support, enrollment assistance, and AI chatbot
  - Live support from licensed benefits experts for employees

Pricing Structure
- Platform fee: $45 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
- Broker commission: $30 PEPM (out of the $45 fee)
- Compliance fee: Flat $50/month regardless of headcount
- Employees not enrolled (e.g., on spouse's plan) incur no fees or allowance costs

Allowance Strategy
- Two approaches: Flat allowance for all employees OR dynamic calculator based on age, ZIP code, and dependents
- Dynamic calculator mirrors insurance carrier pricing methodology
- Allowances cannot be tiered by job title or seniority (non-compliant)
- Surplus funds function like FSA for qualified medical expenses (prescriptions, therapy, dental costs)
- Unused surplus resets to zero at year-end

Enrollment Timing
- Critical deadline: December 22, 2025 for January 1, 2026 start dates
- After deadline, next available start is February 1, 2026
- Enrollment required by 25th of month prior to start date
- All ICHRA plans operate on calendar year basis (January 1 start for 2026 plans)
- Switching from group insurance triggers special enrollment period (can start 1st of any month)

Client Situations Discussed
- Sanchez Group: Already secured coverage for January 2026 through regional plan via carrier group site (not using Thatch)
- Unnamed Client (>10 employees): Facing significant renewal increase for January 1, 2026; switched to worse plan with limited networks; actively seeking alternatives for potential February 1 or March 1, 2026 start

2026 Rate Increases
- National average: 15-30% increases across states
- Arkansas highest at 46% increase
- Washington relatively moderate at 16%
- Data represents both group and ICHRA renewal rates

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Thatch Representatives
- Joseph Firenzi - Business Development, Thatch
  - Role: Presented ICHRA solution, demonstrated platform capabilities
  - Handles accounts of 10 lives or less
  - Contact for ongoing questions and quote submissions

- Chad - Head of Broker Partnerships, Thatch
  - Email: chad@thatch.ai or chad@thatch.com
  - Role: Establishes formal broker partnerships
  - Responsible for partnership presentations and setup

Broker Firm: Sanchez, Mitchell, Eastmant & Cure (Composition Wealth)
- Barbara Kettman - Insurance Broker
  - Role: Primary contact, decision-maker for partnership
  - Interested in offering ICHRA to clients facing renewal challenges

- Carla Gatlin - Insurance Broker
  - Role: Most familiar with specific client groups
  - Asked detailed operational questions about payroll integration, commissions, and onboarding

Clients (Prospects for ICHRA)
- Sanchez Group: Virgin group, already placed for January 2026 (not pursuing Thatch)
- Unnamed Client: Group size >10 employees, facing poor renewal, potential March 1, 2026 start candidate

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

December 16, 2025 - Initial Discovery Call
- First interaction between Thatch and brokerage firm
- Comprehensive platform demonstration completed
- Allowance calculator and cost analysis tools reviewed

December 22, 2025 - Enrollment Deadline
- Final day to enroll clients for January 1, 2026 start dates
- After this date, earliest start is February 1, 2026

January 1, 2026 - Plan Year Start
- All 2026 ICHRA plans begin (calendar year basis)
- Unnamed client's current poor renewal plan takes effect

February 1, 2026 - Potential Start Date
- Earliest alternative start date for unnamed client if switching from current plan
- Enrollment deadline: January 25, 2026

March 1, 2026 - Target Start Date
- Barbara indicated this as likely target for unnamed client analysis
- Enrollment deadline: February 25, 2026
- Client comfortable with first two months on current plan while exploring alternatives

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (Week of December 16, 2025)

Action 1: Establish Formal Broker Partnership
- Responsible Party: Barbara Kettman and Carla Gatlin
- Task: Email Chad (chad@thatch.ai) to request formal partnership setup
- Details: Include Joe Firenzi on email thread; request presentation on partnership structure
- Deadline: ASAP to enable quote submissions for clients
- Outcome: Broker portal access with login credentials for submitting quote requests

Action 2: Cost Analysis Request for Unnamed Client
- Responsible Party: Barbara Kettman (to initiate)
- Task: Contact Joe Firenzi or appropriate Thatch rep for cost analysis
- Client Details: 
  - Group size: >10 employees
  - Current situation: Poor January 1, 2026 renewal with limited networks
  - Target start: March 1, 2026
  - Client open to suggestions due to current plan dissatisfaction
- Requirements: Provide census data (age, ZIP code, dependents) and current renewal rates
- Deadline: Mid-January 2026 to allow time for February decision
- Note: Client aware first two months on current plan acceptable while exploring options

Follow-Up Actions

Action 3: Review Partnership Materials
- Responsible Party: Barbara Kettman and Carla Gatlin
- Task: Review formal partnership presentation from Chad
- Timeline: After initial outreach to Chad

Action 4: Payroll Integration Assessment
- Responsible Party: Carla Gatlin (for unnamed client)
- Task: Determine if client uses payroll provider with Thatch integration (Gusto, ADP, QuickBooks Online, etc.) or requires manual processing
- Note: No additional fees for two-way integrations; manual entry available for in-house payroll

Action 5: Explore Additional Client Opportunities
- Responsible Party: Both brokers
- Task: Identify other clients (virgin groups or poor renewals) who might benefit from ICHRA
- Resources Provided: 
  - Public plan search tool: thatch.com/plans
  - Blog resources for eligible classes and compliance questions
  - Joe Firenzi as ongoing resource for questions

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Technical Capabilities Demonstrated
- Self-service onboarding for groups ≤10 employees
- Dynamic allowance calculator with real-time plan pricing
- Side-by-side plan comparison (up to 3 plans)
- Summary of Benefits and Coverage (SBC) download capability
- Marketplace for additional healthcare products (dental, vision currently available)

Compliance & Operational Details
- Eligible class options: Can separate full-time vs. part-time with different allowances
- Deductible considerations: Switching mid-year means less time to meet deductible on new plan
- No health-based underwriting; risk pool based on entire state population
- Thatch handles compliance, enrollment, separations, receipt verification, and tax documentation

Broker Concerns Addressed
- Commission structure clarified ($30 PEPM)
- Payroll deduction frequency (can align with bi-weekly or other schedules)
- Per-paycheck cost visibility (currently shows monthly; deductions align with payroll frequency)
- Onboarding process for groups >10 employees (different flow than self-service)

Resources Shared
- Public plan search tool for employee/employer preview
- Blog articles on eligible classes and compliance topics
- Contact information for partnership team and ongoing support

attributes.title: Thatch and Sanchez, Mitchell, Eastmant & Cure (Composition Wealth)
attributes.transcript:
Joseph Firenzi:
Hello. 
Barbara Kettman:
Hi Joseph, how are you? 
Joseph Firenzi:
Good, how are you guys doing today? 
Barbara Kettman:
Good, thank you. 
Joseph Firenzi:
It's great to hear. But cool, yeah, I would love to dive right in. Sometimes these meetings actually get down to the wire a little bit in terms of having enough time to get to all the material. So I'd love to just get to it. My name is Joe, I'm on the business team here at Thatch. And before. Before I get too much ahead of myself, I did want to ask if this is your first interaction with us, or have you spoken to other representatives at Thatch before? 
Barbara Kettman:
First time ever. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay, cool. 
Barbara Kettman:
So, yeah. 
Joseph Firenzi:
And then it looked like this is going to be a virgin group. Is that correct? With no previous benefit solution? 
Barbara Kettman:
Yeah, I'll let Carla answer, because she's the one that's most familiar with this group. Okay. 
CarlaGatlin:
I have to remind myself the group. 
Barbara Kettman:
Sanchez. 
CarlaGatlin:
Oh, okay. Yes, it was a merchant group. They did already make a choice for January. So I think that's all. We just want to know how that works for any upcoming new groups. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay, so Sanchez is all taken care of, and they don't need a solution. Did they go on the Government Exchange or did they go with another third party Icra administrator? 
CarlaGatlin:
Yeah, they're going to do a regions plan through us, through the carrier group site that we used. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay, cool. So, for the purpose of today's session, I'll just be outlining how Thatch functions. 
CarlaGatlin:
Perfect. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay, cool. Thank you. That's helpful. Neat. Well, I would love to just give my standard slide deck presentation that I give to... Employers and stuff as well. And then I think that will be very helpful. And then, if you'd like, afterwards, I can show you our allowance calculator, which is how the employers decide on the monetary amount to distribute to the team. Want to pause here, though, because I wanted to see if there was anything pressing. If you guys had. That was top of mind that I could address first. 
Barbara Kettman:
Nothing I know of. Right. 
CarlaGatlin:
I just I assume this is very ICRA. So lots of information that my brain needs to hone in on. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yeah, of course. Well, cool. I'll just start with the presentation here. And then, if you have any questions along the way, feel free to interrupt me and then I'll take a second. But can you guys see this? Yes. Perfect. So this first slide kind of just highlights how that functions in comparison to the traditional group insurance model. Basically, the employer would go out and choose only one to three plan options with the standard model, But because people have different healthcare needs and different, you know, backgrounds, locking them into just a few different plan options might not be the best path forward. One of the many cool things about choosing an IcRa plan on that is that. You will present the option for your team members to choose any plan in the Zip code they live in. The average amount is about 40 in any zip code in the United States. And, you know, in certain areas, there's actually well over 100 different plans to choose from. So that means not only the employee will be able to find the best plan for themselves, but also the best plan for any potential dependents that they add as well. And then, at a high level overview, this is how Thatch is going to function. So at the top of the screen, there is an example of that monthly allowance that you can distribute to team members. This will be pre-tax for the business, of course. So that's very nice there. And for the sake of this example, we'll call this individual here Stacy, and we'll just say that she works for you. You'll send an invite email out to Stacy, saying, hey, we're going to use that this year. Please accept the monthly allowance I've designated for you and create an account, which only takes about five minutes, And then go on our Plan selection page and choose any plan that you like best. Stacy goes and she does just that, but the plans she ends up choosing is only $500 per month with that medical premium. Which means she would have $250 left over monthly. With that leftover $250, she can actually spend those dollars in a very similar way to an FSA. At Thatch, we call those leftover funds qualified medical expenses, and some examples of ways that you can spend those dollars are on things like prescriptions, therapy, dental costs, and many other items that the I.R.S. has deemed to be qualified. You are required to enroll in a plan. Before accessing these leftover funds, which means it is not an option to decline healthcare coverage and then only have the FSA pre-tax spending account with us. These funds that someone could have in surplus after choosing a plan that costs less than the allowance do roll over month to month throughout the entire calendar year, so people can save them up. But if at the end of December, any employee forgot to use their leftover dollars, their balance will reset to zero. And then in January, they can start saving them up once again. These funds are not pre-distributed to the employees, which means that they always just sit in the business bank account awaiting an eligible transaction, which also means if they got unused, those funds would just remain in the business bank account because they never left. And then going to the bottom of the screen here, this is the thatch card. So this is just going to be the most efficient way to spend those dollars that someone could have in surplus. There is both a digital and physical version of this card upon request, But people can also use a personal payment method if they would like to, and then upload the transaction onto their Thatch portal for reimbursement. With those pre-tax dollars there. Then, going back to the top of the screen, we can now flip the script and ask the question, what happens if Stacey chooses a plan that's $850? So now it's $100 more than that monthly allowance she's receiving. fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value: The prospect's current benefits plan is a traditional group health insurance plan with United Health Care (UHC) as the carrier. The plan is administered through Simply Insured, which integrates with QuickBooks Online for payroll processing. The company has 11-12 employees total, with most participating in the plan. Two employees are not currently enrolled: one opted out due to rising costs and obtained individual coverage independently, and another is covered through her spouse's employer plan (city government). The prospect reports that premiums have been increasing by thousands of dollars annually, which is a primary driver for exploring alternative options. The specific funding type (fully insured, level-funded, or self-funded) and plan design details (PPO, HMO, HDHP) were not explicitly mentioned in the conversation.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Point of Light - ICHRA Discovery Call

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Thatch Representative: Taryn Livingstone  
Company: Point of Light  
Location: Central Florida (Zip Code: 33823)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Primary Business Drivers
- Cost Management for 2026 Renewal: Tim expressed significant concern about insurance premiums increasing "thousands of dollars every year" and noted that "2026 is not faring well" for cost projections. The company is seeking alternatives to control escalating healthcare costs.

- Administrative Burden Reduction: Tim highlighted the complexity of administering traditional group plans, particularly around:
  - Annual plan selection decisions for employees
  - Compliance requirements (described as "scary" with "steep penalties")
  - Cash-in-lieu-of-benefits administration (described as a "nightmare" due to post-tax complications and government regulations)

- Employee Empowerment: Tim wants to "put more money in the employees' hands" rather than giving it to insurance companies, preferably through pre-tax vehicles like HSAs or similar mechanisms.

Current Benefits Situation
- Current Carrier: United Health Care via Simply Insured through QuickBooks Online (QBO)
- Enrollment: 10 of 12 employees enrolled
  - 1 employee opted out due to high costs and found cheaper individual coverage
  - 1 employee covered under spouse's plan (city government employee with excellent coverage)
- Integration Requirement: QuickBooks payroll integration is "super important" to minimize paperwork

ICHRA Solution Interest
- Plan Customization: Tim appreciated the ability to customize allowances based on age, location, and dependent count without needing class-based structures (which require 10+ employees per class)
- Plan Variety: Impressed by 162 plan options available in their Florida zip code
- Pre-tax Benefits: Strong interest in the Thatch card/HRA for leftover funds to be used pre-tax on qualified medical expenses and marketplace vendors (mentioned interest in Oura Ring, HIMS, telehealth options)
- Cost Transparency: Values the ability to see comparable plans and ensure employees won't pay more under the new structure

Concerns & Special Situations
- Employee Communication: Tim worried about "scaring employees" with the transition, particularly those with young children. Wants to ensure proper explanation that they're "still getting a traditional plan" just purchased individually with reimbursement.
- Cash-in-Lieu Alternative: One employee (covered by spouse) seeks compensation for not using company benefits. Tim explored whether ICHRA could address this but learned the HRA requires purchasing a medical plan first, and funds expire annually.
- Change Management: Tim researched alternative options including HealthShare and wants a gradual transition approach.

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

At Point of Light (Prospect Company)
1. Tim (tlinamen) - Primary Decision Maker
   - Role: Owner/Employer
   - Responsibilities: Final decision on benefits strategy, cost management, employee communication
   - Technically counts as 12th employee

2. Kayla - Administrative Support
   - Role: Handles administrative tasks
   - Responsibilities: Benefits administration support, likely payroll coordination
   - Present on the call

3. Employees (10 enrolled, 2 not enrolled)
   - Various situations including families with young children, single employees, and one seeking cash-in-lieu alternative

At Thatch
1. Taryn Livingstone - Sales Representative/Account Manager
   - Role: Primary contact, product education, implementation support
   - Responsibilities: Product demonstration, quote assistance, enrollment support, employee presentation coordination

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Dates
- Current Coverage End Date: February 1, 2026 (2-1-2026)
- Desired New Coverage Start Date: February 1, 2026 (2-1-2026)
- Enrollment Deadline: January 7, 2026 (1-7-2026) - Tim must sign up for Thatch and invite employees by end of first week of January
- Employee Selection Period: January 7-24, 2026 - Two-week window for employees to review plans and enroll before February 1st start date
- Open Enrollment Period: Currently active (as of December 16, 2025)

Key Conversation Moments
- Initial Interest: Tim discovered Thatch website, found it "very organized," and appreciated the company appeared stable/established
- Quote Exploration: Tim had previously explored estimated monthly costs on Thatch platform before scheduling call
- Compliance Relief: Significant positive reaction when learning Thatch handles all compliance documentation and legal requirements
- Plan Availability Discovery: Surprised and pleased to learn 162 plans available in their zip code (33823)
- Smart Allowances Feature: Positive response to ability to customize by age/location/dependents without class restrictions
- QuickBooks Integration Confirmation: Relief that Thatch was QuickBooks' "first ever integration" partner

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By January 7, 2026)

Tim's Responsibilities:
1. Continue Quote Exploration (By late December 2025)
   - Play with allowance calculators on Thatch platform
   - Review 162 available plan options for zip code 33823
   - Compare current United Health Care plans to individual market equivalents
   - Determine appropriate coverage level (Bronze/Silver/Gold) and contribution percentage

2. Employee Research (By early January 2026)
   - Optionally share plan options with employees to gauge reactions
   - Identify which employees might need extra support/communication
   - Address concerns from employees with young children

3. Final Decision & Enrollment (By January 7, 2026)
   - Make final decision on allowance structure
   - Sign up for Thatch platform
   - Invite all 12 employees to Thatch system

Taryn's Responsibilities:
1. Follow-up Email (Immediate - by December 17, 2025)
   - Send links discussed during call
   - Provide thatch.com/plans resource
   - Share quote calculator access

2. Check-in Communication (Around January 7, 2026)
   - Follow up closer to enrollment deadline
   - Ensure Tim is ready to move forward if decision is positive
   - Address any outstanding questions

3. Employee Presentation (If requested, before January 24, 2026)
   - Conduct demonstration for all Point of Light employees
   - Explain ICHRA concept and how it works
   - Answer employee questions to build credibility and trust
   - Help with change management concerns

Secondary Considerations

For Tim to Explore:
- Research FSA options for employee covered by spouse (not Thatch-related but mentioned as potential solution)
- Determine if maintaining a small traditional group plan alongside ICHRA is necessary (though likely not needed based on conversation)

Thatch Platform Actions:
- Employees will have January 7-24, 2026 to select plans
- Employees can access AI-powered plan recommendations or speak with Thatch support specialists
- Plans will be active February 1, 2026

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Pricing Structure
- Platform Fee: $45 per employee per month
- Compliance Fee: $50 per month (flat fee)
- Total for 12 employees: Approximately $590/month in Thatch fees (plus allowance amounts)

Technical Requirements Met
- QuickBooks Online payroll integration available
- Self-serve platform with guided support
- Automated payroll deductions for employee contributions (if buying up)
- Receipt verification and reimbursement handling included

Competitive Advantages Noted
- 100+ plan options in Florida (162 in their specific zip code)
- Smart allowances avoid class-based restrictions
- Pre-tax HRA for leftover funds (expires annually, similar to FSA)
- Thatch Marketplace for telehealth and wellness products
- End-to-end compliance management
- Locked annual budget (no mid-year premium increases)

Risk Mitigation Strategy
- Tim wants employee presentation from Thatch to build credibility
- Emphasis on explaining this is still "traditional coverage" just individually purchased
- Concern about cost comparison to ensure employees don't pay more
- Gradual transition approach preferred ("baby steps")

text_plain_content.title: Generated Email
text_plain_content.value:
Subject: Great connecting today - Next steps for Thatch


Hi Tim and Kayla,


Thanks for taking the time to chat today! It was great learning more about Point of Light and your goals for benefits.


Here's a quick recap of what we covered:

- ICHRA allows employees to choose from 162+ individual plans in your area (way more options than traditional group plans)
- Smart allowances adjust budgets based on age, location, and dependents to ensure fair purchasing power
- Leftover funds go on a pre-tax Thatch card for qualified medical expenses (prescriptions, telehealth, even Oura rings!)
- QuickBooks integration is ready to go
- Your budget stays locked for the year - no surprise premium increases


Next Steps:

- Play around with the quote calculator to find an allowance structure that works
- Check out available plans at thatch.com/plans
- If you'd like to move forward for a 2025-02-01 start date, aim to sign up by 2025-01-07
- Let me know if you'd like me to do an employee presentation


I'll follow up early January to see how things are progressing. Let me know if any questions come up!


Best,

Taryn

items.description: • Successfully identified carrier (United Health Care), admin platform (Simply Insured/QBO), and cost escalation patterns affecting the current group structure.
items.title: Understand Current Plan Structure

items.description: • Strong discovery of specific pain: Prospect detailed "insurance plan jump up thousands of dollars every year" and compliance being "a nightmare" with steep penalties.
items.title: Identify Pain

items.description: • Strong discovery: Captured complete enrollment picture - "12 counting me" total with "two that are not" enrolled, plus reasons why.
items.title: Capture Team & Enrollment Size

items.description: • Strong discovery: Tim explicitly stated wanting to "put more money in employees' hands" and reduce administrative burden while maintaining compliance.
items.title: Identify Impact & Priorities

items.description: • Taryn clearly communicated specific enrollment deadlines: "sign up by end of first week of January" for February 1st coverage start.
items.title: Timeline or Decision Deadline Shared

items.description:
• Improvement focus – Identify decision-makers and approval process
• Conversation reference – When Tim mentioned cost concerns and employee buy-in, should have explored who approves benefits decisions
• Action item – Ask about decision-makers, budget approval, and implementation timeline
items.title: Decision Process Mapped

summary.summaryText:
- Taryn identified the current plan structure well, noting the carrier, admin platform, and cost patterns.
- Taryn missed mapping the decision process; next, ask about decision-makers and budget approval.
- Taryn didn't explore employee buy-in; next, discuss who influences benefits decisions.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Client/Prospect Information:
- Prospect: Eric Gilbert, Alpha Risk Management
- Broker: Danielle Hunter, Gallagher - Durham, NC
- Employees: 3 (Eric, Aniyah, Isaac)

Current Situation:
- Isaac pays $273.27/month out-of-pocket for a UnitedHealthcare Choice Plus Network plan with a $3,000 deductible.
- Eric has a spouse and two adopted children, with only the spouse being added to the employer plan.
- Aniyah and Isaac are younger employees with no dependents.

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Rising renewal costs and price hikes.
- Marketplace options are similarly priced to current coverage.
- Need for a more affordable solution for a small team.
- Time pressure due to open enrollment season.

Priorities/Optimization Goals:
- Implement a 50-50 cost-sharing approach for Aniyah and Isaac.
- Consider a ~$500/month allowance per employee.
- Interest in zero-cost plan options for younger employees.
- Include dental and vision coverage options.
- Prefer catastrophic-style plans for younger employees.

Solution Discussed:
- ICHRA solution via Thatch platform.
- Dynamic allowance calculator based on age, ZIP code, and dependents.
- 47 plan options available in their area.
- Platform costs: $45/enrolled employee/month + $50/month flat compliance fee.
- Surplus funds usable for FSA-eligible expenses.

Stated Timelines:
- Enrollment deadline: 2025-12-25 for a 2026-01-01 start date.
- Decision needed by 2025-12-22.
- Follow-up call scheduled for the same day at 5:00 PM.
- Self-service signup link to be provided for Eric to explore independently.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep (Joseph Firenzi) Owns:
- Send standard follow-up email to Eric Gilbert and Danielle Hunter with self-service signup link
- Send meeting invite for follow-up discussion (5:00 PM same day mentioned)
- Provide access to calculator tool for independent exploration

Prospect (Eric Gilbert) Owns:
- Explore the self-service calculator tool independently to adjust allowance inputs
- Review dental and vision plan options available on the platform
- Evaluate cost scenarios for covering the two younger employees (Aniyah and Isaac)
- Make final enrollment decision and enroll employees by 12/25/2025 (hard deadline for January 1, 2026 start date)

Broker (Danielle Hunter) Owns:
- Participate in follow-up discussion to review total costs including monthly platform fees ($45 per enrolled employee + $50 compliance fee)
- Help Eric evaluate dental and vision options

Immediate Next Step:
Schedule and conduct follow-up meeting at 5:00 PM on 12/16/2025 to review additional questions about platform fees, dental/vision options, and finalize allowance structure for the two employees.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect's company currently does not have a group benefits plan in place. One employee, Isaac, is purchasing individual coverage through the ACA marketplace/exchange. His current plan details are as follows:

- Carrier: UnitedHealthcare (specifically through National Foundation Life, which is a UnitedHealthcare ACA-only company)
- Plan Design: Choice Plus Network (PPO)
- Deductible: $3,000
- Monthly Cost: $273.27 (paid entirely out of pocket by the employee with no employer contribution)
- Funding Type: Individual marketplace plan (not employer-sponsored)

The prospect is exploring the implementation of an ICHRA (Individual Coverage Health Reimbursement Arrangement) solution through Thatch to provide employer contributions toward individual marketplace plans for their small team of three employees.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Alpha Risk Management (Gallagher - Durham, NC) - ICHRA Solution Discussion

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Meeting Duration: Approximately 30 minutes (with follow-up scheduled)

1. Key Points Discussed

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: The primary objective is to find affordability solutions to manage 2026 renewal costs while maintaining competitive benefits for a small team. The employer is facing rising premium costs in the traditional group health insurance market and is seeking cost predictability and administrative simplicity. The company has 3 employees, and the employer is exploring ICHRA to provide flexible, individualized health coverage with controlled employer contribution.

- Cost Structure & Affordability Analysis: The current baseline shows employee Isaac paying $273.27/month out-of-pocket for a United Healthcare ACA exchange plan with a $3,000 deductible. The employer's initial preference is a 50-50 cost-sharing model for employees Aniyah and Isaac. Thatch's dynamic calculator structures allowances based on age, zip code, and number of dependents. Platform pricing is $45 per enrolled employee per month, with a $50 flat monthly compliance fee.

- Coverage Details & Employee Situations: Eric Gilbert (Owner) will enroll with his spouse, while Aniyah and Isaac, both young and single, are open to catastrophic/high-deductible plans.

- Plan Options & Buying Power: There are 47 individual health plans available in the employer's zip code area. Allowance flexibility allows employees like Aniyah to access plans with monthly surpluses for FSA-eligible expenses.

- Additional Benefits: Dental and vision are available through the same allowance structure. Surplus allowance can be used for FSA-eligible items.

- Administrative Considerations: The self-service platform allows the employer to use the calculator tool freely before finalizing. The enrollment process is simple for the 3-person team, with compliance support included in the flat fee.

2. Stakeholders Identified

- Eric Gilbert: Owner/Employer, responsible for final decisions on ICHRA adoption and determining employer contribution/allowance amounts.

- Danielle Hunter: Benefits Broker/Consultant, primary relationship manager, presenting ICHRA solution options, and coordinating between Thatch and the employer.

- Joseph Firenzi: Sales Representative/Implementation Specialist, responsible for product demonstration, technical guidance, and compliance support.

- Aniyah and Isaac: Employees, both young and single, needing coverage for 2026.

3. Important Milestones & Timestamps

- 4:00 PM CT: Meeting start with initial connection challenges.
- ~4:05 PM CT: Eric Gilbert attempted to join but was initially unavailable.
- ~4:15 PM CT: Census clarification confirmed Eric's children will not be added to the ICHRA plan.
- ~4:20 PM CT: Eric Gilbert joined the meeting.
- ~4:25 PM CT: Allowance calculator deep dive.
- 4:30 PM CT: Meeting time constraint led to scheduling a follow-up.
- ~4:31 PM CT: Follow-up scheduled for 5:00

• Improvement focus – Systematically gather complete plan structure details

• Action item – Ask specific questions about plan types and funding models

summary.summaryText:
- Joe effectively captured team and enrollment size, tailoring his approach to the 3-person team.
- Joe missed mapping the decision process; next, ask Eric about approval authority and stakeholders involved.
- Joe didn't connect solution benefits to business outcomes; next, link platform features to measurable impact like cost savings.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Current Situation:
- Company: Mobile Technical Training Inc (S-Corp)
- Contact: Karina (W-2 employee, spouse of owner)
- Location: South Hackensack, NJ (Zip: 07606)
- Employees: 3-4 W-2 employees, with 10 total employees (7 may opt out)
- Previous Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield group plan terminated in August 2025 due to not meeting 75% minimum participation requirement
- Now claims to meet participation with 2 employees enrolling (one owner, one regular employee) and others having valid waivers (coverage through spouse/parents)
- Exploring both ICHRA and group insurance reinstatement options

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Small group participation requirements preventing coverage
- Rising group insurance costs (10-20% annual increases)
- Current gap in coverage due to plan lapse
- Unfamiliarity with ICRA/HRA model and research burden
- Confusion between ICHRA quotes and group insurance options
- Communication challenges and information scattered across multiple emails
- Time-sensitive deadlines creating pressure

Priorities:
- Provide medical benefits to current qualifying employees
- Maintain Blue Cross Blue Shield coverage with the same network of doctors
- Pricing is a major deciding factor
- Secure health insurance coverage for employees who want to enroll
- Understand cost differences between ICHRA model and traditional group insurance
- Reinstate coverage similar to previous Horizon plan

Optimization Goals:
- Explore ICRA as an alternative to traditional small group insurance
- Eliminate participation requirement constraints
- Control/stabilize healthcare costs
- Secure competitive pricing and maintain familiar provider network
- Find most cost-effective solution that meets employee needs
- Ensure compliance with minimum participation requirements (75%)
- Maintain similar coverage level to previous plan (75th percentile silver, 40% employer contribution)

Next Steps:
- Alyssa to send group insurance quotes for 2026-01-15 effective date

Timeline:
- Originally requested: 2026-01-01 effective date (no longer possible for group insurance; deadline was 2025-12-15)
- ICHRA option: Must enroll by 2025-12-19 (Friday) for 2026-01-01 effective date
- Group insurance options: Earliest effective dates are 2026-01-15 or 2026-02-01

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep Actions (Taryn & Alyssa):

- Alyssa to follow up via email with group insurance quote details for the two employees who need coverage (Owner: Alyssa)
- Alyssa to confirm whether Medicaid qualifies as a valid waiver in New Jersey (Owner: Alyssa)
- Alyssa to provide group insurance quotes with 1/15/2025 or 2/1/2025 effective dates (Owner: Alyssa)

- Review group insurance quotes once received (Owner: Karina)
- Decide between ICHRA model vs. group insurance based on rates and budget (Owner: Karina)
- If selecting ICHRA: Make final decision on budget/contribution level (Owner: Karina)

Critical Deadlines:
- December 19, 2025 (Friday): Last day to set up employer account with Thatch for ICHRA if pursuing 1/1/2026 effective date
- Group insurance earliest effective dates: 1/15/2025 or 2/1/2025 (1/1/2025 deadline has passed)

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Karina to review both ICHRA and group insurance quotes once received from reps, then schedule follow-up discussion to finalize coverage decision and proceed with enrollment before the 12/19/2025 deadline if choosing ICHRA.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value: The prospect's current benefits plan was previously with Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield (Horizon BCBS). The plan design is an HMO with two tier level options available to employees: silver and gold. The funding type appears to be a traditional group plan (fully insured), as the prospect mentioned familiarity with their network of doctors and stated "we've always done group." The plan was originally scheduled to renew in August but lapsed due to staff changes, and they were unable to renew under the same plan in October, requiring them to reapply for coverage with a target start date of January 1st. The company is located in New Jersey and has 5 total employees. The plan was terminated due to not meeting the minimum participation requirements (75% of full-time eligible employees must enroll or have valid waivers), with only 2 out of 5 employees enrolled at the time of termination. The prospect is interested in potentially reinstating the same Horizon plans they previously had in place.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.title: Decision Timeline
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.value:
- The prospect is looking at a January 1, 2026 coverage start date.
- Decision needs to be made either this week or next week (from December 9, 2025, meaning by approximately December 13-20, 2025).

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes - Thatch and Mobile Technical Training

1. Key Points Discussed

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: Mobile Technical Training is evaluating ICHRA to manage 2026 renewal costs and reduce administrative workload. The company is considering ICHRA due to its budget-based approach, which allows employees to choose individual plans, offering flexibility and control over healthcare spending. The employer is currently using Blue Cross Blue Shield HMO with Silver and Gold tier options and is leaning towards a group plan due to familiarity and network continuity.

- ICHRA Benefits: Key benefits discussed include pricing based on ZIP code, age, and number of dependents, standardized rates, and plan optionality. The ICHRA model offers reduced administrative workload and no participation requirements, which is appealing to the employer.

2. Identification of Stakeholders

- Karina Marroquin: Assistant Director at Mobile Technical Training, primary decision-maker responsible for evaluating benefit options and making the final coverage decision.

- Ty Phillippay: Thatch representative, responsible for providing ICHRA vs. Group comparison, running cost analysis reports, and facilitating the enrollment process.

- Taryn Livingstone: Thatch Account Manager/Sales Representative, responsible for providing quotes, explaining the ICHRA model, and coordinating with the internal team.

- Alyssa: Referral source, introduced Taryn to Karina and may have access to census information.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps

- August 2025: Original renewal date; plan lapsed due to staff changes.
- October 2025: Attempted renewal; too late to submit under the same plan, required reapplication.
- Early November 2025: Initial contact with Ty, census requested from Paycheck, ICHRA overview provided.
- December 9, 2025: Current conversation with Taryn, urgency for decision before Christmas for a 2026-01-01 coverage start date.
- December 16, 2025: Call conducted to review ICHRA options and discuss group insurance reinstatement.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties

- Immediate Actions (By December 19, 2025):
  - Taryn Livingstone: Send ICHRA quote to Karina and Alyssa by December 17, 2025. Provide group insurance quotes by December 18, 2025.
  - Karina Marroquin: Review quote materials and make a final decision between ICHRA and group plan by December 19, 2025.

- Follow-up Actions (Week of December 22, 2025):
  - Taryn/Thatch Operations Team: Set up enrollment if ICHRA is chosen.
  - Alyssa and Carrier: Manage group insurance enrollment if chosen, based on effective date.

- Critical Deadline: Decision required by December 19, 2025, to ensure a 2026-01-01 coverage start date with ICHRA. Group insurance would require a delayed start.

These notes provide a comprehensive overview of the conversation, stakeholders, milestones, and next steps, ensuring clarity and alignment for all parties involved.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value: Mobile Technical Training Inc currently administers employee benefits through Paychex. They have been using a small group insurance plan through Paychex with a 50-50 cost-sharing arrangement (employer pays 50%, employee pays 50%). Their benefits administration workflow involves an annual renewal process with an August 15th deadline, working with Paychex for medical benefits, managing dental benefits separately through Paychex, and handling payroll deductions pre-tax through their payroll system. The conversation indicates they rely on Paychex as their third-party service provider for benefits administration. There is no mention of using a separate benefits administration platform like Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits; their benefits appear to be managed directly through Paychex's services.

- Taryn missed identifying decision-makers; next, ask about stakeholders involved in insurance decisions to map the approval process.

- Taryn didn't explore strategic priorities; next, ask about goals and desired outcomes before demonstrating the product.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect: Sun Capital Hotels (Haleah Todd, Deepesh Kholwadwala, Jon, Will)

Current State:
- Running informal healthcare reimbursement model since pre-2020
- Reimbursing salaried employees $350/month quarterly (post-tax)
- Single-tier structure treating all salaried employees equally
- Multiple properties across different states (5-6 payroll instances, potentially up to 10)
- Entity structure: LLC Partnerships (managed properties) + Sun Capital Hotels (S-Corp with 2 owners)
- Below 50 FTEs per LLC

Priorities:
- Maintaining equal treatment across all salaried employees
- Ensuring compliance with ACA and other regulations
- Understanding value proposition of formalizing ICHRA vs. current approach

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Compliance risk with current informal reimbursement approach
- Managing benefits across multiple states and entities
- Lack of pre-tax benefit structure for employees
- Concern about managing multiple separate Thatch accounts (one per payroll instance)
- Understanding ACA minimum threshold requirements
- S-Corp 2% ownership rule restrictions (2 owners cannot participate in ICHRA)
- Reconciliation complexity across multiple entities

Optimization Goals:
- Enable pre-tax payroll deductions for employees
- Proper plan documentation and compliance protection
- Simplified administration with platform support
- Cost predictability and control
- Employee choice in health plan selection

Stated Timelines:
- Considering Q1 2026 implementation
- Promotional pricing available: $60/employee/month (vs. $75 retail) if enrolled in Q1
- Team to make decision after reviewing information
- Thatch multi-account consolidation feature expected Q2 2026
- No immediate commitment; educational phase complete

Next Steps: Prospect team to evaluate internally and determine if formalization makes sense for their organization.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Ty Phillippay (Thatch Rep) Owns:
- Send ALE (Applicable Large Employer) compliance material to the prospect team - this document was recently updated and will help them understand requirements for larger employers

Prospect Team (Sun Capital Hotels - Deepesh, Jon, Haleah, Will) Owns:
- Review the ICHRA presentation and materials provided
- Internally discuss and make a decision on whether to move forward with Thatch's ICHRA solution
- Consider the $60/employee/month promotional pricing available in Q4 (potentially Q1 if they move forward soon)
- Review the 2% S-Corp ownership rule that affects owners' ability to participate in ICHRA
- Reach out to Ty when ready to discuss further or if additional questions arise

Next Step for Overall Deal:
No specific follow-up meeting was scheduled. The deal is in the prospect's hands to review and make an internal decision. The prospect indicated they would "sit back and make a decision" and knows how to contact Ty when ready to move forward or discuss further. Timeline is undefined and dependent on the prospect's internal decision-making process.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect (Sun Capital Hotels) is currently running an informal reimbursement model rather than a traditional group health insurance plan. They have been operating what amounts to an ICHRA structure without formal documentation or compliance framework. 

Current structure details:
- Reimbursement amount: $350 per month per employee
- Eligibility: Salaried employees only (one tier structure)
- Payment process: Employees submit healthcare invoices on a quarterly basis for reimbursement
- Equal treatment: All eligible employees receive the same $350 monthly allowance regardless of position or tenure
- Company structure: Multiple entities/locations (6-7 sites, potentially up to 10), structured as LLC Partnerships, with Sun Capital Hotels as the parent S-Corp with two owners
- Employee count: Treating themselves as below 50 FTEs per LLC

No specific insurance carrier, plan design (PPO/HMO/HDHP), or traditional funding type (level-funded, fully insured, self-funded) is mentioned, as employees are purchasing their own individual health insurance plans and submitting for reimbursement rather than the company offering a group health plan.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
ACCOUNT NOTES - Sun Capital Hotels
Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Account: Sun Capital Hotels (Paychex referral)  
Thatch Representative: Ty Phillippay  
Meeting Type: ICHRA Platform Presentation & Discovery Call

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Employer's Current Situation & Interest in ICHRA
- Current Benefits Approach: Sun Capital Hotels has been informally running an ICHRA-like reimbursement model pre-2020, reimbursing employees $350/month quarterly for healthcare expenses
- Employee Structure: Salaried employees only; flat $350/month benefit across all eligible employees (no hierarchy)
- Multi-Location Challenge: Company operates multiple properties across different states (5-6 payroll instances, potentially up to 10 entities)
- Entity Structure: Properties are LLC partnerships; parent company (Sun Capital Hotels) is an S-Corp with 2 owners
- Below 50 FTE Consideration: Each LLC operates below 50 FTEs individually, though commonly owned

ICHRA Value Proposition Presented
- Cost Control: Predictable monthly expenses; employer sets allowance amounts and controls budget
- Flexibility: Employees choose their own individual health plans in their home state (49 states supported, excluding Hawaii)
- Multi-State Solution: Thatch can quote and support employees across all company locations with state-specific carrier options
- Tax Advantages: Pre-tax payroll deductions for employees (vs. current post-tax reimbursement model)
- Compliance: Full ERISA, COBRA, ACA compliance built into platform; eliminates self-administration risks
- Age-Based Pricing: Individual market is age-rated (younger employees = lower costs; older employees = higher costs)

Pricing & Platform Features
- Fee Structure: $60 per enrolled employee per month (promotional rate from standard $75; available through Q1 2026 if decision made soon)
- No Minimums: No minimum enrollment requirements per entity
- Payment Flow: Premium pulled on 15th of prior month; platform fees pulled on 1st of month
- Self-Service Platform: 81% of employees complete enrollment independently; 19% use benefits experts
- Language Support: English and Spanish currently; additional languages coming Q1-Q2 2026
- Employer Dashboard: Real-time visibility into enrollment status, eligibility management, email tracking

Compliance & Regulatory Considerations
- 2% S-Corp Owner Rule: Owners with 2%+ ownership in S-Corp cannot participate in ICHRA (federal rule); spouse workarounds discussed
- 1099 Contractors: Cannot participate in ICHRA
- Class Structure: Limited to broad categories (hourly/salary, full-time/part-time, state-by-state); cannot create highly specific position-based tiers
- ALE Requirements: Thatch will provide ALE-specific documentation and guidance
- Plan Documents: Platform auto-generates ICHRA adoption agreement, plan document, and summary plan description annually

Future Developments
- Legislative Changes: ICHRA may be renamed "Choice Plan" federally after January 2026
- Tax Credits: Bipartisan support for employer tax credits for ICHRA adoption (expected to pass early 2026)
- Platform Enhancements: Q2 2026 - ability to merge multiple accounts under one master Thatch account
- Marketplace Expansion: Building vendor marketplace (Aura Ring, Peloton, Hims & Hers, etc.) with discounted products/services

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Sun Capital Hotels Team
1. Haleah Todd
   - Role: Primary contact/coordinator
   - Responsibilities: Meeting facilitation, initial platform review, internal communication
   - Engagement Level: High - attended both calls, coordinated team participation

2. Deepesh Kholwadwala
   - Role: Decision-maker/senior leadership
   - Responsibilities: Strategic evaluation, compliance validation, final approval
   - Key Concerns: Compliance requirements, cost justification, formalization necessity
   - Engagement Level: High - asked detailed questions about compliance, pricing, and ACA requirements

3. Jon
   - Role: Finance/Operations (likely CFO or Controller based on reconciliation comments)
   - Responsibilities: Financial reconciliation, entity structure management, payment processing
   - Key Concerns: Multi-entity setup, payment flows, ownership participation rules
   - Engagement Level: Medium-High - joined late but asked specific operational questions

4. William (Will) Kern
   - Role: Team member (role unclear)
   - Responsibilities: Observer/stakeholder
   - Engagement Level: Low - invited but minimal participation

Thatch Team
1. Ty Phillippay
   - Role: Sales Representative/Account Executive
   - Background: Former VP at UnitedHealthcare (10 years, Northern California)
   - Responsibilities: Platform presentation, compliance guidance, implementation planning

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Pre-Meeting Context
- Previous Meeting: Haleah had prior call with Ty; this is second presentation including broader team
- Referral Source: Paychex referral partnership

Critical Moments During Call

Early Discussion (First 15 minutes):
- Deepesh validated understanding: "Our employees can choose whatever healthcare they want... this is just a very formalized reimbursement process"
- Key revelation: Company has been running informal ICHRA model for years at $350/month reimbursement
- Compliance concern raised: "Why should we formalize it vs. continue current approach?"

Mid-Call Technical Discussion (15-30 minutes):
- Multi-entity challenge identified: Each payroll instance requires separate Thatch account (6-10 accounts needed)
- Jon's concern about minimums addressed: No minimum enrollment per entity
- Payment reconciliation benefit identified: Separate charges per entity actually helps their accounting

Late-Call Compliance Deep-Dive (30-45 minutes):
- S-Corp ownership rule discussed: 2% owners cannot participate in ICHRA
- ACA/ALE requirements to be provided in follow-up materials
- Class structure limitations explained: Cannot create position-specific tiers beyond broad categories

Closing (Final 5 minutes):
- Deepesh: "This has been very educational. We'll sit back and make a decision."
- Ty offered to remain available for follow-up questions
- Holiday wishes exchanged

4. NEXT STEPS & ACTION ITEMS

Immediate Actions (By End of December 2025)

Thatch (Ty Phillippay):
- [ ] DEADLINE: December 20, 2025 - Send ALE-specific compliance materials and documentation requirements
- [ ] Provide detailed information on 2% S-Corp owner participation rules and workarounds
- [ ] Share plan document examples (ICHRA adoption agreement, plan document, SPD)

Sun Capital Hotels (Deepesh/Leadership Team):
- [ ] DEADLINE: January 15, 2026 - Internal decision meeting to evaluate ICHRA formalization
- [ ] Review ALE compliance materials when received
- [ ] Determine total annual benefits budget and per-employee allowance structure
- [ ] Identify which entities/locations would participate initially

Q1 2026 Decision Point

If Moving Forward:
- [ ] DEADLINE: March 31, 2026 - Finalize decision to lock in $60/employee promotional pricing (vs. $75 standard)
- [ ] Complete entity mapping: Confirm all payroll instances and ownership structures
- [ ] Determine class structure: Salary-only vs. expanded eligibility
- [ ] Set allowance amounts: Maintain $350 flat rate or adjust based on budget/age considerations
- [ ] Address S-Corp owner participation strategy

Implementation Planning (If Approved for 2026):
- [ ] Set up 6-10 separate Thatch accounts (one per payroll instance)
- [ ] Integrate with existing payroll systems
- [ ] Establish bank account access for premium and fee withdrawals
- [ ] Create employee communication plan
- [ ] Schedule benefits enrollment period

Ongoing Monitoring
- [ ] Track legislative developments on "Choice Plan" renaming and tax credit passage (expected Q1-Q2 2026)
- [ ] Monitor Thatch platform enhancements, especially multi-account merger capability (Q2 2026)
- [ ] Evaluate marketplace offerings as they expand

DECISION FACTORS SUMMARY

Reasons to Formalize ICHRA:
1. Compliance Protection: Eliminates risk of employee/former employee litigation over benefit administration
2. Tax Efficiency: Pre-tax payroll deductions save employees money vs. post-tax reimbursement
3. Administrative Simplification: Automated platform vs. manual quarterly reimbursement processing
4. Documentation: Auto-generated plan documents ensure ACA/ERISA compliance
5. Future Tax Credits: Potential employer tax credits coming in 2026

Considerations/Concerns:
1. Cost: $60/employee/month fee (potentially $600-1,200/month depending on enrollment)
2. Multi-Entity Complexity: Requires 6-10 separate account setups initially (improving Q2 2026)
3. S-Corp Owner Exclusion: 2 owners cannot participate directly in ICHRA
4. Change Management: Transitioning from informal to formal process requires employee education

Current State vs. Proposed State:
- Current: $350/month post-tax reimbursement, quarterly processing, informal administration
- Proposed: $350/month pre-tax benefit, automated platform, full compliance, employee choice of carriers/plans

ACCOUNT STATUS
Stage: Discovery/Evaluation  
Temperature: Warm - Engaged stakeholders, educational call completed, decision pending  
Probability: Medium - Team needs internal discussion; no objections raised but cost-benefit analysis required  
Timeline: Decision expected by January 15, 2026; potential implementation Q1-Q2 2026  
Next Touch: Follow-up after holidays with ALE materials; check-in mid-January 2026

NOTES FOR FOLLOW-UP
- Emphasize $60 promotional pricing expires after Q1 2026
- Highlight upcoming tax credit legislation as additional cost offset
- Offer to model specific scenarios: $350 flat rate vs. age-adjusted allowances
- Prepare multi-entity implementation timeline and support plan
- Consider case study from similar multi-location hospitality/franchise client

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect: Sun Capital Hotels (Haleah Todd, Deepesh Kholwadwala, Jon, Will)

Current State:
- Running informal healthcare reimbursement model since pre-2020
- Reimbursing salaried employees $350/month quarterly (post-tax)
- Single-tier structure treating all salaried employees equally
- Multiple properties across different states (5-6 payroll instances, potentially up to 10)
- Entity structure: LLC Partnerships (managed properties) + Sun Capital Hotels (S-Corp with 2 owners)
- Below 50 FTEs per LLC

Priorities:
- Maintaining equal treatment across all salaried employees
- Ensuring compliance with ACA and other regulations
- Understanding value proposition of formalizing ICHRA vs. current approach

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Compliance risk with current informal reimbursement approach
- Managing benefits across multiple states and entities
- Lack of pre-tax benefit structure for employees
- Concern about managing multiple separate Thatch accounts (one per payroll instance)
- Understanding ACA minimum threshold requirements
- S-Corp 2% ownership rule restrictions (2 owners cannot participate in ICHRA)
- Reconciliation complexity across multiple entities

Optimization Goals:
- Enable pre-tax payroll deductions for employees
- Proper plan documentation and compliance protection
- Simplified administration with platform support
- Cost predictability and control
- Employee choice in health plan selection

Stated Timelines:
- Considering Q1 2026 implementation
- Promotional pricing available: $60/employee/month (vs. $75 retail) if enrolled in Q1
- Team to make decision after reviewing information
- Thatch multi-account consolidation feature expected Q2 2026
- No immediate commitment; educational phase complete

Next Steps: Prospect team to evaluate internally and determine if formalization makes sense for their organization.

Prospect Team (Sun Capital Hotels - Deepesh, Jon, Haleah, Will) Owns:

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently administers employee benefits manually through an informal reimbursement model. They do not use a benefits administration platform. 

Their current process works as follows:
- Employees submit their healthcare invoices on a quarterly basis
- The company reimburses employees $350 per month for their healthcare expenses
- This reimbursement applies only to salaried employees
- All eligible employees are treated equally with the same flat $350/month amount regardless of position or tenure
- They were essentially running an informal ICHRA-like arrangement without realizing it, treating themselves as an employer below 50 FTEs per LLC

The prospect acknowledged they were "running e-ground without knowing it was e-ground" (referring to ICHRA), operating this reimbursement system without formal compliance documentation or a structured platform. They handle this process internally without mention of using any benefits administration software, broker, or third-party service.

Ty Phillippay:
Hello there.

Hello.

Happy holidays. How are you? Doing great. We've been getting ready for the next week and all good around here. It's the end of open enrollment, though, for individuals, so it's our busy season.

Oh, nice.

Yeah. How are things going for you guys? 
Haleah Todd:
Everything's going pretty good. Can you give me just a second? I just need to make sure everybody's got the invite and they're joining. I forwarded it out. 
Ty Phillippay:
Is that fine? Yeah, for sure, okay. 
Haleah Todd:
And then William Kern, who joined us the last time, he's also invited, but he doesn't have to join.
