Okay, I think we got dipesh here. 
Haleah Todd:
Yeah, and we can get started if you're ready. Will can jump on at any time. For John and Dipesh, I kind of gave them a brief rundown of what Thatch does and what Ichra does. If you can kind of just go through the presentation, what you talked about with me earlier on, and kind of how Thatch works. And all the different offerings that the ICHRA accounts. 
Ty Phillippay:
Absolutely. Let me, I'm going to, I'm trying to get into something real quick and I'll share my screen. See, looks like we got another person joining as well. OK, and we're admitting Will. There's Will. Hi, Will. 
Will:
Hey there. 
Ty Phillippay:
All right. And then I'm sharing my screen. So, yeah, thank you for the opportunity to meet with you again. To make sure we're on the same page. I'm with a company called Thatch and our specialty is ICRA. So we'll go through what that means and really what Icra has the opportunity to become over the next couple years. But talking specifically just about Thatch, we are building a platform from the ground up, have gone through a couple rounds of funding and likely to have another one in the spring. Most of our team, if you think about, let me resize this. It's got funky size. One second, please. Okay, we'll try that. Most of the team here at Thatch, right, we had 113 employees. This is a little old. We'll crest over 200 employees by January and continue to grow. And most of it is building our platform. So a lot of... Technologists and folks who are data science experts, and they come from different financial companies as well as because we're in the benefit space insurance. So, for instance, my background, I was a vice president at United Healthcare for 10 years in Northern California. And so I've got a lot of health insurance background and I see the value of that. Because the ICRa is a way that we can slow down the cost. Upward cost spiral that the market's been stuck in for 10 years, that's only increasing. So the goal here is to take what's worked from small group insurance, which is to have a centralized resource for the employees, Have a predictable amount that you pay month to month, and then have some help with, whether it's a platform or... You know a broker or someone who's involved that when you have questions, you can get your questions answered and keep the process moving forward. What we didn't want to bring from the group and group side is the spiral of cost that just keeps going up and up. And also the constrictive piece of telling all the employees, we have a group insurance plan, but you have to go to this carrier and you have to go to this plan. And we certainly don't want to add more layers to health care. We're really trying to help employers to take a step back from being on the front lines and get back to where. The amount of money you're making available to your employees for benefits is your decision each year over year. And the way it works. Is ICRA, and go ahead and cut me off if I'm being too detailed or anything, but I think it's important that we start with what is ICRA. Icra stands for individual coverage, and then the other part of Icra is health reimbursement arrangements. So it was decided in 2020 that you could use a traditional health reimbursement arrangement as an account that you could set aside funds and make them available to your employees for them to be used for. Qualified medical expenses, and you could use that to purchase individual coverage. And so that's where Individual Coverage and HRA merged together to become ICRA. So really, all you're saying is it's a different model for helping people to afford health insurance benefits. Instead of small group and picking your one plan and having a steady and increasing renewal increase year over year. You're telling everyone, all right, for your job and your age, you're going to get x amount of dollars, and that goes towards your health insurance premium. But the requirement is they do have to go and buy an individual plan if they want to take advantage of the money. If they don't have an individual plan, then they would just choose not to take advantage of that benefit. But for... Just example, if we were to say win the lottery and be able to give $750 a month to all employees or certain employees, they would be able to buy health insurance through the individual market in their own state. And any amount that they had left over either could be returned to the company. Or they could keep that in an HRA and use it for health or qualified medical expenses throughout the year. So, one of the things that Thatch is an expert in is working with employers who have employees in multiple states. I believe one of your or some of your properties were in different states, if I'm remembering correctly. 
Haleah Todd:
So is that true? 
Ty Phillippay:
Wrong button. 
Haleah Todd:
That is correct. 
Ty Phillippay:
Okay, yeah. So that's one of the challenges, both for group insurance and individual insurance. So the way it works on group is you tend to pick a carrier that works best in the home state of where you're located, or the majority of your employees are, or where the leadership team sits. And then sometimes, if you pick a national carrier, it'll work really well in all 50 states. But if you pick a regional or more of a local carrier, sometimes they will tell you, yes, We can cover your people in other states using our rental network that we don't control. And is more expensive and a little bit rougher experience from an employee satisfaction reporting standpoint. So we're able to quote in 49 states, Hawaii does not participate in the ICRA, but in 49 states, We can make sure that anyone that you're employing that's eligible for benefits is getting to choose from carrier and plan options that are in their home state. And we've been steadily growing our network. And I believe we looked last time and saw there were ample carrier options and plan options. So... One thing to consider, though, and this is the other key important part from an ICRa and the way it differs from group insurance. If you have a higher average age than about, I think the number is close to 40, then you're going to see more expensive rates than, say, someone with an age in their 20s. So, individual insurance is age rated. So a group that has 10, 20 year olds. Is going to pay considerably less for the insurance than an employer next door that has 10 58 year olds. And so that's a reality that we have to take into account. When we think about Icra versus small group, Icra's got a ton of merits and is way more flexible. And it protects your finances really well, because you are paying for your employees and in certain circumstances, you may have been overpaying. If you bought a group plan for a bunch of 26 year olds who don't tend to use the doctor. People often ask, is it cheaper for group or for ICRA? The answer I would give you is it depends on your group. If you have a higher average age, group might be cheaper per person per month. If you have a lower average age, Icra will be cheaper. And you take advantage of the way individual is priced with having a lower than average age for your employees. And then we have to talk to. About what that really, really does. But one of the biggest things that as an organization, if you're moving to Ichra, that you need to start thinking about, and it can be very simple, is how much money do we want to pay and who will be eligible for the plan? And that can help you with all of that, can help you to determine your allowance structure. And there are some ways that you can create classes. Of employees. I think that might be important for you guys. And they are generally not as specific as you want the classes to be, meaning they're more like. You can have different classes. For full-time or part-time, or hourly or salary. But often we see employers wanting to have much more specific class structure that they set up. And I advise against that, because really, Icra, in its in its truest form, isn't made to create a boutique benefits offering. That then you or someone else has to manage. It's more of setting up a fair way for employees that if they meet your plan rules, they're eligible for benefits. And they receive x amount from the company to help them to buy the individual coverage if they choose to move forward with it. So I'll talk another two, three minutes tops and then we can open it up for questions on the floor. But we are partnered with ADP Paychecks, a lot of carriers nationally. Icra is still very new in terms of insurance. World Insurance does is a slow changing industry as we've all seen. And so for us to have stood up a space age technology platform that can really make Icra administration easy for employers and their employees. We're starting to have carriers on a national basis come to us and say, we'd like to integrate the Thatch platform and use it as our Icra solution. For our current customers and for future customers that we're trying to reach. So Icra is going to be a much bigger name. You might hear some bills that are going to be passed right after the first of the year. Sounds like they'll be changing it from Icra Federally to the Choice Plan. That'll be the name of what we're discussing. And so two years from now, you'd say, oh, we should work for us. We've got great benefits. Yeah, we use the choice plan and people would know what you were talking about. And the other piece, which is very timely, is some tax credits. For employers who are going to be adding Icra as a way to provide benefits for their employees. I don't have any more detailed information on that, but it was very close to being passed before the government reset. Or closure? And there's bipartisan support. So we're very excited. 2026 is going to be a great year for ICRA. So the last piece I just wanted to touch on is that we are fully compliant with all of the alphabet soup. That you have to be compliant with when you offer benefits to your employees. That's ERISA, COBRA, ACA, and the list goes on. The way we built the simplified administration in the platform is to make sure that you can't administer something that's going to get you sideways or into even a gray area at some future date. So that's a big plus, and it's standardly included in thatch when you choose to go with us. I want to stop there. There's more areas that if this is helpful, I can keep going into, but I'd love to start to get your feedback, thoughts, and questions.

Understood? No, that? Yeah, those are probably the good answers, and those would would have been at the top three of my list as well. Yeah, um, is the the comp? That's because they don't. Yeah. Yep.

Yep.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: AloeDesk - Initial Discovery Call

Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Participants: Mike Vandre (Prospect), Taryn Livingstone (Thatch Business Team)  
Company: AloeDesk  
Call Type: Initial Discovery/Demo

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Employer's Interest in ICHRA
- Primary Driver: High healthcare costs with current Gusto benefits for two families (owners) plus one employee
- Cost Concerns: Thatch quotes appeared significantly lower than Gusto offerings, prompting investigation into legitimacy and pricing structure
- Current Situation: 
  - Maryland-based S-Corporation
  - 3 total people: Mike, business partner, and business partner's 28-year-old daughter (employee)
  - Current benefits through Gusto
  - Renewal period active; current plans expire February 1, 2026
  - Growth anticipated in 2026 with potential new hires

ICHRA Model Understanding
- Education Provided: Explained ICRA (Individual Coverage Health Reimbursement Arrangement) as alternative to traditional group plans
- Key Benefits Discussed:
  - Individual market plans rated against millions vs. small pool (lower premium increases)
  - Pre-tax employer contributions to employee health insurance budgets
  - Employee choice across 5+ carriers with 20+ plan options in Maryland
  - Flexibility to spend leftover funds on qualified medical expenses
  - HRA rollover functionality (unused funds stay with employer)
  - HSA-eligible plans available

S-Corp Ownership Considerations
- Critical Discovery: As S-Corp owners, Mike and his business partner don't qualify for ICHRA coverage
- Solution Presented: Owners can purchase individual ACA marketplace plans and write off as business expense (pass-through entity benefit)
- Action Required: Mike needs to consult CPA for tax implications

Administrative & Integration Concerns
- Gusto Integration: Confirmed seamless integration for payroll deductions and employee roster import
- Current Structure: Employee gets free coverage; family plans covered at 50%
- ICHRA Equivalent: Can structure allowances by dependent count to mirror current approach

Pricing & Plan Availability
- Rate Discrepancy: Mike noted Thatch quotes lower than direct ACA marketplace research
- Explanation: Off-exchange plans (sourced directly from carriers) vs. on-exchange can have pricing differences
- Maryland Market: Favorable individual market with affordable options, including $0 deductible plans

Flexibility & Timing
- Mid-Year Addition: ICHRA can be added anytime, triggering special enrollment period
- Allowance Changes: Annual adjustments only; cannot modify mid-year except through new class creation (to be confirmed)
- Competitive Adjustments: Better to plan allowances upfront; mid-year changes limited

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Prospect Company (AloeDesk)
- Mike Vandre - S-Corp Owner, Primary Decision Maker
  - Role: Evaluating benefits options, managing renewal process
  - Responsibilities: Review Thatch platform, discuss with business partner, consult CPA
  
- Business Partner (Name not provided) - S-Corp Owner, Secondary Decision Maker
  - Role: Co-owner requiring consultation on benefits decision
  - Responsibilities: Review proposal with Mike, provide input on direction
  
- Employee - 28-year-old daughter of business partner
  - Role: Current employee requiring coverage
  - Note: Family relationship may influence decision-making dynamics

Thatch Team
- Taryn Livingstone - Business Team Representative
  - Role: Primary contact for companies <20 employees
  - Responsibilities: Education, quoting, implementation support, follow-up

External Partners
- CPA/Tax Advisor (To be engaged)
  - Role: Confirm S-Corp tax write-off strategy for owner-purchased plans
  - Responsibilities: Validate tax treatment of individual plan purchases

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Dates
- December 16, 2025: Initial discovery call completed
- December 19, 2025: Last day to register company for 1/1/26 coverage start (NOT APPLICABLE - current plans through 2/1/26)
- December 28, 2025: Last day for employee enrollment for 1/1/26 start (NOT APPLICABLE)
- February 1, 2026: Current Gusto plan expiration date - TARGET START DATE
- 2026: Anticipated growth/hiring period

Key Conversation Moments
1. S-Corp Ownership Discovery: Identified that owners cannot participate in ICHRA; alternative solution provided (ACA + business expense write-off)
2. Rate Validation Question: Mike questioned why Thatch quotes lower than marketplace; explained off-exchange vs. on-exchange pricing
3. Flexibility Inquiry: Discussed mid-year addition capability and allowance adjustment limitations
4. Integration Confirmation: Verified Gusto partnership and seamless payroll integration
5. Dependent Coverage Structure: Explored how to replicate current 50% family coverage model using dependent-based allowances

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By December 20, 2025)
- Taryn Livingstone:
  - [ ] Send conversation summary with links and resources
  - [ ] Include thatch.com/plans link for plan exploration
  - [ ] Provide access to sophisticated quoting tool (Start Now → Company Account)
  - [ ] Confirm class creation rules for mid-year allowance adjustments

- Mike Vandre:
  - [ ] Explore Thatch quoting tool using actual employee data (ages, zip code 21769)
  - [ ] Review plan options available in Maryland
  - [ ] Test allowance structures (same dollar vs. smart allowances with dependent counts)

Short-Term Actions (By December 23, 2025)
- Mike Vandre:
  - [ ] Discuss Thatch proposal with business partner
  - [ ] Consult CPA regarding S-Corp owner tax write-off strategy for individual ACA plans
  - [ ] Compare Thatch quotes against current Gusto renewal rates
  - [ ] Determine preferred coverage start date (2/1/26 vs. later if hiring delays)

Follow-Up Schedule
- Late This Week/Early Next Week (December 19-23, 2025):
  - Taryn to check in on business partner discussion outcome
  - Assess interest level and address any additional questions
  - Determine timeline for decision

Implementation Timeline (If Proceeding)
- For 2/1/26 Start:
  - Company registration deadline: ~Mid-January 2026 (more flexible than 1/1 start)
  - Employee enrollment deadline: ~Late January 2026
  - Sufficient time given current renewal through 2/1/26

Outstanding Items to Resolve
1. Confirm exact allowance change rules (annual vs. class-based flexibility)
2. Validate S-Corp tax write-off strategy with CPA
3. Finalize business partner buy-in
4. Determine if waiting for additional hires before implementation makes sense
5. Clarify rate discrepancy between Thatch quotes and direct marketplace research

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Pricing Structure
- $45/month per enrolled employee
- $50/month flat compliance fee
- Only charged for enrolled employees

Competitive Position
- Maryland individual market favorable for ICHRA model
- Significant cost savings potential vs. Gusto group plan
- Strong Gusto integration reduces switching friction

Risk Factors
- Small team size (3 people) with 2 owners ineligible for ICHRA
- Only 1 eligible employee currently (business partner's daughter - potential conflict)
- Growth-dependent value proposition
- Rate confusion may require additional validation/education

Opportunity Indicators
- Proactive research during renewal period
- Cost-conscious decision maker
- Growth plans for 2026
- Open to innovative solutions
- Strong existing Gusto relationship (integration advantage)

Call Sentiment: Positive, educational, exploratory  
Likelihood to Proceed: Moderate (pending business partner discussion and CPA consultation)  
Recommended Follow-Up: December 19-23, 2025

- Explore the quoting tool at thatch.com by clicking "Start Now" and creating a company account
- Review available plan options for employees in Maryland (zip code 21769)
- Input employee information (ages, dependents) to see accurate pricing and allowance structures
- Discuss Thatch ICHRA offering with business partner to determine if they want to proceed
- Consult with CPA about writing off S-Corp owner insurance as business expense
- Decide on timeline: whether to switch for 2/1/2026 coverage start (current plan renewal) or wait until more employees are hired

Next Step for Deal:
Taryn to follow up via email/call by end of week or early next week (12/19/2025 - 12/23/2025) to discuss Mike's decision after consulting with his business partner and determine if they want to proceed with Thatch for their February 1, 2026 coverage start date.

Key Deadline:
Current Gusto plans renew February 1, 2026 - decision needed before then to switch to Thatch.

Mike mentions that they "traditionally use Gusto, our benefits provider, to shop for health plans" and indicates they are currently in the renewal period for their Gusto plans. The company uses Gusto for both payroll and benefits administration, as evidenced by Mike's question about how Thatch would integrate with Gusto for "all of our other stuff" and automatic payroll deductions. The workflow involves shopping for health plans through Gusto during their renewal period, and they are currently evaluating whether to continue with Gusto or explore alternative options like Thatch due to high healthcare costs for their small team.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: VenuePilot - Initial Benefits Consultation

Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Thatch Representative: Monica Hirschheimer  
Prospect Company: VenuePilot

1. KEY DISCUSSION POINTS

Company Overview & Benefits Interest
- Company Size: Small organization with 3 full-time US employees, several part-time US employees, and full-time employees in Croatia
- Current Situation: Employee in Philadelphia inquired about QSEHRA, prompting this exploratory conversation about benefits options
- Primary Focus: Understanding differences between ICHRA and QSEHRA to determine best fit for their team

ICHRA vs QSEHRA Comparison Discussed
- ICHRA Benefits:
  - No IRS-imposed contribution limits (vs QSEHRA's capped amounts)
  - Pre-tax allowances for both employer and employee
  - Plans available through Thatch platform (off-exchange state marketplace plans)
  - Compliance documentation handled by Thatch
  - Thatch manages enrollment and premium payments
  - Can be implemented at any time during the year

- QSEHRA Benefits:
  - More flexibility in fund usage (can apply to spouse's employer plan)
  - Employees can use funds for out-of-pocket medical expenses
  - IRS-imposed contribution limits per individual/family

- Critical Limitation Identified: ICHRA allowances cannot be applied to spouse's employer-sponsored plan (QSEHRA can)

Affordability & Subsidy Concerns
- Key Issue: Enhanced premium tax credits expiring in 2026; income-based subsidies remain
- Affordability Rule: ICHRA deemed affordable if employee spends <10% of annual salary on lowest-cost silver plan
- Family Plan Complexity: Affordability calculated on individual basis but impacts family plan eligibility for marketplace subsidies
- Cannot Combine: ICHRA/QSEHRA allowances cannot be combined with government subsidies

Important Policy Notes
- Entity Type: VenuePilot is C-Corp (Justin confirmed), allowing owner participation in ICHRA/QSEHRA
- Class Requirements: Must offer benefits to all employees within same class (all full-time or all salaried)
- Qualifying Life Events: Having a child allows plan changes mid-year

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

VenuePilot Team
- Justin Kantor - CEO, C-Corp owner
  - Role: Primary decision-maker
  - Current Status: Not currently seeking coverage for himself, potentially in future
  - Responsibilities: Final approval on benefits strategy

- Catherine Hoffman - Operations lead ("doer of all things venue pilot")
  - Role: Key stakeholder in benefits implementation
  - Current Status: Coming off parent's health insurance end of 2025 (turning 26)
  - Already set up on New York marketplace with income-based subsidies
  - Responsibilities: Day-to-day benefits coordination

- Philadelphia Employee (name not disclosed)
  - Location: Pennsylvania
  - Current Status: On spouse's employer-sponsored health insurance
  - Family: Spouse + potentially child on the way
  - Key Consideration: May not benefit from ICHRA if spouse's plan is superior; QSEHRA might be better option due to flexibility

- Third Employee (Vera - mentioned briefly)
  - Status: Unknown if coverage needed

Thatch Team
- Monica Hirschheimer - Sales/Benefits Consultant
  - Responsibilities: Education, plan comparison, implementation guidance
  - Committed to providing plan lists, affordability calculations, and family plan research

3. CRITICAL MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

December 16, 2025 (Meeting Date):
- Initial discovery call completed
- ICHRA vs QSEHRA education provided
- Identified key decision factors for VenuePilot's specific situation

End of 2025:
- Catherine's parent's health insurance coverage expires
- Catherine already prepared with marketplace plan for January 1, 2026

2026:
- Enhanced premium tax credits expire (confirmed today per Monica)
- Income-based subsidies remain available

Potential Implementation Timeline:
- January 1, 2026: Possible start date (tight timeline)
- February 1, 2026: More realistic implementation date (decision needed by mid-January 2026)
- Note: ICHRA can be implemented any time during year

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By End of December 2025):

VenuePilot Responsibilities:
1. Gather Philadelphia Employee Information (Justin/Catherine)
   - Confirm current insurance arrangement with spouse's employer
   - Determine willingness to switch from spouse's plan
   - Understand spouse's plan quality and costs
   - Confirm family composition (spouse + expected child)
   - Deadline: Before next conversation

2. Clarify Third Employee Status (Justin/Catherine)
   - Determine if Vera needs health insurance coverage
   - Confirm coverage status (spouse, other source, etc.)
   - Deadline: Before next conversation

3. Assess Catherine's Subsidy Situation (Catherine)
   - Calculate if ICHRA allowance would be more beneficial than current income-based subsidies
   - Review current marketplace plan costs
   - Deadline: Before next conversation

Thatch Follow-up Actions (Monica):

1. Send Follow-up Email (Immediate)
   - Resources comparing ICHRA vs QSEHRA
   - Article outlining key differences
   - Plan availability information for Pennsylvania

2. Research Family Affordability Rules (Within 1 week)
   - Clarify how affordability calculations work for family plans
   - Provide specific guidance for Philadelphia employee's situation
   - Determine impact on marketplace subsidies for families

3. Provide Plan Lists (Upon request)
   - Pennsylvania marketplace plans available through Thatch
   - New York marketplace plans for Catherine
   - Cost estimates based on employee ages/locations

Decision Point (Mid-January 2026):
- If pursuing February 1, 2026 implementation: Final decision needed by January 15, 2026
- If pursuing January 1, 2026 implementation: Immediate decision required (very tight timeline)

Conditional Next Steps:

If Moving Forward:
- Schedule product demonstration with Monica
- Walk through contribution decision process
- Review Thatch platform functionality
- Complete compliance documentation
- Connect Thatch with Deal (payroll system) for pre-tax deductions

If Not Moving Forward:
- Consider post-tax stipend alternative (taxable for both employer/employee)
- Revisit in future as company grows

OPEN QUESTIONS & CONSIDERATIONS

1. Philadelphia Employee: Will spouse's employer plan remain superior to marketplace options?
2. Affordability Impact: How will family affordability rules affect Philadelphia employee's subsidy eligibility?
3. Budget: What contribution amount is VenuePilot willing/able to provide per employee?
4. QSEHRA Alternative: Should VenuePilot explore QSEHRA vendors if spouse's plan flexibility is critical?
5. Owner Coverage: Will Justin want coverage in near future, affecting plan design?

ADDITIONAL NOTES

- VenuePilot uses Deal for payroll (confirmed integration capability with Thatch)
- Company appears cost-conscious and methodical in decision-making
- Strong emphasis on ensuring benefits actually help employees vs. creating financial burden
- Monica demonstrated strong product knowledge and willingness to research complex scenarios
- Conversation tone: Educational, collaborative, no pressure tactics

Risk Factors:
- Small group size means individual employee situations heavily influence decision
- Mixed employee situations (subsidies, spouse coverage) complicate one-size-fits-all approach
- Timing pressure if targeting January 1, 2026 start date

Opportunity Factors:
- C-Corp structure allows owner participation
- Company growing and thinking proactively about benefits
- Strong relationship-building in initial call
- Clear pain point: Employee requested benefits information

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: 2025-12-16

Prospect: VenuePilot (Justin Kantor, CEO; Catherine Hoffman, Operations)

Current Situation:
- Small company: 3 full-time US employees, part-time US staff, full-time employees in Croatia
- No health benefits currently in place
- Use Deel for payroll
- C-Corp structure
- One Philadelphia employee has insurance through spouse's company (wife's employer)
- Catherine coming off parent's plan at end of 2025; already enrolled in marketplace plan for 2026-01-01

Priorities:
- Explore health benefit options (QSEHRA vs ICHRA) for team
- Understand which option best serves employees' diverse situations
- Provide pre-tax health benefit solution

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Affordability concerns: PA employee has family (spouse + potential child); high ICHRA contribution could disqualify them from ACA subsidies, potentially making family coverage more expensive than current arrangement
- ICHRA limitation: Funds cannot apply to spouse's employer plan (PA employee currently on wife's plan)
- Catherine's situation: Income-based subsidies may be better than ICHRA/QSEHRA benefit
- Small team complexity: Each employee has different circumstances, making one-size-fits-all solution difficult
- Knowledge gap: Team unfamiliar with QSEHRA/ICHRA differences and implications

Optimization Goals:
- Determine if QSEHRA (more flexibility, can apply to spouse's plan) or ICHRA (no contribution limits, Thatch-administered) better fits team needs
- Gather information from PA employee about willingness to leave spouse's plan
- Evaluate cost-benefit for each employee before committing

Stated Timelines:
- Catherine's coverage needed: 2026-01-01 (already arranged independently)
- Potential implementation target: 2026-02-01
- Decision deadline for Feb 1 coverage: mid-January 2026
- Next step: Collect more information from PA employee before proceeding

12/16/2025

Prospect Owns (VenuePilot - Justin/Catherine):

  - Current insurance coverage status (confirm if on spouse's plan)
  - Willingness to come off spouse's plan for individual coverage
  - Review plan options that would be available through Thatch
- Evaluate whether ICHRA or QSEHRA would be beneficial for all employees, including Catherine (coming off parents' plan end of 2025)

Rep Owns (Monica - Thatch):

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Schedule a product demonstration with Monica once VenuePilot completes their internal evaluation and gathers employee feedback. Decision needed by mid-January 2026 if targeting February 1, 2026 coverage start date (though ICHRA can be implemented at any time during the year).

And they match not just the price, but all the other... 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Like deductible out of pocket and stuff and coverage. Usually, yeah, they're going to be pretty similar. Like, the main difference we see is like, sometimes group plans are like a way better option. Sometimes, depending on cost savings and flexibility you have, I could see a super low deductible and a pretty low out of pocket for way less than you would get on the marketplace. But it all depends on state, how many people you have in your plan, the ages of the people on your plan. It's all different. I would expect it to be pretty similar as far, like at least in the Philadelphia area for this one employee. I'd expect them to have a good number of plans because it's a metropolitan area, so I wouldn't really be concerned about plan options. Cost, it just depends on how much they're willing to spend because they are in a metropolitan area. I'd expect it to be a little more expensive. Like the Middle of Nowhere Montana or something, or middle of nowhere Texas, you know, certainly not as much as New York. I'm from New York, so I don't expect that. But we could look at a few things as far as, like what the costs might be for this individual. We have a system where you can look at plan options. You could send this to the employee. They could let you know if maybe they see some plans that would work for them or not. But my thinking is potentially, if their spouse is on a group plan and that's where they have their insurance, it's very possible that the spouse has better group insurance than they would get from the state marketplace. Got it. 
Justin Kantor:
All right. Just one very last question. And then I... Sure, so if everything is kind of in the state marketplace, what is Thatch's offering? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Yeah, that's a great question. Great question. I probably get the question, like, once a week, like, why would we even go through this? So there are two things. First, when you're going through Thatch, everything is a pre-tax allowance, because it's administering the ICRA, which gives the employer the ability to do it pre-tax. Also, the... Contributions on the employee side would also be pre-tax. So pre-tax for everyone, no payroll taxes for that. The other thing with Thatch is that Thatch will do all the compliance documentation for you. So the fact that you're offering an ICRA, whatever tax documentation you need to show that, then we would do that for you, the compliance side. And then when individuals choose plans through Thatch, they're choosing the plan on Thatch, and then Thatch is actually enrolling them in the plan. We are. Putting that forward to the insurance carrier. So no one has to go to their state marketplace and call up and make sure the enrollment went through. So we do all of that for them. And then we also pay the premiums on behalf of the employees. We do that by connecting with the employer's bank account. So that's the main thing. So it's like a one-stop shop for everything and for everyone within the company, both the employee and the employer, hoping to lessen the burden of going to the employee state, the state marketplace and having the flexibility to choose any plan you want. But we try to keep it in-house. We have services to help employees choose plans if they want. They're welcome to use that service, which I always try to recommend, because choosing a health plan is very confusing. Yeah, we just try to make it as easy as possible for the employees. And then take the burden off the employer while they're, you know, offering some kind of benefit to their employee. 
Justin Kantor:
Okay, I guess that's, that's great. I get everything now. And now I'll let Catherine continue the conversation. 
Catherine Hoffman:
I just had a question about, so on thatch, is there an option for a part of our payroll to go pre-tax towards our premium payment for that month? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
So if you're making this up, and tell me if I'm on the same page as you, If you're going to give your employees $500 per month and the employee chooses a plan, that's $600 per month. So your $500 would go towards the employee's premium, and then the employee would have a $100 payroll deduction, right? Because their premium is $100 more expensive than the allowance you provide them that month. So then that $100 would be a pre-tax. Payroll deduction directly through Thatch, We'll calculate that for you. Um, what? uh, payroll system. Oh, use Deal for a payroll. Yeah, yeah. So then that would be an automatic deduction, so Deal and Thatch would be connected to each other, and Thatch would send over the deduction. So you know exactly when it's going to be deducted and how much is going to be deducted per paycheck? Okay, did that answer your question? 
Catherine Hoffman:
Yeah. So if we're going through thatch, do we have to use an Icra, or could we also use a Qsera through that? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
We don't offer QSERAs. We don't administer QSERAs. We strictly administer ICRAs. So if a QSera is a better option for you, which it could be. If your employee gets his insurance through his wife's plant, through his wife's company, and is not willing to change from his wife's company, that could be good benefits. So then I would say a QSera might be a better option, because a QSera allows you to have those funds, those pre-tax dollars go towards a spouse's plan. 
Catherine Hoffman:
Okay. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Where Nicra does not. 
Justin Kantor:
And you can only have one of the two, right? I can't have some employees in one. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Correct. Exactly. Yeah. Good question. Yeah. Any other questions you guys have? These are all great questions, by the way. Love it. Really like testing my QSAR knowledge here. 
Justin Kantor:
I've never heard of it until this call. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Great. Amazing. Where are you guys based, by the way? 
Justin Kantor:
We're in New York. Yeah, we're both in New York. You're both in New York. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
I wasn't 100% sure. I saw behind Justin. I was like, that could be like New York City apartment. I don't know. I'm not really sure. 
Justin Kantor:
Whoreham Hill. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
I'm usually based on Long Island. I'm out of town this week, but I'm usually in Long Island. And Justin, if you were to, whether it's Ick or Kucera, would you be looking for insurance for yourself as well as the owner or no? No, it won't. 
Justin Kantor:
Probably won't be necessary, potentially in the future. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Okay. 
Justin Kantor:
And it would probably also, would that also apply for me as an owner, like either the Icra or the QSERA, if I can? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Are you an s-corp or a C-Corp? C-Corp. Then C-Corp you can. S-corp owners, partnership owners, sole proprietorship owners, they cannot accept the ICRA or QSERA benefit. Because that's this pre-tax allowance, and being one of those other types of owners, then you get other tax benefits. So C-Corp owner, you're good to go. 
Justin Kantor:
You'll be fine. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Yeah. 
Justin Kantor:
Yeah. All right. That's good to know. Yeah. So, maybe. Yeah. I guess. And so the real difference between Icra and Qsehra is the amount. And so we can go higher with it. And the other, so that's the plus with ICRA. The plus with the Cusera is that there's a little bit more flexibility in how it's applied. I think you're, Catherine, is that happening for you, too? The audio, I think, is starting to, is that just on my end, or is it yours, Catherine? 
Catherine Hoffman:
No, I think it kind of sounds like it's like underwater a little. 
Justin Kantor:
It just disconnected, I think, maybe. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
How about now? Is it a little better now? Perfect, yeah. 
Justin Kantor:
Okay, good. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Sorry about that. What were you saying? Okay. 
Justin Kantor:
So I'm just trying to understand the difference between the two. Is there any other significant? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Those are really the main ones. Let me pull up. One thing and see if I'm forgetting anything. 
Justin Kantor:
And yeah, so for QSEHRA, like, it doesn't impact the affordability of the plan in this, or it still does? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
It still could. Because it's still a pre-tax allowance. So it's very possible, because either way. Whether you do an Icra or a QSERA, you can't combine them with subsidies, so the affordability would still have an impact. I see. 
Justin Kantor:
Okay. Yeah. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
It sounds like you're looking into this for a specific individual who asked about it. If you went one direction, you decided to go with a Qsera or an ICRA, You would need to offer it to everyone, as long as they're all full-time or they're all salaried. You have to offer it to everyone within the same class. But it kind of sounds like maybe the decision would be based on whether this is a good option for this one employee. Or even like an option with Catherine. I think you said you were coming off your parents plan. When? when do you turn 26, or when will that expire? 
Catherine Hoffman:
It's the end of this year. This year. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Got it. OK. So have you set yourself up in New York to choose a plan for January 1st? 
Catherine Hoffman:
I set myself up already. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
OK, good. Great. I think. 
Catherine Hoffman:
My subsidies are probably a little better than the other employees, just because of the payment, like the yeah and on the on the UM income-based subsidies. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Right? Yeah, yeah, okay, got it, yeah, so I would, yeah, I mean, you know, offering an Icarus Sarah is it's wonderful. But if for some reason, um, like you're getting a subsidy that I don't know you, your insurance is going to be $200 a month. But then you get. An Icra or Qsera allowance that's actually going to make you pay more out of pocket, sometimes those are not as great. So it sounds like you guys have a small enough group where you could kind of like, figure out, is this going to be good for everyone? Is it going to hurt some people? And maybe getting some more information from the Pennsylvania employee to get an idea of what will actually work? And then at the end of the day, sometimes people just do post tax stipends, you know, that, because it's just it makes more sense for them in those scenarios. 
Justin Kantor:
What's that? A post-tax stipend? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Yeah, like if literally an employer just decides to give everyone an extra $100 a month for, you know, putting to go towards their health care. And that would be taxable. Yeah. Both for the employee and the employer. 
Justin Kantor:
Yeah, got it. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Yeah. So there are things you can figure out, but it just, it's all a pro-con kind of thing. And especially when you have a smaller group, I think it's a little easier because you can have conversations and kind of figure a few things out. 
Justin Kantor:
Got it. Yeah. Timing wise, is this something that we have to figure out by January 1st, or is it kind of like whenever we want to? 
Monica Hirschheimer:
Good question. Yeah, you can bring an Icra on at any point in the year. QSERA is probably, too, but I don't know the timelines for QSERA vendors. You can bring an icra on at any time. If you wanted January 1st, we still got a little bit of time for that. But I feel like for you guys, it sounds like it's not a huge rush and maybe February 1st would be. Better, so you're not like rushing too much. You would have to make a decision basically by, like, mid-January for February 1st coverage, but at least with that you can bring an anchor on at any point during the year. Okay, yeah, isn't it right? I would be really curious to hear some feedback from the other employee if you get other info. And then if you're like, Yeah, okay, maybe this will work, then I'd be happy to, like, walk you through a demonstration. How do you decide on contributions for this person and for the rest of the team. So, yeah, if you want to learn more and you get some more info on your end, then just reach out anytime and we'll go from there. Work on your timeline. Awesome. Well, thank you both for your time. Thanks for listening and thanks for all the great questions and quizzing me a bit. But I'll send you a quick follow-up email with a few resources I think might be helpful, and then reach out anytime with questions. 
Catherine Hoffman:
Thank you so much. 
Monica Hirschheimer:
You're so welcome. Enjoy the rest of your day. Take care. Bye.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
IMPORTANT CLARIFICATION: This conversation does not match the requested account notes format.

The conversation titled "Interview Rachel Antone" that took place on Tuesday, December 16, 2025, is a job interview between:
- Ty Phillippay (Interviewer at Thatch)
- Rachel Antone (Candidate for Sales Enablement position)

This is NOT a sales conversation with a prospect/customer about ICHRA benefits.

Actual Conversation Summary:

Purpose: Fourth-round interview for a Sales Enablement role at Thatch

Key Discussion Points:
1. Rachel's background in sales enablement, including hyper-growth experience (30 to 100+ sales team members in one year at First Up)
2. Her approach to enablement: discovery-driven, data-informed, focuses on quick wins and multi-stakeholder engagement
3. Personal interests: painting (commission artist) and yoga
4. Discussion of Thatch's current challenges:
   - Lack of standardized processes and centralized resources
   - Need for unified messaging and materials
   - Multiple systems without clear hierarchy (Notion, Slack, etc.)
   - Upcoming maturation phase requiring strategic decisions

Stakeholders Identified:
- Rachel Antone: Candidate (4th interview)
- Ty Phillippay: Interviewer (HR/Benefits sales background, 20 years at United Healthcare)
- Previous interviewers: Andrew, Samina, Zach
- Company: Thatch (ICHRA solutions provider, 15-year-old company in growth phase)

Key Timestamps:
- Interview #4 in Rachel's process
- Rachel has been at current company almost 8 months
- Target hiring timeline: End of December 2025 (post-enrollment period)

Next Steps:
- Ty will provide positive feedback to hiring team
- Hiring team will follow up with Rachel on timeline
- Rachel invited to reach out to Ty directly if needed for questions or follow-up

No ICHRA prospect account notes are applicable to this conversation.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Interview Notes - Rachel Antone
Date: December 16, 2025

Current Situation:
- Sales Enablement professional, currently ~8 months into role at SolarWinds (recently acquired by PE firm)
- Located in Austin, TX (downtown, blocks from Thatch office)
- Interview #4 in process (previously spoke with Andrew, Samina, Zach)
- Not actively job searching but being selective about opportunities

What's In Place:
- Extensive enablement experience in healthcare, IT, and finance sectors
- Built enablement programs from scratch at First Up (scaled sales team from 30 to 100+ in one year)
- Consulting experience helping startups establish go-to-market strategies
- Strong skills: discovery, data analysis, coaching, stakeholder management, multitasking

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Current company doesn't prioritize enablement appropriately
- Executive-driven strategy without consideration for individual team needs
- Lack of true empowerment for sales teams
- Missing people and strategy elements at current organization
- Traditional frameworks too rigid for current market dynamics
- Frustrated with top-down approach that doesn't yield results

Priorities & Goals:
- Seeking organization that truly values and prioritizes enablement
- Wants seat at leadership table and involvement in strategic decisions
- Focus on empowering individual sales teams vs. executive mandates only
- Deliver world-class enablement that drives measurable results
- Strategy-first approach combining qualitative feedback and quantitative data
- Modernize established industries (strong interest in healthcare)
- Build programs that consider full employee spectrum, not just one segment

Optimization Approach:
- Discovery-driven: asks questions of leaders, reps, executives to understand obstacles and wins
- Data-informed: analyzes Salesforce trends, deal cycles, persona effectiveness
- Quick wins while building long-term programs
- Balances onboarding for new hires with upskilling for tenured reps
- Emphasizes personalization and intentionality over automation
- Focuses on time/money ROI and behavioral changes

Timeline:
- Available for near-term start given local proximity
- Process moving through end of December (company's enrollment period ends late December)
- Expressed excitement about role and team dynamics

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Next Steps:

1. Ty (Thatch) - Provide feedback and high marks for Rachel to the hiring team
   - Owner: Ty Phillippay
   - Deadline: Not specified, but implied to be soon after the interview

2. Thatch Hiring Team - Follow up with Rachel regarding timeline and next steps in the interview process
   - Owner: Thatch (Andrew/hiring team)
   - Deadline: Not specified

3. Rachel (Candidate) - Wait for follow-up from Thatch team; reach out to Ty if no feedback is received
   - Owner: Rachel Antone
   - Deadline: As needed if no response received

Overall Deal Status: This is interview #4 in Rachel's hiring process for the Sales Enablement position. The next step is for the Thatch team to provide feedback and communicate the timeline for final hiring decisions. The hiring process is expected to extend past Christmas, with final decisions likely by end of December 2025.

attributes.title: Interview Rachel Antone
attributes.transcript:
Ty Phillippay:
Let's see, maybe it's better now. Let's see, it looks like it's got you on mute. 
Rachel Antone:
Hey, Ty, can you hear me now? 
Ty Phillippay:
Yeah, absolutely. 
Rachel Antone:
Hey. Oh, I'm so sorry. I think I didn't allow it to connect to my microphone, so that was my bad. No problem. That happens. How are you today? 
Ty Phillippay:
I'm doing great. I appreciate the opportunity to. Meet you and talk to you. But first, let me understand, where am I? As far as how many interviews you've done so far with that? 
Rachel Antone:
Yeah, absolutely. So this is number four right now. So I chatted with Andrew first and then Samina. So a little bit out of order there. And then just spoke with Zach yesterday. 
Ty Phillippay:
So excellent. 
Rachel Antone:
Yeah. Number four. 
Ty Phillippay:
Awesome. All right. And then, and just, I'd love to kind of find out how... You initially heard about that. Can you tell me about that? 
Rachel Antone:
Yeah, absolutely. So I was actually not in the market looking for a new role, But Andrew actually posted about a role in one of the networking channels that I'm a part of for sales enablement. And I have always loved working with healthcare and really wanting to lean into like, very established industries. That are, you know, or where there are teams that, you know, are focused on modernizing certain things. So I've kind of stuck with the IT finance and healthcare world these past few years. And yeah, just decided to message Andrew. And he just shared so many interesting things about the role. So sent in an application and, you know, the rest is history. 
Ty Phillippay:
Yeah. 
Rachel Antone:
Awesome. 
Ty Phillippay:
Awesome. Now, have you been a part of a... Company that was like, literally growing in every sense of the word. And what I mean by that is, when you get there, everything's kind of jumbled up, you know. There's like the right ideas are in place, but like, the standard processes aren't. And then you're just constantly trying to build and then bring in more people. Have you been in that environment before? 
Rachel Antone:
Yes, I've actually been in that environment a couple of times. Actually, funny that, you know, so Zach mentioned that you were on like the Hris side. So I actually worked with a different startup called First Up a few years back, where I had to lay all of the groundwork for enablement. We were in a hyper growth phase. I think the sales team altogether, that includes SDRs and account executives, was around 30. We grew to over 100. In a year. So lots of changes, lots of breaking into new markets, and really had to kind of figure that out at that company. And actually have consulted with a few companies as well to help them get that momentum, you know, get their ducks in a row, as they're really trying to figure out, okay, there's a product market fit from a solution standpoint, but how do we bring that go to market strategy and a meaningful way to our buyers? Like, how do we take into account their ecosystem, all of their internal levers that need to be pulled? Different stakeholders, um. But also how do we like help the particular personas that we're speaking to, how do we help them win and see that they can win, you know, with our solution? And that's kind of been my main strategy in making sense of of a lot of different complex types of teams. 
Ty Phillippay:
Yeah, yep. And it's it's a repeatable skill set. And what's interesting is what Bowie's found is what doesn't work at the next place. Sometimes I come in thinking like, OK, I'm going to kind of have my little playbook. I'm going to use my my analysis tool for each group that I'm analyzing. I'm going to capture my data there and then I'm going to do this. And then I'm going to hit them with this and they'll love it. And I get to that point and I'm like, they won't love this. And it wasn't even a fit. It's, you know, there's the unique. This to each organization and the speed that we're going on. But I'd say, overall, at that you, the resounding thing that I've found is just really good people. It's a huge difference maker. I've worked at United Healthcare for 20 years and, you know, ran Northern California for them, for key accounts and small group. That was very regimented. It's like you're in a space station, like the Death Star, and floating through space, you know. And then I went to a tech startup and we were just, I was the first commercial hire. It was radically different. Frankly, it was hard, it was harder than I thought the actual transition was. But with that, you think what you're finding is a company that has made it really part of its DNA. To have a rigorous hiring process and to look at an individual beyond their their resume, get to know them, take, invest that time. So what I find is, Sorry, I have a little bit of a head cold. I'm getting over. So my voice is a little scratchy. What I find is I can get a really good idea and everybody loves it. They're like, yes, we need that. Right. You know, there's full support. So not only am I empowered to share the idea, but I get great feedback. Really, the team that we're missing right now is a team that could make that great idea that's been kind of ratified or just known. Like, gosh, we need this to really just make it happen. And so what are some of the ways that you in your past felt like? You've come into an organization? You've kind of taken the amount of time you need to get marinated into what needs to happen. And but when you've really just helped an organization turn a corner by delivering what they needed, whether it was materials or messaging, or any or both. 
Rachel Antone:
Yeah. Yeah. Absolutely. So I loved what you said earlier about how traditional frameworks do not work, especially in startups. But to be honest, you know, I've worked at a couple of larger companies and those frameworks don't work there either. Because of the way that the market is these days. We're in such weird economic times where, you know, things like just smacking MedPick into a deal cycle is not. The only way to win? Like there are, or like competency frameworks. Those types of systems are just too rigid for the amount of movement and the amount of things that we learn. Even on like, a quarterly basis. So I really try to actually, like, think, like a seller, if I'm supporting a sales team. Want to ask the discovery questions to the leaders, to the sales reps, to the executives, to understand, Okay. You know, sure, there's the executive strategy, the initiatives and like, the goals for the year. But what's actually going on within the individual teams? What obstacles are we running into? Um, what things are working well? Um, I think that, you know, chatting with with different folks on the team provides a lot of behavioral context. But also really want to look at the data from an operations standpoint. So what is Salesforce showing? What kind of trends can we glean from where deals are being held up, or where personas are just not getting us anywhere? So how do we change our strategy as far as qualifying who we're speaking to, who we're bringing into the conversation and when? And also what other trends we can gather from? Different accounts that are being worked. I think that it's really, really important to take into account all of those different things. So, of course, like the wants, like the desires from executive team, from leaders, from the individual teams, what is going well, what's going wrong, but then also what is data actually showing? I think that all of those different angles are extremely helpful, but then also... I like to take it upon myself to do a lot of research about the industries that I'm working in as well, so that I can bring in those new ideas. fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-08

Client/Prospect: Infinite Therapy Solutions (Representatives: Poonam, Hillary)

Current State:
- Traditional group health insurance with only 4 employees enrolled (2 are owners).
- Currently using Omnia Silver plan with a $1,500 deductible and $9,200 out-of-pocket max.
- Payroll provider: PayMedia.
- Broker: Liberty (Samantha Winter).
- 60-day waiting period for new hires.
- Frequent hiring (new employees monthly).
- Coverage limited to New Jersey; two new hires located in Florida.
- Group plan with Blue Cross Blue Shield, paying 50% of employee-only rate for two employees.

Pain Points:
- Rising healthcare costs and a 23% renewal increase for 2025.
- Marketplace rates have increased, making individual coverage less affordable.
- Limited knowledge of healthcare plan options beyond the current Silver plan.
- Current plan inadequate for Florida-based employees.
- Confusion about HRA allowance model and benchmarking methodology.
- Extremely tight timeline due to government shutdown delaying marketplace rates.

Priorities:
- Cost reduction and minimizing the impact of the 23% increase.
- Making healthcare coverage more attractive to employees.
- Contributing 50% toward employee healthcare costs.
- Maintaining similar coverage level to the current plan.
- Ensuring equitable benefits across the workforce.
- Quick implementation due to tight deadline.
- Managing employee communication and perception.

Challenges:
- Understanding how the new system works with frequent new hires.
- Managing payroll deductions and administrative tasks.
- Uncertainty about employee plan selection behavior and preferences.
- Difficulty understanding cost implications of various contribution strategies.
- Concern about optics of increasing employer contribution percentage even though dollar amount decreases.
- Need to educate employees on new Thatch platform quickly.
- Managing two separate company enrollments.
- Owners/partners of an LLP are ineligible to participate in Thatch, requiring separate enrollment.

Optimization Goals:
- Increase employee enrollment in healthcare benefits.
- Provide 50% employer contribution.
- Simplify benefits administration.
- Achieve cost savings versus the 23% renewal increase.
- Implement age/location-adjusted allowances for equity.
- Provide national coverage access.

Stated Timelines:
- December 8, 2025, afternoon: Sales agreement to be sent.
- December 9, 2025: Employee education meetings scheduled (daytime and 6:30-7pm sessions).
- December 15, 2025: Employee election deadline for 2026-01-01 effective coverage.
- Deadline for employee enrollment extended to December 19, 2025.
- Owners to enroll separately by December 31, 2025, for a January 1, 2026, start date.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect's current benefits plan is with Aetna as the carrier. The plan design is a POS 3000 (Point of Service plan with a $3,000 deductible). The company contributes 65% of the premium across all tiers (employee only, employee + spouse, employee + children, and family coverage). 

Currently, 13 employees are enrolled in the plan out of 73 total employees (approximately 61 full-time employees). The company recently received a 42% renewal increase from Aetna/AFA. The current monthly employer cost is approximately $10,357 based on renewal numbers.

The workforce consists primarily of hourly employees (with only 5-6 salaried employees) and experiences high turnover due to the seasonal nature of the business. Most enrolled employees are above 45 years of age. The company is located in New Jersey (Belvedere and Morristown area) and is structured as an LLC partnership. The funding type was not explicitly mentioned in the conversation.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Infinite Therapy Solutions - ICHRA Exploration and Implementation

1. Key Points Discussed

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: The primary driver for exploring ICHRA is to manage significant 2026 renewal costs, with the current group plan facing a 42% increase. The employer aims to reduce healthcare costs and administrative workload, particularly due to the challenges of managing a seasonal workforce with high turnover.

- Current Situation: The company currently offers a traditional group health insurance plan (Aetna POS 3000) with a 65% employer contribution. The workforce includes 73 employees, with only 13 currently enrolled in health benefits. The company faces administrative challenges due to frequent hiring and turnover.

- ICHRA Solution Proposed: ICHRA allows employees to receive a pre-tax allowance to purchase individual plans. Two allowance models were discussed: a flat rate for all employees or a variable rate based on demographics. Thatch handles all administration, including premium payments, enrollments, and compliance.

- Compliance and Cost Challenges: Key compliance issues include class carve-out restrictions and partnership owner eligibility. The ICHRA solution was found to be more expensive than the current renewal, with geographic coverage limitations and age demographics impacting costs.

2. Stakeholders Involved

- Infinite Therapy Solutions (Prospect/Customer):
  - Poonam: Co-owner, financial decision-maker, and benefits administrator.
  - Hillary Fryczynski: Co-owner, responsible for employee communication and operational oversight.

- Thatch (Vendor):
  - Caroline Clark: ICHRA solution specialist and primary point of contact for implementation.
  - Molly Marshall: Channel Partnerships team, supporting broker relationships.

- Liberty (Broker):
  - Samantha Winter: Primary broker, coordinating ICHRA exploration and compliance guidance.
  - LeighAnn Panas: Supporting broker, providing compliance guidance and carrier relationship management.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps

- December 04, 2025: Initial discovery call and product demonstration.
- December 05, 2025: Follow-up meeting to review cost analysis and contribution recommendations.
- December 08, 2025: Decision made to proceed with ICHRA; selected 50% contribution at 50th percentile Silver benchmark.
- December 15, 2025: Critical deadline for employee plan selections to ensure January 1, 2026, coverage effective date.
- December 16, 2025: ICHRA exploration meeting, identifying compliance and cost challenges.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties

- Immediate Actions:
  - Quote Review and Analysis: Melissa, Steve Vande Vrede, Samantha Winter, and LeighAnn Panas to review Thatch quote link by December 23, 2025.
  - Owner Coverage Solution Research: Samantha Winter to provide resource link for independent marketplace enrollment by December 20, 2025.
  - Internal Stakeholder Discussion: Melissa and Steve Vande Vrede to discuss ICHRA findings with Michael Vande Vrede by December 23, 2025.

- Strategic Decisions Needed:
  - Renewal Strategy Determination: Ownership team to decide on renewal strategy before Aetna renewal effective date.
  - Alternative Carrier Exploration: Samantha Winter and LeighAnn Panas to pursue quotes

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value: The prospect currently administers employee benefits through a combination of broker services and manual processes. They rely on brokers from Liberty Company, specifically Samantha Winter and LeighAnn Panas, to manage their group health insurance plan. The administration process is relatively manual, involving paper forms for employees who decline coverage and a heavy reliance on broker support for tasks such as preparing census information, obtaining quotes, and providing guidance on compliance and plan options. There is no mention of using a benefits administration platform like Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits, indicating that the process is broker-managed and manual. The brokers play a crucial role in coordinating meetings with vendors and assisting with plan selection and renewals. The prospect has a small enrolled population, with 13 employees enrolled out of 73 total employees, and they depend heavily on their broker relationship for benefits administration support.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect: Lazy SJ & 7J's (two separate New Mexico corporations)

Current Situation:
- ~200 total employees across two locations (Santa Fe and Las Vegas)
- Currently ~30 employees on MEC plan ($80/month)
- ~10 administrative staff on Presbyterian Health Plan (company pays ~50%, total ~$450)
- Use ReadyPay Online for payroll and Employee Navigator for benefits
- 60-day waiting period for new hires

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Tight enrollment timeline (deadline: December 22, 2025 for January 1, 2026 coverage)
- Significant cost concerns: quoted $23,880/month for 29 hourly employees and $3,000/month for 3 salaried employees
- Uncertainty about actual enrollment numbers
- Budget expectations ($200/employee) far below compliance requirements
- Two separate corporations requiring separate billing
- Peak season making staffing predictions difficult
- Geographic separation complicating employee communication

Priorities:
- Maintain ACA compliance as applicable large employer (50+ FTE)
- Offer differentiated contributions: higher allowances for administrative staff vs. hourly workers
- Manage costs while meeting legal requirements
- Understand true enrollment projections for accurate budgeting

Optimization Goals:
- Reclassify 10 administrative employees from hourly to salaried to enable compliant tiered contributions
- Leverage Thatch platform to reduce administrative burden
- Provide employee choice across three carriers (BCBS NM, UnitedHealthcare, Presbyterian)
- Minimize employer cost while maintaining compliance

Stated Timelines:
- December 22, 2025: Final enrollment deadline for January 1, 2026 coverage
- Next steps: Lisa to consult with broker Alex to review quotes and finalize contribution strategy

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Thatch (Jared/Molly) Owns:
- Send quote access to Lisa, Janice, and Rick for both hourly and salaried employee groups
- Catch Alex up on the conversation and where things were left off
- Remain available as a resource for any questions that arise after the prospect reviews the information

Prospect (Lisa/Rick/Janice) Owns:
- Review the quotes sent by Jared for both employee groups (hourly and salaried)
- Schedule a meeting with Alex to discuss the quotes, options, and determine the best path forward
- Decide on contribution strategy and budget for each employee class
- Determine if administrative staff (currently 10 people) should be changed from hourly to salaried classification to offer them higher allowances while remaining compliant
- Consider whether to keep some employees on MEC plan vs. moving to ICRA

Critical Deadline:
- December 22, 2025: Final deadline for employees to select plans for January 1, 2026 coverage (employees who miss this deadline would get February 1, 2026 coverage)

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Lisa needs to schedule a follow-up discussion with Alex after reviewing the quotes to finalize the contribution structure and decide whether to proceed with the ICRA implementation for 2026.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect currently operates two separate corporations (Lazy SJ and 7J's) with over 200 employees total across two locations in New Mexico. They maintain a two-tier benefits structure based on employee classification:

Hourly Employees (majority of workforce):
- Carrier: MEC Plan (Minimum Essential Coverage)
- Approximately 30 employees currently enrolled
- Employee cost: Approximately $80 per month for minimal coverage

Management/Administrative Staff (approximately 10 employees):
- Carrier: Presbyterian Health Plan
- Plan Design: Silver level plan
- Cost Structure: 50/50 split between employer and employee, totaling approximately $450 per month (approximately $225 employer contribution, $225 employee contribution)
- Initially mentioned as 5 employees, later clarified to be about 10 administrative staff

Additional Details:
- New hire waiting period: 60 days before benefits eligibility
- Benefits administration currently handled through Colonial for enrollment notifications
- Payroll system: ReadyPay Online (RPO)
- Open enrollment platform: Employee Navigator
- The company is classified as an Applicable Large Employer (ALE) with over 50 full-time employees

No specific information was provided regarding funding type (level-funded, fully insured, or self-funded) or detailed plan design structure (PPO, HDHP, HMO) beyond the silver tier designation for the Presbyterian plan.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.title: Decision Timeline
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.value:
• No specific decision timeline was explicitly stated by the prospect (Lisa) during the conversation
• The only date mentioned was December 22nd, 2025, which is the enrollment deadline for employees to select plans for January 1st coverage (not the prospect's decision deadline)
• At the end of the call, the prospect indicated she needs to review the quotes and discuss with Alex before making a decision, but no timeframe was provided for when this decision would be made
• The conversation concluded with the plan to regroup with Alex to determine the best way forward, with no specific date set for that follow-up discussion

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Lazy SJ & 7J's - ICHRA Discovery Call

Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Account: Lazy SJ & 7J's (Two separate corporations)  
Meeting Type: ICHRA Product Demo and Quote Review

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Employer's Interest in ICHRA
- Current Situation: Company currently offers two-tier benefits structure:
  - ~30 employees on MEC plan (paying ~$80/month for minimal coverage)
  - ~5-10 administrative staff on Presbyterian Health Plan (company pays 50%, employee pays 50%, approximately $450 total)
  - Total employee base: ~200 employees across two locations (Las Vegas and Santa Fe)

- Pain Points Identified:
  - Rising insurance costs creating affordability concerns for employees
  - Employee uncertainty about whether they can afford coverage ("everybody's questioning the amount of money")
  - Administrative complexity of managing benefits across two separate corporations
  - Need for ACA compliance as an Applicable Large Employer (50+ FTE)

- ICHRA Value Proposition Presented:
  - Flexibility: Employees can choose from multiple carriers (Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Mexico, UnitedHealthcare, Presbyterian Health Plan)
  - Reduced administrative burden: Thatch handles enrollments, compliance documents, COBRA notices
  - Compliance assurance: Dynamic allowances ensure ACA affordability requirements are met
  - Employee support: Access to advisors and self-service platform tools

Compliance Requirements Discussed
- ACA Affordability Standard: Employees must be able to afford lowest-cost Silver plan without spending more than 9.96% of annual income
- Minimum Contribution: For hourly employees, employer must contribute 99% toward benchmark plan (25th percentile Silver plan) to remain compliant
- Employee Classification: Can only group employees by employment type (full-time salary vs. full-time hourly), not by job title

Pricing Structure Presented

Hourly Employees (29 employees quoted as sample):
- Monthly employer cost: $23,880 (includes contributions + platform fees)
- Individual allowances range from $622 to $1,240+ depending on age and income
- Example: Employee "Alan" receives $841/month allowance
- Some Bronze plans would be fully funded; Silver/Gold plans require employee contribution

Salaried Employees (3 employees currently):
- Monthly employer cost: $3,000 for 3 employees
- Could contribute 84% toward benchmark for compliance, but 99% recommended for fairness
- Note: Lisa indicated ~10 administrative staff should receive higher allowances, but only 3 are currently classified as salaried

Employer Concerns Raised
- Cost: Lisa expressed concern that total cost is "a little high"
- Enrollment Uncertainty: Difficult to predict how many employees will actually enroll
- Budget Constraints: Initial budget consideration was $200/employee, which would not meet ACA compliance requirements
- Comparison Needed: Lisa wants to compare ICHRA costs against continuing MEC plan

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Prospect Company Representatives

Lisa (Primary Decision Maker)
- Role: President of Lazy SJ corporation
- Responsibilities: Final approval on benefits strategy and budget
- Key Concerns: Cost management, employee affordability, compliance
- Contact: Email provided (to receive quote access)

Rick (Payroll Administrator)
- Role: Manages payroll operations
- Responsibilities: Payroll processing, benefits administration coordination
- Systems: Uses ReadyPay Online RPO and Employee Navigator for open enrollment
- Key Questions: Asked about contribution structures and cost implications

Janice (HR Manager)
- Role: HR, primarily for Santa Fe location
- Responsibilities: Employee enrollment monitoring, benefits communication
- Note: Will need training on Thatch platform administration
- Challenge: Manages remote employees across two locations

Alex (Benefits Advisor - Not Present)
- Role: External benefits consultant/advisor
- Previous Interaction: Met with Thatch team on December 15, 2025
- Responsibilities: Provided initial company background, will help with decision-making
- Next Step: Needs to be caught up on this conversation

Thatch Representatives

Jared Geredes
- Role: Sales representative/Account manager
- Responsibilities: Product education, quote preparation, account setup coordination

Molly Marshall
- Role: Sales support
- Responsibilities: Demo support, enrollment process clarification

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Dates Identified

December 22, 2025 (6 days from conversation date)
- DEADLINE: Last day for employees to select plans for January 1, 2026 coverage
- Risk: Very tight timeline given conversation occurred December 16
- Consequence: Employees who miss deadline can only get coverage starting February 1, 2026
- Compliance Note: No ACA penalty for missed deadline since offer was made before year-end

January 1, 2026
- Target coverage effective date for enrolled employees

Key Conversation Moments

0:00-15:00 - Introduction & ICHRA Education
- Jared explained ICRA model vs. traditional group insurance
- Covered flat vs. dynamic allowances (dynamic recommended for ALE compliance)
- Explained employee shopping experience and support options

15:00-25:00 - Platform Demo
- Demonstrated admin dashboard functionality
- Showed employee onboarding flow
- Clarified 60-day waiting period process for new hires
- Lisa confirmed: "It's pretty simple"

25:00-45:00 - Quote Review & Pricing Discussion
- Reviewed hourly employee quote (29 employees sample)
- Discussed compliance requirements (99% contribution minimum)
- Lisa's reaction: Cost concerns expressed
- Clarified two separate corporations require two separate Thatch accounts and invoices

45:00-End - Plan Examples & Next Steps
- Reviewed specific employee examples (Alan, Jason)
- Compared to current Presbyterian plan costs
- Discussed enrollment uncertainty
- Confirmed no minimum enrollment requirements

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By December 18, 2025)

Thatch Team (Jared):
- [ ] Send quote access links to Lisa, Rick, and Janice
- [ ] Catch up Alex on conversation outcomes and employer concerns
- [ ] Verify ReadyPay Online API integration availability
- [ ] Prepare comparison analysis: ICHRA costs vs. continuing MEC plan (if requested)

Prospect Team (Lisa/Alex):
- [ ] Schedule follow-up meeting between Lisa and Alex to review quotes
- [ ] Discuss budget implications and enrollment projections
- [ ] Determine if administrative staff should be reclassified to "salaried" for higher allowances
- [ ] Decide on dental/vision strategy (offer through Thatch or separately)

Decision Required (By December 19-20, 2025)

Critical Decision Point:
- Determine if proceeding with ICHRA for January 1, 2026 effective date
- If yes, must immediately begin employee communication and invitation process
- If no, consider February 1, 2026 implementation or alternative solutions

Implementation Tasks (If Proceeding)

Account Setup:
- Finalize contribution strategy for hourly vs. salaried employees
- Confirm employee classification changes (if any)
- Upload employee rosters for both corporations (Lazy SJ and 7J's)
- Configure two separate Thatch accounts with separate billing

Employee Communication (By December 20, 2025):
- Send invitation emails to all eligible full-time employees
- Provide enrollment deadline communication (December 22)
- Offer Janice training on platform administration
- Coordinate support for employees across Las Vegas and Santa Fe locations

Outstanding Questions to Resolve

1. Enrollment Projections: Need more accurate estimate of expected enrollment (currently assuming 30 based on current MEC plan participation)
2. Administrative Staff Classification: Confirm which 10 employees should receive higher allowances and whether employment type changes are needed
3. Dental/Vision: Decide whether to offer through Thatch or maintain separate arrangements
4. Cost Comparison: Obtain MEC plan renewal costs for direct comparison
5. Budget Approval: Confirm if $23,880/month (for sample 29 hourly employees) fits within company budget parameters

RISK ASSESSMENT

High Risk:
- Extremely tight timeline (6 days to decision and employee enrollment)
- Cost concerns may prevent moving forward
- Enrollment uncertainty makes budgeting difficult

Medium Risk:
- Two separate corporations add administrative complexity
- Remote workforce across two locations may complicate communication
- Employee affordability concerns may result in low enrollment

Mitigation Strategies:
- Expedite decision-making meeting with Alex
- Provide clear cost comparisons to current plans
- Consider February 1, 2026 implementation if more time needed
- Emphasize no minimum enrollment requirement reduces financial risk

ADDITIONAL NOTES

- Company is in peak season with many employees on overtime
- Lisa mentioned FedEx relationship (company appears to be FedEx contractor/service provider)
- Current benefits: "Fedex isn't a high product" - suggests limited benefits from FedEx
- Employee sentiment: Shift from "everybody wanted it" to affordability concerns
- Platform feedback: Lisa found demo "pretty simple" - positive signal for adoption

Recommended Follow-up: Schedule 30-minute call with Lisa and Alex within 24-48 hours to address cost concerns and finalize decision before December 22 deadline.
