fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect: Lazy SJ & 7J's (two separate New Mexico corporations)

Current Situation:
- ~200 total employees across two locations (Santa Fe and Las Vegas)
- Currently ~30 employees on MEC plan ($80/month)
- ~10 administrative staff on Presbyterian Health Plan (company pays ~50%, total ~$450)
- Use ReadyPay Online for payroll and Employee Navigator for benefits
- 60-day waiting period for new hires

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Tight enrollment timeline (deadline: December 22, 2025 for January 1, 2026 coverage)
- Significant cost concerns: quoted $23,880/month for 29 hourly employees and $3,000/month for 3 salaried employees
- Uncertainty about actual enrollment numbers
- Budget expectations ($200/employee) far below compliance requirements
- Two separate corporations requiring separate billing
- Peak season making staffing predictions difficult
- Geographic separation complicating employee communication

Priorities:
- Maintain ACA compliance as applicable large employer (50+ FTE)
- Offer differentiated contributions: higher allowances for administrative staff vs. hourly workers
- Manage costs while meeting legal requirements
- Understand true enrollment projections for accurate budgeting

Optimization Goals:
- Reclassify 10 administrative employees from hourly to salaried to enable compliant tiered contributions
- Leverage Thatch platform to reduce administrative burden
- Provide employee choice across three carriers (BCBS NM, UnitedHealthcare, Presbyterian)
- Minimize employer cost while maintaining compliance

Stated Timelines:
- December 22, 2025: Final enrollment deadline for January 1, 2026 coverage
- Next steps: Lisa to consult with broker Alex to review quotes and finalize contribution strategy

12/16/2025

Thatch (Jared/Molly) Owns:
- Send quote access to Lisa, Janice, and Rick for both hourly and salaried employee groups
- Catch Alex up on the conversation and where things were left off
- Remain available as a resource for any questions that arise after the prospect reviews the information

Prospect (Lisa/Rick/Janice) Owns:
- Review the quotes sent by Jared for both employee groups (hourly and salaried)
- Schedule a meeting with Alex to discuss the quotes, options, and determine the best path forward
- Decide on contribution strategy and budget for each employee class
- Determine if administrative staff (currently 10 people) should be changed from hourly to salaried classification to offer them higher allowances while remaining compliant
- Consider whether to keep some employees on MEC plan vs. moving to ICRA

Critical Deadline:
- December 22, 2025: Final deadline for employees to select plans for January 1, 2026 coverage (employees who miss this deadline would get February 1, 2026 coverage)

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Lisa needs to schedule a follow-up discussion with Alex after reviewing the quotes to finalize the contribution structure and decide whether to proceed with the ICRA implementation for 2026.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently uses Employee Navigator as their benefits administration platform. Rick (who handles payroll) specifically mentioned "The only benefit of open enrollment is employee Navigator." 

For payroll processing, they use ReadyPay Online RPO, though Rick noted uncertainty about whether it has API integration capabilities.

Their current benefits workflow includes:
- Enrollment invitations: Colonial (likely a broker or carrier partner) currently sends enrollment invitations to new employees after their 60-day waiting period
- Responsibilities: Rick manages payroll, while Janice (HR) monitors benefits for the Santa Fe location, and Lisa handles the Las Vegas location
- Current coverage structure: They maintain two separate corporations (Lazy SJ and 7J's) with separate bank accounts and billing, requiring separate invoicing for each entity

The prospect currently offers different benefit tiers:
- Approximately 30 employees on a MEC plan (paying around $80)
- About 5-10 administrative staff on a Presbyterian Health Plan (with employer paying half, totaling approximately $450)

They appear to rely on a combination of Employee Navigator for administration and Colonial for enrollment coordination, rather than managing benefits entirely manually.

attributes.title: Thatch / Lazy SJ & 7J's
attributes.transcript:
Jared Geredes:
Hi, Rick. Hi, Lisa. 
Rick:
Hey, guys. Can you hear me? 
Lisa:
Yes. 
Jared Geredes:
Great to meet you. How's everybody doing? 
Lisa:
Thank you. A little down with the cold, but other than that, good. 
Jared Geredes:
Oh gosh, there's definitely something going around. I was sick, I feel like, for two weeks, and I'm finally like, 100% again. 
Lisa:
I know I have so many employees that are constantly in and out and good employees that are always like, I don't know what's going on. Like, I get it. Yeah. 
Molly Marshall:
Hope you feel better. Thank you. Happy holiday. Are there any more folks joining on your end? 
Jared Geredes:
And somebody muted, or Lisa, I think you muted if you're talking. And we could also jump into it. Alex, let us know that he might try to jump in, but that if he does, he's going to be a little bit late. And that we can get started without him. 
Lisa:
I have Janice online as well. 
Jared Geredes:
Okay. Sorry, HR. 
Lisa:
So I kind of tapped her on. Perfect. 
Jared Geredes:
Well, Molly and myself, we work for Thatch. We met with Alex yesterday. He caught us up on your situation, your background and everything. So we're up to speed on everything. To set an agenda for today, I think there's like three kind of topics that we want to cover, three agenda items. Number one, we thought it would be helpful to cover a high-level overview. What is an ICRA? How does Thatch work? And how does thatch actually administer ICRAs? Number two, if it would be helpful for you, we can show you the full employee experience through a demo. So what your employees would be going through, onboarding, selecting a plan, what support they could get along the way. And then at the end of the call, which I think we should probably spend the majority of our time doing. Is discussing what your contributions could look like for next year. That's what we had in mind. This is your call, though. I want to make sure it's helpful. So let me know if that sounds good, or if we're missing something that you think would be helpful to cover. 
Lisa:
That'll work. Beautiful. 
Jared Geredes:
Let's jump into it. And on a scale of one to 10, what's your familiarity with the Icra model? And one is completely okay. I just want a level set. 
Lisa:
I don't know nothing about it. Perfect. 
Jared Geredes:
Okay, we'll start from the very top. I'm very aware that, like, this is new for a lot of people. And it's very different than probably the traditional group insurance model that you're used to. So I'm expecting lots of questions. If at any point I explain something and it makes no sense, please stop me, interrupt me, let me know. I really want to make sure that we leave the call today. And you feel really confident with how this all works and what it all looks like. To set the stage, I usually find it helpful comparing to the traditional group insurance model, because that's what most people are familiar with. In traditional group insurance, you typically select one carrier and maybe one or two different plans to make accessible to employees. We're very different. You don't select a single carrier, you don't select just a couple of plans to make accessible to employees. You're actually going to have the ability to offer tons of different carriers and tons of different plans to your employees. So that they can pick a plan based off of their level of need, their family's level of need, their budget, all of that information that's important to them. And on top of that, all you have to do in this model is decide on a monthly health care budget to give to each employee that they can spend towards their individual health insurance. There's two different ways that you can structure these monthly budgets. Option number one is what we call flat allowances. Option number two is what we call dynamic allowances. I'll start with by describing, like, what a flat allowance is. And it's basically what it sounds like. You would be giving each employee the same dollar amount to spend towards their individual medical plan. I think something to take into consideration and why I don't typically recommend the flat allowance model is these individual plans. Will be priced based off of your employees age. So everybody's going to have a different price for their plans. Because of that, if you give everybody the same dollar amount, they're not going to have the same purchasing power. It won't be fair. Older employees, their plans are more expensive than younger employees. Because of that, I almost always recommend option number two, dynamic allowances, where we will actually base this dollar amount that you're giving to employees on their age. And on the back end, I make sure that that dollar amount will give each employee the same purchasing power. And because you're an applicable large employer, this is really the only direction I would recommend for you so that you're fully compliant with your allowances as well. We'll dig way deeper into that when we actually look into the quotes, but just want to let you know that there are two different ways you can structure budgets. After you give employees these dollars, they're going to shop for their insurance on thatch. So they're not going to the New Mexico State Exchange to pick a plan. Where they then have to submit a receipt for reimbursement. Everything happens on our platform, and this makes it easier for employees. It also makes it easier for you to manage. If an employee is given a budget of $750 and they pick a medical plan that is less expensive than their budget, which oftentimes isn't the case, they can use those leftover dollars towards their prescriptions, their co-pays, their deductible, as well as any qualified medical expense. So think of things like mental health care, telehealth services, all those different things. I just did a lot of talking. I'll take a pause here. Any questions, areas that you're confused about that I could maybe describe in a better way? 
Lisa:
Not yet. 
Jared Geredes:
Okay, we're on it. So, as I mentioned earlier, the great thing about this is you're going to be giving your employees lots of options. They're going to have several different carriers to choose plans from. While it's growing. Great to have a lot of options because everybody can right size their plan based off of what they need. It can also be overwhelming having a lot of choices. We understand this and we wanted to build our entire platform to make this process really easy for your employees. I'll show you this in the demo here in a second, But employees will have two different kind of support channels that they can use when they're actually selecting their plan. Option number one. They can schedule a call with one of our advisors where they can share their medications, the doctors they see, the hospitals they go to, their health history, anything that's important to them. And our advisors will look through all of the plans available and cherry pick a couple that they would recommend based off of what is shared. We also know people don't always like to talk to an individual about their health insurance and all that stuff. For those people, they can use our platform. They can input three pieces of information, how often they use insurance, what their budget is to spend out of pocket each month, And they can list all of the providers that they work with. And we will filter all the plans based off of that criteria as well. The last thing I want to share, and then we'll stop for questions, is administering an icra through Thatch. Our goal here is to take a lot of the administrative work off of your plate so that this is really running smoothly. What that looks like in terms of account setup, I set it up for you. All you need to decide on is how much money are we going to give to employees each month. After you finalize that, you share it with me. I create your account. We will upload your employees onto Thatch either through a payroll integration or we can manually upload the employees. And then we send invites to employees. They go shop for their plans on Thatch and they get enrolled for next year. Outside of account setup, we're handling all of the other admin tasks. So we process every single enrollment with each carrier. We will create and file all of the compliance documents for you at the end of the year. We send out cobra notices if you terminate an employee. And then, depending on what payroll system you use, we have different integrations with it. Which, Rick, I wanted to ask you, I know you're the... The man in charge of payroll. What payroll system do you use? 
Rick:
We're on ReadyPay Online RPO. I don't know if there's an API to this, though. 
Jared Geredes:
Okay. ReadyPay Online. I'll double check. 
Rick:
The only benefit of open enrollment is employee Navigator. Sorry, I was muted. 
Jared Geredes:
Okay. And you use employee Navigator. So, yeah, I'll double check if we have any type of API with ReadyPay Online. I think you're right. I don't think we do. That's not an issue. What we would just do is we would take your employee roster and then we would upload all those employees onto Thatch and then send invites directly from Thatch to those employees. Before we jump to a demo, I want to make sure we're in a good place here. Any questions, concerns that have come up so far? 
Lisa:
No, not yet. Okay. 
Jared Geredes:
On it, let's jump over to a demo. And so what I'm going to show you is both your admin dashboard, so basically what you would have access to see as an admin. We could get Lisa, you Janice, access to this Alex, and we could also get you access Rick. We would upload your employees, you're going to see all of your employees on your dashboard. I'll just create somebody for you right here so you can see. Everybody is going to populate in the not invited status so that you can select the employees that need to be invited to actually join that mid year. If you add any employees or terminate any employees, you would do it directly through that. So if you're adding them, you do that process. I just showed you. You click Add employee. You'd input their first name, last name and email address, and then we would send invites that way. If you're terminating employees. You would go to their row, click actions, Off board, and then you just check this box and click Off board employee. And they're basically off boarded out of our system. We're going to send them a cobra notice so that they can retain coverage if they want to. Other than that, you see at the very top, we're going to show you enrollment data. So where are your employees in this process? Who has not started enrollment? Who's currently in the process of enrollment viewing plans? Who's enrolled and who's declined. When it comes time to, when it comes time to inviting employees, you'll check their boxes, click Invite selected, and then you will invite those employees. When you invite them, they get an email to join Thatch. In that email, they have their own link that will take them to their personal Thatch account. We click Get started. They're going to create a password for their account. You click next. Step number one is for them to put in their basic background information. Based off of that information and the contribution strategy that we decide on together, your employees will see the dollar amount that you're contributing to them each month. Underneath that, they will be able to see where they can spend these dollars. Typically, it's medical, dental, vision, and other healthcare expenses. This might be a conversation for you to have with Alex, but offering dental and vision coverage through Thatch is completely optional. Alex might have something in mind for you, like offering dental and vision coverage outside of the platform, So we would just need to get that figured out before we set up your account. At the bottom of this page, if anybody wants to enroll their dependent in a plan, it's super easy. They click Add Dependent. They would input first name, last name, date of birth, and relationship. And they could do that process several times if they want to enroll multiple dependents. From there, inputting annual household income and tobacco usage. And then we get to, by far, the most important part of the process, where your employees are actually shopping for their medical plan. So we're going to show them every medical plan available in their area. We bring two plans to the top of this page, the lowest cost plan and the plan with the most comprehensive coverage. This is typically also the most expensive plan. When they get to this step, they have those two different options. They can schedule a call with an advisor so they can share their medications and their doctors, or they can do this fully self-serve. If they want to speak with somebody, they go to the bottom left, help and support. I need help deciding between plans. It will take them directly to our advisor's calendar, where they could schedule a call directly with them to speak with them and get recommendations. If they don't want to speak with anybody, they go to the top of this page and they can input those three pieces of information. How often do you expect to use your insurance? A little, somewhat often, a lot. I'll do a little. How much money am I willing and able to spend out of pocket each month? This should be on top of the allowance that you give them. And then last, but probably most important, is our provider search feature. So they can list all of the doctors that they currently work with, that their family currently works with. And when they're actually looking through plans, just pick two random people, when they're actually looking through plans, we're going to show them. Whether or not those providers are in network for that specific planning carrier. As we're going through this, you'll see we bring some of the like high level information to the top of each page. Deductible out of pocket, max, Co Insurance Co pays. I'll be honest, like, I think the average person doesn't know what a lot of these things mean, which is very understandable. That's why we have our advisors to support them through this process. And they can really give them that white glove experience, educate them on what they're picking and why they should pick this plan. Again, if somebody doesn't want to speak to anybody, but they have questions about what they're seeing, We do have a chat bot, which is called our Ask Thatch bot, where they can ask any question. They can say, what is a deductible? And they'll get an automatic answer for what a deductible is. If they want to speak with an advisor, they could do it in the bottom left. They can also just ask to speak with somebody live here. We're running through through this really quickly. Any questions? 
Lisa:
So since we're here in New Mexico, is there just pretty much the MCOS here in New Mexico, or? 
Jared Geredes:
Yeah. So when we look at the quote, I will show you all the different carriers that will be available to your employees. Yeah. If I remember correctly, because I was looking at your quote, I think it's three different carriers. Let's see. And we'll look at this deeper in a second. They'll have access to Blue Cross, Blue Shield of New Mexico. UnitedHealthcare and Presbyterian Health Plan. Okay. We'll jump back to that here in a second. Let me get back here. After they decide on the plan they want to pick, maybe they spoke with somebody, they'll click Select plan. After they enroll in a medical plan, they can then select dental and or vision coverage through Thatch if they want to. I'll select a dental plan, but I'll decline a vision plan. And then the final step. Is for us just to process their enrollment with the carrier. So we need a couple pieces of information and then usually one or two signatures, depending on which carrier they choose. And we click Enroll and it's really as easy as that. So the goal here is like, how can we make this consumer friendly. Avoid as much confusion as possible, and really handhold people through that entire process. They go to their dashboard. We're going to give them some tasks because as soon as they click enroll, we are ordering their insurance card to be sent to their home address. So, keep an eye out for member IDs, ignore payment reminders from the carrier, and if you have access to leftover dollars, to order their Thatch debit card. On their plan page or on their member page, they will see enrollment tracker of where their enrollment is in the process. When everybody receives coverage for January 1st, they will be showed in the enrolled status. Thoughts, questions? Is there anything you wanted to see? 
Lisa:
Yeah, when we first enroll, I might get everybody's enrolling at the same time and then thereafter. Do you automatically send them, like, right now, everybody that starts, I think it's 60 days, Colonial will send them an invite for their insurance plan. Is that something you do, or is it something we're going to have to do? 
Jared Geredes:
It is something that you will have to do on your end. So if you have a 60-day waiting period, when you add an employee here, you would want to schedule. Send that invitation to go out after 30 days so that they could get coverage after 60 days. 
Molly Marshall:
In terms of the enrollments and what have you, that's something that we all take care of on our end, in case that wasn't clear. 
Lisa:
So once the employee comes in, they're at that 60 days, so we don't lose out and get into the 90 day. That's why we did it the 60 day. And then they contact you. And you help them out, we email them, or how does, is that what you're saying? 
Jared Geredes:
Yeah, what we could do, and I think what's been helpful in the past, when you a new employee or hire somebody, if you want to email us that you added this employee. We can make sure that they get their invitation to get coverage after 60 days, okay, or you can send the invite out yourself. 
Lisa:
Okay, that'll work. 
Jared Geredes:
Is that helpful? I wasn't sure, that's completely clear. 
Lisa:
Yes, yes, okay, Perfect. 
Jared Geredes:
Anything else that you wanted to see or were expecting to see in the onboarding part of this whole situation? 
Lisa:
No, it's pretty simple. I'm sure some training for Janice will probably be the one to have to monitor it. 
Jared Geredes:
Yeah, and we could totally do that. Like, at the end of the day, we're here to help your employees. And so if they have any questions, they can come directly to Thatch. They can reach out to our support team. And we'll make sure to get them covered. What I think we see, and what you should expect, is that your employees will probably reach out to either you or Janice. If that's the case, you can just then kind of pass them along to the Thatch support team and we'll make sure to get them handled. fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value: The prospect's organization currently has no benefits plan in place. Libby O'Malley, the Executive Director, mentioned that when she was hired, the organization had no benefits package. She is currently purchasing individual marketplace coverage on her own, paying just under $1,000 per month for her personal plan. The organization is now exploring implementing an ICRA (Individual Coverage Health Reimbursement Arrangement) through Thatch as their first benefits offering.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.title: Decision Timeline
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.value:
• The prospect (Libby O'Malley) is seeking to implement benefits as soon as possible (ASAP), expressing urgency to "get things rolling quickly"

• Target coverage start date: January 1, 2026

• Decision deadline: Employees must choose plans by end of day December 22, 2025 for January 1st coverage (Monica mentioned this deadline may be extended by approximately 2 days to December 24, 2025)

• The prospect's board met approximately one week prior to the conversation (around December 5, 2025) and directed her to secure health insurance for employees

• Monica will send follow-up information and schedule another call to help finalize the allowance structure and next steps before the deadline

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association - ICHRA Implementation

Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Participants: Libby O'Malley (Executive Director, Prospect) and Monica Hirschheimer (Thatch Representative)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Employer's Interest in ICHRA
- Organization Profile: Nonprofit organization (Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association) seeking to implement ICHRA benefits for the first time
- Urgency: Board mandated health insurance implementation at meeting held Friday, December 11, 2025 (5 days prior to this call)
- Target Start Date: January 1, 2026 (ASAP implementation requested)
- Primary Drivers:
  - No existing health benefits currently offered
  - Need to provide competitive benefits to retain/attract talent
  - Budget constraints as a nonprofit organization
  - Desire for equitable benefits structure across diverse employee base

Employee Demographics & Coverage Needs
- Total Employees: 6 (4 full-time, 2 part-time)
- Geographic Distribution: 6 different states (Texas, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania)
- Actual Coverage Needed: Only 2 employees require insurance
  - Libby O'Malley (60 years old, individual coverage, currently paying ~$1,000/month on marketplace)
  - Ashley (31-32 years old, recently pregnant, needs coverage for self, husband, and baby)
- Already Covered: 3 employees have coverage through spouses/military, 1 through Medicare

Budget Considerations
- Current Situation: No specific budget allocated yet; Libby needs to present recommendation to board
- Concerns: Board relationship described as "shaky," uncertain about their willingness to fund benefits
- Benchmark Discussion: $750/month per person discussed as reasonable starting point
- Equity Focus: Libby emphasized importance of equitable policy across all employees despite different needs

ICHRA Structure Options Discussed
- Allowance Types:
  - Same Dollar Amount: Flat rate per employee
  - State-Based Allowances: Different amounts by state to account for cost variations
  - Smart Allowance: Age and location-adjusted for maximum equity
- Coverage Benchmarks: Bronze, Silver, Gold plan median costs
- Dependent Coverage: Additional allowances for family members
- Remaining Funds: Can be used for qualified medical expenses via Thatch debit card (optional feature)

Special Considerations
- Pregnancy: Confirmed not a pre-existing condition; Ashley can get full coverage
- Medicare Employee: Can receive premium reimbursement through ICRA
- Payroll System: Gusto (compatible with Thatch)
- Marketplace Confusion: Libby noted the "Marketplace" terminology in Thatch platform is confusing (refers to wellness vendors, not state exchanges)

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Primary Decision Makers
- Libby O'Malley - Executive Director, Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association
  - Role: Primary contact, benefits administrator, policy decision maker
  - Responsibilities: Present recommendation to board, set allowance structure, manage implementation
  - Context: New to role (hired April 2025), navigating challenging board dynamics

- Board of Directors - Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association
  - Role: Final budget approval authority
  - Responsibilities: Approve benefits budget and policy
  - Context: Mandated insurance implementation but unclear on funding commitment

Employees Requiring Coverage
- Ashley (Employee)
  - Status: 31-32 years old, recently pregnant
  - Coverage Needs: Self, husband, and baby (upon birth)
  - Special Considerations: Qualifying life event when baby arrives

- Libby O'Malley (Also employee)
  - Status: 60 years old, individual coverage
  - Current Cost: ~$1,000/month on marketplace
  - Health Status: Healthy, non-smoker, never hospitalized

- Medicare Employee (Unnamed)
  - Status: Full-time employee with Medicare coverage
  - Opportunity: Can receive premium reimbursement through ICRA

Implementation Support
- Monica Hirschheimer - Thatch Representative
  - Role: Sales and implementation specialist
  - Responsibilities: System setup guidance, allowance structure consultation, ongoing support
  - Background: Works exclusively with small businesses (1-10 employees)

External References
- Monica from Laundry Guys - HR professional who referred Libby to Thatch
  - Previous presentations on ICRA to Libby in February 2024 and recently

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Historical Context
- February 2024: Libby first learned about ICRA during job interview, attended presentation by Monica from Laundry Guys
- April 2025: Libby hired as Executive Director at current organization (no benefits in place)
- Friday, December 11, 2025: Board meeting where insurance mandate was issued (5 days before this call)

Current Timeline
- Tuesday, December 16, 2025: Initial consultation call with Thatch (this meeting)
- December 22, 2025: Current enrollment deadline for January 1, 2026 coverage (may extend 2 days)
- January 1, 2026: Target coverage start date

Critical Moments in Conversation
- 00:05:00 (approx): Libby confirms only 2 of 6 employees need insurance, simplifying implementation
- 00:08:00 (approx): Pregnancy disclosure - confirmed not a barrier to coverage
- 00:15:00 (approx): Discussion of equity in allowance structure - key priority for Libby
- 00:20:00 (approx): Smart Allowance feature demonstrated, showing age/location-based equity
- 00:25:00 (approx): Budget discussion - no firm number from board yet, $750/month discussed as benchmark
- 00:30:00 (approx): Marketplace terminology confusion identified - feedback for product improvement

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By December 18, 2025)
- Monica (Thatch):
  - [ ] Send system access link and setup instructions to Libby immediately after call
  - [ ] Send calendar link for follow-up consultation
  - [ ] Provide follow-up email with key information discussed

- Libby (Prospect):
  - [ ] Create account in Thatch system
  - [ ] Input all 6 employees into system (even those not needing coverage for compliance)
  - [ ] Review allowance structure options (same dollar, state-based, smart allowance)
  - [ ] Explore budget scenarios using system tools

Short-Term Actions (By December 22, 2025)
- Libby:
  - [ ] Schedule follow-up call with Monica to review allowance decisions
  - [ ] Determine preliminary budget recommendation for board
  - [ ] Decide on allowance structure (flat rate vs. smart allowance)
  - [ ] Confirm whether to enable "remaining funds" feature for out-of-pocket expenses
  - [ ] Finalize employee enrollment to meet December 22 deadline (or extended deadline)

Medium-Term Actions (By January 1, 2026)
- Libby:
  - [ ] Present benefits recommendation to board for approval
  - [ ] Communicate benefits offering to all employees
  - [ ] Ensure Ashley and self complete plan selection
  - [ ] Offer ICRA to Medicare employee
  - [ ] Complete any remaining implementation steps with Monica's guidance

Ongoing Responsibilities
- Libby:
  - Manage new employee additions in different states as organization grows
  - Adjust allowances when hiring from new states
  - Monitor for qualifying life events (Ashley's baby arrival)
  - Coordinate with Gusto payroll for pre-tax deductions

- Monica:
  - Provide ongoing support and consultation as needed
  - Available for questions throughout implementation process
  - Calendar open for additional meetings this week

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Organizational Context
- Nonprofit with tight budget constraints
- Executive Director navigating challenging board dynamics
- Strong emphasis on team equity and fairness
- Remote workforce across multiple states
- Growth anticipated but minimal near-term hiring expected

Technical Considerations
- All employees are W-2 (confirmed)
- Payroll through Gusto (compatible)
- No current benefits infrastructure in place
- Need for compliance with offering to all eligible employees

Risk Factors
- Tight timeline to January 1, 2026 start date
- Board budget approval uncertainty
- Executive Director's self-described "shaky ground" with board
- Need to balance equity goals with budget constraints

Opportunities
- Simple implementation with only 2 employees needing coverage
- Potential to offer value to all 6 employees through allowance structure
- Medicare reimbursement opportunity for one employee
- Scalable solution as organization grows

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: 2025-12-16

Prospect: Libby O'Malley, Executive Director - Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association (nonprofit)

Current Situation:
- 6 employees (4 full-time, 2 part-time) across 6 states (TX, FL, GA, NC, OH, PA)
- NO health insurance benefits currently in place
- Only 2 employees need coverage: Libby (age 60, individual) and Ashley (age 31-32, pregnant, needs family coverage)
- 3 employees covered through spouses/military; 1 has Medicare
- Uses Gusto payroll; all W-2 employees
- Libby currently pays ~$1,000/month on marketplace

Priorities:
- Implement ICRA benefits ASAP for equity across team
- Need board-ready recommendation with clear internal policy structure
- Seeking guidance on best practices for allowance structuring (flat dollar vs. percentage-based)
- Balance equity with nonprofit budget constraints

Pain Points/Challenges:
- New ED (started April 2025) tasked with establishing benefits from scratch
- Difficult board relationship; board initially suggested covering only 2 employees who need insurance
- Uncertainty about competitive allowance amounts and structure
- Ashley's pregnancy requires family coverage planning
- Budget limitations as nonprofit organization
- Confusion about marketplace terminology in Thatch platform

Optimization Goals:
- Establish equitable, sustainable benefits policy
- Cover 50%+ of median silver plan (competitive benchmark)
- Create scalable structure for future hires
- Minimize employee out-of-pocket costs while managing organizational budget

Stated Timelines:
- Target start date: 2026-01-01
- Plan selection deadline: 2025-12-22 (possibly extended 2 days)
- Board meeting: 2025-12-11 (5 days prior to call)
- Next steps: Libby to access system, input employees, schedule follow-up with Monica

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Monica (Rep) Owns:
- Send Libby the system access information and instructions to create an account and input employee data
- Send calendar link to schedule a follow-up meeting
- Remain available for questions via email as Libby explores the system

Libby (Prospect) Owns:
- Create account in the Thatch system
- Input all six employees into the system (including those who may not need insurance, as the benefit must be offered to all)
- Explore allowance options and determine budget considerations
- Review plan options for herself, Ashley, and the Medicare-eligible employee
- Prepare questions about allowance structures for follow-up discussion
- Schedule a follow-up meeting with Monica using the calendar link

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Schedule and conduct a follow-up meeting to finalize allowance structure, address remaining questions about the system, and determine next steps toward enrollment. Target is January 1, 2026 coverage start date, with employee plan selection deadline of December 22, 2025 (potentially extended by 2 days).

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__eb.value: Highly Fragmented (<50% in same state + fragmented mix)

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect (Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association) currently does not administer employee benefits at all. The organization has no benefits program in place. Libby O'Malley, the Executive Director, mentioned that when she was hired in April, she discovered the organization offered no benefits and was told by the board that figuring this out was her responsibility as executive director. 

Currently, Libby is purchasing her own individual health insurance through the marketplace, paying just under $1,000 per month. The organization uses Gusto as their payroll system, but there is no benefits administration platform, manual process, or broker relationship in place for employee benefits. 

The board only recently (about a week before this conversation) directed Libby to establish health insurance coverage for employees, making this their first attempt at implementing any kind of employee benefits program.

summary.summaryText:
- Monica captured team size and enrollment needs well, identifying 6 employees and 2 needing coverage.
- Monica missed probing deeper into pain points; next, ask Libby about current challenges and consequences.
- Monica didn't map the decision process; next, clarify board approval steps and timeline with Libby.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Client/Prospect: Daniel's Jewelers (Cindy Stein, VP HR; Joe Donaghy, CFO)

Current Situation:
- Multi-location retail company with employees across California, Arizona, Florida, Texas, Nevada, and New Mexico.
- Approximately 700 employees total, with 219 participating in healthcare plans.
- Currently on group health insurance with multiple plan options through Kaiser (California majority) and UnitedHealthcare (Arizona, Texas, Florida, New Mexico).
- Employee contribution is approximately $209/month for employee-only coverage.
- Facing an 11.8% renewal increase with an April 1, 2026 renewal date.
- Retail jewelry business with high turnover.
- Separate dental and vision coverage in place.

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Escalating year-over-year healthcare costs with unstable renewals.
- Low participation rate (31%) creating anti-selection issues and lack of healthy premium in the risk pool.
- Employee education concerns about transitioning to ICHRA, including understanding plan options, metal tiers, and network selection.
- Busy December season conflicts with benefits decisions.
- Concerns about transitional care issues, such as pregnant employees and established doctor relationships.
- Managing 35+ plan options in California versus current 1-2 plans.

Priorities/Goals:
- Control healthcare costs while maintaining quality benefits.
- Fully evaluate ICHRA as an alternative to group insurance.
- Understand employee impact and disruption.
- Maintain ACA affordability compliance (currently 99% affordable).
- Minimize administrative burden on HR team.
- Maintain good employee experience while meeting budget objectives.

Optimization Goals:
- Achieve cost savings versus the 11.8% renewal (Thatch proposal: $2,411K vs. $2,495K renewal).
- Implement a flat cost-share model: $210 employee-only, $250 first dependent, $150 additional dependents.
- Provide more plan choice while capping employee disruption.
- Leverage individual market stability (25M lives) versus small group volatility.

Stated Timelines:
- Next steps: Follow-up within the next few days/week after 2025-12-16.
- Current renewal deadline: 2026-04-01.
- If proceeding: Short plan year (April 1 to January 1) with deductible reset.
- Future open enrollment recommendation: 2026-11-01 to 2026-11-15 (avoiding busy December season).

Next Steps/Decision:
- Exploring in depth this year after preliminary review last year.
- Keeping ancillary benefits (dental/vision) on group chassis.
- Thatch platform handles multi-carrier billing consolidation.
- Licensed advisors available for employee support (15% utilization typical).
- Plexus continues as broker/consultant partner.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep Actions (Tom/Kaitlin/Thatch Team):
- Share the updated batch analysis spreadsheet with Joe and Cindy with access to modify cost share parameters
- Add benchmark plan details (Gold 1, Gold 25) to the analysis template showing actual plan designs
- Conduct custom analysis comparing Gold 25 vs Gold 1 benchmarks and include silver plan options across different states
- Analyze specific employee samples: California employees on Kaiser (single vs family coverage) and employees in Arizona, Texas, Florida, and New Mexico on UnitedHealthcare plans
- Send follow-up email later today (12/16/2025) after Tom's meetings conclude
- Provide reference customer contact information for Joe/Cindy to discuss implementation experience

Prospect Actions (Joe/Cindy):
- Review the updated analysis spreadsheet and employee cost impact data
- Evaluate sample employee scenarios across different states and plan types
- Assess whether the ICHRA approach is viable for controlling costs while maintaining employee benefits
- Determine if they want to offer the qualified medical expense (QME) benefit for leftover dollars

Next Step for the Deal:
- Schedule a follow-up meeting within the next few days or next week (targeting late December 2025/early January 2026) to review the customized analysis, discuss employee samples, and align on whether to proceed with ICHRA for their April 1, 2026 renewal date
- Timeline is critical as they need to make a decision soon to implement by April 1, 2026 effective date

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
Daniel's Jewelers currently maintains a fully insured group health insurance plan with approximately 700 eligible employees, of which only 219 participate (roughly 31% participation rate). The company uses multiple carriers based on geographic location: Kaiser for the majority of employees in California, and UnitedHealthcare (UHC) for employees in other states including Arizona, Texas, Florida, and New Mexico.

The current plan structure offers limited options, with each individual employee having access to only one plan choice. For the Kaiser plan in California, employees currently pay approximately $209 out of pocket per month for employee-only coverage. The Kaiser plan is an HMO with a $0 deductible, while the UHC plan is a PPO with a $1,000 deductible. The plan includes specific deductibles, copays, pharmacy benefits, and out-of-pocket maximums, though exact plan design details were not explicitly stated in the conversation.

The company is facing an 11.8% renewal increase, with estimated renewal costs of approximately $2,495 (likely in thousands based on context). Their current renewal date is April 1st. In addition to medical coverage, the company maintains separate dental and vision plans that are structured as limited benefit products.

The company has experienced challenges with their group plan structure, including significant turnover (common in retail), variable renewal rates over the years, and anti-selection issues due to low participation rates. The lack of healthy premium from non-participating employees has contributed to renewal instability.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Daniel's Jewelers - ICHRA Evaluation and Proposal

1. Key Points Discussed:

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: Daniel's Jewelers is exploring ICHRA to manage 2026 renewal costs and reduce administrative workload. They face recurring double-digit renewal increases and have a low participation rate in their current health plans. The ICHRA proposal aims to provide cost control, predictability, and administrative simplification.

- Current Situation: The company has approximately 700 eligible employees, with only 219 participating in health plans. They currently offer Kaiser HMO in California and UnitedHealthcare PPO for out-of-state employees. The current renewal is projected at an 11.8% increase.

- ICHRA Proposal: The proposed ICHRA cost is $2,411,000 annually, with a flat cost share model introduced to cap employee out-of-pocket costs. The proposal includes a Gold One benchmark plan, offering flexibility and employee choice.

- Benefits Highlighted: For the employer, ICHRA offers budget predictability, access to a larger risk pool, and reduced administrative complexity. For employees, it provides plan options, licensed advisor support, and the ability to apply unused allowances to qualified medical expenses.

2. Stakeholders Involved:

- Daniel's Jewelers:
  - Joe Donaghy (JMD) - CFO, primary decision-maker, responsible for financial strategy and final approval.
  - Cindy Stein (CCS) - VP of HR, responsible for benefits administration, employee communication, and transition management.

- Plexus Group:
  - Dan Wilke - Lead Benefits Consultant, responsible for strategy advisory and analysis review.
  - Beth Hannes - Supporting Consultant, involved in employee support and implementation considerations.

- Thatch:
  - Tom Hemmingsen - Benefits Advisor, responsible for ICHRA proposal and analysis.
  - Kaitlin Zidar - Solutions Consultant, responsible for technical expertise and implementation support.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps:

- Historical Context: Daniel's Jewelers first explored ICHRA in 2024 but did not proceed. In 2025, they committed to a full evaluation as a cost control strategy.

- Recent Developments:
  - December 2, 2025: Initial ICHRA presentation.
  - December 4, 2025: Analysis review meeting determined ICHRA was not a good fit initially.
  - December 5, 2025: Further discussion on ICHRA structure and employee impact.
  - December 16, 2025: Proposal review with updated analysis and flat cost share model.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties:

- Immediate Actions:
  - Share updated analysis spreadsheet with Joe and Cindy by December 16, 2025.
  - Add benchmark plan details to the analysis within 2-3 days.
  - Conduct multi-state plan analysis before the next meeting.
  - Perform employee-level disruption analysis before the next meeting.

- Short-Term Actions:
  - Schedule a follow-up meeting in late December 2025 or early January 2026.
  - Arrange a reference customer call for Cindy and Joe.

- Medium-Term Decisions:
  - Final decision on ICHRA adoption by January 2026.
  - Determine the strategy for unused allowance dollars

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
Daniel's Jewelers currently administers employee benefits through a broker/third-party service. They work with Plexus Group as their benefits consultant, with Dan Wilke and Beth Hannes serving as their advisors. The broker assists with plan management, dependent count tracking, renewal analysis, and benefits strategy.

Their current setup includes:
- Carriers: Kaiser for California employees and UnitedHealthcare for employees in other states (Florida, Arizona, Texas, New Mexico).
- Plan structure: Limited plan options - primarily one plan per carrier/region.
- Employee access: Employees access their benefits information directly through carrier portals (e.g., myUHC.com for claims history and payment information).
- Payroll integration: Employee contributions are processed through payroll on a pre-tax basis.
- Communications: Cindy (HR) handles employee communications about plan details including deductibles, copays, pharmacy benefits, and out-of-pocket costs.

No specific benefits administration platform (such as Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits) was mentioned. The administration appears to rely on the broker relationship with Plexus for consulting and strategy, combined with direct carrier relationships for enrollment and claims management. Cindy also handles administrative responsibilities, including enrollment tracking and carrier communications. There is no indication of manual processes like spreadsheets or email being used for day-to-day administration.

So, although you may be contributing 70% towards the employee, well, that 70%, the actual dollar amount is going to be higher out of pocket for older employees. And for us, our most important thing in terms of bringing you all to Thatch is you all understand the trade-offs between renewing as is and moving to Thatch. Kaitlin Zidar:
So, yes, you'd be on a family plan, technically. 
JMD:
Okay. So, that's probably simpler. And I may be confusing this issue, but this is different than the self-insured with the caps and administration and the IVNR and all that nonsense. 
Mitchell Andrews:
These are fully insured plans, Joe. Yeah. Okay. 
Kaitlin Zidar:
Yeah, these are fully insured plans. So, since we were talking about the renewal earlier, the carriers actually renew. Each of these plans on an individual basis. So the rates might change year over year, but then you as an individual can change plans if the price becomes not as attainable. 
Mitchell Andrews:
So the example for the California plans, you know, this probably won't happen, but if Kaiser blew up and gave everybody a 22% rate increase, they're going to have options with UnitedHealthcare, with Cigna, with Aetna, with Blue Cross, with Anthem. They're going to have multiple different carriers to select from who, because they are operating on a different business platform, they're not the hospital slash payer insurance company. They are just the insurance company. And maybe they're in the cycle with all of the health systems that their rates are locked in. They might have better rates. Somebody might go to Aetna for a year. And then the following year, when they go through enrollment, Kaiser's gotten their stuff together and they're more competitive. They can switch and you're not having to switch the entire chassis, right? That's been the angst that you've had over the years, changing the chassis, upsetting people who were in Kaiser, right? Not liking the UHC renewal. And it was kind of an all or nothing game, to an extent. Now you're on a chassis that allows you to access. All of those individual markets, something that Kalen and Tom were trying to explain. The consistency when you've got a lot more lives on the individual chassis, and you've got significantly more. Government oversight on individual rates tends to make rates from year to year. Kind of go like this in the individual market versus in the group insurance market, it tends to go like this. 
JMD:
It never goes down, it flatlines and then goes up. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Fair, fair. In your life cycle, certainly, And part of that is because there's 700 people eligible and we've got a little over 200, right? There's we've talked about these. 
JMD:
Yeah, there's split between plants and we can't get record. 
Mitchell Andrews:
We don't have a lot of healthy premium in this group pool that you have. Right. And so you're just saying, look, this hasn't worked for me. That's why I made the comment. This is primarily been used for us. Where it's been attractive for our clients is in that QSR space, because this is not unusual. Where you've got a third of the population that's participating. Even in manufacturing, if it's not good, you're typically in that 50% to 60% range. Versus your more professional industries, you're typically 75% to 95% participation. So you're getting healthy premium with 30% premium, and you get a more consistent average, and you're just playing for a few of the outliers. Now you're losing that healthy premium, who's saying, I can get it from my spouse's plan somewhere else, less expensively. So that that cleaner premium is leaving you. 
JMD:
And we have a lot of turnover, just like those other industries you mentioned, and probably in fewer retail or QSR. So throughout the year, we still have to offer everybody new each month, a whole bunch of same enrollment choices. I would think that that's where the technology makes it clean for them. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Yes. Yeah. And that's. Again, if you look at Trump won when Icra was passed, it was a cool idea. Nobody had the platform. And so people were trying to adapt enrollment platforms to make it worse. But the billing, payment and collection was a real problem for the entire industry. Everybody was paused for a little while with the Biden administration. Are they going to kill this or not? When it was evident, they weren't. Companies like that said, OK, this is going to work. They're not going to kill it. We're going to start investing in the technology platforms to make this work. 
JMD:
And we just make one monthly payment to you guys, or how does that work? Because we're not going to raise 35 million payments. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Yeah, that's yeah, we covered this on a previous call, but we've covered a lot, a lot of ground. So thank you all for going through it. Yeah, like Mitchell said, a lot of the complexity and really where Thash differentiates ourselves is through our technology and us having more of a financial technology background, actually, Joe. And so one of the major problems is, okay, we're not just submitting a payment to one or two carriers, the UHC and Kaiser. We may be submitting payments to 30 different carriers across all different states, across our entire employee base. It's very dramatic. And so we've... Built direct integrations and built infrastructure on our end to ensure that payments happen when they're supposed to happen. So essentially for you, yeah, we bill you for the full premium amount and then the Thatcher platform fees. And then the employees portion goes through payroll, as is the case today. So that's all pre-tax. 
JMD:
And then an employee's experience, currently, I'm on myUHC.com to look at my history. My claims, what's been paid, what I owe, that kind of thing. Each person would then enroll in whatever plan they selected and have similar access. It's not going to be through you guys for that, right? 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Yeah, exactly. They can see some things through us, like their plan, design, you know, like if their enrollment has been actually made, right? We kind of give them like a tracker to see how things are trending there. But yeah, then they'd get emails from the insurance carrier like, hey, here's your login. In our system, we have a little checklist of like, look out for your member ID, and a few other things that employees see as well. 
JMD:
And then we talked about in the case where an employee chooses a plan that's less costly than the amount that we're going to give them, that they would be able to utilize some of those dollars for other medical related activities. Dental or non-covered, medical or gym or whatever. How's that managed? Is that through their Thatch ID or access? 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Yeah. Yep. I know we're at time, so I want to be respectful. I'll answer this and then we could chat through the next steps. But essentially, it's all managed through cash. Now, Joe, again, that's your all's decision as a company, whether you want to offer that. And we can talk more about the trade-offs of offering the ability to use leftover dollars on qualified medical expenses. So think of it more like an FSA. It expires at the end of the year. But yeah, we manage that. So they get a fetched Epic card that they can use and swipe. They can text us and ask if something's a qualified medical expense. And then again, we have that marketplace, which we've gone out and contracted with different kind of point solution companies, like in mental health, fitness products, et cetera. As long as it's qualified medical expense, then they could go in and discover new products and get discounts as well. 
JMD:
And would we keep our same? Limited dental and vision products and plans the way they are structured now. Or would that be something that's thrown into this as well? 
Tom Hemmingsen:
No, keep it, there's. There's no real reason to to switch those. It's like the medical is the the most important piece here. 
Kaitlin Zidar:
So, uh, right, yep, actually, dental and vision are much more attractive. How you have it? 
JMD:
Yeah, yeah, okay, that's what I thought. Um, okay, um, Sydney, I think we talked about this and I don't know what this sounds like. You're going to provide us some version of this spreadsheet or ability. What I thought we would do is just pick a few employees in each of the different markets and see what the choices are now. But one other question I had is you were talking about, Caitlin, the published rate structures or plan structures. Is there a better time of year to adopt the NICRA? I mean, we're currently in April 1. We've had to push that in some prior years by a month or two, but is there a better renewal date for this kind of structure? 
Kaitlin Zidar:
For year one, my understanding is you are looking at this for the April 1st effective date. Is that right? 
JMD:
That's right. 
Kaitlin Zidar:
So I would just advise that you go in eyes wide open that the individual market does align to a January 1st effective date. So if you do, proceed with the April 1st. Then just know that you are looking at a short plan year temporarily. So deductibles and everything will reset come January 1st. And that's part of the upfront communication going in making this decision. 
JMD:
And on a renewal following year, what's the involvement of the employees? I mean, what we don't really want to be dealing with is a lot of distraction in December when they're trying to sell jewelry. Trying to figure out their health care. 
Kaitlin Zidar:
Yep, we try to make that as seamless as possible, where there is a bit of uncertainty with what we contain, as much as we can, with what we can control. We partner closely with the carriers, but then we also recognize that, like Mitchell was explaining earlier, there is the economics that we don't have full control on the carrier side. So if an individual is in a plan that is not renewing into the next year, we guide them to the closest match plan as what they currently are in, but that's where an employee does need to make that evaluation. Do I want a different carrier? Do I like this current carrier? And there is some attention required to make the most educated decision going into the following year. Generally speaking, we are seeing more carriers introducing plan options than removing plan options, But there is that moment of open enrollment. That is usually in the fall. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
And, and Joe, when is it, like, busiest for you? Is it December? Is it late November? 
JMD:
The next nine days. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
The next nine days. Well, then, then, the answer can be pretty simple. It's like, we start your open enrollment 11-1 and it goes till 11-15, right? So you can, you can set whatever window you want from November 1st to December 15th. So given that you're renewing. There isn't a need to have to push that at all. So if we want to do 11-1 to 11-15, that's a very common open enrollment date for many of our customers, you know, in your space. And then also ones who, you know, want to get it done, like before the Thanksgiving holidays generally, as well. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Tom, what's the latest date you've seen rates be published in the individual market? Yeah. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
I mean, this year, Mitchell, it was like October 30th. Like, it's, it's pretty, but what I can say is our... Team who is much smarter than I, the ones that are the data scientists and the people figuring all this stuff out, we got within a few percentage points of the projected rates, based off of the CMS filings and some other data sources as well. So we can't finalize it, but we can have those projections. And what I did with other customers was like, all right, we have those projections. And then as soon as they're finalized, we're getting on the phone, we're reviewing the renewal, we're getting it dialed in, and then we're launching from there. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Yeah, because it's both CMS and the State Insurance commissioner. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Yeah. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Right, because the states will push back. I mean, if you google this topic, Joe and Cindy, you'll see states like Vermont, who started at a 21 to 24 percent increase for individual rates. And that was the rage kind of in August and September. We knew it was coming down. Because that was the first foray, right? Hey, here's the car. You know, it's $10,000. Well, wait a minute. I really think it should be six. And the state's kind of banter back and forth. The State Insurance commission, as well as CMS, is looking at it. And it's a joint effort to try and get their final, This is what their increase will be on their individual book of business. Yeah. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
And then we also, like every year that goes by, Mitchell, we're getting more data as well to actually look at. like, all right, how did the initial CMS? Filings come in compared to what actually finalized. So we have multiple data sources we can look at to to come to a as accurate as as one as possible. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Um, Vermont and New Hampshire seem to be the outliers because small population, very liberal voting block and they want everything and don't worry about the cost. Yes, yes, political comment. It's just what happens in the state. So yeah, yeah, Okay. 
Kaitlin Zidar:
There are a lot of factors at play. Yeah. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
But so I think we can share this with you. I'll send a follow-up email. And then later today, after I'm off of a few meetings, and then, yeah, maybe, you know, we can plan to sync in the next few days, next week or something. I know it's coming up on the holidays and it's your all busy season. 
Mitchell Andrews:
You'll have Joe's attention if you're buying some jewelry, Tom. So you might want to go on their website. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
I know I'm not, and I don't even have a Christmas gift for my wife yet. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Um, Joe can take care of you, Joe, you're in good company. 
JMD:
Joe took care of me. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Once before, that was in the old days. We actually walked into the vault. 
JMD:
Yeah, oh, that's when we were based in Chicago. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Yes, if you're based in L.A. 
JMD:
you can walk into the vault. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Oh, I do see you have the I'm on the website right now. Yeah. 
Mitchell Andrews:
I mean, I'm looking at your watch. You can probably upgrade. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
I was, I was going to say, I saw the pre-owned Rolex was right there, But I don't think I'm going to get my wife. This is my wedding gift. 
Mitchell Andrews:
And I don't think I'm going to be able to put that watch in a trophy case and just say I want to see it all the time, but I want to wear something else. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
I know. Well, my well, now I have two sons. And so I've always been like, I want to pass that to them one day. So the first one, I was like, all right, I got it. Now I'm telling my wife. I'm like, well. The second already is going to get the short end of the stick and his birthday is on December 23rd. So he's already getting gyps. 
Mitchell Andrews:
You've already bought the watch. Just pick out the one you want. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Exactly. Well, thank you all. Thank you all for taking the time. Yeah, I really appreciate it, Cindy and Joe. Great questions. Mitchell and Dan really, really appreciate the partnership. And I mean, you know, Cindy and Joe, it's. A lot of decisions to be made, but I love working with the Plexus group. And you got some great advisors there to help with the right strategy. And there's trade-offs to everything. 
JMD:
Yeah, I mean, last year we heard about this. We looked at it. We didn't really look at it in any kind of depth. And the question is, and the goal this year was to at least fully explore it and see whether or not we think it's a viable thing in terms of controlling costs. And still providing benefits to the employees. I think I'm getting more and more educated on whether or not I can say that, yes, we looked at it, and no, we don't want to do it, or yes, we want to do it. So it's been very helpful. I appreciate it. Of course. 
Cindy Stein:
Thank you. 
Tom Hemmingsen:
Of course. 
Mitchell Andrews:
Thank you guys. Everybody have a wonderful afternoon and we'll talk soon. Great. 
JMD:
Thank you. 
Cindy Stein:
Take care. 
Dan Wilke:
Bye-bye.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-08

Client/Prospect: Infinite Therapy Solutions (Representatives: Poonam, Hillary)

Current State:
- Traditional group health insurance with only 4 employees enrolled (2 are owners).
- Currently using Omnia Silver plan with a $1,500 deductible and $9,200 out-of-pocket max.
- Payroll provider: PayMedia.
- Broker: Liberty (Samantha Winter).
- 60-day waiting period for new hires.
- Frequent hiring (new employees monthly).
- Coverage limited to New Jersey; two new hires located in Florida.
- Group plan with Blue Cross Blue Shield, paying 50% of employee-only rate for two employees.

Pain Points:
- Rising healthcare costs and a 23% renewal increase for 2025.
- Marketplace rates have increased, making individual coverage less affordable.
- Limited knowledge of healthcare plan options beyond the current Silver plan.
- Current plan inadequate for Florida-based employees.
- Confusion about HRA allowance model and benchmarking methodology.
- Extremely tight timeline due to government shutdown delaying marketplace rates.

Priorities:
- Cost reduction and minimizing the impact of the 23% increase.
- Making healthcare coverage more attractive to employees.
- Contributing 50% toward employee healthcare costs.
- Maintaining similar coverage level to the current plan.
- Ensuring equitable benefits across the workforce.
- Quick implementation due to tight deadline.
- Managing employee communication and perception.

Challenges:
- Understanding how the new system works with frequent new hires.
- Managing payroll deductions and administrative tasks.
- Uncertainty about employee plan selection behavior and preferences.
- Difficulty understanding cost implications of various contribution strategies.
- Concern about optics of increasing employer contribution percentage even though dollar amount decreases.
- Need to educate employees on new Thatch platform quickly.
- Managing two separate company enrollments.
- Owners/partners of an LLP are ineligible to participate in Thatch, requiring separate enrollment.

Optimization Goals:
- Increase employee enrollment in healthcare benefits.
- Provide 50% employer contribution.
- Simplify benefits administration.
- Achieve cost savings versus the 23% renewal increase.
- Implement age/location-adjusted allowances for equity.
- Provide national coverage access.

Stated Timelines:
- December 8, 2025, afternoon: Sales agreement to be sent.
- December 9, 2025: Employee education meetings scheduled (daytime and 6:30-7pm sessions).
- December 15, 2025: Employee election deadline for 2026-01-01 effective coverage.
- Deadline for employee enrollment extended to December 19, 2025.
- Owners to enroll separately by December 31, 2025, for a January 1, 2026, start date.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep (Isra Ahmed/Thatch) Owns:
- Send quote link to prospect team (Melissa, Steve, LeighAnn, Samantha) - COMPLETED during call
- Remain available to answer any follow-up questions about the proposal

Prospect (Melissa, Steve, LeighAnn, Samantha) Owns:
- Review the Thatch quote link and proposal details
- Compare Thatch pricing ($11,420/month employer cost) against Aetna renewal ($10,357/month)
- Evaluate the EPO-only limitation in New Jersey and impact on employee access to Pennsylvania/New York providers
- Discuss internally how to handle partnership owners (Michael and Stephen VandeVried) who cannot participate in the ICRA platform
- Determine if the minimum 10 enrolled employees requirement can be met if doing an hourly/salaried class carve-out
- Reach out to Isra if they have questions or want to move forward

Next Step for Overall Deal:
No specific follow-up meeting scheduled. The opportunity appears unlikely to progress due to:
- Higher costs than renewal ($1,063/month more expensive)
- Limited network access (EPO only in NJ vs. current nationwide PPO)
- Complexity with partnership owners needing separate coverage
- Potential compliance issues with Aetna if splitting the group

The prospect team will likely stay with their current Aetna group plan despite the 42% renewal increase.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect's current benefits plan is with Aetna as the carrier. The plan design is a POS 3000 (Point of Service plan with a $3,000 deductible). The company contributes 65% of the premium across all tiers (employee only, employee + spouse, employee + children, and family coverage). 

Currently, 13 employees are enrolled in the plan out of 73 total employees (approximately 61 full-time employees). The company recently received a 42% renewal increase from Aetna/AFA. The current monthly employer cost is approximately $10,357 based on renewal numbers.

The workforce consists primarily of hourly employees (with only 5-6 salaried employees) and experiences high turnover due to the seasonal nature of the business. Most enrolled employees are above 45 years of age. The company is located in New Jersey (Belvedere and Morristown area) and is structured as an LLC partnership. The funding type was not explicitly mentioned in the conversation.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.value: - Unknown

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Infinite Therapy Solutions - ICHRA Exploration and Implementation

1. Key Points Discussed

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: The primary driver for exploring ICHRA is to manage significant 2026 renewal costs, with the current group plan facing a 42% increase. The employer aims to reduce healthcare costs and administrative workload, particularly due to the challenges of managing a seasonal workforce with high turnover.

- Current Situation: The company currently offers a traditional group health insurance plan (Aetna POS 3000) with a 65% employer contribution. The workforce includes 73 employees, with only 13 currently enrolled in health benefits. The company faces administrative challenges due to frequent hiring and turnover.

- ICHRA Solution Proposed: ICHRA allows employees to receive a pre-tax allowance to purchase individual plans. Two allowance models were discussed: a flat rate for all employees or a variable rate based on demographics. Thatch handles all administration, including premium payments, enrollments, and compliance.

- Compliance and Cost Challenges: Key compliance issues include class carve-out restrictions and partnership owner eligibility. The ICHRA solution was found to be more expensive than the current renewal, with geographic coverage limitations and age demographics impacting costs.

2. Stakeholders Involved

- Infinite Therapy Solutions (Prospect/Customer):
  - Poonam: Co-owner, financial decision-maker, and benefits administrator.
  - Hillary Fryczynski: Co-owner, responsible for employee communication and operational oversight.

- Thatch (Vendor):
  - Caroline Clark: ICHRA solution specialist and primary point of contact for implementation.
  - Molly Marshall: Channel Partnerships team, supporting broker relationships.

- Liberty (Broker):
  - Samantha Winter: Primary broker, coordinating ICHRA exploration and compliance guidance.
  - LeighAnn Panas: Supporting broker, providing compliance guidance and carrier relationship management.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps

- December 04, 2025: Initial discovery call and product demonstration.
- December 05, 2025: Follow-up meeting to review cost analysis and contribution recommendations.
- December 08, 2025: Decision made to proceed with ICHRA; selected 50% contribution at 50th percentile Silver benchmark.
- December 15, 2025: Critical deadline for employee plan selections to ensure January 1, 2026, coverage effective date.
- December 16, 2025: ICHRA exploration meeting, identifying compliance and cost challenges.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties

- Immediate Actions:
  - Quote Review and Analysis: Melissa, Steve Vande Vrede, Samantha Winter, and LeighAnn Panas to review Thatch quote link by December 23, 2025.
  - Owner Coverage Solution Research: Samantha Winter to provide resource link for independent marketplace enrollment by December 20, 2025.
  - Internal Stakeholder Discussion: Melissa and Steve Vande Vrede to discuss ICHRA findings with Michael Vande Vrede by December 23, 2025.

- Strategic Decisions Needed:
  - Renewal Strategy Determination: Ownership team to decide on renewal strategy before Aetna renewal effective date.
  - Alternative Carrier Exploration: Samantha Winter and LeighAnn Panas to pursue quotes

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value: The prospect currently administers employee benefits through a combination of broker services and manual processes. They rely on brokers from Liberty Company, specifically Samantha Winter and LeighAnn Panas, to manage their group health insurance plan. The administration process is relatively manual, involving paper forms for employees who decline coverage and a heavy reliance on broker support for tasks such as preparing census information, obtaining quotes, and providing guidance on compliance and plan options. There is no mention of using a benefits administration platform like Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits, indicating that the process is broker-managed and manual. The brokers play a crucial role in coordinating meetings with vendors and assisting with plan selection and renewals. The prospect has a small enrolled population, with 13 employees enrolled out of 73 total employees, and they depend heavily on their broker relationship for benefits administration support.

attributes.title: Samantha Winter and Caroline Clark

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
ACCOUNT NOTES - Thatch Benefits Setup

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

Account: Brian Williams' Company

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED:

Note: The conversation did not explicitly discuss ICHRA or 2026 renewal cost management. Instead, the discussion focused on configuring Thatch benefits with a flat allowance structure.

Benefits Structure Clarified:
- Employer is providing a flat allowance of approximately $2,000-$2,100 per month for employee + family coverage
- Allowance breakdown: $500 for employee, $500 for first dependent (spouse), $500 per additional dependent
- Total family allowance aggregates and applies to the chosen family plan premium (not limited to individual employee portion)
- Unused allowance funds roll over month-to-month but expire December 31st of each calendar year
- Employer is providing 100% premium coverage, eliminating employee payroll deductions

Payroll Integration:
- Payroll system: Deal (already synced with Thatch)
- Payroll schedule: Semi-monthly (15th and 30th/31st)
- First payroll date: January 30, 2026 (originally planned for January 1st but delayed)
- No payroll deduction setup required since employer covers 100% of premiums

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED:

Brian Williams
- Role: Employer/Business Owner/Decision Maker
- Responsibilities: Final approval on coverage start dates, employee enrollment decisions, account configuration

Barbara (Last name not provided)
- Role: Employee to be enrolled
- Status: Currently not a W-2 employee; will transition to payroll employee on January 16, 2026
- Current Coverage: Has existing coverage through end of February 2026
- Responsibilities: Will need to select benefits plan once eligible

Monica Hirschheimer
- Role: Thatch Benefits Representative/Account Manager
- Responsibilities: Account setup guidance, benefits configuration support, clarifying eligibility rules, coordinating coverage start dates

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS:

December 16, 2025 - Configuration call completed; benefits structure confirmed

January 16, 2026 - Barbara's official start date as W-2 employee on payroll

January 30, 2026 - First payroll run through Deal

TBD (February 1 or March 1, 2026) - Barbara's benefits coverage start date (pending Brian's decision)
- February 1, 2026 option discussed
- March 1, 2026 option discussed (since Barbara has coverage through end of February)

End of February 2026 - Barbara's current coverage expires

60-day enrollment window - Employees have 60 days from offer date to enroll in benefits plan (benefits start the following month after enrollment)

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES:

IMMEDIATE - Brian Williams (By end of December 2025):
- Confirm Barbara's preferred benefits coverage start date: February 1, 2026 OR March 1, 2026
- Communicate decision to Monica Hirschheimer
- Discuss timing preference with Barbara based on her current coverage ending February 28, 2026

PENDING BRIAN'S DECISION - Monica Hirschheimer:
- Update coverage start date in Thatch system once Brian confirms
- Ensure eligibility calculations align with chosen start date
- Monitor for any questions during slower period (Monica indicated availability)

JANUARY 2026 - Barbara:
- Once coverage start date is confirmed and communicated, enroll in benefits plan within 60-day window
- Select appropriate family plan based on $2,000-$2,100 monthly allowance

ONGOING - Monica Hirschheimer:
- Available for additional questions as they arise
- Monitor account setup and ensure smooth transition to active benefits

OPEN ITEMS:
- Coverage start date confirmation (February vs. March 2026)
- Verification of eligibility rules for employee starting mid-month (January 16) if January 1 coverage were desired (determined unnecessary since Barbara has existing coverage)

ACCOUNT STATUS: Active setup in progress; awaiting coverage start date confirmation from employer.
