• The prospect (Anna Boon) has a meeting scheduled for the evening of December 16, 2025 ("tonight") with a group of 10 people to discuss and presumably finalize the benefits plan decision

• For 2026: The prospect plans to maintain a salary dynamic allowance for all employees including dependent coverage as a "transition year"

• For 2027: The prospect intends to make structural changes including switching Rachel to hourly status, moving to individual-only coverage (no dependents), and implementing a flat allowance structure

• The immediate decision appears to be happening on December 16, 2025, with the implementation timeline set for 2026 and further modifications planned for 2027

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes - Meeting with Anna Boon

Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Participants: Anna Boon (Customer), Kameron Schmidt (Thatch Representative)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Healthcare Benefits Strategy for 2026-2027

2026 Transition Year Approach:
- Decision made to maintain salaried dynamic allowance structure for ALL employees in 2026, including dependent coverage
- This approach chosen over switching Rachel to hourly immediately, as it provides a smoother transition period
- Estimated budget: ~$25K for existing employees plus coverage for new hire
- Rationale: Avoids disruption while organization transitions to long-term strategy

2027 and Beyond - Long-term Strategy:
- Plan to switch to individual-only coverage (no dependent coverage) starting 2027
- Rachel will be reclassified to hourly with flat allowance in 2027 to maintain her coverage level
- All other salaried employees will remain on dynamic allowance but individual-only
- This change will significantly reduce costs and administrative complexity

Key Decision Factors:
- Priest wants to maintain salaried structure for new hires
- Current employee population analysis shows most don't need dependent coverage:
  - Andrew: Individual coverage only
  - Patrick: Will be individual after wife switches to Medicare
  - Kenny: Has Medicaid coverage
- Future hires unlikely to need extensive dependent coverage

Allowance Structure Decisions

Dynamic vs. Flat Allowance:
- Dynamic allowance preferred for salaried employees as it allows more efficient use of dollars
- Enables better coverage across diverse employee needs
- Flat allowance will be used only for Rachel (hourly classification) starting 2027

Coverage Levels:
- Maintaining first percentile gold coverage standard
- Employees working 30+ hours considered full-time (eligible for benefits)
- Excess allowance policy: If implemented for one employee, must apply to all (decision pending)

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Anna Boon
- Role: Benefits Administrator/HR Lead
- Responsibilities: 
  - Developing benefits strategy and recommendations
  - Communicating changes to priest and 10-person group
  - Managing implementation timeline
  - Budget planning and cost management

Priest (Name not specified)
- Role: Final Decision Maker
- Responsibilities:
  - Approving benefits structure changes
  - Setting policy on salaried vs. hourly classifications
  - Budget approval

Kameron Schmidt (Thatch)
- Role: Benefits Consultant/Account Manager
- Responsibilities:
  - Providing technical guidance on allowance structures
  - Reviewing communication materials
  - Clarifying compliance requirements (30-hour full-time threshold)
  - Supporting implementation

Current Employees:
- Rachel: Needs dependent coverage; will transition to hourly classification in 2027
- Andrew: Individual coverage only
- Patrick: Currently needs dependent coverage; wife transitioning to Medicare
- Kenny: Has Medicaid coverage
- New Hire (TBD): Starting soon; coverage needs unknown

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

December 16, 2025 (Meeting Date):
- Anna finalized 2026-2027 transition strategy after weekend consideration
- Reviewed and validated communication plan with Kameron
- Confirmed spreadsheet calculations and budget projections

Key Decision Point - Friday before meeting:
- Anna spoke with priest who insisted on maintaining salaried structure for new hires
- This conversation shaped the transition year approach

Tonight (December 16, 2025):
- Anna scheduled to present plan to 10-person group
- Critical approval meeting for 2026 benefits structure

2026 (Entire Year):
- Transition year with current structure maintained
- All employees on salaried dynamic allowance with dependent coverage option
- Budget: Approximately $25K+ for current staff plus new hire

2027 (Target Implementation):
- Major structural changes take effect
- Switch to individual-only coverage for salaried employees
- Rachel reclassified to hourly with flat allowance
- Significant cost savings expected

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate (December 16, 2025 - Tonight):
- Responsible Party: Anna Boon
- Action: Present benefits strategy to 10-person group
- Deliverable: Secure approval for 2026 transition year approach
- Status: Pending

Short-term (Before 2026 Plan Year Begins):
- Responsible Party: Anna Boon
- Actions:
  - Finalize 2026 benefits documentation
  - Communicate plan to all employees
  - Process new hire enrollment
  - Confirm Patrick's wife's Medicare transition timeline
- Deadline: Before January 1, 2026

Mid-term (During 2026):
- Responsible Party: Anna Boon with Kameron Schmidt support
- Actions:
  - Monitor actual costs vs. budget projections
  - Track employee coverage utilization
  - Prepare detailed 2027 transition plan
  - Develop communication strategy for 2027 changes
- Deadline: Throughout 2026, with Q4 2026 focus on 2027 planning

Long-term (2027 Implementation):
- Responsible Party: Anna Boon
- Actions:
  - Reclassify Rachel to hourly status
  - Implement flat allowance for Rachel
  - Switch all salaried employees to individual-only coverage
  - Remove dependent coverage option (except for Rachel's flat allowance)
  - Communicate changes well in advance to affected employees
- Deadline: January 1, 2027

Follow-up with Kameron:
- Responsible Party: Anna Boon
- Action: Report outcome of tonight's meeting
- Status: Kameron "eagerly awaits" results

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Communication Corrections Made:
- Corrected "Medicaid" to "Medicare" in reference to Patrick's wife's coverage
- Confirmed 30-hour threshold for full-time status (not 32 hours)

Documentation Reviewed:
- Email communication to priest (reviewed and approved by Kameron)
- Spreadsheet with budget projections and allowance calculations
- Dynamic vs. flat allowance comparison notes

Complexity Factors:
- Anna must explain strategy to both priest and 10-person group clearly
- Multiple employee situations requiring different coverage approaches
- Balancing cost management with adequate employee coverage
- Compliance requirements for offering benefits equitably

Risk Mitigation:
- Transition year approach reduces disruption
- Maintains coverage for all employees during 2026
- Provides time to communicate 2027 changes effectively
- Allows for adjustment based on new hire's actual needs

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: 2025-12-16

Current Situation:
- Religious organization with multiple employees requiring healthcare coverage through Thatch
- Current employees: Rachel (multiple dependents), Patrick (wife transitioning to Medicare), Andrew (individual coverage), Kenny (has Medicare)
- New hire expected in 2026 with unknown dependent status
- Currently using salaried dynamic allowance structure with dependent coverage

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Overpaying to cover dependents across the organization
- Priest wants to maintain salaried structure for all new hires
- Complex coverage situation difficult to explain to leadership and 10-person board
- Switching Rachel to hourly this year doesn't solve long-term coverage inefficiencies
- Patrick needs dependent coverage for 2026 (wife switching to Medicare), which forces offering dependent coverage to all employees

Priorities:
- Maintain standardized approach that's easy to communicate
- Reduce costs while still covering employees adequately
- Keep priest's preference for salaried employees
- Ensure compliance (offering coverage equally across employee classes)

Optimization Goals:
- Use 2026 as transition year with current structure (salaried dynamic allowance with dependent coverage for all)
- Switch to individual-only coverage starting 2027 (no dependent coverage)
- Move Rachel to hourly employee class in 2027 with flat allowance to maintain her coverage level
- More efficient use of healthcare dollars through targeted individual coverage

Timeline:
- 2026: Maintain status quo - all employees on salaried dynamic allowance with dependent coverage (~$25K budget)
- 2027 and beyond: Switch to individual-only coverage for salaried employees; Rachel moves to hourly class with flat allowance

Decision Points:
- Need to determine whether to provide excess allowance to employees (must apply consistently)
- 30+ hours = full-time for hourly employees requiring coverage

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Anna (Prospect) Owns:
- Present the healthcare coverage transition plan to the group of 10 people at tonight's meeting
- Send finalized email to the priest explaining the 2026 healthcare plan structure
- Implement 2026 plan: maintain salaried dynamic allowance for all employees with dependent coverage included (approximately $25K budget)
- Decide whether to provide excess allowance to employees who don't use their full allocation (must apply consistently across all employees)

Kameron (Rep) Owns:
- Await feedback from Anna's presentation and priest meeting
- No immediate action items; available for follow-up questions as Anna implements the plan

Overall Deal Next Step:
Anna will follow up with Kameron after tonight's meeting (12/16/2025) to report how the presentation went and confirm final implementation details for the 2026 plan. The long-term strategy involves transitioning Rachel to hourly status and switching to individual-only coverage (no dependents) in 2027.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently administers employee benefits manually using spreadsheets and email. Anna Boon created a spreadsheet to analyze and calculate different allowance structures for employees, including comparing dynamic versus flat allowance models. She communicates benefits decisions and explanations via email, including sending detailed communications to their priest (who appears to have decision-making authority) and preparing to present to a group of 10 people. 

The organization is working with Thatch as a third-party service provider/broker. Kameron Schmidt from Thatch is consulting with Anna on benefits structure, allowance calculations, compliance requirements (such as the 30-hour full-time threshold), and helping her transition their benefits approach. Anna is responsible for the workflow of analyzing options, creating financial projections, obtaining approval from leadership (the priest), and communicating changes to the broader team.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Current State:
- Crossroads is using Thatch for benefits administration and Workday for payroll/HR, conducting 2025 year-end W-2 reconciliation.
- Employers, including Crossroads, are requesting post-enrollment FAQs for 2026.
- Carrier processing delays are being experienced, particularly with CareFirst, Blue Cross of Texas, and Blue Cross of Minnesota.
- Workday payroll system operates on a biweekly pay schedule with 26 pay periods annually.

Priorities:
- Create a collated FAQ document for employers covering post-enrollment expectations.
- Proactively notify employers about known carrier delays.
- Manage late December enrollment volume and cutoff dates.
- Ensure accurate year-to-date pre-tax and post-tax deduction reporting and complete W-2 reconciliation.
- Reconcile employer medical allowance amounts between Workday and Thatch systems.

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Carrier delays, with 3-4 weeks for physical medical cards.
- Discrepancies between Workday and Thatch year-to-date reports for employer medical contributions.
- Thatch system calculates monthly while client operates on a biweekly schedule, creating mismatches.
- Historical data entry errors and lack of trust in Thatch reporting accuracy.
- Late enrollments between December 22-28 create poor member experiences due to January 1 coverage gaps.

Optimization Goals:
- Improve communication channels for carrier delay notifications.
- Develop ICHRA-specific processes with carrier partners.
- Create scalable FAQ resources for employers.
- Streamline reconciliation process and reduce manual Excel work for 2026.
- Systematic solution for biweekly vs. monthly calculation alignment.

Stated Timelines:
- Immediate need for an FAQ document for the current OEP cycle.
- Critical decision period for enrollment cutoffs is December 22-28, 2025.
- December 22, 2025: Employee deadline for qualified medical expense documentation.
- January 12, 2026: Internal deadline for documentation (extensions available).
- 2025-12-18: Hard deadline for final reconciliation numbers.
- 2025-12-19: Complete EIB (payroll input file).
- 2025-12-22: Payroll processing deadline for final 2025 pay period (pay date 2025-12-26).

Action Items:
- Thatch team (Zafreen, Ryan, Caroline, Mateo) forming working group to resolve employer medical calculation methodology.
- Review 20+ flagged employees with discrepancies before Thursday deadline.
- Determine accurate amounts owed to/from employees for year-end reconciliation.

- Assemble a working group including Ryan, Caroline, Mateo, and finance team members to resolve the employer medical/allowance reporting discrepancy issue

externalOpportunity.title: Treatment Centers HoldCo, LLC (dba Cross - Renewal - 2025

d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.title: Notes
d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.value:
Call #1

Call Date / Timestamp: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Client Name / Account: Emily Bruns / Crossroads  
Call Type: Troubleshooting

1. Objectives
- Reconcile year-end medical deduction discrepancies between Crossroads' Workday system and Thatch's year-to-date reporting
- Resolve employer medical (allowance) calculation issues affecting W-2 reporting

2. Key Updates / Progress
- Blocker Identified: Thatch's employer medical (allowance) reporting does not accurately account for biweekly pay schedules (26 pay periods vs. 12 monthly calculations)
- Root Cause: Thatch system calculates allowances on a monthly basis, but Crossroads operates on biweekly payroll, creating mathematical discrepancies when months have 3 pay periods
- Medical Pre-Tax & Post-Tax: Most discrepancies explained by terminations, coverage timing issues, or carrier cancellation delays
- Specific Cases Reviewed: Sarah Johnson and Tanya Martin showed employer medical discrepancies that don't reconcile with expected calculations
- System Limitation: No month-to-month allowance change tracking available in Thatch platform without reviewing individual payroll reports

3. Client Input / Feedback
- Emily expressed frustration with Thatch reporting accuracy: "I don't trust you guys' reporting numbers"
- Critical deadline: Emily needs accurate reconciliation data by Thursday night (December 18, 2025) at 5:00 PM Eastern for W-2 processing
- Payroll must be processed Monday, December 22, 2025
- Client concern: "From an employer perspective, you guys are a facilitator of our plans, your numbers should be accurate"
- Emily identified ~20 employees requiring individual investigation beyond employer medical issues
- Specific problem employees flagged: Judith Hardin and Elizabeth Hines (known account issues)

4. Action Items
- [Zafreen Arefy] → Assemble working group with payroll team, Caroline (servicing), and Mateo to address employer medical calculation methodology → 2025-12-17
- [Zafreen Arefy & Ryan Hanchett] → Investigate 20 flagged employees from Emily's list and provide explanations → 2025-12-17 (before scheduled call)
- [Zafreen Arefy] → Review Judith Hardin and Elizabeth Hines accounts specifically due to known issues → 2025-12-17
- [Thatch Team] → Provide accurate reconciliation numbers for employer medical that account for biweekly pay schedule → 2025-12-18 (by 5:00 PM ET)
- [Emily Bruns] → Complete EIB (payroll integration file) for W-2 processing → 2025-12-19
- [Emily Bruns] → Submit payroll to team → 2025-12-20

5. Notes
- Emily had been incorrectly entering employee premium amounts instead of allowance amounts earlier in the year, contributing to some discrepancies
- The 2026 date display issue in Thatch platform caused initial confusion during reconciliation
- Penny rounding occurs due to biweekly conversion, but doesn't account for the magnitude of discrepancies found
- Example discrepancy: Sarah Johnson showed $58.92 difference; Tanya Martin showed $124 difference
- Rehire cases (e.g., Andrea Shipman) present additional complexity with missed pay periods
- Some terminated employees show Crossroads owes them money back, requiring verification before processing refunds
- Thatch made methodology changes mid-year affecting how coverage dates are displayed for terminated employees
- Regular check-in meeting scheduled for December 17, 2025 to address non-employer-medical questions

Granola Summary

Objectives so far:
- Reconcile year-end 2025 medical deduction discrepancies between Crossroads Workday and Thatch reporting systems
- Resolve employer medical allowance calculation methodology issues
- Ensure accurate W-2 reporting for tax year 2025
- Investigate ~20 flagged employee accounts with specific discrepancies

Progress made:
- Identified root cause: Thatch calculates employer allowances monthly while Crossroads operates biweekly payroll (26 vs. 12 periods)
- Confirmed medical pre-tax and post-tax discrepancies are mostly explainable (terminations, coverage timing)
- Narrowed focus to employer medical calculation methodology as primary issue
- Assembled cross-functional team (payroll, servicing) to address calculation problem
- Documented specific employee cases requiring investigation

Outstanding issues:
- Thatch's employer medical reporting doesn't accurately reflect biweekly pay schedule reality
- Mathematical discrepancies ranging from $58-$124+ per employee for employer allowances
- No readily available month-to-month allowance change tracking in Thatch platform
- ~20 employees require individual account investigation
- Judith Hardin and Elizabeth Hines accounts have known issues affecting accuracy
- Rehire cases (Andrea Shipman) show missed deductions requiring clarification
- Some terminated employees may be owed refunds, requiring verification

Next steps:
- Working group to develop solution for biweekly vs. monthly calculation discrepancy by 2025-12-18
- Zafreen and Ryan to investigate 20 flagged employees before 2025-12-17 meeting
- Provide Emily with accurate reconciliation data by 2025-12-18, 5:00 PM ET (hard deadline)
- Emily to complete EIB file by 2025-12-19 for payroll processing
- Hold scheduled check-in on 2025-12-17 to address non-employer-medical questions
- Long-term: Thatch product team to review billing/reporting improvements based on Emily's feedback

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect's current benefits plan includes the following structural elements:

- The company uses Thatch as their benefits facilitator/administrator.
- They operate on a biweekly pay schedule with 26 pay periods per year.
- The benefits structure includes three deduction categories: medical pre-tax, medical post-tax, and employer medical (employer allowance/contribution).
- Employees receive an employer allowance toward their health coverage premiums, and they pay the difference between their actual premium amount and the allowance through payroll deductions.
- The company uses Workday as their payroll processing system.
- Coverage periods and allowance amounts vary by employee, with examples showing monthly allowances ranging from approximately $315 to $537 per employee.
- The plan includes provisions for coverage continuation and reconciliation when employees terminate or experience qualifying life events.

Specific details about the insurance carrier, funding type (level-funded, fully insured, or self-funded), and plan design (PPO, HDHP, HMO) are not mentioned in the conversations. However, there is a reference to HSA-supported plans and employer allowances.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Crossroads and Thatch - Year-End Reconciliation and ICHRA Context

1. Key Points Discussed:

- ICHRA and 2026 Renewal Costs: While the conversations primarily focused on payroll reconciliation and reporting issues, the underlying theme of managing costs and reducing administrative workload aligns with the employer's interest in ICHRA. The discussions on operational improvements, carrier delays, and FAQ development indirectly support the goal of streamlining processes and managing costs effectively.

- Payroll Reconciliation Challenges: Significant discrepancies were identified between Crossroads' Workday system and Thatch's reports, particularly concerning employer medical allowances and pre-tax/post-tax deductions. The root causes included differences in calculation methodologies (monthly vs. biweekly) and system limitations in reporting.

- System Limitations and Solutions: Thatch's reporting system faced challenges in accurately reflecting year-to-date data, especially for off-boarded employees and allowance changes. Solutions included updating Metabase reports and providing comprehensive year-to-date enrollment data.

2. Stakeholders Involved:

- Crossroads (Customer/Employer):
  - Emily Bruns: Primary contact responsible for payroll reconciliation and W-2 preparation.
  - Crossroads Payroll Team: Processes payroll and requires updated information for year-end processing.

- Thatch (Vendor):
  - Zafreen Arefy: Account Manager/Customer Success, coordinating resolution efforts.
  - Ryan Hanchett: Payroll Specialist, technical expert on deduction calculations.
  - Kara Kubarych: Account support/Implementation, tracking communications and providing context.
  - Eric Kim: Technical/Implementation specialist, analyzing deduction reports.
  - Caroline and Mateo: Team members involved in resolving reporting issues.
  - Thatch Engineering/Product Team: Addressing report limitations and data issues.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps:

- December 12, 2025: Last payroll period included in current reconciliation reports.
- December 15, 2025: Identification and resolution of Metabase report pay period issue.
- December 16, 2025: Discovery of systematic calculation discrepancies affecting year-end W-2 reporting.
- December 19, 2025 (5:00 PM ET): Hard deadline for providing accurate reconciliation data to complete EIB file.
- December 22, 2025: Employee deadline for submitting qualified medical expense documentation.
- January 12, 2026: Internal Thatch deadline for documentation to ensure W-2 accuracy.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties:

- Immediate Actions (By December 19, 2025, 5:00 PM ET):
  - Zafreen Arefy to lead a working group with Ryan, Caroline, and Mateo to investigate flagged employee discrepancies and provide accurate reconciliation data.
  - Ryan Hanchett to assist with background investigation and resolve calculation methodology issues.
  - Emily Bruns to attend the next scheduled check-in call and complete the EIB file with corrected data.

- Ongoing/Future Actions:
  - Thatch Product Team to receive documentation on billing display improvements needed to prevent future reconciliation issues.
  - Thatch to implement better reporting that accounts for biweekly pay schedules vs. monthly

Date: 2025-12-16

Current State:
- Crossroads is using Thatch for benefits administration and Workday for payroll/HR, conducting 2025 year-end W-2 reconciliation.
- Employers, including Crossroads, are requesting post-enrollment FAQs for 2026.
- Carrier processing delays are being experienced, particularly with CareFirst, Blue Cross of Texas, and Blue Cross of Minnesota.
- Workday payroll system operates on a biweekly pay schedule with 26 pay periods annually.

Priorities:
- Create a collated FAQ document for employers covering post-enrollment expectations.
- Proactively notify employers about known carrier delays.
- Manage late December enrollment volume and cutoff dates.
- Ensure accurate year-to-date pre-tax and post-tax deduction reporting and complete W-2 reconciliation.
- Reconcile employer medical allowance amounts between Workday and Thatch systems.

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Carrier delays, with 3-4 weeks for physical medical cards.
- Discrepancies between Workday and Thatch year-to-date reports for employer medical contributions.
- Thatch system calculates monthly while client operates on a biweekly schedule, creating mismatches.
- Historical data entry errors and lack of trust in Thatch reporting accuracy.
- Late enrollments between December 22-28 create poor member experiences due to January 1 coverage gaps.

Optimization Goals:
- Improve communication channels for carrier delay notifications.
- Develop ICHRA-specific processes with carrier partners.
- Create scalable FAQ resources for employers.
- Streamline reconciliation process and reduce manual Excel work for 2026.
- Systematic solution for biweekly vs. monthly calculation alignment.

Stated Timelines:
- Immediate need for an FAQ document for the current OEP cycle.
- Critical decision period for enrollment cutoffs is December 22-28, 2025.
- December 22, 2025: Employee deadline for qualified medical expense documentation.
- January 12, 2026: Internal deadline for documentation (extensions available).
- 2025-12-18: Hard deadline for final reconciliation numbers.
- 2025-12-19: Complete EIB (payroll input file).
- 2025-12-22: Payroll processing deadline for final 2025 pay period (pay date 2025-12-26).

Action Items:
- Thatch team (Zafreen, Ryan, Caroline, Mateo) forming working group to resolve employer medical calculation methodology.
- Review 20+ flagged employees with discrepancies before Thursday deadline.
- Determine accurate amounts owed to/from employees for year-end reconciliation.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect, Crossroads, currently administers employee benefits using Workday as their primary benefits administration and payroll platform. Emily Bruns manages the benefits administration process and works with an internal payroll team.

Platform and Tools:
- Uses Workday for benefits administration, payroll processing, and reporting
- Operates on a biweekly pay schedule (26 pay periods per year)
- Uses Excel spreadsheets for reconciliation work, including V lookups and X lookups to cross-reference data between multiple reports
- Utilizes Workday's EIB (Enterprise Interface Builder) tool for data integration and updates

Workflow and Responsibilities:
- Emily manages three categories of deductions: medical pre-tax, medical post-tax, and employer medical (allowance amounts)
- Downloads and reviews various reports from Workday including year-to-date reports, payroll reports, and spend reports
- Reconciles benefits data between Workday and third-party reports
- Tracks month-to-month deduction changes for employees
- Processes W-2 information that includes employer-provided coverage amounts
- Must complete payroll processing and data updates by specific deadlines

Third-Party Services:
- Uses Thatch as a benefits facilitator/third-party administrator for employee health benefits
- Receives payroll deduction files and year-to-date reports from Thatch
- Reconciles Thatch's reporting with Workday data, though experiencing significant discrepancies requiring resolution

Emily describes having to "become like an Excel girly" since working with Thatch, indicating significant manual spreadsheet work is required. She mentions pulling data from different reports and using formulas to calculate year-to-date totals, cross-referencing monthly allowances with annual amounts, and tracking approximately 450 employees.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Contour Body Imaging - ICHRA Discovery Call

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Thatch Representative: Taryn Livingstone, Business Team  
Prospect Contact: Laura Losetti (Losetti), Administrative Role  
Company: Contour Body Imaging  
Location: Texas (one owner in Florida)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Current Situation
- Company Profile: Small business, open for 1 year, currently structured as LLC with plans to restructure into S-Corp with trust/holding company structure
- Current Insurance: UnitedHealthcare through Surest platform
- Current Enrollment: 3 active employees (owners) + 1 employee under 16 (dependent of owner)
- Current Cost: Approximately $3,000/month ($1,000 per person) for 3 enrollees
- Pain Point: High cost with minimal utilization - "nobody uses it"
- Growth Plans: Planning to hire additional employees in 2026

Interest in ICHRA
- Primary Motivation: Cost reduction and more efficient benefits management
- Initial Research: Laura was familiar with HSAs from previous employment and sought similar tax-advantaged options
- Discovery: Found Thatch while researching alternatives to traditional group health insurance

ICHRA Model Education
- Key Limitation Identified: ICHRA not available for LLC/S-Corp owners (only C-Corp owners qualify due to pass-through entity tax treatment)
- Solution Presented: Owners would purchase plans on the exchange independently; employees can use ICHRA
- Potential Restructuring Impact: If company converts to C-Corp, all employees including owners could participate in ICHRA
- Allowance Flexibility: Employer sets pre-tax budget; employees choose individual plans from ~5 carriers with 20+ plan options per zip code
- Budget Mechanics: 
  - Monthly allowance builds up if unused
  - Can be used for qualified medical expenses (FSA-like)
  - Unused funds at year-end return to employer
  - Employees can buy plans over/under budget (payroll deduction for overages)

Pricing Structure
- Platform Fee: $45 per employee per month (PEPM) - only for enrolled employees
- Compliance Fee: $50 per month (flat, not per employee)
- Payroll Integration: SurePayroll (current provider) - compatible with Thatch

Plan Options & Support
- Average Availability: ~5 carriers with 20+ plan options per zip code
- Employee Support: Tech platform with plan recommendation algorithm + concierge team (plan support specialists)
- Wellness Perks: Optional partnerships with vendors (HIMS, mental health coaches, etc.) for unused allowance dollars
- Geographic Advantage: Distributed team (Texas/Florida) benefits from carrier diversity across states

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Prospect Company (Contour Body Imaging)
- Laura Losetti (Losetti): Primary contact, administrative role, started August 2025
  - Responsibilities: Benefits research, vendor evaluation, implementation coordination
  - Decision-making authority: Appears to have autonomy but coordinates with owners
  
- Company Owners (3 total): 
  - At least one owner located in Florida
  - Currently enrolled in UnitedHealthcare
  - Final decision-makers on company structure (LLC vs. C-Corp) and benefits strategy
  
- Employee (1): Under 16 years old, dependent of owner

Thatch Team
- Taryn Livingstone: Business Team representative, handles companies <20 employees
  - Responsibilities: Discovery, education, quote generation, implementation support
  - Based in New York (company HQ in Austin, Texas)

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Dates
- Conversation Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025
- Current Plan Renewal: January 1, 2026 (UnitedHealthcare)
- Thatch Enrollment Deadline for 1/1/2026 Coverage: Friday, December 20, 2025 (3 business days from conversation)
- Target Implementation: January 1, 2026 (pending cancellation terms with UnitedHealthcare)

Key Conversation Moments
1. Entity Structure Clarification (Early in call): Laura revealed company is LLC planning S-Corp restructuring - critical for ICHRA eligibility determination
2. ICHRA Limitation Disclosure: Taryn transparently explained owners cannot use ICHRA under current LLC structure, but positioned as "extra feather in the cap" for C-Corp consideration
3. Pricing Transparency: Laura confirmed understanding of allowance model where employees can exceed budget via payroll deduction
4. Urgency Acknowledgment: Laura recognized tight timeline but expressed confidence: "I have time to do this. I can have everything in order by Friday if we need to."
5. Action Commitment: Laura committed to same-day actions (review plans, check UnitedHealthcare cancellation terms, build quote)

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions - Laura Losetti (By End of Day, December 16, 2025)
1. Review Available Plans: Visit thatch.com/plans to spot-check plan options for Texas zip code
2. Contact UnitedHealthcare: Determine cancellation terms and notice requirements for current policy
3. Create Thatch Account: Go to thatch.com, click "Start Now" to access allowance calculator (no-strings-attached account)
4. Build Quote Scenario: Use allowance calculator to model costs for current + projected 2026 hires
5. Owner Coordination: Send information to Florida-based owner for review and discussion

Thatch Follow-Up - Taryn Livingstone (December 16, 2025)
1. Send Follow-Up Email containing:
   - Links to thatch.com/plans and enrollment portal
   - Timeline/deadline information (December 20, 2025 for 1/1/2026 coverage)
   - Additional educational resources
   - Contact information for questions

Decision Point - Contour Body Imaging (By Friday, December 20, 2025)
1. Finalize Entity Structure Decision: Determine if C-Corp conversion is feasible/desirable for ICHRA participation
2. Complete Enrollment: If moving forward, submit employee information and allowance selections through Thatch platform
3. Cancel UnitedHealthcare: Provide required notice to current carrier (pending terms review)

Contingency Planning
- If December 20 Deadline Missed: Laura acknowledged they have current coverage, so missing 1/1/2026 start date is not catastrophic
- Alternative Start Dates: Could potentially target later 2026 implementation if needed

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Open Questions/Considerations
- UnitedHealthcare cancellation terms unknown (30-day notice requirement TBD)
- Final decision on LLC vs. C-Corp structure pending owner discussion
- Exact number of 2026 hires not specified (growth plans mentioned but not quantified)
- Current employee's eligibility unclear (under 16, may be dependent rather than W-2 employee)

Competitive Positioning
- Current cost: ~$1,000/person/month with low utilization
- Thatch positioning: Cost control through individual plan selection + unused allowance flexibility
- Key differentiator: Geographic flexibility for distributed team (Texas/Florida)

Prospect Sentiment
- Engagement Level: High - Laura was attentive, asked clarifying questions, committed to immediate action
- Urgency: Moderate-to-high - recognizes timeline but has fallback (current coverage continues)
- Objections: None raised; primary concern was understanding mechanics and eligibility
- Likelihood to Close: Moderate - depends on UnitedHealthcare cancellation terms and owner alignment on entity structure

Current Situation:

- Cost: ~$3,000/month for coverage that's rarely used
- Structure: LLC (planning S-Corp with trust)

Priorities:
- Reduce healthcare costs significantly
- Find scalable solution for growing team
- Maintain compliance while optimizing spend

Optimization Goals:
- Implement ICHRA model for employee choice and flexibility
- Leverage pre-tax benefits structure
- Provide coverage options that employees will actually use
- Consider C-Corp restructure to include owners in ICHRA

Stated Timelines:
- Target coverage start: 2026-01-01
- Enrollment deadline: 2025-12-20 (Friday)
- Needs to verify UnitedHealthcare cancellation requirements
- Can complete setup by Friday if moving forward

Next Steps:
- Review available plans at Thatch.com/plans
- Contact UnitedHealthcare re: cancellation process
- Use Thatch allowance calculator
- Discuss with Florida-based owner
- Decide on entity structure (C-Corp consideration)

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Prospect Actions (Laura Losetti - Contour Body Imaging):
- Contact UnitedHealthcare to determine cancellation terms and required notice period (ASAP)
- Visit thatch.com/plans to review available insurance plans in her Texas area (by 12/19/2025)
- Go to thatch.com, click "Start now," create account, and use the allowance calculator to model costs for potential new hires (by 12/19/2025)

Rep Actions (Taryn Livingstone - Thatch):
- Send follow-up email with links to thatch.com/plans, signup page, timeline information, and additional resources (12/16/2025)

Overall Deal Next Step:
Laura will review plans and costs, consult with ownership about C-Corp restructuring, and determine whether to proceed with Thatch by the Friday 12/19/2025 deadline. No follow-up meeting scheduled; prospect will reach out to Taryn if assistance is needed during the evaluation process.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently has health insurance through UnitedHealthcare, specifically using their Surest platform which is designed for small businesses. They have three employees actively enrolled in the insurance (the owners). For payroll processing, they use SurePayroll, which Laura describes as suitable because "we're not that complicated."

The company has been open for one year and this is their first time offering insurance to employees. There is no mention of using a dedicated benefits administration platform (such as Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits). Given the company's small size (4 employees total, with one being under 16 and covered under a parent's plan) and recent establishment, they appear to be managing benefits through their insurance carrier (UnitedHealthcare/Surest) and payroll provider (SurePayroll) without additional benefits administration software or complex workflows.

No details were discussed about manual administration methods (spreadsheets, email) or the use of a broker for their current setup.

- The salesperson missed probing strategic priorities; next, ask about growth goals and specific savings targets.
- The salesperson didn't map decision-makers; next, confirm who signs contracts and the budget approval process.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Client/Prospect: Hidden Harvest Corporation

Current Situation:
- Hidden Harvest has 4 active employees.
- The board of directors recently approved a benefits structure after initially considering QSEHRA and transitioning to ICHRA following broker consultation.

Pain Points/Challenges:
- The board approved a non-compliant class structure that separates the "leadership team" and "full-time staff" based on job title, which is not allowed under ICHRA rules.
- ICHRA allowances cannot be tiered by position/job title alone and must use IRS-compliant classes such as age, ZIP code, and number of dependents.

Priorities:
- Implement ICHRA with a compliant class structure.
- Provide differentiated benefits while maintaining IRS compliance.

Optimization Goals:
- Utilize Thatch's allowance calculator to create a compliant, flexible benefit structure.
- Leverage pre-tax payroll deductions, which offer an advantage over government exchanges.
- Allow employees to import existing individual plans if they are not receiving income-based subsidies.

Timeline:
- Target start date for ICHRA implementation is January 2026.
- Enrollment deadline has been extended, allowing more time for setup.

Action Items:
- The broker needs to inform the client of the compliance issue with the board-approved structure.
- Obtain updated census data with dependent information.
- Schedule a three-way meeting with the broker, Thatch representative, and client to present compliant solutions.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Josh Fitzpatrick (Broker) Owns:
- Send email to client (Hidden Harvest Corporation/Cassandra) today to loop in Joseph Firenzi and inform her that the proposed class structure (leadership team vs. full-time staff) is non-compliant for ICHRA
- Obtain clean census data from client including all dependent information for the 4 active employees
- Schedule meeting with client and Joseph using Joseph's calendar link

Joseph Firenzi (Thatch Rep) Owns:
- Respond to Josh's email thread with calendar link for client to book meeting
- Conduct presentation meeting with client to explain ICHRA functionality, platform features, and allowance calculator
- Share resource document outlining the 11 eligible classes for compliant ICHRA structure

Client (Hidden Harvest Corporation) Owns:
- Provide updated census data with dependent information
- Review eligible class structure options (full-time vs. part-time, salary vs. hourly, state-based)
- Book meeting time via Joseph's calendar link

Next Step for Deal:
Schedule and conduct presentation meeting (Joseph mentioned he has availability same afternoon as call) to review ICHRA options, demonstrate allowance calculator, and address compliant class structure alternatives. Goal is to move forward with January 2025 implementation (enrollment deadline recently extended).

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Hidden Harvest Corporation

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

1. Key Points Discussed

   - Employer Interest & Background: Hidden Harvest Corporation initially sought QSEHRA in early October 2025 but required a class-based structure, leading to ICHRA consideration. The Board of Directors approved a benefits structure, but it was non-compliant with IRS regulations. The target implementation is January 2026 for 4 active employees.

   - Compliance Issues Identified: The Board approved tiering based on job titles, which is not permissible under ICHRA regulations. Compliant alternatives include tiering based on age, ZIP code, and number of dependents. There are 11 eligible class options, including full-time vs. part-time employees and salaried vs. hourly employees.

   - Platform Features Discussed: The allowance calculator automatically tiers allowances based on compliant variables. Thatch offers pre-tax payroll deductions and a real-time view of buying power and plan options for each employee.

2. Identification of Stakeholders

   - Internal (Thatch/Broker Team):
     - Joseph Firenzi (Joe Firenzi): Thatch Sales Representative responsible for product education, compliance guidance, and enrollment support.
     - Josh Fitzpatrick: Broker/Benefits Advisor (Paychex, Inc.) acting as an intermediary between the employer and Thatch, responsible for client communication and meeting coordination.

   - External (Prospect):
     - Hidden Harvest Corporation: Employer/Prospect with the Board of Directors as the approval authority for the benefits structure.

3. Important Milestones & Timestamps

   - Historical Timeline:
     - Early October 2025: Initial conversation about QSEHRA; ICHRA introduced as an alternative.
     - October-December 2025: Extended approval process through the Board of Directors.
     - Week of December 16, 2025: Board approval received with a non-compliant structure.

   - Critical Moments in Conversation (December 16, 2025):
     - Compliance issue identified by Joe.
     - Educational pivot with IRS-compliant class structure resource shared.
     - Census data gap identified.
     - Enrollment deadline extension provided for January 2026 implementation.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines & Responsible Parties

   - Immediate Actions (Week of December 16, 2025):
     - Josh Fitzpatrick:
       - Contact Hidden Harvest about the non-compliant class structure.
       - Request clean census data including employee names, ages, ZIP codes, and number of dependents.
       - Send introductory email looping in Joe Firenzi and Hidden Harvest contact.
       - Coordinate meeting scheduling between all parties.

     - Joseph Firenzi:
       - Respond with a calendar link for meeting scheduling.
       - Conduct presentation if the employer is available.
       - Send IRS-compliant class structure resource document.
       - Prepare to demonstrate ICHRA functionality on the Thatch platform.

   - Meeting Agenda (To Be Scheduled):
     - Present ICHRA overview and Thatch platform capabilities.
     - Demonstrate allowance calculator with compliant class structures.
     - Review eligible class options and recommend structure.
     - Show plan options

Here, we actually have this cool resource here. I'll send you in the Zoom chat. So here's the 11 eligible classes. You can do full-time versus part-time. So, in other words, you can do... For all full-time people, you give them like 700 a month, all part-time get 350 a month. You can do salary and hourly in the same structure. Um, and then all these different ones here. Yes, okay, that's about it. 
Josh Fitzpatrick:
So it's really just separating, like full-timers, part-timers, and then hourly and correct, and then, um. 
Joseph Firenzi:
You're also not required to present an allowance to part-time people if you do not want to. Um, so you are compliant if you exclude them, but okay, um, oh yeah. The other one, I forget how they word it here. Oh, the same region. They should have just said geography or something like that. But another eligible class is state-based. So, for example, you could have one flat allowance for everyone in California, and then a different one for Texas, because it's more affordable in Texas. 
Josh Fitzpatrick:
Okay. Is that based on ZIP code or state? 
Joseph Firenzi:
Ideally, state for like, if you're going to class it out and like, tier the allowances. And then a calculator kind of does that automatically, though. I'll show you what that looks like. Do you have any census data for this group? 
Josh Fitzpatrick:
Yes, I do. And I can send that over. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay. And are they trying to get started in January? We still have some time left, and we actually just extended our enrollment deadline. So there's some extra time now. 
Josh Fitzpatrick:
Yeah, I was going to give her a call today after I talked to you, or schedule a meeting with her. But I'll need to get, like, a cleaner census, because, I thought. I didn't think she was going to, I didn't, I didn't heard back from her. And then she literally just emailed me, like this week, and was like, Hey, the board approved this. Like, can we get started on this? So it was a, yeah, but I wanted to talk to you first. So I got to let her know, though. Like, she can't even class it out that way. So I assume that's going to be just going to go have to go back on that. Let me see. Yeah, I'll have to get, I mean, right now I have four employees that are active, so I'll have to go back and get her. Like a clean census with the dependents on it, but I can do that today. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay. Yeah. And luckily my calendar has, you know, it's slowed down a little bit, so I have more openings, So we should be able to find something. I can send you my calendar link like right after this call. But for these smaller groups, this is generally the flow I go through. I generally do like a presentation to outline how ICHR is function on thatch with our platform and everything. And then after that, I pivot to this, which is the allowance calculator. This is actually the real sign-up experience, by the way. So after that call on Zoom, I send them a link for them to input their account information. And then eventually, they'll progress to this page with the calculator. They'll see all their employees. And then, with the default settings right now, we can see the dynamic calculator come to life. And it's tiering the allowances based on those three variables of age, ZiP code, and number of dependents. And you can adjust it as much as you want. So, in other words, here, you could just say, I want the employee to cover the entire cost that comes with adding dependents to the plan. Or, you could provide some extra financial support to people that have families by choosing something here. You can adjust it at the employee level and do lowest cost, better benefits, or this one in the middle. And then you can also hit this custom slider and move this down to whatever you're happy with. And you can see how much flexibility there is. And then for groups of under 50 people, you don't need to worry about this compliance thing. This only applies to people with over 50 employees. So the other very cool thing as well is that you can click See plans next to each employee. And then get a look at the buying power that you're giving them with your selections and then adjust accordingly, which is pretty awesome for each plan available to them.

On like the government exchange. 
Josh Fitzpatrick:
Yeah, yeah. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yeah, so they can actually, they can import it into Thatch. So that is an option when you create your account. The only restriction there is that if they were receiving an income-based tax subsidy, it would not be eligible to be imported. Because the IRS would consider that double dipping in pre-tax funds. Yeah. Because of the pre-tax dollars that Thatch offers. And then I'll just highlight this as well, since we're on that topic. These green numbers are instances of the current allowance covering the entire cost of this plan in full. And then red numbers are the opposite. So this plan would be a cost sharing scenario where the employee would have to pay $140 with a pre-tax payroll deduction each month. Note: The provided conversation is a single internal pipeline review meeting, not a series of client calls. Below is the structured analysis of this meeting.

Call Date / Timestamp: Tuesday, December 16, 2025
Client Name / Account: Internal Sales Team - MM Pipeline Review  
Call Type: Status

1. Objectives
- Review mid-market pipeline status for 2/1 renewals and upcoming opportunities
- Discuss Medicare enrollment challenges and workflow improvements for elderly populations

2. Key Updates / Progress
- Medicare Workflow Issues Identified: Multiple pain points with Medicare-eligible employees (85+ at one prospect), including difficulty with digital enrollment, lack of phone support, and confusion about Parts A, B, D enrollment process
- Phone Number Solution in Development: Team confirmed a phone number for Medicare support is top priority for next year (timeline TBD)
- Medicare One-Pager: Medicare team working on educational one-pager to be ready early January 2026
- Providence Network Expansion: Potentially available by end of month in Tahoe/El Dorado/Nevada area
- 2/1 Pipeline Status: Light pipeline for 2/1 renewals as expected; focus shifting to 3/1 and 4/1 opportunities

3. Client Input / Feedback
- Elco Feedback: Medicare-eligible employees struggled with computer literacy, couldn't navigate email links, Google forms, or create accounts independently
- Broker Feedback: Multiple brokers requesting phone number for Medicare population as primary contact method
- Timing Issues: Clients want immediate enrollment support, not appointments 4+ days out
- Device Limitations: Many Medicare-eligible employees don't have laptops, only cell phones
- Social Security Enrollment Confusion: Lack of clarity on how to support employees through Social Security office enrollment process

4. Action Items
- [Zach Egan] → Coordinate with Medicare team on phone number implementation timeline → Ongoing
- [Medicare Team] → Complete one-pager for sales cycle distribution → Early January 2026
- [Zach Egan] → Verify Providence network expansion timeline with Corey → This week (by 2025-12-20)
- [Retsy Holliday] → Follow up with Tiro (Michael) on 2/1 decision, offer additional discount if needed → This week (by 2025-12-20)
- [Retsy Holliday] → Check in with KMC on quote evaluation → This week (by 2025-12-20)
- [Retsy Holliday] → Get decision timeline from Wraps via Paychex rep → End of week (by 2025-12-20)
- [Retsy Holliday] → Confirm decision timeline with Home Life/USI team → End of week (by 2025-12-20)
- [Chad Schneider] → Send gift to USI broker team (Casey and Chris) → ASAP
- [Retsy Holliday] → Push LJ Rogers for contract signature by 2/1 with 2025 pricing → By 2026-02-01
- [Denis Kalamar] → Mid-January meeting with LFC to evaluate 3/1 opportunity → Mid-January 2026
- [Zach Egan] → Clarify Medicare support requirements with Jeremy for Wraps (85 Medicare-eligible employees) → This week

5. Notes
- Active 2/1 Opportunities:
  - Tiro: No benefits currently offered, in due diligence, already at $20 PEPM (matched Vent), willing to go lower if needed
  - KMC (La-Z-Boy split-off): Quote $200-300K higher than expected, but competitive with group quotes; carve-out strategy for hourly/part-time vs. incentive-based sellers
  - Wraps: 85 Medicare-eligible employees (owner estimates only ~10 would enroll), competitive quote, concerns about Medicare workflow
  - Home Life (USI referral): 110 enrolled, highest likelihood of 2/1 close, strong broker advocacy from Casey and Chris

- Future Opportunities:
  - LJ Rogers: 108-110 enrolled, trucking company in North Carolina, 4/1 renewal, pushing for 2/1 contract signature with 2025 pricing
  - Edgewood Companies: Tahoe/El Dorado area, waiting on Providence network expansion
  - LFC: 250+ employees, 25 Medicare-eligible in New York, self-funded, targeting 3/1

- Strategic Discussions:
  - Team discussed potential account management structure for renewals and upsells (currently undefined)
  - Emphasis on booking deals before 2/1 for fiscal year impact, even if enrollment is later
  - Willingness to discount PEPM significantly to secure 2/1 deals vs. 3/1 or later

Granola Summary

Objectives so far:
- Review and advance 2/1 renewal pipeline opportunities
- Address Medicare enrollment workflow challenges and improve customer experience
- Identify solutions for elderly/less tech-savvy employee populations
- Shift focus to 3/1 and 4/1 opportunities as 2/1 pipeline is light

Progress made:
- Identified critical Medicare workflow pain points through field feedback (Elco visit)
- Confirmed phone number solution is in development as top priority
- Medicare educational one-pager in progress for early January 2026 distribution
- Strong broker relationships established (USI team for Home Life)
- Multiple competitive quotes delivered to prospects (KMC, Wraps, Home Life)
- Gift program established for broker appreciation

Outstanding issues:
- Medicare enrollment process remains confusing and burdensome for elderly populations
- No phone support currently available for Medicare-eligible employees
- Digital literacy barriers preventing successful self-service enrollment
- Timing mismatch between when employees want help (immediately) vs. when advisors are available (4+ days)
- Lack of clear guidance on Social Security office enrollment process
- Providence network expansion timeline unclear
- 2/1 pipeline lighter than desired

Next steps:
- Secure decisions on 4 active 2/1 opportunities by end of week (2025-12-20)
- Implement Medicare one-pager in sales process (January 2026)
- Clarify Providence network expansion timeline for Tahoe/El Dorado opportunities
- Continue pushing LJ Rogers for early contract signature with 2025 pricing
- Develop account management structure for renewals and upsells
- Focus energy on 3/1 and 4/1 pipeline development
- Partner with CS team on post-sale expansion opportunities

KMC: They are a new business splitting off from La-Z-Boy. They have their own in-house payroll system. No current benefits administration platform mentioned as they are establishing a new entity.

Wraps: Works with Paychex (referenced as "Paychex rep" in the conversation), suggesting they use Paychex for benefits or payroll services.

Home Life: Works with USI as their broker. The USI team (Casey and Chris) is actively involved in the sales process and advocating for the prospect.

LFC: Has a broker involved in their benefits administration, as evidenced by a scheduled meeting in mid-January to evaluate options with their broker.

For other prospects mentioned (LJ Rogers, Edgewood companies), specific details about their current benefits administration methods were not discussed.

d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.title: Notes
d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.value:
Call Date / Timestamp: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Client Name / Account: Internal Team Meeting - Multiple Accounts Discussed  
Call Type: Status / Pipeline Review

1. Objectives
- Review Q1 2025 (two-one) pipeline opportunities and enrollment status for mid-market groups
- Assess 12/15 mid-market group enrollment performance and discuss groups with 12/19 deadline extensions

2. Key Updates / Progress
- Over $300K in ARR booked from enrolled members in one night across mid-market groups
- MetaSource grew from 60 to 260 enrolled; NPA grew from 600 to ~1,200 enrolled
- Almost all mid-market groups performing at or above 80% of expected enrollment threshold
- LenStoler exceeded expectations: 177 enrolled vs. 140 expected
- Team identified significant gaps in Medicare enrollment workflow and support process
- Limited Q1 pipeline - only handful of realistic two-one opportunities remaining

3. Client Input / Feedback
- LenStoler (Retsy): Broker (Andy) expressing high anxiety about Medicare enrollment process for S-corp owners (95-year-old owner and 68-year-old son); broker feels Medicare workflow is insufficient
- Wraps (Retsy): 85 Medicare-eligible employees; client concerned about Medicare enrollment experience; owner estimates only ~10 of 85 would actually enroll
- KMC (Retsy): Quote coming in $200-300K higher than expected, but group quotes are similar; evaluating carve-out options for different employee segments
- Home Life (Retsy): USI brokers feel this is client's only viable option; client actively exploring platform over weekend
- Multiple groups: Feedback that Medicare population needs phone support, not just digital workflow

4. Action Items
- Retsy → Schedule call between LenStoler broker (Andy) and Jeremy re: Medicare enrollment for owners → Week of 2025-12-16
- Retsy → Check in with Tiro decision-makers about Q1 start; consider additional discount beyond current $20 PEPM → Week of 2025-12-16
- Retsy → Get decision from Wraps by end of week/early next week for successful two-one → By 2025-12-20
- Retsy → Confirm with USI brokers on Home Life decision timeline → By 2025-12-20
- Retsy → Push LJ Rogers to sign contract by two-one with 2025 pricing (four-one start) → By 2026-02-01
- Zach → Work with Medicare team to develop one-pager for sales cycle explaining Medicare enrollment process → Early January 2026
- Zach → Confirm with Corey if Providence network expansion will be in new quoting tool by end of month → Week of 2025-12-16
- Zach → Coordinate with Jeremy on additional Medicare questions/requirements for large Medicare populations → Week of 2025-12-16
- Chad → Send gift to USI broker team (Casey and Chris) for Home Life deal → ASAP
- Denis → Follow up meeting with LFC in mid-January; move to three-one timeline → 2026-01-15
- Team → Complete two-ones updates in Salesforce (mostly complete) → Ongoing
- Team → Medicare workflow training scheduled with implementation managers → Early January 2026

5. Notes
- Product team offsite happening in office; Zach attended but felt guilty about breakfast tacos
- Julia has an AOL email address causing AI bot to join calls
- Team discussing potential phone number solution for Medicare population (top priority for Garrity, timeline TBD)
- Medicare workflow issues: population struggles with technology, needs phone support, confusion about Parts A/B enrollment vs. supplemental coverage
- Sales team needs better education on what Thatch does/doesn't support for Medicare enrollment
- Discussion about AE involvement in land-and-expand scenarios; no formal structure yet but open to case-by-case involvement
- Bookings before two-one important for fiscal year even if enrollments occur later
- Denis noted 65+ can enroll in ACA plans (not illegal), though Medicare typically cheaper with better benefits
- 3G example: 7 Medicare folks enrolling in ACA plans as stopgap until Medicare plans ready end of January

Granola Summary

Objectives so far:
- Review and optimize Q1 2025 pipeline for mid-market segment
- Assess 12/15 enrollment performance across mid-market groups
- Address Medicare enrollment workflow gaps and client concerns
- Identify opportunities to accelerate deals into Q1 vs. later quarters

Progress made:
- Strong enrollment performance: $300K+ ARR booked in single night
- Most mid-market groups at or above 80% expected enrollment
- Multiple groups significantly exceeded expectations (LenStoler, MetaSource, NPA, Elco)
- Identified and documenting Medicare workflow issues for product improvement
- Active pipeline management with several two-one opportunities in motion

Outstanding issues:
- Medicare workflow insufficient: Tech-challenged population struggles with digital enrollment process; needs phone support
- Sales education gap: Team needs clarity on what Thatch supports for Medicare (Parts A/B vs. supplemental)
- Pricing challenges: Some groups (KMC) coming in $200-300K over budget expectations
- Timeline pressure: Limited time to close two-one deals; most realistic opportunities are three-one or four-one
- Process gaps: Expected enrollment field not consistently populated in Salesforce
- Product availability: Providence network expansion timing unclear for quoting tool

Next steps:
- Resolve LenStoler Medicare enrollment concerns with broker and Jeremy
- Push for decisions on Wraps, Home Life, and Tiro by end of week (2025-12-20)
- Develop Medicare one-pager for sales cycle (January 2026)
- Schedule Medicare workflow training for team (January 2026)
- Shift focus to Q2/Q3 pipeline development given limited Q1 opportunities
- Consider aggressive discounting (down to $10 PEPM) to pull three-one/four-one deals into Q1
- Confirm Providence network expansion availability for Dennis's Tahoe/El Dorado opportunities

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes - MM Pipeline Review Meeting
Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

Meeting Overview
This was an internal mid-market sales pipeline review focused on Q1 2026 opportunities, particularly deals targeting 2/1/2026 (February 1st) start dates. The team reviewed enrollment performance for 12/15 groups and discussed pipeline opportunities.

Key Discussion Points

Enrollment Performance (12/15 Groups)
- Strong Performance: Mid-market groups exceeded expectations with over 300K in ARR booked from enrolled members on 12/15 alone
- Enrollment Rate: Almost all mid-market groups hit or exceeded 80% of expected enrollment
- Notable successes:
  - MetaSource: Increased from 60 to 260 enrolled
  - NPA: Close to 1,200 enrolled (from ~600)
  - LenStoler: 177 enrolled vs. 140 expected (127% of target)
  - Elco: Over 100% of expected enrollment

Critical Business Challenge: Medicare Workflow Gaps
Major Issue Identified: Current Medicare enrollment process is insufficient for the Medicare-eligible population
- Root Causes:
  1. Tech literacy barriers - many Medicare-eligible employees struggle with computers/online forms
  2. Lack of phone support option (population prefers phone calls)
  3. Advisor availability timing issues
  4. Insufficient upfront education during sales cycle about Medicare requirements
  5. Confusion about Parts A, B, D enrollment responsibilities

Impact: Multiple groups experiencing friction:
- LenStoler: 95-year-old owner and 68-year-old son need Medicare support
- Elco: On-site experience revealed employees unable to navigate digital workflow
- Wraps: 85 Medicare-eligible employees raising concerns

Proposed Solutions:
- Phone number for Medicare population (top priority for 2026, in development)
- One-pager document for sales cycle education (target: early January 2026)
- Better sales cycle communication about Medicare requirements
- Training for sales team on Medicare support scope

Stakeholder Identification

Internal Team (Thatch)
- Zach Egan: Sales team lead, facilitating pipeline review
- Retsy Holliday: AE managing multiple opportunities (LenStoler, Tiro, KMC, Wraps, Home Life, LJ Rogers)
- Kaitlin Zidar: Working with Retsy on deals
- Denis Kalamar: AE managing 3G, LFC, Edgewood Companies
- Tom Hemmingsen: Mid-year deal owner
- Andrew Solomon: Operations/data support
- Kara Kubarych: CS team lead, enrollment tracking
- Julia Korzeniowski: Marketing/operations support
- Chad Schneider: Gift/broker relations coordination
- Jeremy: Medicare team lead
- Gary: Leadership (mentioned re: two-ones completion)

External Stakeholders (Prospects/Brokers)
- Andy (LenStoler broker): High-anxiety, old-school broker requiring significant handholding
- Casey & Chris (USI brokers): Strong advocates for Home Life deal
- Paychex rep: Working on Wraps opportunity
- Danielle: Involved in LJ Rogers deal progression

Important Milestones & Timestamps

Completed Milestones
- 12/15/2025: Original enrollment deadline for mid-market cohort
- 12/16/2025 (Meeting Date): Pipeline review conducted
- Week of 12/9/2025: Multiple cost analyses and presentations delivered

Critical Upcoming Dates
- 12/19/2025: Extended enrollment deadline for 12/15 groups
- End of Week (12/20/2025): Target decision date for:
  - Wraps (85 Medicare-eligible employees)
  - Home Life (USI referral, 110 enrolled potential)
- Mid-January 2026: LFC meeting scheduled to evaluate options
- Early January 2026: Medicare education materials and team training planned
- 2/1/2026: Target start date for active pipeline opportunities

Active Pipeline Opportunities (2/1/2026 Target)

1. Tiro (Due Diligence Stage)
- Size: Not offering benefits currently
- Status: Decision-makers in Amsterdam, slow decision-making
- Pricing: $20 PEPM (matched vendor pep), no broker
- Strategy: Willing to discount further to secure 2/1 vs. 3/1 start
- Next Step: Check-in call this week (week of 12/16)
- Owner: Retsy Holliday

2. KMC (La-Z-Boy Split-Off)
- Size: New business, non-La-Z-Boy branded furniture
- Challenge: Quote is $200-300K higher than expected budget
- Status: Presented quote 12/12/2025, awaiting feedback
- Structure: Carve-out approach (hourly/part-time vs. incentive-based sellers)
- Competitive Position: Group quotes also coming in high
- Next Step: Follow-up this week
- Owner: Retsy Holliday & Kaitlin Zidar

3. Wraps
- Size: 85 Medicare-eligible employees (owner estimates only ~10 would enroll)
- Average Age: 59 years old
- Status: Very interested, quote competitive
- Concern: Medicare enrollment workflow
- Deadline: Decision needed by end of week (12/20) for successful 2/1 implementation
- Next Step: Paychex rep back-channeled for decision timeline
- Owner: Retsy Holliday

4. Home Life (USI Referral)
- Size: 110 enrolled potential
- Status: HIGHEST LIKELIHOOD - Decision-maker actively engaged, requesting SBCs and quotes
- Broker Support: USI team (Casey & Chris) fully advocating
- Activity: Weekend emails from decision-maker showing strong engagement
- Next Step: Decision expected by end of week (12/20)
- Action Item: Send gift to USI broker team (Chad coordinating)
- Owner: Retsy Holliday

5. LFC (Denis)
- Status: Good meeting last week
- Timeline: Mid-January meeting scheduled
- Challenge: 25 Medicare-eligible employees in New York
- Reality Check: Moved to 3/1 target (unrealistic for 2/1 given timeline)
- Owner: Denis Kalamar

Future Pipeline (3/1 - 5/1/2026)

LJ Rogers (4/1 Target)
- Size: 110 enrolled, 210 total employees
- Industry: Trucking company, North Carolina
- Status: Strong engagement, completed employee disruption analysis
- Pricing Strategy: Offering 2025 pricing to accelerate decision
- Next Step: Danielle meeting this week/early next week
- Goal: Contract signed by 2/1 for preferred pricing
- Owner: Retsy Holliday & Kaitlin Zidar

Edgewood Companies (Denis)
- Location: Tahoe, El Dorado, Nevada area
- Blocker: Waiting for Providence network expansion
- Timeline: Potentially mid-year or later
- Action: Zach to confirm Providence network availability timeline with Corey

Critical Next Steps & Deadlines

Immediate (Week of 12/16/2025)
1. Retsy: Follow-up calls with Tiro, KMC, Wraps decision-makers
2. Retsy: Confirm Home Life decision timeline with USI brokers
3. Chad: Send gift to USI broker team (Casey & Chris)
4. Zach: Consult with Jeremy on Medicare questions for Wraps (85 Medicare-eligible)
5. Andrew/Retsy: Update expected enrollment fields for separated EIN groups

Short-term (By 12/20/2025)
1. Target Decisions: Wraps and Home Life by end of week
2. LJ Rogers: Danielle meeting to advance deal
3. All AEs: Push remaining 12/19 deadline groups for final enrollment

Medium-term (Early January 2026)
1. Zach + Medicare Team: Finalize one-pager for sales cycle Medicare education
2. Team Training: Medicare workflow and support scope training
3. LFC Meeting: Mid-January evaluation meeting (Denis)
4. Zach: Confirm Providence network expansion timeline with Corey for Edgewood

Strategic Priorities
1. Focus Shift: Pivot energy to Q1 2026 (3/1, 4/1 opportunities) given limited 2/1 pipeline
2. Pricing Strategy: Willing to discount to $10 PEPM for 2/1 commitments
3. Bookings Focus: Any contracts signed before 2/1 improve fiscal year, even if enrollment is later
4. Account Management: Consider AE involvement in land-and-expand scenarios (e.g., carve-outs)

Key Business Insights

Pricing Flexibility
- Team authorized to go as low as necessary on PEPM for 2/1 deals
- 2025 pricing being offered for 4/1 deals if contracts signed by 2/1

Process Improvements Needed
1. Medicare Education: Must happen earlier in sales cycle
2. Expected Enrollment Field: Critical metric for CS team tracking
3. Phone Support: Top priority for 2026 product roadmap
4. Broker Gifts: Workflow established through Ally's channel

Market Dynamics
- Strong Q4 enrollment performance demonstrates product-market fit
- Medicare population support remains significant competitive differentiator and operational challenge
- Land-and-expand opportunities emerging (carve-outs, state expansions)

Risk Factors
1. Medicare Workflow: Current process creating friction with brokers and clients
2. Tight 2/1 Pipeline: Limited opportunities for February starts
3. Budget Constraints: Some prospects (KMC) facing sticker shock vs. expectations
4. Network Limitations: Providence expansion timing affecting Tahoe-area deals
