Rep Actions (Taryn Livingstone - Thatch):
- No immediate action items assigned

Overall Deal Status:
The opportunity is currently on hold with no scheduled follow-up meeting. The deal has encountered a significant blocker: the primary decision-makers (LLC owners) are ineligible for the ICRA product. The prospect needs to decide if employee-only coverage justifies moving forward. Leticia indicated she has no availability for the rest of the year, suggesting this will not progress until 2026 at the earliest.

So what you're seeing here, actually, so these numbers, the difference between going to the marketplace and buying insurance and going through us is you are paying for this. Pre-tax, so basically that means that this budget is is not being taxed when it's going into paying for insurance. So you're able to save based on that. Um, so that's one, that's one difference there and then and then. Also too for your company, are you you're the owner of the company, right or no? Yes, yes, I am okay, nice. And do you know, do you? Um, do you know if you're, like, taxed as a C-Corp or an S Corp. sole proprietorship? The structure is it's LLC, LLC, okay, gotcha, and is Jeffrey also an owner? Yes, okay, so actually, I actually he, he, he, okay, gotcha. okay, so you're an LLC. So I was going to say, Leticia, actually, this is something that we should have clarified up front. But within ICRA, so an individual coverage health reimbursement arrangement, owners of LLCs wouldn't qualify for this kind of insurance anyway. The reason being that, because I mentioned this is a pre-tax allowance that's being set for your employees. Right. As an owner, you already are able to get the tax benefit. On your insurance, because you can include it as a business expense, and um, when you're, when you're doing your reporting there. So, yeah, unfortunately, I don't think that we'd be able to cover you. Um, with with the way that Thatch works any, anyhow. Okay? So then would you be able to just cover the employee? The employee? Yes, as long as they aren't an owner of the business. Please find out, because I was referred by another CoD League, and I don't think they're an S-Corp. I don't know. Okay. Yeah, I would check in. Generally speaking, for LLCs, we don't cover unless you are taxed as a C-Corp, but I rarely come across LLCs taxed as a C-Corp. All right. So you think that the employees will be eligible? You got it. Yeah, employees will be eligible. Because obviously we work with a lot of owners of LLCs. What we will tell you guys to do is just simply go to the marketplace for your plan, because that would probably be the easiest way of doing it. You just wouldn't be able to use the Icra on your plan. Okay, thank you so much. Yeah, of course. Yeah, happy to help here. Anything else I can help with as far as getting this set up? No, I'll be back in touch. Okay. Sounds good. All right. We'll connect later on. Have a great one.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value:
The prospect's current benefits plan is with Primera Blue Cross, which they have maintained for over a decade. The plan is a unified group HSA (High Deductible Health Plan) that they have been using for approximately three to four years. 

The plan features an individual deductible in the $5,000-$6,000 range and a family deductible of $11,000-$12,000. The employer contributes approximately $300-$400 per month per employee (with some variation based on age), while employees contribute 25% of the premium cost. The plan design is the same across all age bands in terms of services, with only the premium costs varying by age.

The company consistently selects the middle-tier option (Plan B) from three available tiers offered in each category (HSA, HMO, standard plan) by their current provider. The benefits package includes dental and vision coverage, which are bundled with the medical plan but paid for separately by employees at relatively low rates. The company does not contribute toward dependent coverage, though employees can purchase it at additional cost.

The company has fewer than 50 employees and offers benefits after a 90-day probationary period. The HSA component has been underutilized due to a poor user interface and administrative challenges. No specific information about the funding type (fully insured, level-funded, or self-funded) was mentioned in the conversation.

• Maria plans to have employees complete their plan selections by Friday (December 19, 2025), with the standard enrollment cutoff being Monday, December 22, 2025

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: European Stone Tile - ICHRA Consultation

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Company: European Stone Tile  
Meeting Type: Product Demo and Quote Review

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Primary Business Drivers:
- Administrative Burden Reduction: Maria is seeking to eliminate manual processes for health insurance and HSA contributions. Currently experiences issues with forgetting monthly payments and receiving threatening letters about policy expiration.
- Technology Integration: Primary motivation is finding a solution that integrates seamlessly with QuickBooks Online, similar to their recent 401(k) platform upgrade that automated processes.
- Cost Management: Managing 2026 renewal costs while maintaining competitive benefits for approximately 9 employees (under 50 employees, not subject to ACA employer mandate).

Current Situation:
- Current Provider: Primera Blue Cross (group plan)
- Current Contribution Model: Employer pays ~75%, employees pay ~25%
- Current Plan Details: 
  - $5,000-$6,000 individual deductible
  - $11,000-$12,000 family deductible
  - HSA-eligible plan (underutilized due to poor interface)
  - 90-day probationary period for new hires
- Current Monthly Contributions: Range from $300-$400 per employee (approximately $360-$362 average)
- Tenure: Providing benefits for over a decade

ICHRA Solution Discussed:
- Proposed Monthly Allowance: $395 per employee (flat dollar amount model recommended over age-banded approach due to company size)
- Platform Fees: 
  - $45 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
  - $50 flat monthly compliance fee
  - Total estimated: ~$455/month for 9 employees = ~$5,460 annually
- Total Estimated Annual Cost: $4,900/year (if all employees enroll)
- Cost Delta: Approximately $6,000 difference compared to current quotes from competitors

Key Features Highlighted:
1. QuickBooks Integration:
   - Automatic roster sync from QuickBooks to Thatch
   - Automated payroll deductions for employee premium overages
   - Eliminates manual payment processing

2. Multilingual Support:
   - High Hispanic employee population requiring Spanish language support
   - Spanish communications and resources available
   - Spanish-speaking licensed advisors for plan selection support
   - Website currently in English but uses Google Translate (full Spanish localization planned for next year)

3. Mobile Optimization:
   - Web-based enrollment optimized for mobile devices (both Android and Apple)
   - No dedicated app, but mobile-responsive design
   - Important for under-30 workforce

4. Employee Experience:
   - 29 plans available (EPO, HMO options from Ambetter, Kaiser, Blue Shield, United)
   - Individual market plans (cannot discriminate based on pre-existing conditions)
   - Priced only by age and location
   - 85% of employees complete enrollment without advisor assistance
   - AI chatbot for basic questions
   - Licensed broker support available 7am-8:40pm Central, including weekends

5. Plan Flexibility:
   - Employees can filter by provider networks, costs, and plan types
   - 60-day window to change plans after initial enrollment
   - HSA options available (employee would self-administer or use existing vendor)
   - Optional dental (Guardian) and vision (VSP, Renaissance) add-ons

Compliance & Administration:
- Pre-tax allowance structure (ICHRA = Individual Coverage Health Reimbursement Arrangement)
- No ACA employer mandate requirements (under 50 employees)
- Thatch handles all administration, COBRA (when applicable), 1095 forms, and compliance
- Four years in operation with zero payment delinquencies
- Stripe/Ramp infrastructure for reliable billing

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

At European Stone Tile (Prospect Company):
1. Maria (Primary Contact)
   - Role: Appears to be owner/decision-maker with financial responsibilities
   - Responsibilities: Benefits administration, payroll processing, vendor selection
   - Self-described as "most tech-savvy person" at company
   - Handles QuickBooks, HSA contributions, monthly insurance payments
   - Pain Points: Manual processes, forgetting payments, administrative burden

2. Partner (Unnamed)
   - Role: Business partner/co-decision-maker
   - Responsibilities: Must review and approve final decision
   - Maria needs to "sit down with my partner and kind of chat with him about all of this"

3. Director (Recently Joined)
   - Role: New hire from more advanced company
   - Influence: Opened management's eyes to integration tools and modern benefits administration
   - Catalyst for seeking better solutions

4. Employee Population:
   - Size: Approximately 9 employees (under 50 total)
   - Demographics: High Hispanic population, many Spanish-speaking
   - Age Range: Includes "under 30 crowd" and employees across age bands
   - Current Engagement: Some employees complained about previous 401(k) and HSA experiences

At Thatch (Vendor):
1. Seth Wood
   - Role: Sales Representative/Account Executive
   - Responsibilities: Product demonstration, quote preparation, customer education
   - Has been in communication with Maria for "a few weeks"

2. Monica
   - Role: Initial contact (likely SDR or Account Manager)
   - Maria spoke with Monica before Seth took over

3. Support Team
   - Licensed advisors available for Spanish-speaking employees
   - Support@thatch.com for post-enrollment issues
   - Available 7am-8:40pm Central, including weekends during enrollment

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Pre-Meeting Context:
- Several Weeks Prior: Initial contact between Maria and Monica at Thatch
- ~1.5 Years Ago: Maria struggled with 401(k) administration, leading to search for integrated solutions
- Recent: New director joined and complained about benefits administration, catalyzing change

During Meeting (December 16, 2025):
- Opening (0:00-5:00): Apologies for delay due to Q4/open enrollment busy period; Maria acknowledges being "last minute"
- 5:00-15:00: Overview of ICHRA model, flat dollar vs. age-banded approaches
- 15:00-25:00: Maria's three critical requirements revealed:
  1. QuickBooks integration
  2. Spanish language support
  3. Mobile device functionality
- 25:00-35:00: Quote review and cost breakdown discussion
- 35:00-45:00: Platform demonstration and enrollment flow walkthrough
- 45:00-50:00: Discussion of timeline, next steps, and decision-making process

Critical Moments:
1. Maria's Transparency: "I'm nothing if not just very straightforward. I found you guys simply by researching which insurance companies integrate with QuickBooks online."
2. Pain Point Revelation: Manual HSA processing, forgetting payments, threatening letters from carriers
3. Cost Comparison: Maria calculating $6,000 delta between Thatch and competitors
4. Positive Reception: "Very impressive. This is very much what I am looking for. This is how I like to treat my employees."
5. Decision Timeline: "24 hours is all I'm giving myself to make a decision"

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (December 16, 2025 - Same Day):
Responsible: Seth Wood
- [ ] Send quote link with dynamic tool for Maria to review and adjust allowance amounts
- [ ] Provide public-facing tool for employees to preview plan options
- [ ] Send QuickBooks integration help articles and setup documentation
- [ ] Share Spanish language resources and communications materials
- [ ] Provide all supporting resources and documentation

Responsible: Maria
- [ ] Review quote and play with dynamic tool
- [ ] Meet with business partner to discuss proposal and make decision
- [ ] Review all other competitor quotes for final comparison

Short-Term Actions (December 17-20, 2025):
Responsible: Maria
- [ ] Make final decision on moving forward with Thatch (24-hour self-imposed deadline)
- [ ] Notify Seth of decision
- [ ] If proceeding, initiate Thatch account setup (10-15 minutes)

Responsible: Seth Wood
- [ ] Follow up with Maria for decision
- [ ] Be available for any economic discussions or questions
- [ ] Assist with account setup if Maria decides to proceed

Enrollment Period (By December 22-28, 2025):
Critical Deadlines:
- Standard Cutoff: Monday, December 22, 2025 (for January 1, 2026 effective date)
- Possible Extension: Saturday, December 28, 2025 (requires team approval)

Responsible: Maria (If Proceeding)
- [ ] Complete Thatch account setup
- [ ] Complete bank verification (1-3 business days, possibly same-day)
- [ ] Invite eligible employees through Thatch platform
- [ ] Conduct employee meetings (group and individual sessions as needed)
- [ ] Ensure all employees complete enrollment by deadline
- [ ] Plan: "Pulling each employee in and sitting them down" by Friday to complete enrollment

Responsible: Thatch
- [ ] Process bank verification
- [ ] Provide enrollment support
- [ ] Make licensed advisors available for Spanish-speaking employees
- [ ] Process enrollments and submit to carriers

Post-Enrollment (January 2026):
Responsible: Thatch
- [ ] Process first premium payments on 15th of month
- [ ] Handle any carrier issues or enrollment problems
- [ ] Provide ongoing support through support@thatch.com

Responsible: Maria
- [ ] Monitor QuickBooks integration and payroll deductions
- [ ] Address any employee questions or concerns
- [ ] Evaluate 90-day probationary period for new hires and invite when eligible

DECISION FACTORS & CONSIDERATIONS

Pros Identified:
- Seamless QuickBooks integration eliminates manual work
- Spanish language support for employee population
- Mobile-optimized for younger workforce
- Automated payroll deductions
- No payment delinquencies in 4-year company history
- Employee choice and flexibility
- Licensed advisor support included
- Comprehensive administration and compliance handling

Concerns/Questions Addressed:
- No automatic alerts for 90-day eligibility (may need QuickBooks reminder)
- Website not fully translated to Spanish yet (planned for next year)
- HSA would need to be self-administered by employees
- Carriers may still send billing reminders (can be ignored)
- Cost delta of ~$6,000 annually vs. competitors

Outstanding Items:
- Final decision pending partner discussion
- Review of QuickBooks integration documentation
- Comparison with other competitor quotes
- Determination of final monthly allowance amount ($395 proposed)

ACCOUNT STATUS

Stage: Late-stage evaluation/decision imminent  
Temperature: Hot - Maria expressed strong interest and appreciation  
Competition: Multiple other quotes received  
Timeline: Extremely urgent - 24-hour decision window, enrollment must complete by December 22-28, 2025  
Key Risk: Tight timeline may create implementation challenges  
Win Probability: High based on enthusiasm and fit with requirements

Quote: "Seth, thank you for how expeditious you've been... It's actually been very clear. So thank you. Very well done."

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect (Maria) currently administers employee benefits manually without using a benefits administration platform. She describes the process as "very manual for a very long time," involving manual processing of HSA contributions and monthly health insurance payments. She sometimes forgets to make payments because the process is not automated, which has resulted in receiving threatening letters from carriers about policy expiration if payments aren't made by the 10th of the month.

Maria uses QuickBooks Online for payroll and accounting. She has repeatedly asked her current insurance provider for automated ACH withdrawals but was told "we're not there yet." 

They work with a broker or insurance organization that provides them with group plan options. This organization offers three tiers per category (HSA, HMO, standard plans), and Maria typically selects the middle-tier option ("Plan B"). They've been with Primera Blue Cross and have been providing employee benefits for over a decade.

About 1.5 years ago, a new director from a more advanced company complained about their benefits administration and introduced them to integration tools. Since then, Maria successfully implemented a 401k plan that integrates with QuickBooks, which she describes as "a godsend" compared to the manual health insurance and HSA processes.

Maria's primary motivation for exploring Thatch is finding a solution that integrates with QuickBooks Online to automate benefits administration and eliminate the manual workflows she currently manages.

- Seth effectively captured team size and plan details, ensuring a strong understanding of the current plan structure.
- Seth missed mapping the decision process; next, ask about the partner's role and decision timeline.
- Seth didn't fully explore pain points; next, delve deeper into manual processing issues for more insights.

attributes.title: MARIA / Seth: Thatch
attributes.transcript:
Seth Wood:
Hey, Maria. 
maria:
Good morning. 
Seth Wood:
Good morning. I'm so sorry to keep you waiting a few minutes today. 
maria:
No, you're perfectly fine. It's great. 
Seth Wood:
It's, you know, Q4, open enrollment, Q4, anywhere. It's just busy. It is. 
maria:
And I'm not helping by being last minute. So thanks for your patience. 
Seth Wood:
Oh, you don't, don't feel too bad, because tell you, there's groups like Mega, bigger groups that are still figuring it out. So I can't believe it, but that's how it works. So yeah. And I appreciate you jumping on a call. Realistically, I obviously want to meet, connect, but also just want to walk you through, there's going to be questions when we show you the quote. So I just want you to like, see it and we can answer in real time and make sure you understand like the tool. I appreciate that. It'll be dynamic and you can get a link today so you can start playing around with it and look at it. But, yeah, I know we've been chatting for a few weeks, so no worries. And thank you for being. I wasn't trying to be any difficult. It's just we're trying to run it as accurate as possible. So our system is going to be. 
maria:
Oh, no, absolutely. 
Seth Wood:
I totally happily to help make it as easy as possible with whatever we need to do. So, yeah, I know, because I know you spoke to Monica and then me. I jumped in later, but. But basically what I'll do, I'll show you the, I ran two quotes for you. I didn't want to make it too complicated, but I did want to show you the two ways you can do it. So with this model, with an ICRA, and feel free to pop in any point if you have questions, But just to highlight how it will work. You can offer, you can do two things. You can offer every person a flat dollar amount. You can say, hey, I'm giving every person very somewhat similar to what you're doing today. So if you wanted to offer everybody 360-ish. Some people have more or less, but you can give them a simple $400, whatever you decided. That's probably the most straightforward way to do it at a group your size, if you did have that. These plans are also priced on the individual market. One of the advantages to the individual marketplace is obviously they can't disqualify you for pre-existing conditions. They can't, if you're really sick or you have special needs, they're not going to charge you more for your premiums. So they can't do anything like that. The only thing they can do is price the plans by age and location. That's the only two things. fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Prospects:

1. J&H Reptile Mythology (Primary discussion)
   - Current Setup: Small group HMO plan, $1,500 deductible, $6,250 out-of-pocket max; paying $7,309/month (2026 rates); ~$333/employee allowance (50/50 split)
   - Status: Applicable Large Employer (ALE, 50+ FTEs); California-based
   
2. 4-Life Group (Secondary discussion)
   - Current Setup: No active plan; previously had ICHRA with Take Command (dropped ~1 year ago); currently contributes 75%/70% of Kaiser rates
   - Demographics: Ages late 40s to 60

Pain Points/Challenges:
- ICHRA dynamic range quote shows higher costs for J&H ($9,269/month vs current $7,309/month)
- Flat dollar ICHRA option ($333/employee) yields similar costs ($7,326/month pre-fees) with no clear advantage
- Confusion about dynamic range methodology (age-banded contributions) vs flat dollar approach
- ALE compliance concerns regarding affordability requirements (9.96% household income rule)
- Missing salary data needed for accurate compliance calculations
- 4-life group uncertain if they need to restart ICHRA on 1/1 or can start mid-year

Priorities/Optimization Goals:
- Understanding ICHRA mechanics and contribution models
- Finding cost-effective alternatives to current group plans
- Ensuring ALE compliance
- Simplifying employee communication about allowances

Stated Timelines:
- J&H Reptile: No immediate timeline; exploring options for current year
- 4-Life Group: Target 2026-02-01 start date
- Standard enrollment cutoff: 22nd of month (extension to 28th possible)
- Employees need ~2 weeks to select plans after enrollment opens

Outcome: J&H Reptile does not appear to be a strong ICHRA fit at current pricing; no cost savings identified.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes - Thatch ICHRA Discussion
Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Participants: Seth Wood (Thatch), Jeff Lue (One Digital - Broker/Benefits Consultant)

ACCOUNT 1: J&H REPTILE MYTHOLOGY

Executive Summary
Initial ICHRA quote review for J&H Reptile Mythology's 2026 renewal. After detailed analysis, the ICHRA solution does not present a clear cost advantage over their current group plan arrangement.

Key Discussion Points

Current Situation:
- Employer currently offers HMO deductible plan: $1,500 deductible, $6,250 out-of-pocket maximum
- Current contribution structure: Flat $332-333 per employee per month (50/50 split)
- 2026 monthly cost: $7,309
- Company is an Applicable Large Employer (ALE) - over 50 full-time equivalents
- Located in California

ICHRA Pricing Models Discussed:

1. Dynamic/Age-Banded Approach (Recommended by Thatch):
   - Allowances range from $354 to $738 based on employee age
   - Benchmarked against 25th percentile gold plan (equivalent to current $1,500 deductible plan)
   - 50% employer cost share maintained
   - Estimated monthly cost: $9,269 (approximately $1,960/month increase)
   - More equitable for older employees whose individual market premiums are higher
   - Compliant with IRS ICHRA regulations (allowances must increase with age, cannot exceed 3:1 ratio)

2. Flat Dollar Approach:
   - $333 per employee per month (matching current structure)
   - Estimated monthly cost: $7,326 pre-fees
   - Essentially cost-neutral compared to current arrangement
   - Simpler to administer but less equitable for older employees

Compliance Issues Identified:
- Red flags in system due to missing salary information
- ALE affordability requirement: Employees cannot pay more than 9.96% of household income for lowest-level Silver plan
- System currently using poverty level as default (needs updating with actual salary data)

Cost Analysis Conclusion:
- No significant cost advantage for ICHRA versus current group plan
- Dynamic model increases costs by ~$1,960/month
- Flat dollar model essentially cost-neutral (~$17/month difference pre-fees)
- Standard PEPM fee: $30 per enrolled employee per month

Educational Points Covered:
- Individual marketplace plans priced by age and location (similar to auto insurance model)
- ICHRA allows age-based contribution increases (compliant under IRS rules)
- Cannot do age-based contributions with traditional small group plans
- ICHRA managed by IRS with clear black-and-white guidelines
- Plans sourced off-exchange directly from carriers (not through Covered California exchange)

ACCOUNT 2: UNNAMED 4-LIFE GROUP

Brief Overview
- 4 employees, California-based
- Current contribution: 75% of Kaiser premium (percentage-based)
- Age range: Late 40s to 60 years old
- Quote previously provided by Joe (Thatch team member)

Discussion Points:
- Cannot do percentage-based contributions with ICHRA (dollar amounts only)
- Recommendation: Convert current 75% contribution to flat dollar amount
- Given small group size and same zip code, flat dollar approach recommended for simplicity
- Potential 2-1-2026 effective date discussed

Open Question:
- Employer previously had ICHRA with Take Command, dropped it a year ago
- Uncertainty about whether they need to restart on 1-1 or can start mid-year
- Seth's opinion: If no current plan in place, start date shouldn't matter (needs verification)

STAKEHOLDER IDENTIFICATION

Thatch (ICHRA Provider):
- Seth Wood - Account Executive/Sales Representative
  - Role: Primary contact, product education, quoting, compliance guidance
  - Responsibilities: Quote generation, demo presentations, technical support
  - Email contact provided for follow-up questions

- Joe - Team Member (mentioned)
  - Role: Handled initial quote for 4-life group
  - Can assist with enrollment deadline extensions

One Digital (Broker/Benefits Consultant):
- Jeff Lue - Benefits Consultant/Broker
  - Role: Client relationship manager, benefits advisor
  - Responsibilities: Presenting options to employer clients, coordinating with vendors
  - Previous experience with Take Command (Thatch competitor)

Employer Groups:
- J&H Reptile Mythology - Primary prospect (decision-maker not on call)
- Unnamed 4-Life Group - Secondary prospect (decision-maker not on call)

CRITICAL MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

December 16, 2025 (Call Date):
- Initial quote review and education session conducted
- Compliance gaps identified (missing salary data)
- Cost comparison completed showing no advantage for J&H Reptile Mythology

Key Enrollment Deadlines Discussed:

For 1-1-2026 Effective Date:
- Standard enrollment cutoff: December 22, 2025 (Monday) - 6 DAYS FROM CALL
- Possible extension: December 28, 2025 - 12 DAYS FROM CALL
- Admin account setup: 10 minutes
- Bank verification: 2-3 days (potential bottleneck)
- Note: Larger groups already in pipeline for 1-1-2026 start

For 2-1-2026 Effective Date:
- Recommended for 4-life group
- Would allow 2+ weeks for employee plan selection (standard timeline)
- More realistic timeline given current date

Historical Context:
- J&H Reptile Mythology 2026 rates already received and quoted
- 4-life group previously had ICHRA with Take Command, discontinued ~1 year ago

COMPETITIVE INTELLIGENCE

Thatch vs. Take Command:
- Thatch: All-in-one platform, in-house administration
- Take Command: Uses multiple vendors, less tech-forward
- Thatch advantages highlighted:
  - Single platform for all functions (enrollment, COBRA, filings, payments)
  - Off-exchange enrollment (90% of cases, except NY and some states)
  - Automated 1095 and ACA filings included
  - Thatch debit card for unqualified medical expenses
  - Batch dashboard for employer administration
  - Zero delinquencies in 4 years
  - Built by FinTech team (Stripe, Ramp background)
  - Many Take Command customers switching to Thatch in 2025

Resources Provided:
- Thatch.com/plans - Plan comparison tool (can be used for any prospective group)
- Employee-specific plan views available in quoting tool
- Onboarding videos and resources to be sent

NEXT STEPS & ACTION ITEMS

Immediate Actions (Seth Wood - Thatch):
- [ ] COMPLETED DURING CALL: Provide education on dynamic vs. flat dollar ICHRA models
- [ ] PENDING: Send flat dollar quote ($333/employee) for J&H Reptile Mythology
- [ ] PENDING: Send onboarding resources and video materials to Jeff
- [ ] PENDING: Send thatch.com/plans link for future reference
- [ ] IF REQUESTED: Rerun J&H quote with actual salary information (currently using poverty level default)

Jeff Lue (One Digital) - Action Items:
- [ ] PRIORITY: Share both quotes (dynamic and flat dollar) with J&H Reptile Mythology
- [ ] PRIORITY: Obtain salary information for lowest-paid eligible employee at J&H (if pursuing ICHRA)
- [ ] DEADLINE: December 22, 2025: Confirm if J&H wants to proceed for 1-1-2026 (or request extension to 12-28-2025)
- [ ] FOR 4-LIFE GROUP: Verify whether mid-year start is permissible given previous ICHRA history
- [ ] FOR 4-LIFE GROUP: Calculate current 75% Kaiser contribution in flat dollar amounts
- [ ] FOR 4-LIFE GROUP: Target 2-1-2026 effective date
- [ ] Review onboarding materials from Seth

Collaborative Next Steps:
- [ ] IF INTEREST CONTINUES: Schedule demo call with employer (Seth/Joe to present, Jeff to facilitate)
- [ ] IF PURSUING: Coordinate on timeline - 1-1-2026 (aggressive) vs. 2-1-2026 (recommended)
- [ ] ONGOING: Jeff to use Seth as ICHRA resource; Seth to use Jeff as group plan resource

Decision Points:
- J&H Reptile Mythology: Likely NOT moving forward due to lack of cost savings
  - No advantage over current group plan
  - Would need significant rate increase on group side to make ICHRA attractive
  
- 4-Life Group: Potentially viable for 2-1-2026
  - Pending verification of restart requirements
  - Needs conversion of percentage to dollar contribution
  - Age variance (late 40s to 60) may benefit from dynamic model

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Technical Learning Points for Jeff:
- ICHRA contributions must be in dollar amounts (not percentages)
- Age-banded contributions are IRS-compliant for ICHRA but not traditional group plans
- Dynamic model uses percentile benchmarking (e.g., 25th percentile gold plan)
- System calculates affordability based on lowest-level Silver plan in employee's area
- Employer can adjust cost-share percentage and percentile benchmark as desired

Outstanding Questions:
1. Can 4-life group start mid-year given previous ICHRA termination? (Needs research)
2. What are actual salary ranges for J&H employees? (Affects compliance calculations)
3. Will J&H's 2027 group rates make ICHRA more competitive? (Future consideration)

Relationship Status:
- First formal meeting between Seth and Jeff
- Established mutual expertise areas (Seth: ICHRA, Jeff: Group plans)
- Open communication channel for future opportunities
- Jeff has direct email access to Seth for questions

RECOMMENDATION SUMMARY

J&H Reptile Mythology: Not recommended to pursue at this time. Cost-neutral at best, with potential for increased costs under dynamic model. No administrative or financial advantage over current group arrangement. Revisit if 2027 group renewal shows significant increases.

4-Life Group: Potentially viable for 2-1-2026 pending resolution of restart question and conversion of contribution structure to flat dollar amounts. Age variance in group may benefit from ICHRA's individual market pricing.

Date: 2025-12-16

Prospects:

1. J&H Reptile Mythology (Primary discussion)
   - Current Setup: Small group HMO plan, $1,500 deductible, $6,250 out-of-pocket max; paying $7,309/month (2026 rates); ~$333/employee allowance (50/50 split)
   - Status: Applicable Large Employer (ALE, 50+ FTEs); California-based
   
2. 4-Life Group (Secondary discussion)
   - Current Setup: No active plan; previously had ICHRA with Take Command (dropped ~1 year ago); currently contributes 75%/70% of Kaiser rates
   - Demographics: Ages late 40s to 60

Pain Points/Challenges:
- ICHRA dynamic range quote shows higher costs for J&H ($9,269/month vs current $7,309/month)
- Flat dollar ICHRA option ($333/employee) yields similar costs ($7,326/month pre-fees) with no clear advantage
- Confusion about dynamic range methodology (age-banded contributions) vs flat dollar approach
- ALE compliance concerns regarding affordability requirements (9.96% household income rule)
- Missing salary data needed for accurate compliance calculations
- 4-life group uncertain if they need to restart ICHRA on 1/1 or can start mid-year

Priorities/Optimization Goals:
- Understanding ICHRA mechanics and contribution models
- Finding cost-effective alternatives to current group plans
- Ensuring ALE compliance
- Simplifying employee communication about allowances

Stated Timelines:
- J&H Reptile: No immediate timeline; exploring options for current year
- 4-Life Group: Target 2026-02-01 start date
- Standard enrollment cutoff: 22nd of month (extension to 28th possible)
- Employees need ~2 weeks to select plans after enrollment opens

Outcome: J&H Reptile does not appear to be a strong ICHRA fit at current pricing; no cost savings identified.

Uh, yeah, for sure. And then the tool also will show you that if you just click on an employee FYI like the View plans. It'll break down all of that same information. With whatever allowance that we've adjusted here on the left and show them what they'd be paying and stuff there, too. 
Jeff Lue:
So can I use that just for any group, or does it have to be, oh, for any group? 
Seth Wood:
I would use that, that tool. Use this tool if you want to get an idea. If you want a quote, you just. You can send it over in the future to me. And we can run it without having to meet. Once you understand the tool, I can just run it. I can just give you a little blurb. Hey, this one seems potentially like a fit, or this doesn't. As long as you understand the tool, I think it's a lot easier to to figure out. 
Jeff Lue:
But yeah, okay, another question. So I know, like I worked with Take Command before. Um, I'm assuming that's a competitor, right? is that or not? Really? Yeah, they're, they're, they're a competitor. 
Seth Wood:
But we've got a lot of their customers switching from them to us this year for a lot of different reasons. But yeah, we're more tech forward than they are, and Yeah, a lot more seamless than they have in their experiences, from what I understand, with other customers. 
Jeff Lue:
Yeah, so that's what I was going to ask you. Because my experience is that it's pretty straightforward, for the most part on take Command. But the one piece that I felt was kind of a huge miss on their side, and I'm hoping you guys do, is kind of the whole help with the filing. Because I'm assuming you still have to do the whole recovery fee and all that stuff. Or stop. 
Seth Wood:
So, some of the customers that I've worked with take command, and I don't know if this is your experience, but they use multiple vendors. To connect everything together, we do everything in one place, in-house. It's all through thatch. So like we handle just to kind of give you like a high level. Like we do all the filings for them, everything is included, right? So like ACAS filings 1095, we manage the cobra, we do it. We two weeks, one stop shop and no employees going on the exchange. It's through thatch 90% of the time, like, there's a couple of states that are weird. That's just like New York or some other weird ones, but every other employee goes through thatch. So I would say, Take Command has not invested in the technology, and the technology has made the ICHRA a lot more appealing. And so they go through the thatch for the enrollment, they choose the plan. And then they get, if they have leftover dollars with the ICHRA, cause they can have that option. If they want to have leftover dollars, they have a thatch debit card we have for them so they can utilize those unqualified medical expenses. We have a marketplace that we've built out. It's a lot more streamlined. And then administratively for the employer, which is super important, they have like a batch dashboard where they can, like this, they see the view of all their employees that have enrolled. They can see and generate reports. They can also off-board the employee, right? If they're done, they can click off-board, and then we'll send out the Cobra notice right away and then stop the payments. And so they can do a lot. It's a lot. The product is very good. Like, I, we're from, we're from Stripe, Rex, Ramp, FinTech. That's kind of how we built the background, backend of things. We have had no delinquencies in four years. So like, we're very, very tech forward. And that helps the problems that some of the other vendors that we've had now, no shade on anyone's just, we hear other ICHRA providers. We had a lot of customers switching from other providers to us this year. So I think it shows that not everyone does the basics really perfectly, and some people get more. You know, bad experiences, right? And so at least we have good infrastructure here that we've built out. 
Jeff Lue:
Yeah, that's, that's really helpful. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, I'll send you some videos, onboarding resources, just so you have your back pockets you can look at later with us. But yeah, like, obviously, this group is not perfect here. And if it was these were the 2025 rates, I'd be like, Oh, maybe 26 is still higher and this could be more competitive. But in that case, this is, yeah. I think your instinct was totally fair and I that's why I just sent it over just to get you. At least take a look at it. But it doesn't seem like a home run hit, for sure. 
Jeff Lue:
Yeah, um, I know we're running out of time here. But I had a my other group. I quoted to a smaller group. I forgot who I talked to. Um, but it was four lives, was it? JOSEPH Yeah, yeah, yeah, okay. Um, that might work. I guess, I think, you know, we're struggling with. The whole contribution is right now, they are doing like a percentage, like a 75% of Kaiser's 70%. That's kind of how it started. Got it. Then, you know, it was showing me the dynamic rate, and then, you know, either dynamic rate, or flat rate, flat dollar. Could they still do a percentage kind of more traditionally, or is that not really? 
Seth Wood:
Only because these are in dollar amounts. It's harder to, you can't really do a percentage on individual plans. So we can do a percentage with the dynamic, but it's a percentage of a benchmark. It's not like a percentage of a plan and it's going to be the more dynamic. If it's a group for people, are they in the same age range? Are they kind of all over the place? 
Jeff Lue:
Right. Rough, It's kind of rough, it's probably like late 40s, the one, and another one is 60. That was. 
Seth Wood:
I was asking what I would be doing. I would, I mean, I know they're doing it already. I would just be saying, what's the 75 in dollar amounts currently? What does it look like if we just do that flat rate for everybody, because that's the easiest path, especially with only four employees? Usually, flat dollars seem to be pretty good if they're in the same Zip code, if they're not, and the ages or variants. Dynamic can make a lot more healthier sense, but they can contribute whatever they want. Um, but that's the shifting mindset of the ICHRA. It's just it's like, what do you want to budget, like, how much do you want to spend on your health care for your employees? And that's that's the freedom they have, the flexibility they have. So it's going to be more like, because the plans might cost a different amount on the individual market than they do here, they might be less for some people. So I would just be focusing on the dollar amount they're currently spending on each employee and try to average it or figure out if a flat dollar could work. Just to keep it easy for them to comprehend. 
Jeff Lue:
Like, that's what we used to do, but that's cool. I can share that with that group. They can look at it and those would be, would those actually be plans that would be available, should they go this route? Okay. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, yeah, yeah. And also, Don, we are happy to jump in. Joe could jump in. You're not having to, you can definitely show the interest, build that up if you have, you think this could be helpful, But we would always want to jump on a call to show the demo and walk them through the quote, too. So don't feel like you have to position this alone with that. You're, you're allowed to ask us. We prefer to do it that way because it's it's you're not going to know. Ikra, I know Ikra, I don't know. Group, I would trust you to group. If I had a group plan. I'd be like, Hey, I've got my guy, Jeff, I'm gonna have you talk to Jeff, like he's gonna tell you everything you need to know. I wouldn't know anything about that. So let us be a resource. 
Jeff Lue:
Yeah, another question is, for now, uh, turn around time. So, like, you know, obviously one one's around the corner. 221. What do we? 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, we can do a one-one. Our standard cutoff enrollment standard has been the 22nd, Monday. Setting up a badge account is not hard. It takes 10 minutes to set up an admin account. And then the only time, the only thing that can take two to three days is just bank verification, in case that needs to be manually verified. So we need to move this week. If it's needed to be done, we could get an extension for the 28th. We could move that out a little further. That's a possibility. You could talk to Joe about that group. Um, that can be done. Worst case, then, if that's not doable, they need more time. We could look at a 2-1, but it's we have groups bigger in size that are looking to potentially move forward. Uh, this week, so yeah, yeah, in this case, uh, I will. 
Jeff Lue:
Sorry, this other group, not the group we're talking about, um, probably would be a two one perfect. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, yeah, that in the beginning of the next month, you know, if they get things rolling, this is what they want to do, we could. They could then give their team at least two weeks to choose a plan. It's standard. 
Jeff Lue:
So, one more question. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, you're good. 
Jeff Lue:
Because I guess, so when I was talking to him, I'm saying, that had taken me. But then they dropped it a year ago. So he wasn't sure if they had to restart it. He thought they restarted. They had to restart it on one one. I said, can you find out that? 
Seth Wood:
Well, I'll take that. Are they on a group plan today, though? Or no? 
Jeff Lue:
Nothing. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, like, I would circle back with them on that. I don't know the answer, so I don't want to steer you wrong. But my opinion would be, if they're not currently on an ICRA, and they don't have any current plans, I don't know why it would make any difference. Like, I don't understand. 
Jeff Lue:
Like, there's nothing in place. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, like, my gut instinct, but I could be totally wrong, because healthcare is complicated. So. 
Jeff Lue:
I don't know. 
Seth Wood:
It's not easy. Yeah. But yeah, I do have to hop off. If you do have questions that pop up after, feel free to shoot me an email. I'm happy to look into them. But yeah, we'll get the next one, hopefully. And yeah, just keep us in the loop. Yeah, I did. I'll send you the flat dollar amount one, too. And if you want to run, if you know the salary information, I can rerun it with the right salary information. But I don't, it's not going to really make a difference. Yeah, I don't think it matters to myself. 
Jeff Lue:
Okay, at this point. 
Seth Wood:
I agree. Yeah, yeah. Okay, cool. 
Jeff Lue:
Thanks, I appreciate it. 
Seth Wood:
You too. Have a great week. Bye. Bye.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Participants: Christian, Devin (ADP ICHRA reps), Nic, Zach, Tonya (Thatch team)

What's In Place:
- Dedicated ICHRA sales team at ADP (Christian in Allentown, PA; Devin in Pittsburgh, PA)
- Receiving 40-50 ICHRA-specific leads per week from deal desk and H&B partner bubble-downs
- New compensation structure launched: $1,800 for 10+ employees, $4,100 for 25+ employees
- Two new reps hired: Priscilla (has group health experience) and Courtney (transitioned from health sales)
- Achieving 2-3 day sales cycle vs. 30-45 days for traditional group health
- Strong performance: Christian closed 16 units last month at $16K revenue; Devin at 12 units this month

Priorities:
- Maintain fast turnaround and high close rates
- Scale team to handle lead volume
- Train new reps on ICHRA and Thatch platform (scheduled for 2025-12-17)

Pain Points:
- Platform bug: DP run connection process fails after completing all steps (Sailor 100 Group example)
- Prospects page cluttered with 70+ accounts, no search functionality
- Cannot delete old/duplicate quotes from prospects page
- Quote resharing issues when quotes sit too long
- New York market has limited plan options

Optimization Goals:
- Add search bar to prospects page
- Enable deletion of prospects/old quotes for cleaner interface
- Streamline "bring your own plan" integration process
- Continue leveraging speed advantage over traditional group (no QBMS headaches, no quarterly wage/tax audits)

Stated Timelines:
- New rep training: 2025-12-17
- Bring your own plan client call: Early next week (2025-12-22 or 2025-12-23)
- New compensation contest: Running for next 3 months
- Marketplace enrollment deadline: Closed 2025-12-15

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes - Internal Team Sync Meeting
Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Meeting Title: Christian/Devin/Nic/Zach/Tonya Sync

Meeting Overview
This was an internal sync meeting between ADP ICHRA sales representatives and Thatch platform team members. The conversation focused on sales performance, new rep onboarding, platform improvements, and operational processes rather than a specific employer prospect discussion.

1. Key Discussion Points

ICHRA Sales Performance & Process
- Sales Velocity: Christian and Devin report 2-3 day sales cycles from initial call to closed deal, compared to 3+ weeks for traditional group health
- Volume Metrics: Team receiving 40-50 leads per week; Christian closed 16 units last month with $16K revenue; Devin has 12 units in December
- Close Rate: Team achieving high close percentages according to DeRosa's weekly update
- Revenue Structure: New compensation contest launched - $1,800 for 10+ employees, $4,100 for 25+ employees based on active payroll

Platform Technical Issues
- DP Connection Error: Issue identified where employers complete marketplace subscription and DP login but connection fails to complete (Sailor 100 Group account)
- Prospect Page Limitations: Need for search bar functionality and ability to delete old/duplicate quotes (Devin has ~70 accounts making navigation difficult)
- Quote Expiration: When quotes sit too long, resending with onboarding privileges doesn't properly save/create new account

Team Expansion
- New Hires: Two new reps added - Priscilla (Allentown, PA) and Courtney (location TBD)
- Training Scheduled: Thatch platform training scheduled for December 17, 2025
- Geographic Coverage: Team now spans Allentown PA, Pittsburgh PA, Tucson AZ

2. Stakeholder Identification

ADP ICHRA Sales Team
- Christian: ICHRA sales rep, Allentown PA - Training Priscilla, 16 units closed last month
- Devin (messengd): ICHRA sales rep, Pittsburgh PA - Training Courtney, 12 units in current month
- Priscilla: New rep, has prior group health insurance experience, received full-day training from Christian on December 15, 2025
- Courtney: New rep, has 1 year health insurance experience, recently returned from vacation and assigned to ICHRA role

Thatch Platform Team
- Tonya Salter: Platform support/customer success
- Nic Paul: Platform support/sales enablement
- Zach Laurer: Platform support (newly introduced to team)

Referenced Partners
- Sutherland's Team: H&B partners with Thatch access
- Total Source Reps: Referring clients due to participation issues and cost concerns

3. Important Milestones & Timestamps

December 15, 2025 (Yesterday):
- Open enrollment deadline for marketplace plans closed
- Christian provided full-day ICHRA training to Priscilla

December 16, 2025 (Meeting Date - 10:00 AM EST):
- Sync meeting held
- Technical issues with Sailor 100 Group account identified
- Platform improvement requests submitted
- New merchant referral from Echo mentioned

December 16, 2025 (4:45 PM EST - Scheduled):
- Devin conducting full account setup call with Russian/Ukrainian client
- Courtney shadowing to learn integration process

December 17, 2025 (Tomorrow - Scheduled):
- Thatch platform training for Priscilla and Courtney
- Full walkthrough of Thatch platform and ICHRA processes

Week of December 23, 2025 (Next Week):
- Devin scheduling call with client regarding bring-your-own-plan integration
- Requesting Thatch team member to join call for support

4. Next Steps with Deadlines & Responsible Parties

Immediate Actions (December 16-17, 2025)

Tonya Salter:
- [ ] Submit ticket for DP connection error (Sailor 100 Group account) - ASAP
- [ ] Submit product requests to development team:
  - Add search bar functionality to Prospects page
  - Enable deletion of old/duplicate prospects
- [ ] Conduct platform training for new reps - December 17, 2025

Zach Laurer:
- [ ] Send email address to Christian for future communications - December 16, 2025

Nic Paul:
- [ ] Send "bring your own plan" documentation and guide to Devin - December 16, 2025 (sent during meeting)

Devin:
- [ ] Conduct account setup call with Russian/Ukrainian client with Courtney shadowing - December 16, 2025 at 4:45 PM
- [ ] Schedule bring-your-own-plan integration call with client - Week of December 23, 2025
- [ ] Request Thatch team member availability for client call - Week of December 23, 2025

Christian:
- [ ] Continue training Priscilla on ICHRA processes - Ongoing
- [ ] Review bring-your-own-plan documentation - December 17, 2025

Ongoing Priorities

Sales Team:
- Maintain 2-3 day sales cycle velocity
- Continue high-volume lead processing (40-50 leads/week)
- Leverage new compensation structure to maximize unit closures
- Train new reps on fast-paced ICHRA sales methodology

Platform Team:
- Monitor and resolve technical issues
- Implement requested platform improvements
- Provide ongoing support for bring-your-own-plan integrations
- Schedule follow-up training sessions with new reps over coming weeks

Additional Context

Competitive Advantages Identified
- ICHRA eliminates quarterly wage & tax requirements
- No QBMS backend work required
- Guaranteed issue removes underwriting delays
- Faster partner payouts through roll call vs. 30-45 day carrier payments
- Higher partner commissions driving more referrals

Market Challenges
- New York market has limited plan options
- Some clients prefer full payroll integration over FSA card option
- Managing high lead volume with limited rep capacity (reason for new hires)

Client Scenarios Mentioned
- Sailor 100 Group: Technical connection issue
- Russian/Ukrainian client: Requires translation assistance for plan explanations
- Marketplace plan client: Wants full integration vs. FSA card, scheduled for follow-up week of December 23, 2025

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: 2025-12-16

Client/Prospect: Risant Health (Sarah Kee, Will Calderwood, Stefan Jarmusz)

What They Have in Place:
- Implementing Workday HRIS system (currently on version 45.1)
- Moving to ICHRA benefits model through Thatch
- Test environment (RH1 tenant) established with ISU account created
- Biweekly payroll schedule (pays on Fridays, even if holidays)
- Employee ID format: 3-digit with padded zeros (001-999)
- Successfully connected Workday test environment to Thatch during call

Priorities:
1. Complete Workday-Thatch integration testing
2. Validate employee data sync from Workday to Thatch
3. Test deduction file process back to Workday
4. Coordinate open enrollment timing with system go-live
5. Ensure production environment ready before open enrollment

Pain Points/Challenges:
- No employee data currently in test environment
- Originally planned paper-based open enrollment due to timing concerns
- Need to align March open enrollment with April system go-live
- Concern about duplicate employee records if manual upload used
- 90-day advance notice requirement for ICHRA communication
- Must finalize funding approach before employee communication

Optimization Goals:
- Seamless automated data sync between Workday and Thatch (24-hour sync cycle)
- Test hire, job change, and termination scenarios to ensure data accuracy
- Establish clean production cutover without duplicate records

Call #1

Call Date / Timestamp: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Client Name / Account: Risant Health  
Call Type: Configuration

1. Objectives
- Set up and test Workday-to-Thatch integration connection for ICHRA benefits administration
- Discuss unit testing approach and plan for end-to-end testing in January 2026

2. Key Updates / Progress
- Integration Setup Completed: Successfully connected Workday test environment (RH1 tenant) to Thatch demo account using ISU credentials
- System Account Created: Deloitte created ISU (Integration System User) account in Workday with necessary security permissions
- Security Permissions Added: Added required domains including "Get Access to Worker Data," "Manage Organization Integration," and "Private Work Email Integration"
- Connection Validated: Integration successfully authenticated and connected
- Payroll Schedule Configured: Set biweekly pay schedule with Friday paydays (no adjustment for holidays as direct deposit processes automatically)
- Data Staging in Progress: Deloitte team working to create fictitious employee data in test tenant by end of week (December 20, 2025)
- Current Blocker: No employee data currently exists in test environment for validation

3. Client Input / Feedback
- Open Enrollment Timeline Clarification: Sarah Kee indicated original plan was to conduct March 1, 2026 open enrollment on paper, manually entering data into Workday post-go-live
- Preference for Workday-Based Enrollment: Team agreed it would be cleaner to conduct open enrollment directly in Workday if production environment is ready
- Adjusted Open Enrollment Window: If using Workday, Sarah prefers opening enrollment on Friday, February 27, 2026 (instead of Sunday, March 1) and closing by March 15, 2026
- Email Preference: Brad O'Neill noted that personal email addresses are preferred over work emails for ICHRA transitions
- Employee ID Format: Sarah confirmed need for 3-digit employee IDs with padded zeros (001-999 range expected)

4. Action Items
- [Alia/Thatch] → Send email with required employee data fields for test scenarios → December 17, 2025
- [Raghav/Deloitte] → Create fictitious employee data in Workday test tenant with specified fields → December 20, 2025
- [Raghav/Deloitte] → Notify Thatch team when employee data is staged for validation → December 20, 2025
- [Alia/Thatch] → Provide sample deduction report in EIB format → December 20, 2025
- [Raghav/Deloitte] → Conduct hire, job change, and termination test scenarios during Agnelis's staffing tests → Week of January 5, 2026
- [Stefan/Risant] → Schedule follow-up meeting for end-to-end testing results → January 21, 2026, 1:30-2:30 PM
- [Raghav/Deloitte] → Plan production tenant cutover for week of February 23, 2026 to enable March open enrollment → February 23, 2026
- [Nicole O'Neill] → Adjust plan document dates for compliance if enrollment starts February 27 vs March 1 → TBD
- [Sarah Kee/Risant] → Finalize funding approach before communicating ICHRA changes to employees → TBD
- [Michael Han] → Create implementation timeline with key communication dates → TBD

5. Notes
- Integration Sync Frequency: Workday syncs to Thatch every 24 hours after initial full sync
- Testing Approach: Two-phase testing planned:
  - Unit testing (current phase): Validate connection and data pull
  - End-to-end testing (January 2026): Test hire, promotion, termination scenarios with 10-15 test cases
- Data Validation: Thatch account provides visibility into synced employee data; team can validate demographic information directly
- Deduction File Process: Thatch will generate deduction reports; Deloitte will load into Workday via EIB template
- Production Cutover Considerations: Production environment must be ready by February 27, 2026 to support open enrollment starting that date
- Go-Live Date: April 1, 2026 for benefits effective date
- All-Employee Workday Go-Live: March 2, 2026
- Compliance Requirement: 90-day advance notice to employees required
- Current Workday Version: 45.1
- Tenant Details: Risant Health will have dedicated Workday instance separate from Kaiser Permanente; single legal entity for all Risant employees

Objectives So Far:
- Establish Workday-to-Thatch integration for ICHRA benefits administration
- Validate data synchronization between systems
- Plan and execute comprehensive testing strategy (unit and end-to-end)
- Ensure production readiness for March 2026 open enrollment

Progress Made:

- Configured security permissions and integration settings

- Defined required employee data fields for testing

Outstanding Issues:

- Funding approach must be finalized before employee communications begin

- Review testing results in follow-up meeting (January 21, 2026)

- Finalize compliance documentation and employee communications timeline

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: ThatchDeloitte Workday Account Setup and Scenario Testing
Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

Important Note
The conversation did not discuss ICHRA interest related to 2026 renewal costs or administrative workload reduction. This was a technical implementation call focused on Workday integration setup and testing protocols.

Key Points Discussed

1. Workday Integration Setup (Successfully Completed)
- Successfully connected Risant Health's Workday test environment (RH1 tenant) to Thatch demo account
- Configured ISU (Integration System User) credentials: ISUInt004demographicdataAPIoutbound
- Added required security permissions: Get Access to Worker Data, Public Worker Reports, Manage Organization Integration, and Private Work Email Integration
- Connection established and validated during the call
- Payroll sync frequency: Every 24 hours
- Current status: No employee data in test environment yet; Deloitte team creating fictitious employees by end of week

2. Data Requirements for Testing
Required employee fields for integration testing:
- First name, last name
- Personal email, work email (at least one required)
- Start date, employment type, pay type
- Employee ID (format: 3-digit with padded zeros: 001, 002, etc.)
- Secondary employee ID (if applicable)
- Phone number, job title, yearly pay (useful but not necessary)

3. Testing Strategy

Unit Testing (Current Phase - Week of December 16, 2025):
- Validate environment connectivity
- Confirm data retrieval from Workday to Thatch
- Verify employee demographic data sync

End-to-End Testing (January 2025):
- Test scenarios: New hires, job changes/promotions, terminations
- Validate demographic updates flow correctly to Thatch
- Deduction file testing with sample data
- Timeline: Third week of January (week of January 19, 2025)
- Meeting scheduled: Wednesday, January 21, 2025, 1:30-2:30 PM

4. Payroll Configuration
- Pay schedule: Biweekly, Fridays
- Holiday handling: Payments process on Friday even if it's a holiday (direct deposit automation)
- Deduction reports will be generated by Thatch based on this schedule

5. Critical Timeline Adjustment - Open Enrollment
Major Decision: Open enrollment will be conducted in Workday (not on paper as originally planned)
- Original plan: March 1, 2025 (Saturday) start date with paper enrollment
- Revised approach: Open enrollment Friday, February 27, 2025 (or February 28)
- Enrollment window: Approximately 2 weeks, ending by March 15, 2025
- Benefits effective date: April 1, 2025 (unchanged)
- Critical dependency: Workday production tenant must be ready and connected to Thatch by week of February 23, 2025
- All-employee Workday go-live: March 2, 2025

6. Compliance Considerations
- Plan documents must be adjusted to reflect February offer date (instead of March 1) for April 1 effective date
- 90-day advance notice to employees required
- Communication strategy: Waiting to finalize funding approach before socializing ICHRA changes to employees

Stakeholders Identified

Risant Health (Customer/Employer)
- Sarah Kee: Primary contact, decision-maker on enrollment dates and payroll configuration
- Will Calderwood: Project oversight, timeline coordination
- Stefan V. Jarmusz: Meeting coordination, project management

Deloitte (Implementation Partner)
- Raghav Vasudevan: Lead technical consultant, Workday configuration, testing coordination
- Premanand Kumar (Prem): Technical setup, ISU configuration, testing strategy
- Sonya Unger: Data staging, employee setup in test environment
- Agnelis: (Referenced) Conducting staffing test scenarios, open enrollment planning

Thatch (Vendor/Platform Provider)
- Alia Gurtov: Technical integration specialist, led setup walkthrough, primary technical contact
- Jared: Thatch team member (limited participation)

O'Neill Group (Benefits Compliance)
- Nicole O'Neill: Compliance oversight, plan document adjustments
- Brad O'Neill: Implementation timeline coordination, compliance requirements
- Michael Han: Implementation timeline documentation

Important Milestones & Timestamps

| Date/Timeframe | Milestone | Status |
|----------------|-----------|--------|
| December 16, 2025 | Workday test environment connected to Thatch | ✅ Completed |
| End of week (Dec 20, 2025) | Fictitious employee data created in RH1 tenant | In Progress |
| Week of January 5-12, 2025 | Bulk of test data creation, staffing scenarios begin | Planned |
| Week of January 19, 2025 | End-to-end integration testing phase | Planned |
| January 21, 2025, 1:30-2:30 PM | Testing results review meeting | Scheduled |
| Week of February 23, 2025 | Production tenant cutover must be completed | Critical Deadline |
| February 27-28, 2025 | Open enrollment begins in Workday production | Target Date |
| March 2, 2025 | All-employee Workday go-live | Planned |
| March 15, 2025 | Open enrollment ends | Target Date |
| April 1, 2025 | Benefits effective date | Confirmed |

Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties

Immediate Actions (By December 20, 2025)
1. Alia (Thatch): Send email with complete list of required employee data fields for testing
2. Raghav/Sonya (Deloitte): Create fictitious employee data in RH1 tenant with proper employee ID format (001, 002, etc.)
3. Raghav (Deloitte): Share spreadsheet with details of fake employees created
4. Alia (Thatch): Provide example deduction report by end of week

Week of December 23, 2025
5. Alia (Thatch): Validate employee data sync from Workday to Thatch demo account
6. Alia (Thatch): Review EIB template from Deloitte and provide feedback on report format compatibility

January 2025
7. Agnelis (Deloitte): Conduct staffing test scenarios (hires, job changes, terminations) - Weeks of January 5 & 12
8. Raghav/Team (Deloitte): Execute end-to-end testing scenarios - Week of January 19
9. All parties: Testing results review meeting - January 21, 2025, 1:30-2:30 PM
10. Stefan/Raghav (Deloitte): Develop detailed cutover planning timeline with Thatch involvement

February 2025
11. Deloitte/Risant: Complete production tenant build and cutover - Week of February 23
12. Alia (Thatch): Connect Workday production environment to live Thatch account - Week of February 23
13. Nicole/Brad (O'Neill Group): Finalize plan document adjustments for February enrollment offer date
14. Sarah (Risant): Finalize funding approach and begin employee communications (90-day notice)
15. Michael (O'Neill Group): Create and distribute implementation timeline with key compliance dates

Ongoing
16. Thatch Team: Address any questions on EIB template format before third week of January
17. All parties: Maintain communication on cutover timeline to ensure February 27/28 open enrollment readiness

Technical Notes
- Workday version: 45.1
- Integration method: Merge API (read-only from Workday)
- Deduction handling: Thatch generates reports; manual upload to Workday via EIB template
- Test environment: RH1 tenant (separate from any Kaiser Permanente systems)
- Production environment: Separate Ryzen-specific Workday instance and legal entity
- Duplicate handling: Thatch has capability if CSV upload needed before Workday sync

Risk Items
- Critical Path: Production cutover must complete by February 23, 2025 to support February 27/28 open enrollment start
- Data dependency: All testing dependent on employee data creation in test environment
- Format compatibility: EIB template format may require adjustment based on Thatch's standard deduction report output
- Communication timing: Employee notifications pending funding approach finalization

attributes.title: Thatch<>Deloitte WD Account setup and scenario testing
attributes.transcript:
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
Hi. Hi. How is everyone? 
Nicole O'Neill:
Hey. 
Alia from Thatch:
Hey. 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
It is cold here. 
Nicole O'Neill:
It's cold. How cold is cold? 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
Well, it says it's 37 degrees. 
Nicole O'Neill:
That is cold. 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
It feels colder than that and last night it was 20 and with the wind chill, I think it was 7. 
Nicole O'Neill:
Oh my gosh, yeah. We're expecting big winter this year in Colorado, this week in Colorado. So, oh well, where's the snow and the snowflakes and the holiday spirit? 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
We had it actually, we had snow over the weekend and it's been so cold, it's still lingering here. But I won't talk about cold with Will on here. 
Nicole O'Neill:
Because I'm sure whatever Chicago's going through is, yeah, right, uh, we're. 
Will Calderwood (Risant Health):
We're in the middle of a heat wave, it's like 35 degrees or something today. 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
People in short, me, you know, there are some people out there in shorts and birkenstocks with socks. 
Will Calderwood (Risant Health):
I thought somebody wearing shorts yesterday when I was like, nine degrees and I was like, What is wrong with you? 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
Yeah, that is crazy. 
Jared (Thatch):
It's brave, nice to see everybody. 
Unger, Sonya:
Sorry, I'm the only slacker, but I'm not camera ready. 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
No worries, Sonia. 
Jared (Thatch):
Do we have everybody from Deloitte and Ryzen? 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
The Deloitte team, yeah. 
Will Calderwood (Risant Health):
Yeah, Stefan said he'd be a couple minutes late, so he should be on here in a minute, But I'm going to start the transcription here for him in case, unless there are any objections. 
Sarah Kee (Risant Health):
Yep, good to go, okay. 
Kumar, Premanand:
Uh, yeah, I think, uh, Stefan set this up, uh, for us to talk about, like doing some unit testing primarily. Uh. So, just to give an update from a workday perspective, we have set up the account, the system account, or what we call as the ISU. We are ready to share the credentials with the Thaats team here. Raghav and Sonia are trying to create some data. Currently, we don't have any data in our test environment. So they are trying to get some employees set up in the tenant. And Raghav, Sonia, please. Keep me honest here, but I think we are trying to get some data created by end of this week. 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
Yeah, that's right. And I think, so just to give everybody a little bit of context, we're doing our first prototype build of the workday tenant right now. So getting all of our initial config in against what Sarah and Agnelli have provided us with requirements. I think one question that we did have on unit testing and Prem, you might. You might be getting to this as well, is just whether there are any sort of like specific parameters or data elements that you would like for us to populate. For any fictitious employees that we create in order to help facilitate, like any sort of like specific test scenarios that you have. 
Alia from Thatch:
Yeah, absolutely. So I can talk us through those fields. One thing that, uh, we can definitely do on the call today as well, is if you, if you have the ISU, we can actually connect to a test production account. Um, so, at least that's there. And then when you have data that can populate, we should see that sync within 24 hours. So you let us know that that's happened, we'll take a look, see what's come through. Um, in terms of the parameters I can send over, uh, it's really just like the basics. Um, as much data as you are able to populate, the better. So even if it's just, I think, like, placeholder nonsense for a lot of it. 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
Yeah, but just putting something in there. 
Alia from Thatch:
Yeah. 
Vasudevan, Raghav:
Are you saying that mostly around like personal information, like, I don't know, demographic details or things like that? Or is it beyond that?

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: NetReputation - Thatch ICHRA Discovery Call

Meeting Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Company: NetReputation  
Referral Source: Paychex (Todd and Michael)  
Meeting Title: Thatch and NetReputation - Paychex referral

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED - EMPLOYER'S INTEREST IN ICHRA

Primary Driver
- Immediate Need: One employee (Valeria) in New Mexico cannot be covered under current group benefits plan
- Employee is currently "on the bench" waiting for benefits solution
- Urgent timeline due to open enrollment window closing

Secondary Interests & Pain Points
- Cost Management: Experienced significant premium increases in 2026 renewal
- Scalability Concerns: Need to support distributed workforce across multiple states as company grows
- Administrative Efficiency: Interest in reducing complexity of multi-state benefits administration
- Current Benefits Sentiment: "On the fence" - performing adequately compared to similar-sized companies but see room for improvement
- Employee Communication Gap: Some executives unaware of employer contributions; lack of total rewards communication strategy

Interest in ICHRA Solution
- Attracted to state-by-state scalability without geographic limitations
- Interest in employee choice and personalization (20+ plan options per location)
- Excited about marketplace offerings (Lyra Health, Function Health, GLP-1 access via Hims & Hers)
- Potential for cost containment through individual market flexibility
- Ability to avoid year-over-year 20%+ renewal hikes
- Integration capabilities with existing Paychex Flex system

Current Benefits Context
- Using benefits as recruitment tool (highlighting $5,000+ employer contribution)
- Recently added fully-covered individual employee plan
- Not currently offering point solutions but exploring options within Paychex
- One EIN structure (simplifies integration)

2. STAKEHOLDER IDENTIFICATION

NetReputation Team

Bryce Young - HR Lead
- Role: Manages all HR functions and benefits administration
- Responsibilities: Benefits strategy, recruitment, employee value proposition
- Tenure: Few months in current role
- Background: Previously at larger company with better benefits costs
- Decision-making authority: Primary benefits decision-maker
- Key concerns: Cost management, employee coverage gaps, scalability

Sean Hollis - Director of Operations
- Role: Oversees operational systems and integrations
- Responsibilities: CRM, document processor, payment processor, Paychex integration management
- Interest: Ensuring benefits solution supports scaling and expansion plans for 2026
- Focus: Operational efficiency and system integration

Tommy Meyer - Inside Counsel
- Role: Legal counsel
- Participation: Joined late in call, no questions raised
- Involvement: Legal review and compliance oversight

Valeria (Employee in New Mexico)
- Status: New employee requiring immediate benefits coverage
- Location: New Mexico
- Current situation: Unable to access current group plan

Thatch Team

Retsy Holliday - Business Advisor
- Role: Guide NetReputation through evaluation process
- Responsibilities: Quote building, financial analysis, demo facilitation, decision support
- Next actions: Send census template, build quote, schedule follow-up

Kaitlin Zidar - Solutions Consultant
- Role: Benefits expertise and implementation support
- Background: 10+ years in benefits industry, former broker-side experience
- Responsibilities: Administrative transition guidance, compliance assurance, internal meeting support

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & CRITICAL TIMESTAMPS

Meeting Timeline (December 16, 2025)
- 00:00-05:00 - Introductions and small talk; established rapport
- 05:00-10:00 - Discovery of current benefits situation and pain points
- 10:00-25:00 - Thatch platform demonstration and ICHRA education
  - Smart allowance methodology explained
  - Plan shopping experience demonstrated
  - Marketplace offerings showcased
  - Administrative integration covered
- 25:00-30:00 - Q&A and next steps discussion

Critical Dates Identified
- December 16, 2025 - Initial discovery call completed
- December 17, 2025 (Tomorrow) - Target for quote review meeting
- December 22, 2025 - FINAL DEADLINE for open enrollment to achieve January 1, 2026 effective date
- January 1, 2026 - Target effective date for Valeria's coverage

Key Decision Points
- Immediate decision needed for New Mexico employee (within 1-2 days)
- Longer-term evaluation for full company rollout to be discussed separately
- Universal January 1 renewal cycle noted for future planning

4. CLEARLY DEFINED NEXT STEPS

Immediate Actions (December 16-17, 2025)

Action 1: Census Template Submission
- Responsible Party: Retsy Holliday (Thatch) to send template
- Responsible Party: Bryce Young (NetReputation) to complete
- Deadline: December 16, 2025 (same day)
- Details: Information needed for single employee (Valeria) quote

Action 2: Quote Development
- Responsible Party: Retsy Holliday (Thatch)
- Deadline: Same day or December 17, 2025
- Details: Build quote for one New Mexico employee; $68 PEPM per enrolled employee

Action 3: Quote Review Meeting
- Responsible Parties: Retsy, Kaitlin (Thatch) + Bryce, Sean, Tommy (NetReputation)
- Deadline: December 17, 2025 (tomorrow)
- Purpose: Review financial analysis and make go/no-go decision
- Critical: Must decide quickly to meet December 22 enrollment deadline

Action 4: Internal Discussion
- Responsible Party: Bryce Young, Sean Hollis, Tommy Meyer (NetReputation)
- Deadline: December 17, 2025
- Purpose: Review quote and make decision on immediate implementation

Conditional Next Steps (If Approved)

Action 5: Open Enrollment for Valeria
- Deadline: Must complete by December 22, 2025
- Duration: 2-3 days (expedited for single employee)
- Support: Thatch concierge team available for one-on-one plan selection assistance

Action 6: Carrier Setup
- Responsible Party: Thatch team
- Timeline: Post-enrollment, pre-January 1, 2026
- Details: Establish coverage effective January 1, 2026

Future Considerations

Action 7: Full Company Evaluation
- Timeline: To be determined
- Scope: Evaluate ICHRA for entire NetReputation workforce
- Considerations: 
  - Geography carve-out option (one of 11 compliant classes)
  - Potential February 1 or March 1, 2026 effective date with January 1, 2027 renewal
  - Cost savings analysis for full team
  - Long-term scalability strategy

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Technical Integration Details
- Payroll System: Paychex Flex (confirmed)
- EIN Structure: Single EIN (simplifies integration)
- Integration Capabilities:
  - Automated employee roster uploads
  - 24-hour sync for new hires and terminations
  - Automated payroll deductions
  - COBRA administration available
  - ACA reporting (1094s and 1095s) included

Pricing Structure
- Platform Fee: $68 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
- Applies to: Only employees who enroll in coverage
- Initial Scope: One employee (Valeria)

Compliance Considerations
- ICHRA Class: Geography-based carve-out (compliant)
- No Minimums: Geography class has no minimum participation requirements
- Renewal Cycle: Universal January 1 annual renewal
- Mid-year Start: Can start first of any month, but will have dual renewal in first year

Risk Factors
- Tight Timeline: Only 6 days until enrollment deadline (December 22, 2025)
- Decision Pressure: Quick turnaround required for financial review and approval
- Single Employee Test: Starting with one employee before broader rollout

Opportunities
- Cost Containment: Potential to avoid 20%+ annual renewal increases
- Employee Satisfaction: Enhanced choice and personalization
- Recruitment Tool: Marketplace benefits (Lyra, Function Health, etc.) as differentiator
- Scalability: Solution for distributed workforce growth in 2026
- Administrative Relief: End-to-end compliance and enrollment support

Call Outcome: Positive interest; proceeding to quote stage with expedited timeline for single employee implementation.

Priorities:

- Achieve cost predictability and avoid large renewal increases

Stated Timelines:

- December 17, 2025: Follow-up meeting to review quote for New Mexico employee
- 2026: Considering full team rollout (February 1 or March 1 potential start dates)
- Decision needed quickly due to urgent New Mexico employee situation

Next Steps:
- Thatch to provide census template and quote (same day/next day turnaround)
- Review numbers together on December 17, 2025
- Quick decision required for January 1, 2026 implementation
- Explore long-term full team transition for broader cost savings
