fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
NetReputation currently administers employee benefits through Paychex Flex, which serves as their integrated benefits administration and payroll platform. Bryce Young confirmed they use Paychex Flex when asked directly during the conversation. Sean Hollis, Director of Operations, mentioned that Paychex is part of their integrated programs alongside their CRM, document processor, and payment processor, indicating it's a central part of their HR infrastructure.

The company appears to be exploring additional options within the Paychex ecosystem, as Bryce mentioned they are "looking at some options within Paychex" when discussing point solutions. They operate under one EIN, which simplifies their benefits administration setup.

Bryce Young, who runs the HR side, has primary responsibility for benefits administration and has been in his role for just a few months. He noted that benefits communication has not been well-marketed historically, with some executive team members not even aware that the employer was contributing to their benefits, suggesting the administration has been relatively passive or under-communicated rather than actively managed.

text_plain_content.title: Generated Email
text_plain_content.value:
Hi Bryce,


It was great speaking with you, Sean, and Tommy today! Coming out of our conversation, here's a quick recap of where you are today and the goals we aligned on:


Your Current State

- Unable to provide coverage for your New Mexico employee (Valeria) under your current benefits setup

- Experiencing significant premium increases year-over-year, with prices going up "quite a bit" this year

- Limited benefits visibility—some executive team members weren't even aware of employer contributions to their benefits

- Need for scalable benefits solution as you expand across multiple states


Goals

- Immediate: Secure coverage for Valeria in New Mexico before the December 22nd deadline

- Enable seamless benefits coverage for employees across all states as you scale

- Achieve cost savings or containment to offset ongoing premium increases

- Provide flexible plan options (20+ choices) that meet varied employee needs and circumstances

- Strengthen your recruitment strategy by better communicating your total rewards package


Next Steps

- I'll send over the census template for Valeria's information today

- You'll return the completed census data

- I'll prepare a detailed cost analysis and quote within same day/next day of receiving the data

- We'll regroup tomorrow to review the numbers together and make a decision

- Timeline: We're targeting December 22nd as the last open enrollment day for a January 1st effective date


Resources


Thatch/ICHRA Overview — a helpful summary of who we are and how we work


You can reach me anytime at (571) 234-7147.


Looking forward to getting Valeria covered and exploring the long-term solution for your entire team!


Cheers,

Retsy

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: 2025-12-16

Prospect: Maggie Hammarstrom (Broker)

Current Situation:
- Works exclusively with groups sized 2-50 employees
- Currently has only 2 groups with HRAs
- Recently transitioned clients from Ease to Employee Navigator platform
- Has historically viewed ICRA as something clients pursue independently, not through broker involvement
- Limited experience with ICRA in her book of business

Priorities:
- Understanding Thatch's platform functionality and differentiators
- Ensuring simplicity of use for employer clients
- Competitive and transparent pricing structure
- Maintaining broker involvement in the ICRA process

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Client education is the biggest obstacle - employers find new benefit concepts intimidating
- Clients have limited benefits knowledge baseline, making paradigm shifts difficult
- Employee Navigator proving less user-friendly than promised, causing adoption issues
- Previous ICRA conversations with groups have been "too much for them to wrap their brains around"
- Clients often "throw up their hands and walk away" when presented with complex new concepts

Optimization Goals:
- Needs a platform she can confidently describe as "easy to use"
- Wants to "spoon-feed" ICRA education to clients gradually over time
- Seeking video demos and resources to help with client education
- Looking for a partner that can support client education process

Stated Timelines:
- No immediate implementations planned
- Strategy: Plant seeds with mid-year conversations for future year consideration
- Expects to explore options "next year" (2026) with potential clients
- Acknowledged need for repeated education cycles before clients will adopt

Next Steps:
- Seth to send onboarding videos, demo walkthrough, and one-pagers
- Tyler Ackerman identified as ongoing point of contact
- Future collaboration on client education and potential on-site support

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Seth (Rep) Owns:
- Send onboarding videos and demo walkthrough showing the Thatch platform interface and user experience
- Send one-pagers and educational resources about ICHRA and Thatch's offering
- Provide materials explaining the pricing structure ($45 PEPM with $30 standard broker fee)

Maggie (Prospect) Owns:
- Review the onboarding videos and platform demo materials Seth sends
- Evaluate the simplicity and ease-of-use of the Thatch platform
- Consider Thatch as an option for client groups in 2025, particularly those facing high renewals or getting risked out of pools
- Begin educating her 2-50 employee client base about ICHRA as an alternative option through gradual, repeated exposure

Overall Deal Next Step:
- No specific follow-up meeting scheduled
- Tyler Ackerman (Maggie's designated point of contact at Thatch) will reach out in the future
- Maggie will submit a census to Tyler when she has a group that may be a fit for ICHRA
- First-time engagement will include a call with Seth to review numbers and determine competitiveness before presenting to the client

Account Notes - Thatch Discovery Call

Date: Tuesday, December 16, 2025  
Meeting Type: Educational/Discovery Call  
Duration: Approximately 30 minutes

STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Thatch Team:
- Seth Wood - Sales Representative/Account Manager
  - Role: Primary contact for broker partnerships, product education
- Tyler Ackerman - Broker Channel Point of Contact
  - Role: Census submission, quote tracking, ongoing broker support
- Jeremy - Head of Broker Channel Partners
  - Role: Strategic broker relationship management, on-site enrollment support

Broker/Partner:
- Maggie Hammarstrom - Insurance Broker
  - Company: Works with employer groups 2-50 employees
  - Role: Evaluating Thatch ICHRA platform for potential future client recommendations
  - Current Status: Learning about ICHRA as alternative solution; has limited experience with HRAs

KEY DISCUSSION POINTS

1. ICHRA Education & Product Overview
- Maggie's Initial Position: Historically viewed ICHRA as something clients handle independently; unclear on broker's role in ICHRA arrangements
- Thatch's Value Proposition:
  - Tech-forward platform (founded 3-4 years ago) improving traditional ICHRA experience
  - 80-90% of business through broker partnerships
  - Off-marketplace plans offered directly through carriers
  - Full end-to-end solution (not pieced together with external partners)
  - Fintech foundation (team from Stripe, Ramp, Rex) ensuring reliable billing
  - Zero payment delinquencies in 4 years of operation

2. Pricing Structure & Fees
- Under 50 Employees: $45 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
  - Standard broker commission: $30 PEPM
  - Thatch retention: $15 PEPM
  - Broker can adjust their fee with approval
- One-time Compliance Fee: $50 flat rate
- COBRA Administration: 2% of premium
- No implementation fees
- Competitive positioning: Market range $20-$100 PEPM (competitors often have reimbursement models or inferior platforms)

3. Plan Structure & Compliance
- Subsidy Eligibility: Employees do NOT qualify for ACA subsidies if employer allowance is affordable (≤9.96% of household income for low-level silver plan)
- Group Size Rules: Groups over 50 employees don't qualify for marketplace subsidies regardless
- Plan Access: Off-exchange plans through direct carrier relationships (similar pricing to on-exchange, occasionally better)
- Ancillary Benefits: Dental/vision typically remain on group platform (more competitive rates); Thatch focuses on medical only
- COBRA Requirements: Must be offered for continuation of HRA benefits if unused allowance remains

4. Implementation & Technology
- Setup Timeline: 
  - Best case: Same day (15 minutes to set up account)
  - Standard: 2-week enrollment window recommended
  - Fastest observed: 1-week turnaround possible
  - Banking verification: 1-3 business days (can be instantaneous)
- Payroll Integration: Connects with all major providers (ADP, Paychex, Paylocity, etc.)
- Employee Experience:
  - Mobile-optimized platform
  - Plan filtering by doctor networks and prescriptions
  - Same-day licensed advisor support
  - On-site enrollment support available for larger groups (50+ enrollments)
- Administrative Features:
  - COBRA administration
  - 1095 filings
  - Transparent cost display including all fees
  - Age-banded allowance options

5. Market Trends & Future Outlook
- 2024 Market Conditions: 23-24% average increase in individual plans (vs. historical 6% annual increases)
- Carrier Support: All major carriers expanding individual marketplace presence, viewing ICHRA positively
- Legislative Developments: Potential "Choice Act" rebranding in January 2025 with possible $100 PEPM incentive for small businesses in first year
- Industry Adoption: Growing word-of-mouth referrals; early adopters becoming advocates

6. Broker Challenges Identified
- Education Barrier: Employer groups intimidated by paradigm shift; limited benefits knowledge makes new concepts difficult
- Maggie's Experience: Previous ICHRA conversations with clients resulted in overwhelm and abandonment
- Platform Usability Concerns: Recent negative experience with Employee Navigator (vs. Ease) makes simplicity critical
- Adoption Strategy: Need for gradual education, "spoon-feeding" information over time

CRITICAL MOMENTS & TIMESTAMPS

Early Conversation (Minutes 1-5):
- Maggie admits limited ICHRA knowledge; historically positioned it as "do it yourself" option
- Confusion about broker's role in ICHRA arrangements

Mid-Conversation (Minutes 10-15):
- Detailed pricing discussion; Maggie confirms focus on 2-50 employee groups
- COBRA clarification needed (Maggie unfamiliar with COBRA on individual plans)
- Subsidy eligibility questions resolved

Late Conversation (Minutes 20-25):
- Maggie acknowledges education as primary obstacle with employer clients
- Requests demo video to evaluate platform simplicity
- Discusses need for "HSA champion" approach - one early adopter to drive adoption

Closing (Minutes 25-30):
- Agreement to gradual education approach with future clients
- Maggie acknowledges need to "spoon-feed" concept to employers over time

NEXT STEPS & ACTION ITEMS

Immediate Actions (By End of Week - December 20, 2025):
Responsible Party: Seth Wood
- [ ] Send onboarding videos demonstrating platform walkthrough
- [ ] Provide one-pagers and educational resources
- [ ] Share demo showing employee user experience and simplicity

Short-Term (Q1 2026):
Responsible Party: Maggie Hammarstrom
- [ ] Review educational materials and platform demo
- [ ] Identify potential client groups for mid-year ICHRA education conversations
- [ ] Consider "seed planting" approach with select clients (no pressure, future-year consideration)

Responsible Party: Tyler Ackerman (Thatch)
- [ ] Follow up with Maggie in early 2026
- [ ] Remain available for census submissions and quote requests

Ongoing Partnership Development:
Responsible Party: Both Parties
- [ ] Maggie to submit census for any interested groups to Tyler Ackerman
- [ ] Initial quote review meeting with Seth before client presentation
- [ ] Joint client presentations/demos when appropriate
- [ ] Potential on-site enrollment support for larger groups (if applicable)

Future Considerations (2026 Planning):
- Monitor January 2025 legislative developments regarding "Choice Act" and small business incentives
- Evaluate ICHRA as alternative for groups facing significant renewals
- Position as choice-based solution rather than "last resort"
- Build internal broker team knowledge on ICHRA fundamentals

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Maggie's Current ICHRA Experience: Only 2 groups currently using HRAs; not her primary expertise area

Relationship Status: Positive educational conversation; Maggie receptive but cautious due to past client resistance

Key Success Factor: Platform simplicity and ease of use will be critical for Maggie's confidence in recommending to clients

Competitive Advantage: Thatch's technology focus and broker-friendly approach differentiate from traditional ICHRA administrators

Cultural Note: Maggie values straightforward communication and appreciates Seth's patience with rescheduling

FOLLOW-UP PRIORITY: Medium-High
Maggie is an active broker with relevant book of business (2-50 groups) but needs education and confidence-building before bringing ICHRA to clients. Relationship development and resource provision are key to future partnership success.

Optimization Goals:

- Wants to "spoon-feed" ICRA education to clients gradually over time
- Seeking video demos and resources to help with client education
- Looking for a partner that can support client education process

Stated Timelines:
- No immediate implementations planned
- Strategy: Plant seeds with mid-year conversations for future year consideration
- Expects to explore options "next year" (2026) with potential clients
- Acknowledged need for repeated education cycles before clients will adopt

Next Steps:
- Seth to send onboarding videos, demo walkthrough, and one-pagers
- Tyler Ackerman identified as ongoing point of contact
- Future collaboration on client education and potential on-site support

Loop this in. And if you even just want to have, like a mid-year, Hey, I want to share this idea with you. Not no pressure, just, just to plant the seed for future years. No, know, that person's your HSA champion and there it's going to grow. And yeah, it's, it's, yeah, you've always got to have at least one person banging the drum.

And it took 10 years, once the HSAS were released, for it to really start to gain traction nationally. And so we're still at seven or eight years in with the era. And I think we're getting more and more interest now. It just takes healthcare moves at a snail's pace for some of us, you know that. So it's taking time, but it is a great alternative. And if you use the technology and a good third party administrator like us, or someone else who knows what they're doing, it can be a really good fit for certain groups, especially if they're getting hit hard with renewals or they're getting risked out of pools because of sick people and things like that. So that can be very beneficial or choice. Sorry, go ahead.

Definitely send me if you've got like a video that sort of walks you through the site, like as a demo, that would be helpful because. You know, simplicity of use is a big, a big deal. Like, we moved, you know, we just moved everybody from ease to employee navigator, and employee navigator is no ease. Like, you know, we were promised it would be simple to use. Well, it's not that simple. So people who are, who don't, you know, grasp the technology in the first place are having a hard time with navigator. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah. 
Maggie Hammarstrom:
That for, you know, if I can say with confidence, the Thatch platform is easy to use, that will make all the difference.

Yeah, it's. I mean, I'm not just I'm picky. It's easy because I come from Stripe and I come from like tech companies, like, it's very easy. It's mobile optimized, like it's a. But I'll show you the walkthrough. It's really straightforward. I think there always will be questions. So we just got to handle that. Well, like, how do I get my prescriptions? If you have any clients, you think this could be a fit, We can always jump and help work with you on that station and explore that option for them. But yeah, I appreciate your, your two, four time. So. Yeah, no, no, no.

I thank you for your time as well. And, and for your patience, I know I sort of blew things off a couple of times, but. No, no, it's good.

Yeah.

I think it's just, if we're, if it's going to work for us, we just need to like, sort of spoon. Feed it to people over and over and over again, until they kind of get it. And then we'll go from there.

For sure. And I expect we'll be working more on sites next year with MMA and a lot of other partners. Just to be in-house, so we can meet and to educate and talk and show things. So I expect more of that on our end. We've been doing a lot of education globally with our partnership teams. So you'll probably hear from Tyler at some point in the future, either way. But great to meet you and have a great little holiday. And if you can, in the middle of it all, but thank you.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Roof Consulting Services, Inc. - Thatch ICHRA Discovery Call

Date of Conversation: Tuesday, December 16, 2025

COMPANY OVERVIEW
- Company Name: Roof Consulting Services, Inc.
- Location: Richmond, Virginia (with some employees in other states)
- Company Structure: S-Corporation
- Total Employees: 34
- Current Health Plan Enrollment: 18 employees
- Current Renewal Date: March 1, 2026
- Current Contribution Strategy: $300 flat allowance (meets ACA minimum affordability requirement)

KEY DISCUSSION POINTS

Primary Motivation for ICHRA Exploration
1. Cost Management Concerns:
   - Historical rate increases: 15-20% annually
   - Expected 2026 renewal increase: 10-15% (per current broker Sheldon)
   - Industry trend: Other companies experiencing 20-30% increases for 2026
   - William Sanders' wife's company successfully implemented similar ICHRA model to avoid rate increases

2. Desired Outcomes:
   - Avoid constant premium increases for employees
   - Provide flexibility for employees to use health spending in alternative ways
   - Reduce administrative burden
   - Give employees more plan choice

Current Insurance Situation
- Current Carriers: Anthem (medical), switched from Anthem to Sentara previously for better rates
- Dental/Vision: Separate group plan with stable pricing (no increases in recent years)
- Rating Structure: ACA-rated, age-banded with composite rates
- Broker Flexibility: Limited negotiation power due to small group size

ICHRA Model Discussion

Advantages Presented:
- Individual marketplace rates historically increase ~6-8% annually (vs. 25-35% group average)
- 2026 individual market rates already set and locked for full 12 months
- Employees can choose from 65+ plan options in Virginia (Anthem, United, Oscar, Cigna)
- Plans range from $397 (Bronze) to $527+ (Gold) for age 45 in ZIP 23060
- No underwriting based on health status - only age and location
- Protection from risk pool issues (one sick employee doesn't impact entire group)
- Leftover allowance dollars can be used for qualified medical expenses pre-tax
- Plans are portable - employees keep coverage if they leave company
- Special enrollment period triggered by switching to ICHRA

Administrative Features:
- Thatch handles enrollment, carrier coordination, COBRA administration, 1095 forms
- Integration with current CPA payroll process via CSV deduction report
- Mobile-optimized enrollment platform
- Same-day licensed advisor support available
- Direct carrier payment (not reimbursement model)
- 85% of employees complete enrollment without assistance

Pricing Structure:
- $45 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
- $50 flat monthly fee to company
- No implementation fees
- All compliance and administrative services included

CRITICAL ISSUE IDENTIFIED: S-CORP OWNERSHIP RESTRICTION

The Problem
- IRS Regulation: Owners of >2% of S-Corp cannot participate in ICHRA due to pre-tax benefit rules
- Impact on This Company: 5 out of 18 enrolled employees are part-owners
- Reason: IRS considers it "double-dipping" since S-Corp owners already receive tax advantages and can write off healthcare costs

Implications
- Owners would need to purchase individual marketplace plans post-tax (not through Thatch ICRA)
- Owners would not receive the $300 (or any) pre-tax allowance through ICHRA
- Thatch could assist with plan selection, but not facilitate pre-tax payment
- Alternative mentioned: Owners could potentially get separate small group plan (compliance to be verified)
- William Sanders indicated this is "prohibitive" to moving forward

STAKEHOLDER IDENTIFICATION

Prospect Company Representatives

William Sanders
- Role: Part-owner (>2% S-Corp ownership)
- Responsibilities: Primary decision-maker, initiated contact with Thatch
- Engagement Level: High - drove the meeting, asked detailed questions
- Key Concern: S-Corp ownership restriction affecting 5 of 18 enrolled employees

Kim West
- Role: Part-owner (>2% S-Corp ownership), appears to handle HR/benefits administration
- Responsibilities: Benefits management, employee communication
- Engagement Level: Active participant, asked clarifying questions about enrollment, Medicare, dental/vision
- Context: Has personal experience with Medicare (spouse Dennis on Medicare Advantage with $0 premium)

Current Broker

Sheldon
- Role: Current insurance broker for Roof Consulting Services
- Responsibilities: Manages current group plan, provides rate quotes, plan selection
- Engagement Level: Collaborative, asked technical questions to understand ICHRA model
- Attitude: Professional, stated "I want what's best for them" and willing to support ICHRA if it's the better option
- Expertise: Handles both small group and large group clients, familiar with ACA rating, has Medicare knowledge
- Key Contributions:
  - Confirmed expected 10-15% renewal increase
  - Asked about subsidy eligibility and on-exchange plans
  - Clarified Medicare Part B reimbursement questions
  - Discussed rate increase timing for individual plans

Thatch Representative

Seth Wood
- Role: Sales representative for Thatch
- Responsibilities: Product education, cost analysis, enrollment support
- Location: Middle Tennessee
- Approach: Educational, transparent about limitations (S-Corp issue), no pressure

IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Historical Context
- Past Practice: Company switched from Anthem to Sentara previously for better rates
- Dental/Vision Stability: No rate increases in recent years on separate group plan
- Consistent Increases: 15-20% annual medical premium increases historically

Current Timeline
- December 16, 2025: Discovery call held
- March 1, 2026: Current group plan renewal date
- Late October 2025: 2026 individual marketplace rates finalized (already completed)
- January 1, 2027: Next potential rate increase point if ICHRA implemented in 2026

Critical Decision Points in Conversation

Minute 8-10: William explained motivation based on wife's company experience with 20-30% increases and successful ICHRA implementation

Minute 15-18: Sheldon provided context on expected 10-15% renewal increase and explained ACA rating limitations

Minute 25-28: Seth demonstrated Virginia marketplace options (65 plans, $397-$527+ range for age 45)

Minute 35-38: CRITICAL TURNING POINT - Seth disclosed S-Corp ownership restriction
- William's immediate response: "That would be kind of prohibitive to us"
- Reason: 5 of 18 enrolled employees are part-owners

Minute 42-45: Discussion of workarounds and implications for owners (post-tax purchase, no allowance)

Minute 48-50: Sheldon asked technical questions about subsidies, rate increase timing, Medicare reimbursement

Minute 52-54: William confirmed S-Corp issue is likely prohibitive but willing to review numbers

NEXT STEPS & ACTION ITEMS

Immediate Actions (No Specific Deadline Assigned)

Prospect's Responsibilities:
1. Internal Discussion - William, Kim, and ownership team to discuss S-Corp ownership impact
   - Responsible: William Sanders, Kim West, other part-owners
   - Decision Point: Whether 5 owners being excluded is acceptable given potential employee benefits

2. Consult with CPA - Verify tax implications and explore potential workarounds for S-Corp owners
   - Responsible: Company CPA
   - Questions to address: Can owners get separate group plan? Any other compliant structures?

3. Gather Renewal Information - Collect 2026 renewal rates from Sheldon when available
   - Responsible: Sheldon (broker)
   - Timing: Before March 1, 2026 renewal
   - Purpose: Enable apples-to-apples cost comparison

4. Collect Census Data - If proceeding, provide employee census for cost analysis
   - Responsible: Kim West
   - Information needed: Ages, locations, dependent information for all 18 enrolled employees

Thatch's Responsibilities:

1. Send Follow-up Resources - Seth to email:
   - Plan comparison tool link (Virginia marketplace options)
   - Employee onboarding experience walkthrough video
   - Additional educational materials
   - Responsible: Seth Wood
   - Status: Committed during call

2. Clarify Medicare Part B Reimbursement - Confirm whether Part B premiums ($185/month base) are reimbursable through ICHRA
   - Responsible: Seth Wood
   - Status: To follow up via email

3. Cost Analysis (If Requested) - Run detailed cost comparison showing:
   - Individual plan costs for each employee by age
   - Flat rate vs. age-banded allowance options
   - Total cost including Thatch fees ($45 PEPM + $50/month)
   - Comparison to 2026 group renewal rates
   - Responsible: Seth Wood
   - Timing: After census data received and renewal rates available

Sheldon's Responsibilities:

1. Provide 2026 Renewal Rates - Deliver group plan renewal quotes for March 1, 2026
   - Responsible: Sheldon
   - Timing: Standard renewal timeline (typically 60-90 days before renewal)

2. Support Decision Process - Provide objective comparison between group and ICHRA options
   - Responsible: Sheldon
   - Approach: "I want what's best for them" - will recommend ICHRA if it's superior option

3. Assist Owners if ICHRA Proceeds - Help 5 part-owners select individual marketplace plans (post-tax)
   - Responsible: Sheldon (or Thatch team)
   - Timing: Only if company decides to proceed despite S-Corp restriction

DEAL STATUS & PROBABILITY ASSESSMENT

Current Status: Discovery/Education Complete - Awaiting Internal Decision

Primary Obstacle: S-Corp ownership restriction affecting 5 of 18 enrolled employees (28% of covered population)

Decision Framework:
- Proceed if: Cost savings and employee benefits significantly outweigh negative impact to 5 owners
- Do Not Proceed if: Owners unwilling to lose pre-tax benefit and pay post-tax for individual plans

Likelihood Assessment:
- William's statement "prohibitive to us" suggests low probability of immediate adoption
- However, left door open: "We may still consider it" if employee benefits are significant
- Company is being proactive (renewal not until March 1, 2026) which shows serious interest
- Cost comparison will be determining factor

Alternative Scenarios:
1. Delay to 2027: Company may revisit after seeing 2026 renewal impact
2. Partial Implementation: Explore if non-owner employees could use ICHRA while owners stay on group plan (compliance unclear)
3. Corporate Restructuring: Unlikely, but could explore changing ownership structure (not discussed)

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Dental/Vision Strategy
- Current separate group plan is stable and cost-effective
- Recommendation: Keep dental/vision separate from ICHRA
- Employees could potentially use leftover ICHRA dollars for dental/vision premiums if applicable

Medicare Considerations
- At least one employee's spouse (Dennis) currently on Medicare Advantage ($0 premium)
- Medicare-eligible employees (65+) would need separate Medicare plans
- Would still receive ICHRA allowance for Medicare premium reimbursement
- Thatch has team to assist with Medicare enrollment

Subsidy Eligibility
- Sheldon asked about marketplace subsidies
- With $300 "affordable" allowance, employees unlikely to qualify for subsidies
- If allowance were lower (unaffordable), employees could opt out and get subsidized marketplace plans independently

Rate Increase Timing
- Individual plans: Annual increases effective January 1
- If implemented March 1, 2026: No rate increase until January 1, 2027
- Employees would have partial deductible year one (March-December 2026)
- Company could offer post-tax bonus to offset partial deductible if desired

COMPETITIVE INTELLIGENCE

- William's wife's company successfully implemented similar ICHRA model
- That company maintained same insurance plans at individual rates without premium cost impact
- Indicates there are other ICHRA providers in market (not specified which one)
- Thatch differentiation: Technology platform, same-day advisor support, full administrative services

FOLLOW-UP TIMELINE RECOMMENDATION

- Week of December 23, 2025: Seth sends promised resources and Medicare clarification
- Early January 2026: Check in on internal discussions and CPA consultation
- Mid-January 2026: Sheldon provides 2026 renewal rates
- Late January 2026: Run cost analysis if company still interested
- Early February 2026: Final decision needed to implement by March 1, 2026
- If No for 2026: Stay in touch for potential 2027 consideration after experiencing renewal increase

RISK FACTORS

1. S-Corp Ownership Structure: Primary deal-breaker - 28% of enrolled population excluded
2. Decision-Maker Impact: Both primary contacts (William and Kim) are affected owners
3. Timing Pressure: March 1

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Meeting Date: December 16, 2025

Prospect: Roof Consulting Services, Inc. (Richmond, VA)
Participants: Kim West, William Sanders, Sheldon (current broker)

Current State:
- 34 total employees, 18 enrolled in group health insurance
- S-Corp structure with current broker (Sheldon)
- Group plan through Anthem/Sentara
- $300 flat allowance toward health plans (meets ACA minimum affordability)
- Separate dental/vision plans (stable rates, no increases)
- Payroll managed by CPA
- Renewal date: March 1, 2026

Pain Points:
- Historical 15-20% annual rate increases on group health insurance
- Expected 10-15% increase for 2026 renewal
- Industry seeing 20-30% increases this year
- Rising costs impacting employees
- One-size-fits-all group plan limitations

Priorities/Optimization Goals:
- Avoid constant premium increases for employees
- Provide flexibility for employees to allocate health spending based on individual needs
- Maintain affordable healthcare coverage
- Cost optimization and predictability

Key Challenge:
- 5 of 18 enrolled employees are part-owners (>2% S-Corp ownership)
- IRS rules prohibit S-Corp owners from participating in ICHRA pre-tax
- This ownership restriction is "prohibitive" to moving forward with Thatch solution

Stated Timeline:
- Renewal: March 1, 2026
- Currently ahead of renewal timeline
- Will collect renewal rates from current carrier
- Plan to compare costs internally with Sheldon before making decision

Next Steps:
- Internal discussion with ownership team
- Obtain 2026 renewal rates from current carrier
- Potentially request cost analysis from Thatch if employee benefits significantly outweigh owner limitations
- Decision pending on feasibility given S-Corp ownership constraints

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Prospect Actions (William Sanders/Kim West - Roof Consulting Services, Inc.):
- Discuss internally whether the S-Corp ownership restriction (5 out of 18 enrolled employees being ineligible) is prohibitive to moving forward
- Consult with Sheldon (current broker) about the ownership limitation and potential alternatives
- Collect employee census information and renewal rate data from current carrier (Anthem/Sentara) for March 1, 2026 renewal
- Once renewal rates are received, reach out to Seth to run cost comparison analysis between current group plan and Thatch ICHRA model
- Evaluate whether employee cost savings outweigh the negative impact to the 5 owners who cannot participate

Rep Actions (Seth Wood - Thatch):
- Send resources to prospect: plan comparison tool link, employee onboarding walkthrough video, and other educational materials
- Follow up via email to confirm whether Medicare Part B premiums are reimbursable through ICHRA
- Stand by to run census-based cost analysis once prospect provides employee data and 2026 renewal rates
- Remain available to answer questions from Sheldon or the prospect team

Sheldon Actions (Current Broker):
- Discuss the S-Corp ownership implications with William and Kim
- Assist in obtaining 2026 renewal rates (expecting 10-15% increase)
- Help evaluate cost comparison once Thatch analysis is complete
- Potentially assist owners with individual plan enrollment if they proceed (since owners would need post-tax plans)

Overall Deal Status:
No immediate follow-up meeting scheduled. Deal is in evaluation phase pending internal discussion about ownership restriction and receipt of 2026 renewal rates. Prospect will re-engage with Seth when ready to run numbers comparison (timeline: before March 1, 2026 renewal date).

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently administers employee benefits through a broker and manual processes. Sheldon serves as their current insurance broker and manages their group health insurance plan. For payroll administration, they use a CPA (Certified Public Accountant) rather than a benefits administration platform like Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits.

Their workflow involves receiving deduction reports (in CSV file format) which they then send to their CPA to process payroll deductions for employee benefits. The company currently offers a $300 allowance towards employee health plans and maintains separate dental and vision coverage. Some of the dental and vision plans are voluntary, with employees paying out of pocket for those benefits.

The company does not appear to use any automated benefits administration platform, instead relying on their broker (Sheldon) for insurance management and their CPA for payroll processing and benefits deductions.

Hey, Sheldon.

How you doing? Good.

Hey, Kim. Hey, William. Nice to meet you. How's it going? Happy Tuesday. Happy Q4. How's everyone doing today? Same to you. Yeah. Where are you guys based out of? 
William Sanders:
Richmond, Virginia. Awesome.

Awesome. Yeah. I'm over here in Middle Tennessee. So nice to meet everyone. Is there anyone else today joining on the call? Is it a full house here?

So we have Sheldon on the call, who is our current insurance broker. OK, cool. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah.

So that he can kind of compare and contrast what we've traditionally done with what this looks like.

Okay, cool. Yeah, I mean, I know it's great to meet everyone. So we'd love to just maybe good starting point today, would just would love to know maybe a little bit about, you know, prompted you to reach out, for sure. And then I can happily walk you through a little more about what we do here and how it works. If there's questions, we can go through the slides, things like that. We'd love to know, just starting, and I'm glad Sheldon's here. Tell me, Kellen, a little bit, what maybe prompted you to want to look into Thatch, and how did you hear about us? 
William Sanders:
The main thing that prompted it, my wife does HR and bookkeeping for another company who's already been through their insurance renewal process for the upcoming year. And they were looking at about a 20 to 30 percent increase in rates. For their group rate. So they actually had, like, a company-wide survey and sort of proposed using a program similar to y'all's. That they were able to basically maintain the same insurance plans, but on an individual rate basis. And it really didn't affect their premium cost at all. Okay. We're basically trying to avoid constant increases in cost to our employees and the option to use their health spending, what we allocate to them, in other avenues, if that's what they desire. 
Seth Wood:
Got it. This is your current organization that's been dealing with the 20% to 30%? Increase or is this just another separate organization? 
William Sanders:
Yeah, I mean, historically, you know, our organization has seen about a 15 to 20 percent increase on an annual basis. 
Seth Wood:
Okay. 
William Sanders:
You know, my wife's company, they were looking at like a 20 to 30 percent increase this year. And from what I've heard from a couple other business owners, that their increases this year have been more significant than in years prior. Yeah. So that's what we're trying to avoid. 
Kim West:
Our renewal is March 1st, so we're a little bit behind the January 1st. And Sheldon, with your other companies, what kind of rate hikes have you been seeing?

Sheldon, I know we haven't worked together. Feel free to reach out to me directly. If you happy to walk me through how we work with our partners. We have a lot of broker partners who most of our business comes through you as well. So happy to walk you through that on our end. To support you with this. If this is something the group does, consider more. But please just, uh, everyone have a great holiday. Let me know if. 
Sheldon:
Yeah, you too. I just got a couple quick questions. Yeah, my whole purpose, I want what's best for them. And if this is best, I'm going to be honest and tell them that. Because it's individual plans, some people may be able to get a subsidy. Now, I don't know. They may be going away. They may not. Who knows? But if they remain, can they do on-exchange plans through you? And do you help them with the? Because it's a pain in the butt going through healthcare.gov, as you probably know. Do you help them through that process? I don't know if anybody there would qualify for a subsidy or not. 
Seth Wood:
That's the question. So you can, With this model, if the allowance is considered affordable, they wouldn't qualify for the subsidy through the ICRA. Because their employer is, it's the way for the ACA to kind of push them towards the employer, basically. If they were getting $5 a month or something crazy low, right? Like, that's on an affordable allowance. Like, then the they would then be able to get a subsidy on the marketplace and just go through that. They wouldn't go through thatch because we can't bring a stipend, not stipend, a subsidy, a plan with a subsidy into thatch. So, like, the employee could go on the marketplace and bring a plan if they wanted to. 
Sheldon:
They would be qualified for a subsidy. They could opt out of this and go. Yeah. 
Seth Wood:
If they wanted to do that. Yeah. It's probably based on your point. Unlikely, they would. Given their salary and then the allowance, they probably won't qualify. But that's an option if they did. Yeah. 
Sheldon:
Okay. Another question I have is because these are individual plans, let's say they do this March 1. Would they get an increase in January 1 because all individual plans go up January 1? Or would these rates hold for 12 months and then? 12 months. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, yeah. So the 2026 rates are set. We're already set for the whole year. For the year. 
Sheldon:
But on December 31, would they switch over January 1 to a higher? Would the increase hit them in mid-year? 
Seth Wood:
For 2027? Yeah. So, yeah, the plan. So every year the rates get finalized at the end of October for the next year. 
Sheldon:
And they start January 1. 
Seth Wood:
So if they were starting to backtrack. So if they're starting in the spring of this next year, pretending that, like, they would have the 2026 rates you're seeing through the whole year. And then. The next beginning of the next year, their rates would increase, it would go up before a year was up. 
Sheldon:
They wouldn't have an increase January one, yeah, they wouldn't have an increase at all next year, but the following year, they might have January 2027, they would have an increase. 
Seth Wood:
So they're gonna go full 12 months, okay, the deductible would obviously be a partial deductible, too. Um, you can do things around that you can offer. Like sometimes people do little bonuses if they want post tax to just help offset that a little bit and stuff like that. But overall. Yeah, they can join any point. We have people that join mid-year, but the rates will be updated. And then it moved you to a universal 1-1 after that with the ICRA. So you're always on a 1-1 renewal. 
Sheldon:
Okay, gotcha. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, good questions, though. But yeah, I'll give you, everyone will have resources. I'll send you some links. The plan link, the tool that I showed, I'll send that. You can go in and see the plans for different states, different employees, see the kind of options they're going to have. If you do want to explore this more, no pressure there, either way. Just let us know. We can, I think the next step is always just to look at your numbers, to see, kind of, does it make sense? We can walk you through that piece. And then you can see the two options of doing a flat dollar amount or a dynamic amount where you're giving somewhat older people a little more. You can see if that is helpful and the cost difference there if you wanted to do that. So that's just how we like to approach it. But yeah, let me know how I can be helpful. Otherwise, I hope you guys have a great holiday. 
Sheldon:
Thank you, too. 
Seth Wood:
Merry Christmas. 
William Sanders:
I appreciate your time, Seth. We'll talk about this internally and get with Sheldon and stuff. Once we start collecting all the information and stuff for the renewal, we'll get with you as far as running comparisons for numbers. Definitely. 
Seth Wood:
Yeah, sounds great. Just keep us in the loop, either way. Not this year, maybe next future years. Happy to help. 
Kim West:
Thanks, Seth. 
William Sanders:
Thank you, too. 
Seth Wood:
Bye.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Freestate Auto & Truck Service, Inc.

Date of Conversation: December 16, 2025  
Thatch Representative: Taryn Livingstone  
Prospect Contact: Michelle (Benefits Administrator/HR)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED - ICHRA INTEREST

Current Situation:
- Small auto repair shop in Capitol Heights, Maryland with 10 employees total
- 6-7 employees require health insurance coverage
- Currently using Northwestern Mutual as broker with Kaiser Silver Group plan
- Primary Pain Point: Kaiser network limitations - several employees (including Michelle) have long-term doctors (15+ years) who don't participate with Kaiser, and Kaiser doctors don't accept other insurance

ICHRA Interest & Goals:
- Owner wants to offer $400 monthly stipend for employees to purchase individual health insurance
- Seeking flexibility for employees to choose plans that work with their existing doctors
- New to ICHRA model - in research phase to understand compliance requirements and feasibility
- Want to ensure coverage options work for diverse employee demographics (youngest: 2-year-old dependent; oldest: 64, turning 65 in June/July 2026)
- Goal to support Medicare-eligible employees with the same $400 contribution for supplemental coverage

Administrative Considerations:
- Challenge: Old-school accounting system - pen and paper, no direct deposit, paper checks only
- Concerned about payroll integration complexity
- Previously signed up for Kaiser Silver Group plan but can cancel before January 1, 2026
- Seeking compliant solution that reduces administrative burden while providing employee choice

Budget & Coverage Structure:
- Flat $400/month allowance per employee (regardless of age/dependents)
- Employees responsible for any premium costs exceeding $400
- Acknowledged that $400 will primarily cover premiums with minimal leftover for out-of-pocket reimbursements

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

At Freestate Auto:
- Michelle - Primary contact, Benefits Administrator/HR role, participating employee with doctor network concerns
- Owner/Boss - Decision maker, set $400 budget, wants employee flexibility
- Accountant - Old-school, manages payroll manually (pen and paper, paper checks)
- Shop Manager - Has 2-year-old dependent on plan
- Employees - 10 total, 6-7 need coverage, age range 2-64 years old
- 64-year-old employee - Will turn 65 (Medicare-eligible) in June/July 2026

Current Vendors:
- Northwestern Mutual - Current broker (not 100% satisfied with service)
- Kaiser - Current group plan carrier (Silver level)

Thatch Team:
- Taryn Livingstone - Business team, focused on <20 employee companies
- Thatch Concierge Support Team - Plan support specialists (included, no extra cost)
- Thatch Engineering Team - Silicon Valley engineers (Stripe, Robinhood backgrounds), 0% delinquency rate

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Conversation Date: December 16, 2025

Critical Deadlines Discussed:
- December 19, 2025 - Last day to sign up and confirm Thatch account for January 1 coverage
- December 28, 2025 - Deadline for employees to select individual plans
- January 1, 2026 - Target coverage effective date
- Before January 1, 2026 - Can cancel Kaiser Silver Group plan without penalty

Key Moments in Conversation:

Early Discussion (Setup):
- Michelle successfully connected phone/Zoom independently
- Established company size, location, and current insurance situation
- Identified primary pain point: Kaiser network limitations

Mid-Conversation (Education):
- Taryn explained ICHRA model vs. traditional group insurance
- Demonstrated allowance calculator and plan selection process
- Addressed affordability compliance flags (only applies to 50+ FTE employers)
- Clarified government subsidy rules: employees cannot receive both employer ICHRA contribution AND government subsidy (mutually exclusive)
- Explained Medicare support: Thatch fully supports Medicare with stipends

Concerns Addressed:
- Payroll Integration: Confirmed manual payroll can be accommodated despite no direct deposit system
- Reimbursement Process: Explained automatic monthly reimbursement from business bank account to Thatch to employee
- Security Concerns: Addressed banking connection concerns with 0% delinquency rate track record
- Support Structure: Clarified Thatch acts as liaison between employer, employee, insurance carriers, and government

Pricing Transparency:
- $45 per enrolled employee per month (PEPM)
- $50 flat monthly compliance fee (not per employee)
- No startup fees, no hidden fees, no support fees
- Example: 7 enrolled employees = (7 × $45) + $50 = $365/month in Thatch fees

Trust Building:
- Michelle asked if Taryn uses Thatch for her own insurance - confirmed yes
- Thatch employees have highest enrollment rate among all customers
- Maryland identified as strong state for ICHRA options

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (By December 19, 2025):

Michelle's Responsibilities:
1. Explore Allowance Calculator - Access via Thatch.com "Start Now" button
   - Upload employee information (ZIP code, date of birth, number of dependents)
   - Test flat $400 allowance vs. smart allowance options
   - Review plan options available in Maryland ZIP codes
   - Deadline: Before December 19, 2025

2. Review Plan Options - Use ZIP code lookup tool (to be provided by Taryn)
   - View available carriers and plans from employee perspective
   - Confirm adequate options for employees with specific doctor networks
   - Deadline: Before December 19, 2025

3. Confirm Allowance Amount - Finalize whether to proceed with:
   - Flat $400/month for all employees, OR
   - Smart allowance with age/dependent adjustments
   - Deadline: Before December 19, 2025

4. Sign Up for Thatch Account - If moving forward
   - Complete account setup through allowance calculator flow
   - No human interaction needed until payroll setup
   - Deadline: December 19, 2025 (CRITICAL)

Taryn's Follow-Up Actions:
1. Send Follow-Up Email with:
   - Allowance calculator link (Thatch.com)
   - ZIP code plan lookup tool
   - Timeline/deadline confirmation (Dec 19 & Dec 28)
   - Manual payroll integration process information
   - Pricing summary ($45 PEPM + $50 flat compliance fee)

2. Research Manual Payroll Process - Confirm accommodation for pen-and-paper accounting system

Employee Actions (By December 28, 2025):
- Once employer account confirmed, employees have until December 28, 2025 to:
  - Review available plan options
  - Use doctor/medication lookup tools
  - Schedule concierge support calls if needed (optional, included)
  - Select individual health insurance plans
  - Complete enrollment for January 1, 2026 coverage

Contingency Planning:
- Kaiser Plan Cancellation - Ensure cancellation before January 1, 2026 if proceeding with Thatch
- Payroll Setup - Schedule manual payroll deduction setup with Thatch support team
- Bank Account Connection - Connect business bank account for automatic monthly reimbursements

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Competitive Context:
- Michelle researched competitor "Tasks" (T-A-S-K-S) - found poor Reddit reviews
- Thatch differentiation: 0% delinquency rate, Silicon Valley engineering team, comprehensive support

Compliance Considerations:
- Affordability flags not applicable (under 50 FTE threshold)
- Some employees may qualify for government subsidies - must choose between ICHRA or subsidy
- Medicare coordination confirmed for 65+ employee

Support Resources Available:
- 24/7 support team access
- Concierge plan selection specialists (no extra cost)
- Direct access to Taryn for ongoing questions
- Full plan documents available for employee review

Geographic Context:
- Freestate Auto location: Capitol Heights, MD (10 minutes from D.C.)
- Maryland identified as strong market for ICHRA plan options
- Taryn located in Manhattan, NY

RISK FACTORS & OPEN QUESTIONS

Risks:
- Tight timeline (3 days to December 19 deadline)
- Manual payroll system may complicate implementation
- Owner/decision-maker not on call - Michelle needs to present findings
- Some employees may find $400 insufficient for older age brackets (affordability concerns noted but not compliance issue)

Open Questions:
- Will owner approve moving forward after Michelle's research?
- Can manual payroll integration be completed smoothly?
- Will all 6-7 employees find suitable plans within $400 budget?
- Kaiser plan cancellation process and timing confirmation needed

Status: Active opportunity, research phase, decision needed by December 19, 2025

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect (Freestate Auto & Truck Service, Inc.) currently relies on a broker through Northwestern Mutual to administer their employee benefits. They have been paying for a Kaiser group plan through this broker arrangement, though Michelle indicates they are not 100% satisfied with this service.

The company operates with a very manual, traditional administrative approach. Their accountant is described as "old school" and still uses pen and paper methods. They do not have direct deposit capabilities and still issue paper checks to employees. This suggests they do not use any modern benefits administration platform (such as Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits) and likely manage benefits administration manually without integrated payroll systems or digital tools.

The lack of payroll integration and reliance on manual processes indicates that benefits administration workflows are handled through traditional methods rather than automated platforms.

attributes.transcript:
Taryn Livingstone:
Hey, Michelle, I just saw your email. Good morning. Hey, good morning. I just, I'm reading your email right now, so I just saw, did you figure out how to get your phone connected? 
FREESTATE AUTO:
Yep, I sure did. Oh, amazing. Perfect. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Okay, great. Sorry about that. I honestly am very, like, I know Slack enough to, like, know Slack when it comes, or I just said Slack, I meant to say, Zoom. Oh my goodness. I know it enough to know it enough, although when it comes to switching around, I'm not the best, but thank you for figuring that out. That's, that's awesome. Sure. Sure. Well, anywho, I'm excited to chat this morning. Thanks so much for grabbing time with me and taking the time. And my goal, really with this call is just to learn more about where your head is at regarding benefits and insurance for the coming year. And then we'll see if Thatch might be able to help. So with that quick intro on my end, I'm Taryn. On the business team, mainly focused on companies that are less than 20 employees, hence why we are chatting right now. And Yeah, I'd love to kick it over to you for a quick intro, and then please tell me what sparked your interest in Thatch. So we're a small auto repair shop in Capitol Heights, Maryland. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
We have about 10 employees. Not all of them need health insurance. I want to say we have like maybe six or seven that do. We do. We have a broker with Northwestern Mutual that we've been using, but I can't say that we're like 100% happy with them. And what my boss wants to do is offer like a $400. If you call it a stipend, or what he wants to offer. $400 for employees to put towards their health insurance, whichever plan they pick. And then, you know, if they pick, like, you know, one that's more expensive than the $400, then the employees are responsible for the difference. He has been paying for a group plan through Kaiser, but with Kaiser, they're only like, we have a few of us, myself included, that our doctors don't participate with Kaiser. And, you know, after going to the same doctor for over 15 years, I don't really want to switch to a, you know, Kaiser-specific doctor. And Kaiser doctors don't take any other insurance other than Kaiser. So it's kind of... We want to find something that will be able to work for everyone. But we're new to the, what's it called, ICRA. We haven't had an Icra before, so we're not 100% sure how it even works, or what's required, or if it's even the best option for us. So we're just kind of in the research stages now. We did sign up for... Or we did say that we'll go ahead and do like a Kaiser Silver Group plan, but hopefully we can. If we decide to go with that, we shouldn't have an issue like canceling that as long as it's before December 1st or January 1st, right? 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yeah, generally speaking, you have this whole window to sign up and cancel plans. So you should be fine there. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
Okay, perfect. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yes. All right. Perfect. Yeah, this is great context, by the way, Michelle. Thanks so much for filling me in here. Is there anything else that would help in terms of, like, what you want to learn from the call, or anything like that? 
FREESTATE AUTO:
Just kind of what our options are. I know there's, like, I don't know if it's government regulations or what, you know, so we want to make sure that we're compliant, that we have a plan that, you know, we have options that are going to work for all of our employees. The youngest on the plan is our manager's two-year-old, and the oldest would be, we do have an employee who's 64, almost 65. 
Taryn Livingstone:
He'll be 65, I think, in June or July. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
So we want to have an option for the employees who, you know, are going to be required to go on. I'm not sure if it's Medicare or Medicaid, whatever. One is 65 and older. Like, we want to, you know, even though they're getting Medicare or Medicaid, I know there's still some expenses that they have to pay out of pocket. So we still want, you know, we want to be able to give them the $400 that all the other employees are getting as well. So that they can put that towards whatever health care they need to come in good health so they can keep working on vehicles. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Totally. Yeah, that also is a great thing to flag. So, on our end, we fully support Medicare with the stipends. So that's no issue for us in terms of making sure they're all good to go. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
All right. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yeah, perfect. Okay, so I think, can you actually, would you be able to see my screen if I share it? Yeah. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
Oh, perfect. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Okay, so you don't have to. 
FREESTATE AUTO:
I can see you. You just don't. I don't have a camera on this computer. Oh, gotcha. No, no worries at all. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Okay, perfect. Well, in that case, here's what I'll do is I'll give you the overview of that, just to give you the nuts and bolts. And, like, answer pretty much any other questions you have regarding how our Icra model works. And then after that, I'll show you how you can actually go and get a quote for yourself. So how that works, basically, is you just simply make a quick account with us. It's the no strings attached account. fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Prospect: Salvado Law Offices (Alberto - Principal, Judy, Lexi)

Current Situation:
- 19 employees across two office locations
- Currently on Kaiser health insurance with 2026 renewal at $5,421/month
- Age-banded pricing structure
- 50% employer contribution for employee-only coverage; employees pay dependent costs
- Current employer cost: ~$4,900/month
- Payroll processed through QuickBooks via CPA
- Employees located in Maryland and Virginia

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Kaiser's limited network (services only available at their campuses in MD/DC/VA area)
- Lack of flexibility and carrier choice for employees
- Employees requesting PPO options and flexibility beyond Kaiser HMO
- Rising premium costs year-over-year
- One employee (Maureen) in urgent situation needing to add children due to divorce

Priorities:
- Provide employees with greater flexibility and freedom of choice
- Maintain Kaiser option for those who prefer it
- Reduce costs for both employer and employees
- Ensure smooth transition with minimal disruption

Optimization Goals:
- Expand carrier options beyond Kaiser (CareFirst, UnitedHealthcare, Kaiser available)
- Implement ICRA model with dynamic age-based pricing
- Reduce employer costs to $4,766.50/month maximum (includes $3,861 contribution + $905 platform fees)
- Reduce employee costs by approximately $400/month for comparable coverage
- Streamline administration through payroll integration
- Projected savings: $654.50/month with full enrollment vs. 2026 Kaiser renewal
- Greater savings with current 7-employee enrollment
- Predictable budget control through fixed contributions
- Improved employee satisfaction through choice

Stated Timelines:
- Target effective date: 2026-02-01 (alternative: 2026-03-01 if needed)
- Onboarding deadline: Early January 2026
- Next meeting with Alberto: Within 1-2 weeks from 2025-12-08
- Contract turnaround: 24 hours once approved
- Employee enrollment period: 2+ weeks recommended
- Decision made: December 16, 2025
- Paperwork needed by: January 1, 2026
- Benefit counselors on-site: Week of January 12, 2026
- Target implementation: Early January 2026

Next Steps:
- Thatch to send business information forms to Alberto
- Greg to provide current enrolled employee list
- Revised proposal with 50th percentile silver benchmark
- Turn off dental/vision offerings in Thatch (voluntary benefits handled separately)
- Educational webinar for employees in early January

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep Team Actions:

1. Kameron Schmidt - Send reworked proposal with updated enrollment numbers (only 7 currently enrolled employees vs. all 19) and ensure plans match 50th percentile silver coverage comparable to current Kaiser plan. Timeline: ASAP

2. Kameron Schmidt - Send business information request form and required paperwork to Alberto. Timeline: Immediately following call

3. Greg Woolley - Send list of currently enrolled employees to Kameron (Matt, Madeline Bell, Maureen Falo, Samantha Hall, Kimberly, Ricardo, Polaris, and Carlos). Timeline: Immediately

4. Kameron Schmidt - Set up Thatch account and send employee invites once green light received. Timeline: 24-hour turnaround after approval

5. Greg Woolley/Team - Schedule benefit counselors to visit offices for in-person enrollment support. Timeline: Week of 01/12/2026

6. Greg Woolley - Coordinate potential webinar for employees to explain new ICRA model and plan options. Timeline: Second week of January 2026

7. Greg Woolley - Speak with Lauren (Maureen Falo) about adding her children to Kaiser for January due to loss of coverage from ex-husband, or discuss COBRA options

8. Kameron Schmidt - Turn off dental and vision offerings on Thatch platform (keep only medical and required child dental)

Prospect Actions:

1. Alberto Salvado - Complete and return business information forms and required paperwork. Deadline: Before 01/01/2026

2. Alberto Salvado - Provide final approval to proceed with Thatch ICRA implementation

3. Lauren (Maureen Falo) - Contact Greg Woolley regarding coverage situation for her children

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Alberto has verbally agreed to proceed ("I'm fine with it if you wanna, I'll give it a go"). Implementation target is 02/01/2026 with benefit counselor visits scheduled for week of 01/12/2026 to ensure all employees can enroll with coverage effective 02/01/2026.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value: Salvado Law currently has Kaiser as their health insurance carrier. The plan is a Silver-level HMO with an individual deductible of $2,750. The employer contributes 50% of the employee-only premium, and employees are responsible for the full cost of dependent coverage. Currently, 7 out of 19 employees are enrolled in the plan. The company's total monthly spend for 2025 is approximately $4,800-$4,900, with a renewal cost of $5,421 for 2026, representing a 13% increase. Employees are located in Maryland and Virginia, and the current coverage extends through February 1st, with some discussion of extending to February 15th. While the funding type is not explicitly stated, the plan structure suggests it is fully insured, which is typical for a group of this size with Kaiser.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Salvado Law Offices - Thatch ICHRA Deal Summary

1. Key Points Discussed:

- Employer's Interest in ICHRA: The primary motivation for Salvado Law Offices to consider an ICHRA is to manage the 2026 renewal costs and reduce administrative workload. The current Kaiser plan is set to increase by 13%, prompting the need for a more cost-effective solution. The ICHRA offers potential monthly savings of $1,654.50 if all employees enroll, though currently, only 7 employees are enrolled. The Thatch platform provides administrative benefits by handling compliance, payroll integration, and employee support. Employees are particularly interested in the flexibility to choose from 43 plans across CareFirst, Kaiser, and UnitedHealthcare, offering HMO, POS, and PPO options.

- ICHRA Structure Proposed: The proposed ICHRA includes a 50% employer contribution based on a 50th percentile silver plan, matching the current Kaiser plan's deductible. The platform fee is $905/month for enrolled employees, with the flexibility for employees to choose different plan levels. The ICHRA is pre-tax for both employer and employee, with HSA-eligible plans available for high-income or healthy employees.

- Current vs. Proposed Coverage: The current coverage is a Kaiser silver plan with a $2,750 deductible, with 7 of 19 employees enrolled. The proposed coverage through Thatch offers individual marketplace plans with comparable or better coverage and multiple carrier options.

2. Identification of Stakeholders:

- Prospect Company (Salvado Law Offices):
  - Alberto Salvado: Owner and decision-maker, approved moving forward with ICHRA.
  - Carlos Salvado: Employee with dependent coverage.
  - Tolar: Handles finances and payroll questions.
  - CPA/Accountant: Manages payroll taxes through QuickBooks.

- Broker Team (Liberty Run Benefits):
  - Greg Woolley: Primary broker contact, responsible for operational questions and account management.
  - Lexi Davis: Manages account administration and data requests.
  - Judy: Works with the client and previously sent census information.
  - Benefit Counselors: Scheduled for on-site enrollment assistance.

- Thatch (ICHRA Platform Provider):
  - Kameron Schmidt: Thatch representative responsible for platform setup, compliance, and ongoing support.

- Employees: Total of 19 employees, with 7 currently enrolled in the company plan.

3. Important Milestones and Timestamps:

- December 8, 2025: Initial quote review and financial analysis presented.
- December 16, 2025: Alberto approved moving forward with ICHRA during the meeting.
- January 1, 2026: Deadline for completing business information forms and providing required data/documentation.
- Week of January 12, 2026: Scheduled on-site enrollment assistance by benefit counselors.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines and Responsible Parties:

- Immediate Actions (By January 1, 2026):
  - Kameron Schmidt (Thatch): Revise proposal, send updated quote, and business information request form to Alberto.
  - Greg Woolley: Send list of currently enrolled employees to Kameron and coordinate with Maureen Falo regarding urgent dependent coverage.
  - Alberto Salvado: Complete business information forms and inform Tolar about the new ICHRA structure.

- Week of January 12, 2026:
  - Benefit Counselors

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-12-16

Prospect: Salvado Law Offices (Alberto - Principal, Judy, Lexi)

Current Situation:
- 19 employees across two office locations
- Currently on Kaiser health insurance with 2026 renewal at $5,421/month
- Age-banded pricing structure
- 50% employer contribution for employee-only coverage; employees pay dependent costs
- Current employer cost: ~$4,900/month
- Payroll processed through QuickBooks via CPA
- Employees located in Maryland and Virginia

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Kaiser's limited network (services only available at their campuses in MD/DC/VA area)
- Lack of flexibility and carrier choice for employees
- Employees requesting PPO options and flexibility beyond Kaiser HMO
- Rising premium costs year-over-year
- One employee (Maureen) in urgent situation needing to add children due to divorce

Priorities:
- Provide employees with greater flexibility and freedom of choice
- Maintain Kaiser option for those who prefer it
- Reduce costs for both employer and employees
- Ensure smooth transition with minimal disruption

Optimization Goals:
- Expand carrier options beyond Kaiser (CareFirst, UnitedHealthcare, Kaiser available)
- Implement ICRA model with dynamic age-based pricing
- Reduce employer costs to $4,766.50/month maximum (includes $3,861 contribution + $905 platform fees)
- Reduce employee costs by approximately $400/month for comparable coverage
- Streamline administration through payroll integration
- Projected savings: $654.50/month with full enrollment vs. 2026 Kaiser renewal
- Greater savings with current 7-employee enrollment
- Predictable budget control through fixed contributions
- Improved employee satisfaction through choice

Stated Timelines:
- Target effective date: 2026-02-01 (alternative: 2026-03-01 if needed)
- Onboarding deadline: Early January 2026
- Next meeting with Alberto: Within 1-2 weeks from 2025-12-08
- Contract turnaround: 24 hours once approved
- Employee enrollment period: 2+ weeks recommended
- Decision made: December 16, 2025
- Paperwork needed by: January 1, 2026
- Benefit counselors on-site: Week of January 12, 2026
- Target implementation: Early January 2026

Next Steps:
- Thatch to send business information forms to Alberto
- Greg to provide current enrolled employee list
- Revised proposal with 50th percentile silver benchmark
- Turn off dental/vision offerings in Thatch (voluntary benefits handled separately)
- Educational webinar for employees in early January

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/16/2025

Rep Team Actions:

1. Kameron Schmidt - Send reworked proposal with updated enrollment numbers (only 7 currently enrolled employees vs. all 19) and ensure plans match 50th percentile silver coverage comparable to current Kaiser plan. Timeline: ASAP

2. Kameron Schmidt - Send business information request form and required paperwork to Alberto. Timeline: Immediately following call

3. Greg Woolley - Send list of currently enrolled employees to Kameron (Matt, Madeline Bell, Maureen Falo, Samantha Hall, Kimberly, Ricardo, Polaris, and Carlos). Timeline: Immediately

4. Kameron Schmidt - Set up Thatch account and send employee invites once green light received. Timeline: 24-hour turnaround after approval

5. Greg Woolley/Team - Schedule benefit counselors to visit offices for in-person enrollment support. Timeline: Week of 01/12/2026

6. Greg Woolley - Coordinate potential webinar for employees to explain new ICRA model and plan options. Timeline: Second week of January 2026

7. Greg Woolley - Speak with Lauren (Maureen Falo) about adding her children to Kaiser for January due to loss of coverage from ex-husband, or discuss COBRA options

8. Kameron Schmidt - Turn off dental and vision offerings on Thatch platform (keep only medical and required child dental)

Prospect Actions:

1. Alberto Salvado - Complete and return business information forms and required paperwork. Deadline: Before 01/01/2026

2. Alberto Salvado - Provide final approval to proceed with Thatch ICRA implementation

3. Lauren (Maureen Falo) - Contact Greg Woolley regarding coverage situation for her children

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Alberto has verbally agreed to proceed ("I'm fine with it if you wanna, I'll give it a go"). Implementation target is 02/01/2026 with benefit counselor visits scheduled for week of 01/12/2026 to ensure all employees can enroll with coverage effective 02/01/2026.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently administers employee benefits through a combination of manual processes and broker support. For Salvado Law, they use QuickBooks for payroll administration, with Alberto submitting hours and his CPA handling taxes. Alberto manually enters payroll information including hours, bonuses, and benefit deductions into QuickBooks on a weekly basis. For benefits administration, they rely on a broker service provided by Greg Woolley's team, which includes Judy and Lexi Davis who handle data management and behind-the-scenes account administration. Currently, the company offers Kaiser health insurance and manages employee enrollment through this broker relationship. There is no mention of using a dedicated benefits administration platform like Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits. The workflow appears to be manual, with Alberto handling payroll entries and deductions while the broker team manages enrollment data and carrier communications.

For All Valley Heating & Air, they also rely on a broker (Colonial Life) for benefits administration. The administration involves specific PEPM fees and a flat monthly admin fee, with the broker assisting in employee enrollment and managing the ICHRA setup. This indicates a reliance on broker services rather than a dedicated benefits administration platform. 

Overall, both companies manage benefits through broker relationships and manual processes, without the use of a dedicated benefits administration platform.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Date: 2025-11-17

Prospect: Paul Martinez (EVP at Newfront) and Ashley Bielicki discussing client Ty Warner

Current State:
- The client is currently using the Icarus ICHRA platform with existing groups and is facing a 50% renewal increase.
- The current monthly gross premium is approximately $203K.
- They are a late-stage new client in the open enrollment period, located in Phoenix, Arizona, with a Spanish-speaking employee population.

Priorities:
- Maintain the current coverage quality without downgrading plans, specifically avoiding standard gold tier.
- Compare platinum or high-tier gold plans (Gold 100/Gold Plus) to current coverage.
- Require Spanish-speaking one-on-one support for employees.
- Need quick access to gross premium comparisons for feasibility assessment.

Pain Points:
- There is a premium discrepancy: Thatch quote showed $192K monthly versus the actual $203K monthly, creating a $10K gap.
- The quoting tool does not clearly show the total gross premium upfront.
- Lack of plan design details in the quote, such as deductibles and copays.
- The Gold 100 option shows a $493K total monthly cost, significantly higher than the current spend.

Challenges:
- The cost increase makes ICHRA potentially unfeasible for this client.
- Need for employer/employee contribution flexibility, but gross premium is the primary decision factor.
- Requires plan design comparison across rating areas, specifically requested for the Santa Barbara area.

Optimization Goals:
- Streamlined quoting process with immediate gross premium visibility.
- Access to plan design details within quotes.
- Web-based quoting tool for self-service analysis across the book of business.
- Better mapping of current plans to individual market equivalents.

Stated Timelines:
- Q1 2026: Follow-up discussion on improved quoting tools and partnership feedback.

- CC Andrew on the email
- Deadline: ASAP to allow time for employee enrollment before 12/29/2025

d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.title: Notes
d44c6cd2-ec7b-494d-a2a6-e4927c24fdf1__71.value:
Call Notes

Call Date / Timestamp: Monday, December 15, 2025  
Client Name / Account: Akido (Candice Cruz)  
Call Type: Configuration / Training

1. Objectives
- Configure onboarding process for 19-20 new employees from an acquired clinic to be added to Thatch benefits platform
- Ensure new employees have benefits coverage effective January 1, 2026

2. Key Updates / Progress
- Client has purchased a new clinic and is absorbing approximately 19-20 employees
- Employees will be invited to enroll within the next two weeks with coverage starting 2026-01-01
- Employees qualify for special enrollment period as they're being offered ICRA for the first time
- Enrollment deadline enforced through 2025-12-29
- Client confirmed familiarity with the employee invitation process from previous onboarding

3. Client Input / Feedback
- Client requested clarification on what start date to use for inherited employees (some with 10+ years tenure)
- Client asked about 30-day waiting period - confirmed this is not enforced by Thatch and is at client's discretion
- Client noted some employees are part-time and may not be eligible for benefits
- Client wants to honor acquired employees by grandfathering them in without waiting period
- Client mentioned another acquisition expected in February 2026
- Client noted challenge with dental/vision benefits in Rippling requiring override for waiting period

4. Action Items
- [Candice Cruz] → Send employee spreadsheet with required fields (first name, last name, personal email, start date, employment type, pay type, phone number) → 2025-12-15 (immediate)
- [Alia Gurtov] → Upload employees to Thatch dashboard → 2025-12-16
- [Alia Gurtov] → Confirm when employees are added to system → 2025-12-16
- [Alia Gurtov] → Backfill employee ID data later (to be obtained from Bonnie) → TBD
- [Candice Cruz] → Send invitations to employees for enrollment → By 2025-12-29
- [Candice Cruz] → CC Andrew on employee data email → 2025-12-15

5. Notes
- Required spreadsheet fields: First name, last name, personal/work email, start date, full-time/part-time status, salary/hourly pay type, phone number, and employee ID (can be added later)
- Client can use inherited start dates from previous employer without issue as long as they're prior to 2026-01-01
- Invitations can be sent to personal email addresses
- Client has 18 employees to process (mentioned during conversation, slightly different from initial 19-20 estimate)
- Alia provided screen-share walkthrough of the employee addition process
- Data sensitivity level allows for email transmission rather than requiring secure file transfer

Granola Summary

Objectives so far:
- Onboard 19-20 new employees from acquired clinic to Thatch benefits platform
- Ensure benefits coverage effective 2026-01-01 for all eligible employees
- Prepare for additional acquisition in February 2026

Progress made:
- Clarified employee data requirements and spreadsheet format
- Confirmed special enrollment period eligibility for new employees
- Established process for adding employees with inherited start dates
- Confirmed enrollment timeline (invitations within 2 weeks, deadline 2025-12-29)
- Identified workaround for employee ID data (can be backfilled later)

Outstanding issues:
- Employee ID numbers not yet available (will be obtained from Bonnie later)
- Some phone numbers may be missing from initial data submission
- Dental/vision benefits override needed in Rippling system (separate from Thatch)
- Part-time employee eligibility determinations pending

Next steps:
- Candice to send employee data spreadsheet immediately
- Alia to upload employees and confirm completion
- Candice to send enrollment invitations to employees
- Prepare for February 2026 acquisition using same process
- Obtain employee IDs from Bonnie for deduction reporting
