fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Ty Warner - ICHRA Quote Review

Date: 2025-11-17

Meeting Type: Quote Review Call

Opportunity Status: Late-stage evaluation, likely not proceeding due to cost constraints

1. Key Points Discussed

   - Employer's Interest & Requirements:
     - Primary Driver: Managing significant renewal increase (50% renewal mentioned as impetus for exploring ICHRA).
     - Critical Constraint: Employer is NOT willing to downgrade plan quality. Specifically stated they will not move to standard Gold plans; they want to maintain current coverage levels.
     - Coverage Preference: Interested in Platinum or high-tier Gold plans (Gold 100 or "Gold Plus") to match current benefits.
     - Employee Demographics: Significant Spanish-speaking population requiring dedicated support.
     - Spanish Support Requirement: One-on-one consultative support in Spanish is essential for implementation success.

   - Cost Analysis & Feasibility:
     - Current Monthly Premium: $203,000 (approximately $2.436M annually).
     - Initial Quote Discrepancy: Thatch quote showed $192,000 monthly - $11,000/month ($132k annually) below actual.
     - Gold 100 Benchmark: Would result in approximately $5M+ annual total spend (significant increase even with 50% renewal).
     - Preliminary Assessment: Cost analysis suggests ICHRA may not be financially viable for this client given their coverage requirements.
     - Quote Methodology: Thatch used new "flat cost share" contribution strategy for this quote.

   - Technical Discussion Points:
     - Confusion around "total monthly cost" vs. "total premium cost" in quote structure.
     - Need for clearer gross premium comparisons (employer + employee contributions combined).
     - Request for plan design details to help client understand coverage comparisons across rating areas.
     - Discussion of Platinum plan benchmarking challenges (not available in all rating areas, requires custom "and/or" structure).

2. Stakeholders Identified

   - Broker Team (Newfront):
     - Paul Martinez
       - Role: Executive Vice President
       - Responsibilities: Leading this evaluation personally due to late timing and team capacity during open enrollment; has 18-person support team; 20 years industry experience.
       - Location: Mill Valley, California (Marin County).
       - Experience: Has implemented ICHRA before with other clients; currently has groups on ICHRA.

     - Ashley Bielicki
       - Role: Team member supporting Paul Martinez
       - Responsibilities: Day-to-day quote management and service support.
       - Location: Phoenix, Arizona.

   - Vendor Team (Thatch):
     - Tom Hemmingsen
       - Role: Sales Representative, dedicated Newfront contact for mid-market/larger clients.
       - Responsibilities: Quote development, demos, evaluation support through implementation handoff.
       - Tenure: Nearly 3 years at Thatch, 10th employee, first go-to-market hire.
       - Location: Oakland Hills, Montclair (San Francisco Bay Area).

     - Jesse Hernandez
       - Role: Account Executive/Relationship Manager
       - Responsibilities: Newfront relationship management, opportunity coordination.

   - Client:
     - Ty Warner (Employer Group)
       - Location: Santa Barbara area (California).
       - Employee Base:

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently administers employee benefits using multiple platforms and tools:

Benefits Administration Platforms:
- Thatch: Used for health benefits administration (ICRA). Candice manages employee enrollment, sends invitations to employees (via personal or work email), and tracks employee data through Thatch's dashboard. She has been actively adding employees and managing their enrollment periods.
- Rippling: Used for dental and vision benefits administration. Candice mentions needing to coordinate hire dates and potentially request overrides for the waiting period requirements in Rippling.

Manual Management:
- Spreadsheets: Candice maintains employee data in spreadsheets that include fields such as employee name, effective date, entity (MSO), pay type, employment type, personal email, and phone number. She prepares these spreadsheets to upload employee information to Thatch.

Workflow Details:
- Candice is responsible for inviting employees to enroll in benefits through Thatch.
- She distinguishes between full-time and part-time employees to determine eligibility.
- She coordinates with Bonnie on deduction reports and employee ID information.
- She manages the onboarding of new employees from acquired clinics, including setting effective dates and ensuring proper coverage start dates.
- The company has a 30-day waiting period option, though enforcement is flexible.

The prospect uses a hybrid approach combining benefits platforms (Thatch and Rippling) with manual spreadsheet management for data preparation and tracking.

fb908262-6b40-48aa-890d-bcd87db3589a__0f.title: Name of Company Broker is Working With
fb908262-6b40-48aa-890d-bcd87db3589a__0f.value: The formal name of the employer or company is not mentioned in the conversation. Diane Borhani discusses her company's employee benefits and insurance situation but does not state the company name.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.title: Current Benefits Plan
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__33.value: The prospect's current corporate health insurance plan has high deductibles and high premiums. The company has been working with an insurance agent for several years but has been dissatisfied with the coverage. No specific carrier, funding type, or plan design details were mentioned for the corporate plan. The prospect noted that all four employees who were interested in coverage declined it because they found better options either on the marketplace or through private plans. One employee mentioned having a private plan through UnitedHealthcare described as an indemnity-type plan. At the time of the conversation, the prospect had decided to discontinue offering the corporate health insurance and was planning to provide employees with a post-tax medical stipend instead.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.title: Decision Timeline
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__37.value:
• The prospect (Diane) has already made a decision to keep the current benefits arrangement as-is for the remainder of 2025, stating "everybody's settled for this year" and "I think we should just leave it the way it is right now"

• For next year (2026), the prospect is considering implementing Thatch's ICHRA solution but has not committed to a final decision timeline

• A follow-up meeting is scheduled for January 13, 2026 (at 2:00 PM Arizona time) to discuss potential implementation

• Potential implementation timeframes mentioned include February 1, 2026 or March 1, 2026 start dates

• The prospect expressed that "next year, doing this with enough planning, this could be a really good option for everybody," indicating interest but no firm decision date established yet

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
ACCOUNT NOTES - Thatch ICHRA Consultation

Date of Conversation: Monday, December 15, 2025  
Prospect Company: Diane Borhani's company (Phoenix-based)  
Thatch Representative: Taryn Livingstone (New York City)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED - EMPLOYER'S INTEREST IN ICHRA

Current Situation:
- Company has 8 employees (fluctuates between 10-15)
- Currently offers group health insurance but experiencing significant challenges:
  - High deductibles and high premiums
  - Only 4 of 8 employees were interested in coverage
  - All 4 declined company plan, finding better options on marketplace or privately
  - Dissatisfaction with current insurance agent (multi-year relationship)

Decision Point:
- Employer had decided on Friday (December 12, 2025) to discontinue offering health insurance
- Planned to provide post-tax medical/healthcare stipend instead
- Discovered Thatch's ICHRA offering through weekend ad while scrolling

Interest in ICHRA:
- Primary motivation: Seeking pre-tax benefit solution for employees
- Concern about post-tax stipend reducing actual employee benefit (e.g., $200/month becomes significantly less after taxes)
- Interest in reducing administrative workload through automated payroll integration
- Desire to provide better healthcare options while managing costs

Current Employee Coverage Status (as of conversation date):
- Some employees have marketplace plans
- At least one employee has private UnitedHealthcare indemnity plan
- All employees accustomed to payroll deductions for health insurance
- All current employee plans cost more than proposed employer contribution

Partnership Complexity:
- One partner with 5% ownership (currently more employee than partner role)
- Partner cannot participate in ICHRA due to 2%+ ownership IRS restriction
- Partner would need to continue marketplace coverage or receive post-tax stipend

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Primary Decision Maker:
- Diane Borhani - Business Owner/Principal
  - Location: Phoenix, Arizona
  - Role: Final decision authority on benefits
  - Responsibilities: Budget approval, benefits strategy, employee communication

Affected Employees:
- Total Headcount: 8 employees
- Full-time employees: 7 (majority, same class)
- Part-time employees: 1
- Partner (5% ownership): 1 (ineligible for ICHRA, would need alternative solution)
- Employees with marketplace plans: Multiple (exact number not specified)
- Employees with private plans: At least 1 (UnitedHealthcare indemnity plan)

Thatch Team:
- Taryn Livingstone - Sales Representative/Account Manager
  - Responsibilities: Product education, quote preparation, implementation support
- Thatch Plan Specialist Team - Available for employee support during plan selection

Current Insurance Provider:
- Existing insurance agent (multi-year relationship, dissatisfaction noted)

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Pre-Conversation Timeline:
- Friday, December 12, 2025: Diane decided to discontinue group health insurance offering
- Weekend (December 13-14, 2025): Diane saw Thatch advertisement while scrolling
- Week of December 8-12, 2025: Employees selected individual coverage (marketplace or private plans)

During Conversation (December 15, 2025):
- Early in call: Diane expressed unfamiliarity with ICHRA concept
- Mid-conversation: Taryn explained ICHRA vs. QSEHRA differences
- Key revelation: Special Enrollment Period (SEP) capability - ICHRA can start outside open enrollment (February 1 or March 1, 2026 potential start dates)
- Product demonstration: Taryn shared screen showing Thatch platform features:
  - Mini marketplace with ~5 carriers, 20+ plan options per zip code
  - AI-powered plan recommendations
  - Wellness marketplace partnerships
  - Payroll integration capabilities
  - Receipt verification and reimbursement system

Pricing Discussion:
- Per Employee Per Month (PEPM): $45
- Monthly Compliance Fee: $50 (flat fee, not per employee)

Decision Point:
- Diane determined current year (2025/2026 plan year) too late to implement
- Expressed strong interest for future implementation
- Requested follow-up after New Year for detailed planning

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES & RESPONSIBLE PARTIES

Immediate Actions:

1. Follow-up Email - Taryn Livingstone
   - Deadline: Week of December 16, 2025
   - Responsible Party: Taryn Livingstone
   - Action Items: 
     - Send recap email
     - Confirm scheduled follow-up meeting
     - Provide any additional resources

2. Calendar Invitation - Taryn Livingstone
   - Deadline: Week of December 16, 2025
   - Responsible Party: Taryn Livingstone
   - Action: Send meeting invitation for January 13, 2026

Scheduled Follow-up Meeting:

3. Reconnection Call
   - Date: Monday, January 13, 2026
   - Time: 2:00 PM Arizona Time (4:00 PM Eastern Time)
   - Participants: Diane Borhani and Taryn Livingstone
   - Agenda Items:
     - Review employee census
     - Prepare budget/quote for ICHRA implementation
     - Discuss contribution levels
     - Explore February 1 or March 1, 2026 start date options
     - Address partner's alternative coverage solution
     - Plan employee communication strategy

Pre-Meeting Preparation:

4. Employee Census Preparation - Diane Borhani
   - Deadline: Before January 13, 2026 meeting
   - Responsible Party: Diane Borhani
   - Action: Compile current employee information for quote preparation

5. Quote/Budget Preparation - Taryn Livingstone
   - Deadline: For January 13, 2026 meeting
   - Responsible Party: Taryn Livingstone
   - Action Items:
     - Create customized budget projection
     - Map out monthly per-employee costs
     - Calculate contribution scenarios
     - Prepare implementation timeline options

Future Considerations:

6. Implementation Decision
   - Target Timeframe: January-February 2026
   - Responsible Party: Diane Borhani (decision maker)
   - Potential Start Dates: February 1, 2026 or March 1, 2026
   - Dependencies: 
     - Budget approval
     - Employee communication
     - Payroll integration setup
     - Partner alternative coverage solution

7. Employee Transition Planning
   - Responsible Parties: Diane Borhani (communication), Taryn/Thatch (technical support)
   - Considerations:
     - Employees with existing marketplace plans can import to Thatch
     - Employees with private plans may need to switch or decline coverage
     - Special Enrollment Period triggered by ICHRA addition
     - Payroll deduction setup for employee contributions

ADDITIONAL NOTES:

- Employer Preference: Afternoon meetings (after 2:00 PM Arizona Time) work best for Diane
- Geographic Context: Phoenix-based company, East Coast Thatch representative (manageable time zone difference)
- Competitive Advantage: Pre-tax benefit vs. post-tax stipend is primary value proposition
- Technical Capability: Thatch offers end-to-end platform including compliance, enrollment, payroll integration, and reimbursement processing
- Employee Support: AI recommendations plus human plan specialists available
- Flexibility: Class-based contribution structures allow different amounts for full-time vs. part-time employees

RISK FACTORS TO MONITOR:
- Partner coverage solution needs resolution
- Employees with private plans may resist switching
- Timeline pressure if targeting Q1 2026 implementation
- Need to ensure all employees understand pre-tax benefit advantage

OPPORTUNITY ASSESSMENT: High potential - employer is actively seeking solution, dissatisfied with current arrangement, employees already self-selecting coverage, and strong interest in administrative simplification and tax advantages.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__98.title: Tech Stack
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__98.value:

Payroll: Not specified in conversation

Benefits Administration: Not specified (only mentioned they have "an agent that's helped us have corporate insurance for several years")

Banking: Not specified in conversation

Note: While Taryn discusses Thatch's ability to integrate with payroll systems and mentions that payments would flow from the business bank account, Diane Borhani did not disclose which specific payroll platform, benefits administration tool, or bank her company currently uses.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.title: Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Call Date: 2025-12-15

Prospect: Diane Borhani, Phoenix-based company with 8 employees (fluctuates between 10-15)

Current Situation:
- Currently offers corporate health insurance through an agent (unhappy with service for several years)
- High deductibles and high premiums
- Only 4 of 8 employees were interested; all 4 declined coverage (found better options on marketplace or privately)
- Decided Friday (2025-12-13) to discontinue offering health insurance
- Planning to provide medical/healthcare stipend instead
- Employees have already selected plans for current year: some marketplace plans, one UnitedHealthcare indemnity plan, one private plan
- One partner with 5% ownership wants to participate but cannot under ICHRA rules (2%+ owners excluded)

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Dissatisfaction with current insurance broker/agent
- High costs (premiums and deductibles) making coverage unattractive to employees
- Concern about post-tax stipend reducing actual benefit to employees (e.g., $200/month becomes much less after taxes)
- Need to offer benefits equally to all employees in same class
- Partner (5% owner) cannot participate in ICHRA
- Employees already have payroll deductions for current plans
- Limited time/late in enrollment period to make changes

Priorities/Optimization Goals:
- Find pre-tax solution for employee healthcare benefits
- Automate payment process
- Provide meaningful financial support to employees for healthcare
- Simplify benefits administration
- Explore ICHRA as alternative to traditional group insurance

Stated Timelines:
- Already decided not to continue current insurance (as of 2025-12-13)
- Employees settled on plans for current year
- Follow-up meeting scheduled: 2026-01-13 at 2:00 PM Arizona time
- Potential implementation: February 1 or March 1, 2026 start date (ICHRA creates special enrollment period, doesn't require open enrollment timing)

Thatch Solution Discussed:
- ICHRA platform with $45/employee/month + $50/month compliance fee
- Pre-tax benefit for employees
- Integrates with payroll for automatic deductions
- Employees can keep marketplace plans or switch
- AI-powered plan selection + human support available
- Wellness marketplace for FSA-like spending

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.title: Next Steps
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/15/2025

Rep (Taryn Livingstone) Owns:
- Send follow-up email to Diane summarizing the conversation
- Send calendar invitation for the January 13th meeting at 2:00 PM Arizona time
- Prepare a quote/budget based on Diane's employee census showing monthly costs per employee and contribution amounts
- Be available for any questions Diane may have before the follow-up meeting

Prospect (Diane Borhani) Owns:
- Review follow-up email and materials from Taryn
- Consider the ICHRA option for implementation (potentially February 1st or March 1st start date)
- Attend scheduled follow-up meeting on January 13th at 2:00 PM Arizona time
- Reach out to Taryn if any questions arise before the meeting

Next Step for Overall Deal:
Follow-up meeting scheduled for 01/13/2026 at 2:00 PM Arizona time to review the quote/budget, discuss implementation timeline (February 1st or March 1st 2026 start date), and determine if ICHRA through Thatch is the right solution for Diane's company of 8 employees.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__eb.value: Single State

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect currently relies on an insurance agent/broker to administer their corporate health insurance benefits. Diane mentions she has "had an agent that's helped us have corporate insurance for several years" but has "never been very happy with them." The agent has provided them with insurance that has high deductibles and high premiums.

The current workflow involves payroll deductions, as Diane notes "They're all used to coming out of their paycheck to pay for their" insurance contributions. However, there is no mention of using a benefits administration platform such as Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits.

At the time of the conversation, Diane had recently decided to discontinue offering traditional group health insurance and was planning to transition to providing employees with a post-tax medical/health care stipend instead. All four employees who were interested in coverage had declined the company plan and found alternatives through the marketplace or private plans. No specific details about manual administration tools (spreadsheets, email) were discussed.

attributes.title: Thatch Onboarding Support
attributes.transcript:
Diane Borhani:
Hi Diane, Hi, how are you Taryn? Is that how you say your name? 
Taryn Livingstone:
All right? Yeah, you, you got it perfect. Um, but yeah, I'm doing well. How's it going with you? 
Diane Borhani:
Oh, it's, it's going. It's been a day, end of the day for me. Where are you at? 
Taryn Livingstone:
It's also end of the day for me too. I'm in a New York City myself. Where are you calling in from? 
Diane Borhani:
Oh my gosh, it is very end of the day where you. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yeah, my days last a little longer these days than they used to, but that's okay. We're getting people enrolled for insurance, and it's just the time of the year. 
Diane Borhani:
It is the time of the year. Well, I'm in Phoenix, and I was curious because I saw your ad come through this weekend. I was scrolling, and I saw it. And I just wanted to make sure that I touched it. It intrigued me. I've talked to. I've had an insurance, I've had an agent that's helped us have corporate insurance for several years, have never been very happy with them. And frankly, the insurance they've got us has high deductibles, high premiums. So I only have vacillates between 10 and 15 employees all the time. Right now, I only have eight, only four wanted to, were even interested. And all four declined because they found better things on the marketplace or privately. Gotcha. So I had pretty much made the decision on Friday to not continue to offer health insurance. And decided that I was just going to give them some kind of medical stipend, health care stipend. I have lots of questions around that. And then I saw your ad and thought, let me just talk to you and see, because I had never heard. Nobody, I'd heard of ICRA. And one of the things, one of the people who wants to be part of our health plan is a partner. She only has 5%. She's at this point more an employee than a partner. She's a partner, nevertheless. And my understanding is that she can't participate if we do ICRA. 
Taryn Livingstone:
That is correct. Yeah. So she would still have to go to the marketplace to get her plan, But every other employee who is not a 2%. Or greater owner could use the ICHRA. 
Diane Borhani:
Okay. So what did, so, and then I had never heard of this other thing. That was what intrigued me. I can't remember the letters, but there was some other offering that you have. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Um, so we only do ICHRA. You may have seen QSERA. I know these acronyms are insane, but that one that starts with a Q, very similar to an ICHRA. It's just basically, it's a little bit more limited. For one thing, it's more tailored toward companies that are less than 10 employees. It also, for instance, like, just to give you an example here. So with an ICRA, you're able to class out different employees, which means that if you have, say, a full-time people and part-time people, if you'd like to, you can split that up and offer the full-time folks more in allowance than the part-time folks, right? So you can do, there's basically more you can actually do with it to tailor it around your needs as a business. Qsehra tends to be a little bit more rigid in terms of setup. It used to be the more popular one when it was the easier one to do, but since more companies like us have come out to make Ichra easy to run, it's becoming a little more popular there. 
Diane Borhani:
Does it change with that one, the partner status? 
Taryn Livingstone:
No, it's the same situation with Accusera. So basically, the problem being that, technically, as a partner, because your tax has a pass-through entity, The insurance for anyone with ownership greater than 2% can be considered a business expense instead of an expense to the employee. It's an expense to the business. So that's where that comes into play. So the reason being that the IRS doesn't want you to both have two pre-tax benefits. So that's kind of why they limit your access to ICRA, QSARA, that sort of thing. 
Diane Borhani:
So now that everybody, so we've spent all last week on this and gotten everybody, everybody's picked their own thing, right? So they either have, like, a private plan. I'm not even sure it's really health insurance, but it's. It's through UnitedHealthcare, so I'm hoping it's going to be okay. But it's like an indemnity plan. Have you heard of those? 
Taryn Livingstone:
I'm not super familiar. I definitely heard of it. I'm not that familiar with how it works. That's okay. 
Diane Borhani:
But they either have that or they've gone through the marketplace. So I'm not sure it's really worth, at this point, your time or mine, to talk about this. But I thought, maybe you'd have an. I was looking for something that would offer me kind of pre-tax for the employees? 
Taryn Livingstone:
Well, so here's the thing, right? So for the employees who went through the marketplace, what they could do is with the plans they've already chosen. So, say you started with Thatch today, whatever you're planning on offering them as a stipend for the marketplace, you could actually just get completely pre-tax if you went through Thatch on ICRA, meaning that they already have their plans that they picked. What they would do for their sign up is they could actually, because it's still during open enrollment, if they wanted to, they could cancel the plan and pick a new one. Or, and this actually is a very easy step for them, as they're signing up for Thatch, it will ask, hey, do you already have a plan through the marketplace? If they say yes, they can, in one step, import that plan to Thatch. So that the dollar amount you're giving them for the pre-tax stipend there goes straight from your business bank account to Thatch. To then go and pay for their marketplace plan. So. It actually, to answer your question is still something you can set up. Um, and it again, actually. It would probably probably lead to some savings in terms of just the fact that this would be pre-tax versus post tax dollars there. 
Diane Borhani:
And that then eliminates the problem I would have if I. Because if I do this post tax, then I've got to offer it to everybody, right? 
Taryn Livingstone:
You do it post tax, so, so, no. So, well, I'm not sure about post-tax, but pre-tax wise, though, with the ICRA, you would need to offer it to everyone in the same class. So, meaning that if everyone's like full time salaried employee, for instance, you'd have to offer it to all of them. You wouldn't be able to take one person out of that. But if you might have somebody who's a full time hourly employee, that would be a different one. So, so, so. Basically, you have to offer it to all employees of the same class. 
Diane Borhani:
And yeah. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yeah, you got it. And you said, you have eight folks right now, right? Right. 
Diane Borhani:
Okay. 
Taryn Livingstone:
And they're all the same class, it sounds like? 
Diane Borhani:
Well, yes. I've got one that's a part-timer. I have one that is, everybody else is probably the same class, and then the person who's partner. Partner, right. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Okay, gotcha. Yeah. So in that case, for the folks who are an indigent, you don't need to class out if you don't want to. But the only person who wouldn't be eligible would be the partner, who would just simply keep doing. However, their insurance is being done right now. 
Diane Borhani:
And what do I do for her to be able to help her out? There's just nothing. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Yeah, it's a good question. Honestly, I don't know. To my knowledge, I don't believe there would be a pre-tax way to help her out. I think it would be the stipend plan that you have to. To begin with. Okay. 
Diane Borhani:
Well, tell me a little bit, since I have you, a little bit about your software and how it works. Sure. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Actually, yeah. You know what? Let me, let me like, let's see. I will show you a couple of things. So let me first start with here. I'm going to pull up my, my screen real quick. Can you see, can you see this? 
Diane Borhani:
Yes. 
Taryn Livingstone:
Okay, perfect. So I'll give you the quick rundown on how that works. This is going to include ICRA, but also to like what that means for running on thatch. So to give you the quick overview, at thatch, our mission is to build a healthcare system people love. So how do we do that? Well, right now, and you may be pretty familiar with this, But for small employers, generally speaking, insurance is a tough thing to do for a couple of reasons. So, first off, usually it means you need to pick one carrier with a couple plan options to fit everybody. If you're going to go the group route, which can be a little bit sticky. Because you might have someone who prefers one doctor network, a different one, and then it's hard to meet everybody's needs. Likewise, if there was ever anybody who happened to be more expensive one year for their health care, it would end up taking the premiums up for your entire group. So it just becomes like a one size fits all situation. And so that is where. Right. And you obviously know you're familiar with this, given that you're going the stipend approach. So to illustrate how this works with an ICRA, basically, what you would do is set a pre-tax budget. And then, with that budget, employees first would buy their medical plan. And then if they were to have any leftover funds, that can be worked very similarly, like an FSA account, where they can spend that on prescriptions, copays. But also they can go on to a telehealth vendor to get a specific prescription, too. So it really makes it so that they can go in a few different directions to get what they need for their care. Okay, yeah. And then also to illustrate, Thatch a bit more here. So for any given area, we have around five carriers with over 20 plan options. So this basically means that we provide a mini marketplace, if you will, for each person, depending on exactly what their Zip code is. Right.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Creator Ventures (Sasha Kaletsky)

Meeting Date: Monday, December 15, 2025  
Meeting Title: Thatch and Creator Ventures - Deel  
Thatch Representative: Joseph Firenzi (Business Team)  
Prospect Contact: Sasha Kaletsky (Primary Owner/Only W-2 Employee)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Company Overview
- Company Structure: VC fund operating as an LLC taxed as a pass-through entity
- Current Team Composition: 
  - 1 W-2 employee (Sasha himself - recently transitioned to W-2)
  - 1 contractor based in South Africa
  - 1 co-founder based in London (paid through UK entity, not W-2)
- Funding Status: Raised $45 million with capacity to hire
- Payroll: Currently using Deel

Primary Need & Motivation
- Immediate Need: Health insurance coverage for Sasha and his wife
- Urgency Factor: Wife likely getting pregnant in 2026, making immediate coverage critical
- Initial Interest: Wanted to leverage pre-tax dollars through Thatch's ICHRA platform

Critical Discovery - Tax Structure Limitation
- Disqualification: As an LLC owner with pass-through entity taxation, Sasha CANNOT use Thatch's ICHRA platform
- IRS Reasoning: Pass-through entity owners already have access to pre-tax benefits through their business structure; using Thatch would constitute "double dipping" per IRS regulations
- Required Solution: Must purchase coverage through New York State Exchange (government marketplace)
- Future Opportunity: When non-owner W-2 employees are hired (expected within 1-2 years), they CAN use Thatch's ICHRA platform

ICHRA Education Provided
- Plan Options: New York has limited third-party ICRA administrator options (only 6 plans available)
- Government Exchange Advantage: More plan options available on NY State Exchange
- Workaround for Future Employees: Employees can purchase plans on government exchange and import to Thatch for administration
- Calendar Year Structure: ICHRA plans renew in January; earlier enrollment in calendar year provides more time to meet deductibles
- Special Enrollment Period: First-time ICHRA users can enroll on the first of any month

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Prospect Organization (Creator Ventures)
- Sasha Kaletsky
  - Role: Primary Owner, VC Fund Manager, Only W-2 Employee
  - Responsibilities: Decision-maker for benefits; needs to enroll in coverage for self and spouse
  - Current Status: Recently transitioned to W-2 employee status

- Sasha's Wife
  - Role: Dependent/Spouse
  - Relevance: Requires coverage; potential pregnancy in 2026 creates urgency

- Future Employees (Not Yet Hired)
  - Timeline: Expected within 1-2 years
  - Relevance: Will be eligible for Thatch ICHRA platform as non-owner W-2 employees

Vendor/Service Provider (Thatch)
- Joseph Firenzi
  - Role: Business Team Member
  - Responsibilities: Sales consultation, education on ICHRA regulations, resource provision
  - Commitment: Offered ongoing support if Sasha encounters issues with state exchange enrollment

External Resources Mentioned
- CPA/Tax Advisor (Not Named)
  - Role: Tax filing and advice
  - Relevance: Can help Sasha understand pre-tax benefits available through pass-through entity structure

- New York State Exchange
  - Role: Government marketplace for health insurance
  - Relevance: Required enrollment platform for Sasha's current situation

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Enrollment Deadlines

December 15, 2025 (Day of Call) - IMMEDIATE DEADLINE
- Last day to enroll for January 2026 coverage start date on NY State Exchange
- Sasha indicated he would not meet this deadline

January 15, 2026 - ALTERNATIVE DEADLINE
- Enrollment deadline for February 2026 coverage start
- Sasha expressed comfort with February start date ("if I'm chill with it being February")

Special Enrollment Period - ONGOING OPTION
- As first-time ICHRA user, Sasha can enroll on the first of any month
- However, later enrollment means less time to meet deductible before 2026 plan year ends

Future Milestones

2026 - PREGNANCY TIMELINE
- Wife expected to become pregnant
- Makes comprehensive coverage with maternity benefits essential

Within 1-2 Years (2026-2027) - HIRING PHASE
- Expected to hire non-owner W-2 employees
- Trigger point for re-engaging with Thatch for ICHRA platform
- Would enable centralized benefits administration

January 2026 - PLAN RENEWAL
- All ICHRA plans renew on calendar year basis
- Important for understanding deductible reset timing

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES & RESPONSIBLE PARTIES

Immediate Actions - Sasha Kaletsky (Prospect)

By January 15, 2026:
- [ ] Access NY State Exchange portal (link provided by Joe during call)
- [ ] Create account on government marketplace
- [ ] Review available health insurance plans
- [ ] Evaluate plan options considering:
  - Wife's potential pregnancy/maternity coverage
  - Deductible amounts
  - Premium costs
  - Provider networks
- [ ] Complete enrollment for February 2026 coverage start

Optional - Before Enrollment:
- [ ] Consult with CPA regarding pre-tax benefits available through pass-through entity structure
- [ ] Reach out to Joe Firenzi if encountering issues or needing guidance

Future Actions - Sasha Kaletsky

When Hiring Non-Owner W-2 Employees (Est. 2026-2027):
- [ ] Re-engage with Thatch (contact Joe Firenzi)
- [ ] Evaluate ICHRA platform for employee benefits administration
- [ ] Consider importing government exchange plans to Thatch for centralized management

Thatch Follow-Up - Joseph Firenzi

Immediate:
- [x] Send NY State Exchange portal link (completed during call)
- [ ] Send additional resources about enrollment process
- [ ] Provide contact information for ongoing support

Ongoing:
- [ ] Remain available as resource if Sasha encounters enrollment challenges
- [ ] Monitor for future opportunity when Creator Ventures begins hiring employees

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Disqualification Summary
This opportunity is not currently viable for Thatch due to tax structure limitations. Sasha, as the sole owner of a pass-through entity, is ineligible for Thatch's ICHRA platform per IRS regulations.

Future Opportunity Assessment
- High Potential: Company has raised $45M and plans to hire within 1-2 years
- Strong Fit When Ready: Future non-owner employees would benefit from Thatch's platform
- Relationship Status: Positive interaction; Sasha expressed intent to return ("eventually I'll live back with you guys")
- Recommended Action: Maintain relationship and check in when hiring begins

Competitive Context
- Currently using Deel for payroll
- Open enrollment season (Q4) is peak period for Thatch

Risk Factors
- Timeline for hiring is uncertain ("within next year or two")
- Company may choose alternative benefits solution when ready to hire
- Sasha must navigate state exchange independently, which could create friction

It's New York State Exchange. I have, yeah, I have. I think it's very expensive. So I was hoping to find a way to use pre-tax dollars. You're saying I will be able to use pre-tax dollars? 
Joseph Firenzi:
You can't use the pre-tax funds on Thatch. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
So you would be saying, I could in my government if I use the government New York State thing, I can. 
Joseph Firenzi:
You can purchase a plan there. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
It's just pre-tax dollars. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yes. Well, you're as a pass-through entity owner, you'll be able to get some kind of break at the end of the year. If you speak to your CPA or however you file. Basically, you'll just go to this portal here that I sent you and then you'll look at all the plans there. And then, because you're in New York, there actually are going to be some more options available on the Government Exchange there. And the reason for that is that there's two kinds of Icra plans. There's on the exchange, you're on this government website, and then there's something called third party Icra administrators, which is what Thatch is. And then, for whatever reason, there's only six plans available in New York. In downtown New York for the third-party Icra administrators. There is kind of a workaround, though, if hypothetically, you hire more employees and you want to let them use the extra pre-tax dollars that Thatch offers. They can purchase a plan on the government exchange and then import it to Thatch. But again, you, as the employer, will just need to keep it off of thatch because you're, um, you're already able to access pre-tax dollars with your business filing there. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
I see. So you're basically saying, I need to use the government New York State thing. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yes, that's correct. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
Okay. So I can't work with that. And then when I get employees, which I probably will within the next year or two, then I'll be able to use that and just manage it all from there. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yeah, yeah. That'll be a lot easier. And then there should be time, by the way, to enroll in a plan for a January start date for the exchange there. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
Wouldn't have to be today. Would have to be today or tomorrow. 
Joseph Firenzi:
I think it might be different than ours. We just extended our enrollment deadline to the 22nd. Can try to find that for you quickly. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
No, you go ahead, please. 
Joseph Firenzi:
I was just going to say, it's not very time consuming. The most time consuming part is just going to be evaluating all the different plan options, because there are quite a few. When it comes to ICHRAs. But in terms of like the actual technical aspects of, you know, going on there and creating your account, it's very quick. But there should be some good options on there. Let me see. Yeah. Okay, so it does look like if you wanted the coverage to begin today, or not today, If you wanted the coverage to begin in January, it looks like today might actually be the enrollment deadline. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
And if I'm chill with it being February, then I just need to do it by 15th of January. Yes. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Or is this your first time using an icra plan? Yeah. So then, yeah, If it is your first time switching to one, it does trigger what's called a special enrollment period, and you can sign up on the first of any month. The thing to keep in mind, though, is that the sooner in the year that you start, the better, because Icras always function on a calendar year basis, which means. Your new plan will always renew in January. So, hypothetically, if you got started in November, you would only have two months to pay off the deductible on your plan. Before that new 2026 plan kicked in. So, in other words, the longer you have the plan throughout the year, the longer you have to pay off your deductible. But if the deductible is not a factor and you choose a $0 deductible plan, then that won't be very relevant. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
Okay, well, I appreciate it very much. That's really helpful. So I'll use that state marketplace. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yeah. Thank you very much. Yeah, happy to help, by the way, if you hit any snags and send any resources or put you in touch with our team, because I know there's a lot of moving pieces here. So I want to be a resource to you. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
Well, that's really appreciated. Thank you, Joseph. And then, yeah, when I do get employees, which will happen, we've raised $45 million. So we have the ability to hire people. But right now, we haven't. And so, yeah, eventually I'll live back with you guys. Cool. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Sounds good. Well, it was a pleasure meeting you, Sasha. And please feel free to reach out if you have any questions. And I hope you have a great day. All right. 
Sasha Kaletsky:
Bye-bye.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Gabe Gibitz - Jivet's

Date of Conversation: Monday, December 15, 2025  
Thatch Representative: Taryn Livingstone  
Prospect Company: Jivet's  
Location: Kentucky (Zip: 40291)

Executive Summary
Discovery call revealed that Thatch's ICHRA solution is not a fit for this prospect due to entity structure limitations. Prospect is an S-corp owner seeking Section 105 plan options, which are incompatible with ICHRA due to pass-through entity tax treatment.

Key Discussion Points

Business Context
- Entity Type: S-corporation with single owner (Gabe Gibitz)
- Current Structure: No W-2 employees, all contractors
- Immediate Challenge: Health insurance costs increasing by 700% for 2026 (significant cost pressure)
- Current Coverage: Already has existing health insurance plan; comparing marketplace and private plans
- Income Level: Salaried out of marketplace subsidies; marketplace would cost $1,700/month

Initial Interest & Exploration
1. Section 105 Plan Investigation: Gabe was exploring hiring his wife (who already does some work for the business) to establish a Section 105 plan for family coverage
2. Desired Outcome: Coverage for medical expenses for family (Gabe, wife, and children) through business entity
3. Future Considerations: Mentioned interest in HRAs and QSEHRAs as business grows and adds employees

Critical Discovery - Disqualification Factors
1. Entity Type Restriction: ICHRA requires C-corp taxation for owners; S-corps are pass-through entities and already receive tax benefits on health insurance expenses (would be "double dipping")
2. Sole Proprietorship Alternative Explored: Also wouldn't work due to same pass-through taxation issue
3. Marketplace Dependency: ICHRA is built on individual ACA marketplace plans or off-exchange plans at similar rates, which doesn't align with prospect's need to avoid marketplace pricing
4. Premium Requirement: ICHRA requires purchasing a medical plan first before accessing funds for other medical expenses

Educational Moments
- Taryn clarified that ICHRA vs QSERA differences (ICHRA offers more flexibility with class divisions)
- Explained that S-corp owners cannot use ICHRA for themselves due to tax treatment
- Corrected CPA misinformation: Wife CAN be W-2 employee but cannot claim owner as dependent under ICHRA
- Clarified ICHRA is pre-tax benefit, which creates the double-dipping issue for pass-through entities

Stakeholders Identified

Prospect Side
1. Gabe Gibitz
   - Role: Owner, S-corp (Jivet's)
   - Responsibility: Decision-maker for business health benefits
   - Current Status: Seeking alternative solutions to manage 700% insurance cost increase

2. Gabe's Wife
   - Role: Potential W-2 employee (currently doing some work for business)
   - Responsibility: Would be vehicle for Section 105 plan if viable
   - Current Status: Not yet formally hired

3. Gabe's CPA
   - Role: Tax advisor
   - Responsibility: Advising on entity structure and tax implications
   - Note: Provided some incorrect information about Section 105 eligibility that was corrected during call

Thatch Side
1. Taryn Livingstone
   - Role: Sales Representative
   - Responsibility: Discovery, education, qualification
   - Action: Disqualified prospect due to entity structure incompatibility

Critical Timestamps & Milestones

Early in Call (Minutes 1-3):
- Context setting: Open enrollment period, health insurance cost increase discussion
- Gabe shares 700% premium increase challenge

Mid-Call (Minutes 3-8):
- Gabe explains S-corp structure and Section 105 plan exploration
- Initial discussion of ICHRA vs QSERA
- Confusion about whether existing health insurance plan matters

Critical Turning Point (Minutes 8-12):
- Gabe asks: "What if I already have health insurance?"
- Reveals he's salaried out of marketplace ($1,700/month cost)
- Key question: "Is the ICRA built on the marketplace, the ACA?" - Answer: Yes
- Realization that ICHRA requires marketplace-based or similar pricing

Disqualification Moment (Minutes 12-15):
- Clarification that S-corp owners cannot use ICHRA due to pass-through entity taxation
- Exploration of sole proprietorship alternative - also doesn't work
- Gabe confirms: "I'm not looking for an ICRA" - "Correct"

Call Conclusion (Minutes 15-16):
- Mutual agreement that Thatch ICHRA is not the right solution
- Taryn suggests consulting CPA for alternative Section 105 options

Next Steps & Action Items

Prospect Actions
1. Immediate: Consult with CPA about Section 105 plan alternatives that work with S-corp or sole proprietorship structures
   - Deadline: No specific deadline set
   - Responsible Party: Gabe Gibitz
   - Note: Gabe acknowledged he "doesn't know enough to advise himself" on this topic

2. Future Consideration: If entity structure changes to C-corp, or if W-2 employees are added, revisit Thatch ICHRA
   - Timeline: Undefined (mentioned "as business grows")
   - Responsible Party: Gabe Gibitz

Thatch Actions
1. No immediate follow-up required - prospect disqualified due to entity structure
2. Future Opportunity: Monitor for potential re-engagement if:
   - Business converts to C-corp taxation
   - Business adds W-2 employees (wife or others)
   - Business structure changes in any way that would make ICHRA viable

Open Items
- Gabe needs to identify viable Section 105 plan providers that work with S-corps
- CPA consultation needed to clarify conflicting information about Section 105 eligibility
- Alternative health insurance solutions needed to address 700% cost increase

Disposition
Status: DISQUALIFIED - Not a fit for Thatch ICHRA  
Reason: S-corp entity structure incompatible with ICHRA tax treatment  
Future Opportunity: LOW (unless entity structure changes to C-corp)  
Competitor Intelligence: Prospect exploring private plans and Section 105 alternatives outside marketplace

Additional Notes
- Prospect was well-prepared and had done research on Section 105 plans
- Demonstrated understanding of tax implications and entity structures
- Significant cost pressure (700% increase) indicates strong motivation to find solution
- Geographic location: Kentucky (40291 zip code)
- Family coverage needed (2 adults + children)
- No current employees, all contractors - limits group plan options

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__b0.value:
Call Date: 2025-12-15

Prospect: Gabe Gibitz (S-corp owner, Kentucky - zip 40291)

Current Situation:
- S-corp with single owner, no W-2 employees (all contractors)
- Has existing health insurance (comparing marketplace and private plans)
- Health insurance premium increasing 700% for next year
- Lost tax credits as business has grown
- Projected marketplace cost: $1,700/month
- Wife already doing some work for business; has sole proprietorship providing services to the S-corp
- Family coverage needed: himself, wife, and children

Priorities/Goals:
- Implement Section 105 plan to cover family healthcare expenses
- Hire wife as employee to facilitate Section 105 plan structure
- Future goal: Offer HRAs and QSEHRA options as business adds employees

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Dramatic health insurance cost increase (700%)
- Income level makes marketplace plans expensive and tax credits unavailable
- Confusion about entity structure requirements (S-corp vs C-corp vs sole prop) for Section 105 plans
- Needs third-party administrator for compliant Section 105 plan setup

Key Discovery:
- Thatch's ICRA solution is not a fit because:
  - S-corp owners cannot participate in ICRA (pass-through entity limitation)
  - ICRA requires C-corp taxation for owner participation
  - Would constitute "double dipping" on pre-tax benefits for S-corp/sole prop owners
  - Sole proprietorship structure also wouldn't work (same pass-through entity issue)

Next Steps:
- Consult with CPA about alternative Section 105 plan options
- Explore non-ICRA solutions for S-corp owner health coverage

Timeline: Needs solution for 2026 coverage year (open enrollment period active)

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__da.value:
12/15/2025

Prospect Actions (Gabe Gibitz):
- Consult with CPA about Section 105 plan options and alternative solutions for health insurance coverage as an S-corp owner
- Explore other health insurance options outside of ICRA since Thatch's solution is not compatible with his S-corp entity structure
- Reach out to Taryn if he has questions or if his business structure changes in the future

Rep Actions (Taryn Livingstone):
- Remain available for future questions or if Gabe's situation changes

Overall Deal Status:
The opportunity is not progressing at this time. Thatch's ICRA solution is not a fit for Gabe's current business structure (S-corp). The deal is effectively closed-lost unless Gabe converts to a C-corp or adds W-2 employees in the future. No follow-up meeting is scheduled.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Joshua Tree Coffee Company - ICHRA Discovery Call

Date of Conversation: Monday, December 15, 2025  
Company: Joshua Tree Coffee Company  
Location: California (Primary ZIP: 92252)

1. KEY POINTS DISCUSSED

Employer's Interest in ICHRA
- Primary Motivation: Provide health reimbursement to employees as a cost-effective alternative to consistent salary raises due to excessive premium costs
- Current Situation: 
  - No group health plan sponsorship
  - Employee premiums becoming increasingly expensive
  - Seeking more affordable benefits solution
- Target Coverage: 3-5 salaried employees initially (out of ~40 total employees)
- Proposed Stipend Amount: $300-$500/month (Brian mentioned starting low with flexibility, using $400 as working example)
- Coverage Strategy: Carve-out approach - offering only to full-time salaried employees, excluding hourly workers

ICHRA Structure & Mechanics
- Allowance Type: Fixed dollar amount for all eligible employees
- Plan Selection: Employees can either:
  1. Purchase off-exchange plans through Thatch (pre-tax for both employer and employee contributions)
  2. Import existing ACA marketplace plans (pre-tax for employer contribution only)
- Payment Flow: Automated through Thatch platform
  - Employer contribution flows from business bank account → Thatch → Insurance carrier
  - Employee contribution (if any) flows from payroll → Thatch → Insurance carrier
- Compliance: Zero delinquency rate maintained through automated payment controls

Administrative Considerations
- Payroll Integration: QuickBooks Payroll (confirmed compatibility)
- Automation: Fully automated after initial setup - no ongoing admin tasks required per payroll cycle
- Employee Management: High turnover concern addressed through streamlined platform
- Plan Availability: Multiple PPO and low-deductible options available in ZIP 92252 area

2. STAKEHOLDERS IDENTIFIED

Prospect Company (Joshua Tree Coffee Company)
- Brian Timmer - Primary Decision Maker
  - Role: Company representative/owner
  - Responsibilities: Final approval on ICHRA implementation, budget setting, employee eligibility determination
  - Authority: Controls benefits decisions for ~40 employees

Thatch Team
- Taryn Livingstone - Business Development Representative
  - Role: Primary contact for companies under 15 employees
  - Responsibilities: Product education, implementation guidance, compliance clarification
  - Support scope: Discovery through setup assistance

- Thatch Support Team (mentioned)
  - Role: Employee assistance for plan selection
  - Responsibilities: Doctor network verification, prescription coverage checks, plan comparison support

Eligible Employees
- 3-5 Full-Time Salaried Employees
  - Role: Benefit recipients
  - Responsibilities: Plan selection by deadline, enrollment completion
  - Classification: Full-time salaried (carve-out from 80%+ hourly workforce)

Payroll Administrator (implied)
- Role: QuickBooks Payroll operator
  - Responsibilities: Initial integration setup (one-time), ongoing automated processing
  - Note: Minimal ongoing involvement after setup

3. IMPORTANT MILESTONES & TIMESTAMPS

Critical Conversation Moments

[Early in call] - Employer Needs Assessment
- Brian clarified company size: ~40 total employees, 3-5 eligible for ICHRA
- Established carve-out strategy: salaried vs. hourly distinction
- Confirmed no current marketplace stipends for employees

[Mid-call] - Compliance & Structure Discussion
- Key Question Raised: Legality of age-based allowance differentiation
  - Resolution: Thatch's smart allowance formula handles compliant age/location/dependent banding automatically
- Decision Point: Brian chose fixed dollar amount over smart allowances for simplicity

[Mid-call] - Payment Mechanics Clarification
- Critical Understanding: Brian questioned reimbursement process for employees who drop coverage
  - Resolution: Thatch controls fund flow through platform, preventing delinquencies
  - Automated payment from payroll ensures continuous coverage verification

[Late call] - Integration & Admin Burden
- Concern Addressed: High employee turnover creating admin burden
  - Resolution: Automated payroll integration eliminates per-payroll manual tasks
  - QuickBooks compatibility confirmed

[End of call] - Outstanding Items
- Open Question: Whether all 40 employees must be uploaded or only the 3-5 eligible ones
  - Status: Taryn to follow up with compliance team for clarification

4. NEXT STEPS WITH DEADLINES

Immediate Actions (Week of December 15-19, 2025)

Action Item #1: Clarify Employee Upload Requirements  
- Responsible Party: Taryn Livingstone (Thatch)
- Deadline: Before December 19, 2025
- Details: Confirm whether Brian must upload all 40 employees or only the 3-5 eligible salaried employees for compliance purposes

Action Item #2: Employer Account Creation  
- Responsible Party: Brian Timmer (Joshua Tree Coffee Company)
- Deadline: December 19, 2025 (HARD DEADLINE for 2026-01-01 coverage start)
- Process: 
  1. Visit Thatch.com and click "Start Now"
  2. Complete self-serve signup
  3. Upload employee census (name, email, DOB, ZIP, dependent count)
  4. Set fixed allowance amount ($300-$500 range)
  5. Integrate QuickBooks Payroll

Action Item #3: Review Plan Options  
- Responsible Party: Brian Timmer
- Deadline: Before December 19, 2025 (recommended)
- Details: Visit Thatch.com/plans, enter ZIP 92252 to preview available plans for employees

Employee Actions (December 19-28, 2025)

Action Item #4: Employee Plan Selection & Enrollment  
- Responsible Party: 3-5 Eligible Salaried Employees
- Deadline: December 28, 2025 (for 2026-01-01 coverage start)
- Process:
  1. Receive invitation from Thatch
  2. Review available plans (off-exchange through Thatch or import existing ACA plan)
  3. Select plan and complete enrollment
  4. Set up automated payment (if applicable)

Follow-Up Actions

Action Item #5: Post-Setup Support  
- Responsible Party: Taryn Livingstone / Thatch Support Team
- Timeline: Ongoing as needed
- Details: Available for employee questions on doctor networks, prescription coverage, plan comparisons

Action Item #6: Alternative Timeline (if needed)  
- Coverage Start Date: February 1, 2026
- Note: If December 19 deadline cannot be met, Brian can target February 1 start date with adjusted timeline

ADDITIONAL NOTES

Pricing Structure
- Per Employee Fee: $45/month per enrolled employee
- Platform Fee: $50/month (flat rate, not per employee)
- Example: 5 employees = $275/month total ($225 employee fees + $50 platform fee)

Outstanding Questions for Follow-Up
1. Employee census upload requirements (all 40 vs. only eligible 3-5)
2. Final stipend amount determination ($300-$500 range)
3. Exact coverage start date preference (January 1 vs. February 1, 2026)

Risk Factors / Considerations
- High employee turnover (mitigated by automated platform)
- Tight timeline for January 1 start (4 days until account creation deadline)
- Employee adoption/education needed for plan selection

Competitive Advantages Highlighted
- Zero percent delinquency rate
- Full automation post-setup
- Pre-tax treatment for employee contributions (off-exchange plans)
- Comprehensive plan marketplace with PPO options
- Direct support for employees during plan selection

Call Outcome: Positive - Brian understands ICHRA mechanics, pricing, and timeline. Ready to proceed pending clarification on employee upload requirements. Self-serve implementation path confirmed.

Meeting Date: December 15, 2025

Prospect: Brian Timmer, Joshua Tree Coffee Company

Current Situation:
- Small company in California desert with ~40 employees (80%+ full-time)
- No group health plan currently sponsored
- Primarily hourly workforce with 3-5 salaried employees
- Uses QuickBooks payroll
- Employees located primarily in ZIP code 92252

Priorities:
- Provide health reimbursement specifically to salaried employees (3-5 people)
- Offer pre-tax benefit as cost-effective alternative to salary increases
- Differentiate benefits by employee class (salaried vs. hourly)

Pain Points & Challenges:
- Employee health insurance premiums becoming excessive
- High employee turnover creates administrative burden concerns
- Needs compliance-safe way to differentiate between employee classes
- Wants assurance that reimbursements stop if employees drop coverage
- Concerned about ongoing administrative tasks for payroll staff

Optimization Goals:
- Start with conservative stipend ($300-500/month, likely $400)
- Maintain flexibility to increase amounts later (can't decrease)
- Automate payment flows and minimize manual administrative work
- Ensure full integration with QuickBooks payroll

Stated Timelines:
- Target coverage start: January 1, 2026 or February 1, 2026
- Must create account by: December 19, 2025 (for Jan 1 start)
- Employee enrollment deadline: December 28, 2025 (for Jan 1 start)

Outstanding Questions:
- Whether all 40 employees must be uploaded to platform or only the 3-5 eligible salaried employees (Taryn to follow up)

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.title: Current Benefit Process
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value:
The prospect (Brian Timmer) does not currently sponsor a group health insurance plan for employees. Instead, employees are responsible for obtaining their own health insurance coverage individually. To help offset rising premium costs, the company has been providing consistent salary raises to employees rather than offering formal health benefits. 

The company uses QuickBooks payroll for payroll processing, but there is no mention of using any benefits administration platform (such as Ease, Rippling, or Zenefits) or working with a broker or third-party service to manage employee benefits. The current approach appears to be informal and compensation-based rather than utilizing any structured benefits administration system or workflow.

summary.summaryText:
- Taryn captured team size and enrollment details early, showing strong discovery skills.
- Taryn missed mapping decision-makers; next, ask about the approval hierarchy and key stakeholders.
- Taryn didn't align features to priorities; next, connect each feature to Brian's goals and desired outcomes.

Date: 2025-12-15

Client/Prospect: Sapiom  
Participants: Rachel (Chief of Staff), Alon (Owner/CEO)  
Location: San Diego, CA  
Structure: C-Corp  
Team Size: 5 FTEs (all in California)

Current State:
- Baseline healthcare through Rippling (current broker)
- $1,500/year wellness stipend for reimbursement
- No competitive benefits package in place
- Insurance renewal cycle: September annually

Priorities:
- Establish competitive benefits infrastructure from the outset
- Explore comprehensive benefits options (interested in niche providers like Carrot, Maven for family building)
- Support anticipated team growth in early 2026

Pain Points/Challenges:
- Lack of structured benefits offering
- Potentially locked into current Rippling contract mid-year (described broker as "sharks")
- Uncertainty about ability to exit current plan before renewal
- Unfamiliar with ICHRA model - learning curve on new benefits structure

Optimization Goals:
- Provide employee choice in healthcare plans
- Implement pre-tax benefits structure
- Build scalable benefits infrastructure for growing team

Stated Timelines:
- Desired start: January 2026 (ASAP)
- Enrollment deadline: 2025-12-22 (extended)
- Realistic target: 2026-02-01 (pending ability to exit current plan)
- Team growth: Early 2026 (dependent on ongoing fundraising)

Next Steps:
- Rachel to contact Rippling to determine if they can exit the current plan before the September renewal.
- Rachel to discuss with Alon and follow up this week with questions.

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.title: Account Notes
fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__51.value:
Account Notes: Thatch and Sapiom Discovery Call

Meeting Date: Monday, December 15, 2025

Participants:
- Joe Firenzi (Thatch - Business Team)
- Rachel (Sapiom - Chief of Staff, attending as proxy for Alon)

1. Key Points Discussed

Company Background & Current Situation:
- Sapiom is a very early-stage startup with 5 full-time employees.
- Currently offers baseline healthcare through Rippling (broker) and a $1,500/year wellness stipend.
- Plans to grow the team quickly in early 2026, contingent on fundraising success.
- Operates as a C-Corp, which is important for ICHRA eligibility.

Interest in ICHRA:
- Sapiom aims to build a competitive benefits infrastructure from scratch.
- Interested in niche benefits providers like Carrot and Maven.
- Attracted to Thatch's model but still learning about ICHRA.
- Rachel believes ICHRA is the future of benefits but acknowledges the learning curve.

Key Concerns & Questions:
- Current health insurance renewal is in September, with Rippling as the broker.
- Concerns about the feasibility of exiting the current Rippling plan.
- Questions about Thatch's market presence and why ICHRA isn't more widely adopted.

ICHRA Education Provided:
- Employees can choose from ~40 plans in California.
- Allowance structure is pre-tax and can be customized.
- Surplus funds function like an FSA.
- ICHRA can be cost-competitive depending on demographics.
- Group insurance saw significant rate increases in 2025.

Pricing Structure:
- Platform Fee: $45 per enrolled employee per month.
- Compliance Fee: $50/month flat.
- Discounts available upon request.

Demo Highlights:
- Demonstrated dynamic calculator with sample employees.
- Explained cost-sharing scenarios and Thatch Marketplace.

2. Stakeholders Identified

Prospect Company (Sapiom):
- Alon - Owner/CEO, final decision-maker.
- Rachel - Chief of Staff, benefits administrator, and project lead.

Thatch Team:
- Joe Firenzi - Sales/Account Management.

3. Important Milestones & Timestamps

Critical Dates:
- December 15, 2025: Discovery call conducted.
- December 22, 2025: Extended enrollment deadline for January 2026 coverage.
- February 1, 2026: Target start date discussed.
- September 2026: Current Rippling health insurance renewal date.

Key Conversation Moments:
- Rachel attended as proxy for Alon.
- Joe explained the ICHRA model and addressed concerns about Rippling.
- Rachel committed to forwarding resources to Alon and discussing internally.

4. Next Steps with Deadlines

Immediate Actions (This Week - by December 22, 2025)

Rachel's Responsibilities:
1. Forward Thatch resources to Alon.
2. Discuss with Alon by December 16, 2025.
3. Contact Rippling to determine exit feasibility.
4. Reach out to Joe with any questions.

Joe's Responsibilities:
1. Send calculator link and resources to Rachel.
2. Research Rippling exit options upon request.
3. Prepare potential fee discount upon request.

Conditional Next Steps (Pending Rippling Exit Determination)

If Exit is Possible:
- Target Start Date: February 1, 2026.
- Finalize allowance strategy and employee data.
- Send employee invitation emails

fed6e1f8-fc50-4dcf-bff7-494a231ae9f3__ed.value: The prospect currently uses Rippling as their benefits administration platform and broker. They are mid-year in their current plan with a renewal date in September. Their current benefits setup includes baseline healthcare coverage administered through Rippling and a $1,500 per year wellness stipend that employees can spend however they want and submit for reimbursement. Rachel, the chief of staff, describes the company as "very early" and notes they are trying to establish a more competitive benefits package. She mentions that Rippling acts as their broker and expresses concern about the difficulty of exiting their current arrangement, referring to Rippling as "sharks" in terms of contract restrictions. The company has 5 full-time employees (including the owner Alon), all located in California, and they are looking to build actual benefits infrastructure beyond their current baseline offering.

- The salesperson missed mapping the decision process; next, clarify Rachel's authority and Alon's role in approvals.
- The salesperson didn't connect benefits to business goals; next, link benefits investment to talent acquisition strategy.

But it is better to sign up earlier in the year because all Icra plans always function on a calendar year basis. So that means, hypothetically, if you got started November 1st, you would only have two months to pay off your deductible plan before your 2026 plan kicked in. Regardless of the month that you sign up in your new 20, your new plan for the following year will always start in January. 
rachel:
Okay. Okay. So I think the long pole or the stage gate is determining if we can change. And then, yeah, understood we would want to start this in the beginning of the year. I doubt we'll get an answer by January 1st, just going into the holidays and everything, but we could target February 1st. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay. 
rachel:
Once we get an answer. Cool. 
Joseph Firenzi:
And then I want to call out that, you know, this does add together all the allowances here and then also adds in the thatch fees. So the fees to use our platform are going to be forty five dollars per enrolled employee per month. If you have someone that declines coverage to go on a spouse's plan, you will not be charged for them. And then there is also a fifty dollar monthly compliance fee, but that stays flat at fifty dollars, regardless of headcount. So if you have one person on that or five on that, that will stay at fifty. We do have some slight wiggle room on those fees there. So if you're interested in a potential discount, please let me know over email and I'll see what I can do there. And then also want to call out that. After you finalize your allowances and you send the invites out to your team members, the allowance structure will be locked for the year, which means you cannot update it in the middle of the season. So definitely want to be mindful of it. And that also means the same inputs you decide on now will be applied to future hires in 2026. Okay. And again, you can play around with this as much as you want. And nothing will be finalized because you had not invited the employees. So feel free to use this as like a nice cost projection calculator tool. And yeah, happy to answer any questions you might have along the way. 
rachel:
OK, yeah, thanks. I'll definitely forward the resources to Elan too. But do you have any advice on how to determine if we can get out of the plan? Is that a question to our insurance provider, or is that a question for Rippling? 
Joseph Firenzi:
Yeah, that would probably... Be rippling. 
rachel:
Okay. Yeah. Okay. 
Joseph Firenzi:
It might be challenging depending on how that functions and how those plans are structured. 
rachel:
Yeah. I mean, we're so small. We're probably on some, like other small group plan. So I'll ask them. Okay. 
Joseph Firenzi:
And then if you have any questions on that, too, I can loop in our support team that might have more knowledge on that. They're pretty awesome and they can be reached at support at thatch.ai or .com. Either one will work. Okay. 
rachel:
Yeah, great. No, yeah, we'll parse through these resources. I'll talk to Alon about it tomorrow and then I'll be in touch this week with any questions. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Okay, cool. It was great to meet you, Rachel. Please let me know if I can help. And yeah, excited to help if anything comes up. Yeah. 
rachel:
Okay. Thank you. Nice to meet you. You too. 
Joseph Firenzi:
Bye. See you.

Date: 2025-12-15 (Monday)

Client: Summerset (Memory Care and Assisted Living facilities)

Current State:
- Two separate facilities: Memory Care (MC) and Assisted Living (AL)
- Previously used different benefits administration system
- Dental and vision remain with HUB/EASE (separate from Thatch)
- Life insurance policy offered at no cost (administered separately through EASE)
- Payroll managed through ADP
- Multi-cultural workforce requiring Spanish language support

Priorities:
- Ensure no gap in employee medical coverage for January 1, 2026 start date
- Offer medical benefits only to full-time employees
- Maintain separate administration for dental, vision, and life insurance through existing vendors

Pain Points:
- Employees asking for printed materials/paper summaries to take home and discuss with family
- Multi-system administration burden (ADP, EASE, and now Thatch)
- Communication challenges with current broker (Jessica Reyes at HUB - gone silent on EASE setup for 2026)
- Employees with limited technical knowledge need simple, accessible enrollment process
- Language barriers for non-English speaking employees
- Receiving insurance cards before enrollment completed (confusion)

Challenges:
- ADP integration issues preventing automatic sync (proceeding without integration temporarily)
- Need to manually manage employee additions/terminations across three systems
- Part-time vs. full-time employee status changes requiring manual updates
- Census data accuracy and keeping employee rosters current across two facilities
- Bank account connection required before inviting employees

Optimization Goals:
- Streamline benefits administration
- Provide employees with more plan choices and options
- Reduce administrative burden on office managers (Inga and Shauna)
- Enable employee self-service with broker support available
- Mobile accessibility for enrollment

Stated Timelines:
- December 22, 2025: Final deadline for employees to select plans to ensure January 1, 2026 coverage start date
- January 1, 2026: Target effective date for new medical coverage through Thatch
- Immediate: Need to invite employees and set up admin access for Inga and Shauna
- Post-enrollment: Plan to reconnect ADP integration after initial rollout

Next Steps:
- Mason to complete setup for AL account and invite employees
- Office managers to verify employee rosters and make necessary edits
- Employees to schedule appointments with Spanish-speaking brokers if needed for plan selection support
- Follow up with Jessica Reyes at HUB regarding dental/vision/life insurance through EASE
